HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;
The Old Guard in a New Government

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 25

 BODY:
One month after Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife were executed as despots, this nation is lurching awkwardly under the influence of those who finally overthrew the old regime as well as those who had helped sustain it in power for 24 years.
The remnants of the old guard are still around, and many thousands of them still hold the positions they had under the Ceausescus or have received new appointments.
Among these Ceausescu holdovers, as disclosed this week by the boldest Bucharest daily, Romania Libera, are officials of the Foreign Ministry who took part in a meeting last March 15 condemning a former colleague, Mircea Raceanu, as a spy and traitor before he was even tried.
Mr. Raceanu, the Deputy Director for Western Hemisphere Affairs, was arrested as an opponent of the Government a year ago, apparently on direct orders from President Ceausescu, and condemned to death by a secret military tribunal in July. He was released from solitary confinement on death row at Rahova prison on Dec. 23, the day after the Ceausescu Government toppled. 
 
Embarrassing Transcript
On Sunday, Romania Libera published an excerpt of the transcript of the March meeting at which Constantin Ene, then and now the ministry's Director of Foreign Economic Relations, called for ''the maximum penalty under the law'' to be applied to Mr. Raceanu. He was joined by Dumitru Stanescu, then and now Director of African Affairs, who said, ''I indignantly condemn the act of treason'' of his colleague; by Moise Petre, Director of Protocol, who demanded ''no clemency,'' and by Ion Mielcioiu, Director of Asian and Middle East Affairs, who declared, ''I condemn these grave acts.''
The newspaper promised to continue printing excerpts of the transcript. But the next day, it was ordered by Silviu Brucan, a senior member of the governing Council of National Salvation, to cease because of the embarrassment it was causing at the Foreign Ministry. The council replaced the Ceausescu Government on Dec. 22. Romania Libera defied Mr. Brucan and resumed publishing the account today.
''There is still censorship of the press, and also of radio and television,'' Mr. Raceanu remarked today. ''It is not over.''
Another instance of the authoritarian manner in which the council is conducting its affairs is the demand by Andrei Plesu, a historian and art critic who is a member of the council, that the publication Cinema get rid of four of its chief editors and instead accept six outsiders of his choice. The reporters, critics and editors of Cinema are protesting vigorously that this is not the democratic way to do things.
 
New Post for a Ceausescu Official
An example of a new appointment of a Ceausescu official is that of Virgil Constantinescu, the newly designated Rumanian Ambassador to Washington. In a previous post, Mr. Constantinescu served in the Ceausescu Government's Department of Cults, which supervised religious organizations.
There, according to a knowledgeable Rumanian source, he served as an informer for the Securitate, the state security police, which has been officially dissolved by the new Government. For that matter, a huge number of Securitate officers remain on the job at lower levels, Rumanian officials said in interviews.
Throughout this month, members of the Securitate's elite troops who kept fighting the popular insurgency even after President Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were captured, sentenced and executed have kept surfacing from their hiding places, mostly underground, and turning themselves in.
In the same period, many Rumanians who have spoken out against the Ceausescu Government and against the presence of Communists in the new provisional Government have received anonymous death threats on the telephone and in their mailboxes. A widely distributed anonymous leaflet specifically threatens death to outspoken people on Friday, which would have been Mr. Ceausescu's 72d birthday.
Despite these continuing threats and their own fears, thousands of Rumanians have gone into the streets in Bucharest and in Timisoara, the western city where the national uprising started, to demonstrate in favor of democracy and, on Wednesday in the capital, against the political plans of the Council of National Salvation.
 
A Clumsy Announcement
In a particularly clumsy way, the council first declared five days ago that it intended to field its own candidates in spring elections, then announced the decision to do so on Wednesday at a press conference for foreign journalists. Mr. Brucan, of the council's 11-member executive board, even chastised a Rumanian journalist for daring to ask a question about the decision at the conference. Only that night did Ion Iliescu, the president of the council, inform the nation about the action on Rumanian television.
Affronted not only by the decision itself but the manner in which it was conveyed, leaders of the three main political parties that have sprung up since December joined in demanding that the provisional leaders step down immediately and give way to a caretaker government. These political organizations are the National Peasants Party, the National Liberal Party and the Social Democratic Party of Rumania.
The council's decision also affronted members of the council itself, one of whom, Prof. Doina Cornea, a brave dissident under the Ceausescus, immediately resigned. Ana Blandiana, a prominent poet, who is still in the council, published a commentary in Romania Libera today saying she was offended by the manner in which the decision was made.
On Wednesday, thousands of people, many of them students, suddenly gathered on University Square to march in two separate demonstrations protesting the council's decision.
 
Council Bans Demonstrations
This prompted the council to issue a fresh decree on Wednesday night, banning spontaneous demonstrations, demanding 48 hours' notice for any demonstration, confining demonstrations in the capital to four city parks or agreed street routes, and threatening violators with fines and up to 30 days in jail. A small group of young people defied the ban this afternoon by marching on Nicolae Balcescu Boulevard this afternoon and shouting anti-council slogans. A big demonstration downtown is scheduled for Sunday in defiance of the ban as well. And Nicolae Costel, head of the small Free Democratic Party, said there would be strikes in the cities of Sibiu, Brasov and Timisoara at the same time.
The guiding force of the council appears to be Mr. Brucan, a veteran Communist who opposed Mr. Ceausescu publicly from 1987 onward. He had said on Jan. 1 that the council should enter Rumanian politics and persuaded the council to accept this proposal 23 days later. He also played a central role in reversing the council's plan to hold a referendum on banning the already defunct Communist Party and reviving the death penalty.
Despite the efforts of Mr. Brucan, or perhaps because of them, Rumania seems to be only marginally governable at this stage and, in the case of Timisoara, hardly governable at all. From Dec. 22 to Jan. 12, Timisoara province was run by Lorin Fortuna, a former Communist Party official. He was replaced by Maj. Gen. Gheorghe Popescu, who took over until Jan. 20, when he, too, stepped down. Since then the province and city have been in the hands of a murky group of self-appointed people who call themselves the Commission of Competents and whose main task is to prepare local elections.
There are demonstrators every day in the streets of Timisoara. ''It is chaos,'' said Gabrela Paulet, a 22-year-old physics and chemistry teacher from Timisoara who arrived in Bucharest this morning.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Protesters outside Victoria Palace in Bucharest heckling a representative of the interim government late Wednesday as he announced a new policy limiting mass demonstrations. (AP)

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East;
Five of the Financiers Investing in Hungary

 BODY:

Andrew Sarlos
Andrew Sarlos, a Toronto investment manager who fled Hungary in 1956, has been among the leaders of the movement to invest in Eastern Europe. In 1989, he joined American financiers in creating an $80 million fund for Hungarian investment, the largest capital pool in the country.
In an interview last year with a Canadian newspaper, he said that of the Eastern European countries, ''Hungary is probably the most advanced in its transition politically.''
Citing the experiences of McDonald's and Citibank, he said that Western businesses could earn a high rate of return in Hungary. The main role of the West, he said, is to provide capital and sophisticated management. 
 
Melvin Simon
Along with his brother, Herbert, Melvin Simon owns the nation's largest mall development corporation, Melvin & Associates. Forbes magazine estimates that the corporation is worth $900 million. Melvin Simon, 62, owns two-thirds; Herbert Simon, 54, owns the other third. Melvin Simon is also a co-owner of the Indiana Pacers professional basketball team, which he purchased in 1983.
Mr. Simon, the son of a tailor, was born in Brooklyn and attended City College of New York. The winner of a Horatio Alger award, he once took a job selling encyclopedias in Indianapolis to augment his Army pay. He founded Melvin & Associates in 1960.
The company is estimated to own 60 million square feet of mall space and to manage another 13 million. In the 1970's, Simon produced several Hollywood films, including ''Love at First Bite.''
 
Albert Reichmann
Albert Reichmann is one of three Reichmann brothers controlling Olympia & York Development Ltd., which Business Week magazine recently called ''the richest and most powerful real estate developer in the world.'' Based in Toronto, the privately held company controls a worldwide real estate empire worth an estimated $25 billion, including the World Financial Center in New York.
The brothers - Albert, 60, Paul, 59, and Ralph, 56 - are three of six children born to a Hungarian couple who fled Europe at the beginning of World War II. The family settled in Tangier, where the father became a successful currency trader and the mother worked to smuggle Spanish passports to Jews trying to flee Hungary. Ralph Reichmann moved to Toronto in 1956, and the family followed in stages.
The Reichmanns have contributed $65 million for a civic center in Jerusalem and have pressed the Soviet Union to allow more Jews to emigrate. Olympia & York is scheduled to begin work this year on a $210 million, 60-story office tower that will be Moscow's tallest.
''The Jewish population is the reason I'm interested in Hungary and the Soviet Union,'' Albert Reichmann recently told Business Week.
 
R. Mark Palmer
Mr. Palmer, 48, is a career Foreign Service officer who was appointed Ambassador to Hungary in 1985. At the time of his appointment, he had spent three years as a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, heading up sections on Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
Earlier in his career, Mr. Palmer served as chief speechwriter for two Secretaries of State, William P. Rogers and Henry A. Kissinger. He served in Moscow from 1968 to 1971 and has also worked in India and Yugoslavia.
Mr. Palmer had hoped to be named an Assistant Secretary of State in the Bush Administration. He is known to have close ties with both Communists opposition members in Hungary. He has been an outspoken advocate of free enterprise and the privatization of the Hungarian economy.
 
Ronald S. Lauder
An heir to the Estee Lauder cosmetics fortune, Mr. Lauder recently spent more than $12 million on an unsuccessful race for Mayor of New York. He lost the Republican primary to Rudolph W. Guiliani, whom he had criticized in highly negative campaign ads.
In his campaign, conducted without public funds, Mr. Lauder called for lower taxes to stimulate business growth. He urged private companies to provide many of the services now offered by the city.
Largely in return for his work as finance chairman for the New York Republican Party, Mr. Lauder was appointed a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense in 1983. In 1986, he was sent to Austria as Ambassador. Mr. Lauder is 45 years old.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Tokyo;
Japanese Leader's Europe Trip Missed Mark

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu returned from a trip to Poland, Hungary and Western Europe last week saying Japan had lived up to its new international responsibilities as an economic superpower by offering nearly $2 billion in financial aid to support democracy in Eastern Europe.
But a decidedly different light was shed on Japan's view of its role in the world when Government, banking and business leaders here responded to Mr. Kaifu's trip. The people who will have to give substance to the Prime Minister's initiatives generally criticized them as geographically and politically misguided. They still found it hard to support a program that would bring no tangible benefit to Japan. 
''Why he had to go to Eastern Europe is beyond me, since it is not clear what we get from it'' in business terms, one of Japan's top bankers said in a surprisingly angry denunciation. He continued: ''In the long run, China is much more attractive. Why does Japan have to wait on the U.S. before lifting sanctions?''
The executive, who asked not to be identified, expressed the view that to establish an independent stance in international affairs, Japan would have been better off ending its freeze on relations with China after the military crackdown last June and permitting new economic programs to move ahead with its Asian neighbor - even if the United States did not approve.
 
'Its Future Is Not So Bright'
The banker's outburst has been repeated all over Tokyo. What has been noteworthy is how consistently those leaders turned the situation into an economic equation, which they saw as tilted decidedly away from Eastern Europe and toward China, where Japan enjoys many economic advantages that it is nervous about losing.
The countries of Eastern Europe ''have changed politically; they have not necessarily changed economically yet,'' said Noboru Hatakeyama, head of the international trade policy bureau of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, offering that important ministry's lukewarm reception to the visit.
''Down the road, its future is not so bright,'' he said. ''Investing in Asian countries might be better than investment in Eastern European countries.''
Kazuo Nakazawa, a managing director of Keidanren, the trade group representing Japan's largest corporations, said, ''We have more to lose by staying out of China that we have to gain in Eastern Europe.''
 
Image as a Statesman
The flow of news since the visit demonstrated that inclination even more clearly. The only big announcement relating to Eastern Europe recently was that Suzuki Motors is to build an auto plant in Hungary.
There is still a recognition that doing business in China is frought with difficulties and contracts between Japanese trading houses and China were down about 20 percent last year.
Nonetheless, a group of Japanese banks have said they would permit China to draw $500 million of a large loan arranged several years ago. In the first technology deal with China since June, Mitsui & Company agreed to sell China a plant to help make television tubes and switches. The Kisho Corporation, a maker of tape recorders and audio equipment, plans to open a new factory in Guangdong Province next month. And Nippon Steel said it had agreed to provide China the technology to build high-grade silicon steel, used in consumer electronics products.
Many political commentators have agreed that the Prime Minister's trip was motivated largely by domestic political concerns, which is often the case for foreign visits by national leaders. Mr. Kaifu, they have said, was trying to establish an image as a statesman in advance of parliamentary elections, to be held on Feb. 18. The lower house of Parliament was dissolved on Wednesday to open way for the elections.
 
Program for Use of Aid
But of most concern to business leaders involved in international affairs was that Mr. Kaifu passed up an opportunity to articulate a vision for the world and state Japan's case for the development of capitalism in Eastern Europe.
Shijuro Ogata, deputy governor of the Government-owned Japan Development Bank and former deputy governor for international relations at the Bank of Japan, described the visit as a watershed because Japan occupied center stage of a major international development. But he was critical of the fact that Mr. Kaifu did not present a clear program for use of the aid.
''We are willing to give money, but not ideas or leadership,'' Mr. Ogata said. ''The Government isn't ready to produce ideas, and that is what people are criticizing.''
Some have also expressed concern that aid to Eastern Europe will just contribute to the development of a large European economic bloc that excludes Japan. Japan has not had strong ties with the region in the past, and economic assistance would not be likely to build such ties in the future, in that view.
Keidanren has agreed to sponsor visits by hundreds of Eastern European officials to Japan to learn about the country's business methods. The aim, an official said, would be to begin building those ties.
''We want them to understand us before we just give over money,'' said Hiroya Ichikawa, deputy director of the international cooperation department at the Keidanren. But he held out little hope, given the realities of economic competition.
''We are close to China,'' Mr. Ichikawa said. ''They understand us. Perhaps it would be more useful for Japan to be more of an actor there.''

HEADLINE: Cuts in Military Threaten Big Bases

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is considering closing some of the nation's largest military bases and making deep cuts in the National Guard and reserves of virtually every state, Administration and Congressional officials said today.
The list includes the possible closing of the Army's base at Fort Ord, Calif., and Navy bases in the San Francisco Bay area as well as the Philadelphia Navy Yard. Among the bases and units being considered for major reductions are the New York Army National Guard's 42d Infantry Division and the Army's base at Fort Hood, Tex.
Fort McClellan in Alabama is also being considered for closure, and the Pentagon is considering large reductions in the 9th Infantry Division at Fort Lewis, Wash., and the 194th Separate Armored Division at Fort Knox, Tenn. 
 
Document to Be Offered
The officials said that Mr. Cheney will tell Congress next week about the possible cutbacks in a document that outlines the military's strategy and plans for the next five years. The changes would come on top of the 86 military bases that Congress agreed to close last year.
Mr. Cheney's document is certain to touch off a furor on Capitol Hill, where each state's delegation stoutly protects its military bases.
The plan appears to be an opening step in his effort to keep control of the budget process, which begins next week when President Bush formally presents to Congress his requests for the 1991 fiscal year. By publicly identifying bases that may be closed, particularly those used by the National Guard and Reserves, Mr. Cheney would put pressure on Congress to either follow his lead or take responsibilty for ducking difficult decisions.
The plan, entitled ''The Structure of U.S. Military Forces in 1995,'' also includes a general discussion of military strategy and an overall approach for deploying American forces on the assumption that Moscow and Washington reach agreement on a pact to reduce conventional forces in Europe.
 
Right to Reject Closings
By law, the Pentagon must formally notify Congress of planned base closings, and the officials emphasized that the Pentagon document was only a proposal to study which bases should be eliminated.
By not making any formal proposals at this time, Mr. Cheney will be able to generate debate without having to submit the six complex assessments of economic, environmental and other consequences that must accompany a formal plan to close bases.
Congress has the right to overturn any base closure that affects 300 civilian jobs or any transfer of troops that affects 1,000 civilian jobs or more than 50 percent of the local work force. Those limits would apply to most of the bases on the list.
Closing a large base also requires environmental studies, which if challenged in court which can lead to years of delay.
 
National Guard Reductions
Mr. Cheney has broad authority to trim the National Guard and reserves, and the document he will give Congress suggests possible reductions in such units across the country. National Guard and reserves have long been popular with politicians because they provide jobs and benefits to many local citizens.
Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado and chairwoman of the House Armed Services Committee panel on military installations, praised Mr. Cheney's overall proposal today, but disagreed with his plan to cut active duty and reserve forces equally.
''I think deeper cuts must come in active forces and the reserves ought to be strengthened,'' Ms. Schroeder said in a statement. ''Secretary Cheney proposes only modest cuts overseas. I think we should close many more foreign bases.''
She added, ''I want to make sure that no base is being closed for political reasons.''
A Congressional official said the Cheney plan also calls for base closing and troop reductions overseas, but he said that the identities of those bases were being kept secret while American diplomats brief the allies this weekend about the plan.
 
Effects for the Navy
Mr. Cheney's list of possible base closes heavily affects the Navy, the service that suffered the least under the 1989 base closings. Navy officials have felt protected from cuts by the Navy's roles in drug interception and the fact that it is the service responsible for projecting American power throughout the world.
Among the Naval installations that are being considered for possible closure, officials said, are San Francisco's Treasure Island Naval Air Station, the Oakland Naval Supply Center and the Oakland Naval Hospital.
The Long Beach Naval Shipyard is also on the list, as is the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, which employs 9,000 military and 20,000 civilian workers.
Army bases under consideration for closure include Ford Ord, Calif., home to the 7th Infantry Division, which would be transfered to Fort Lewis, Wash. The division would be sharply reduced from its current level of 14,800 soldiers and 2,300 civilian support workers.
At Fort Lewis, the Pentagon is considering reducing the 9th Infantry to a motorized brigade, a cut of 7,900 soldiers, officials said.
Mr. Cheney's Army list includes a proposal to deactivate the 10,000-man 2d Armored Division at Fort Hood, Tex.
Proposals for possible cuts in the National Guard and Reserves would hit especially hard in the Northeast, officials said.
In New York, for example, the Pentagon would consider cutting 5,000 slots in 1991 and 8,000 more between 1993 and 1994 from the 42nd National Guard.
In Massachusetts, there is a proposal to reduce the 26th Army National Guard Infantry Division by more than 3,000 slots, eliminating the headquarters division and two brigades.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Living With Washington Mayor: Sense of Realism as a Tonic for Rumors

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Last Sunday, after Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. publicly and tearfully confessed to ''weaknesses'' and prepared to enter a substance abuse clinic, he turned and planted a big kiss on the cheek of his wife, Effi. ''She's just great,'' he said. ''For our family,'' she responded, ''this is just the beginning.'' Then, arm in arm, they departed. There was more to that exchange and departure than met the ear or eye.
By her own account, Effi Barry has never been quite sure where she stands with her husband, whether he does, in fact, think she is great. He has been accused of womanizing almost from the start of their marriage a dozen years ago. While he has never conceded having extramarital affairs, saying only that the relationships have been ''personal,'' Mrs. Barry herself has called him an ''indiscreet street dude.''
 
A 'Beginning'
So when she spoke Sunday of a ''beginning,'' a beginning brought on by the Mayor's arrest on a charge that he used crack that he obtained from a woman described by the police as a former girlfriend, it was perhaps inevitable that Washington would begin speculating once again why Effi Barry did not instead speak of an ''ending,'' and why she had not spoken of one long ago. 
Other than her statement Sunday, she has said nothing publicly about the current situation and has turned aside all requests for interviews. For that matter, she has never said much publicly about her life with Marion Barry except to call him ''indiscreet'' several times and to suggest acidly once that a woman linked to him by the press should get out of town.
Realistically, she has told friends and an occasional interviewer, the wife of a public figure must always be aware that certain kinds of women will be drawn to her husband.
In good part, some of her friends say, it was that realism that led her to be at her husband's side on Sunday in the auditorium of St. Timothy Episcopal Church, next to the Barry home. And it was that realism, the friends suggest, that led her two days earlier to walk side by side with the Mayor into the United States Courthouse here, to see him arraigned like any other common drug suspect.
 
For the Sake of Their Son
There is also something else at work here, those who know Mrs. Barry best say. They do not use the word ''love.'' Rather, they suggest that she continues to endure all the rumors and innuendo about the Mayor, in part because of 9-year-old Christopher Barry, the couple's only child, who in one of the most poignant scenes of the past week was led from his home on the morning of his father's arraignment with a coat over his head.
''Effi is a very strong and determined woman,'' said Peggy Cooper Cafritz, one of Christopher's godmothers, who is a prominent figure in the city's arts world. ''She is determined to create an atmosphere that will allow her child to be raised in the best possible way. She's very aware of all the pressure on black families today. She very much wants to hold this family together.''
Another family friend, Ruby McZier, a Washington lawyer, suggested that Mrs. Barry is able to deal with whatever trauma injects itself into her life because she ''internalizes'' problems. ''I've never seen her fall apart,'' Ms. McZier said. ''She has this ability to put problems on almost a third-party basis.''
Ms. McZier, like many of Mrs. Barry's friends, refused to discuss her further. ''We owe her that protection,'' she said.
In her most candid interview to date about her marriage, Mrs. Barry two years ago told Barbara Harrison, a reporter for WRC-TV, a local station: ''You must be philosophical, and you have to be a realist.''
''There is a caliber of female in this world,'' she continued, ''for whatever her own personal needs might be, who tends to gravitate toward a power figure. It has always been that way and, unfortunately, will continue to be that way.''
She did not elaborate on the nature of those personal needs. But the consequences are often mates who go astray, she said, alluding to revelations of extramarital affairs about any number of Presidents, members of Congress and other public figures over the years.
''This kind of involvement is a necessary nuisance that the wife of a power figure has to deal with,'' she concluded.
And so, there was Effi Barry last Sunday, dealing, gently stroking her husband's hand as he prepared to take the stage and confess to weaknesses of ''body, mind and soul,''
After he had spoken, she took the stage, put herself in the limelight that she normally avoids, and rephrased his message, throwing in words like ''problem'' that he would not use or, for political and legal reasons, could not use. Then, that chore done, she threw in the plug for their marriage, adding to the drama of the moment, leaving the impression that here was a woman who would do whatever she had to do, swallow whatever she had to swallow, to save a job, a man, a family and, indeed, herself.
 
A Striking Figure
Mrs. Barry herself has not been entirely free of rumors and allegations since she arrived in town in the late 1970's and her regal good looks caught the eye of a new City Councilman, Marion Barry.
Tall, angular, given to designer clothes and bright jewelry, she cuts a striking figure: people notice her. And when she shows up at a club or somewhere without the Mayor, as she has done now and again with friends, male and female, the talk starts anew.
The friends say that Mrs. Barry is just relaxing, that there is nothing to be made of the fact that she is not with her husband. She does not respond to the talk for the most part, though when she does she can be tart.
Once she called the city's gossip-mongers ''piranhas, alligators, crocodiles.'' Another time she pointed her finger at an investigative reporter and snapped, ''You're going to hear from me!''
While she herself was drawn to and married a man of power, she has never shown much inclination to seek power or play the role of first lady to its fullest potential.
Except for major occasions, like a State of the City Message by the Mayor or a welcoming ceremony at the White House, she has seldom shown up at official functions with her husband.
She is a member of the Mayor's cabinet, but does not attend all meetings. She works with a number of groups in child care, health, education and the arts, but mostly in the background.
''This is not a woman out to impress a lot of people or to build a very high profile,'' said a former top mayoral aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''She lets him do his thing and she does her thing. She's very private, very much her own person. They tend to stay in contact through their secretaries.''
Ms. Cafritz said Mrs. Barry likes to be involved in city matters and makes a solid contribution. ''But she prefers to work quietly,'' Ms. Cafritz said. ''She looked at all the hoopla that a lot of other first ladies here and around the country have been involved in and decided she wanted to be substantive, not flashy. She works hard, but she seeks no great publicity.''
 
A Conventional Youth
Born in a modest, racially mixed neighborhood in Toledo, Ohio, Mrs. Barry, now 45 years old, never knew the poverty and racism that scarred and molded her husband from an early age. As a young man, he was one of the shock troops of the civil rights movement, then jumped into the hurly-burly of elective politics.
Her youth was less remarkable, more conventional - a home economics degree from Hampton Institute, an all-black college in Virginia, then on to New York and eventually Washington in search of a future, first as an airline stewardness, then as a Wall Street credit reporter, then as a teacher, model and, finally, city health inspector.
The last job was where Marion Barry found her.
They were married in early 1978, the year Mr. Barry won his first term as Mayor, and Effi Barry almost immediately found herself plunged into the fishbowl ''filled with piranhas, alligators, crocodiles.''
She knew little or nothing about political life or what to expect, and while she eventually learned how to slap a back, smile through her teeth and duck the tough question, she mainly coped by becoming a more private person, more protective of herself, her friends said.
She had always been something of a loner, ever since her youth in Toledo, where she grew up an only child. She simply became more of a loner, in touch with a small group of close protective friends, but otherwise low key, low profile.
In those early years as the Mayor's wife, several controversies broke out around her.
She and Mr. Barry received a discount on the $125,000 loan on their new house, in a mostly black neighborhood on the southeastern edge of the city. When it was disclosed that she sat on the bank's board, the discount was rescinded and she resigned her seat.
When she took a job with an advertising and public relations company that did business with the city, another conflict-of-interest problem loomed. She left the company.
Then she was criticized for accepting a gift of designer clothes from a friend who also happened to be a city lobbyist. And she was criticized for wearing a coat paid for with city money. Eventually the Mayor paid for the coat with his own money, explaining that when a deliquent bill on the coat had come in an aide had mistakenly used city money to settle it.
 
'What About the Wife?'
After a while, those controversies died down and slipped into the background of city politics and gossip. Not so the controversies about the Mayor's personal life.
Mrs. Barry has never been able to get away from them. And while they obviously bother her and concern her, the self-described ''realism'' she brings to the situation has never permitted her to present herself as long-suffering or put upon.
Only once, publicly at least, has she come close to that. In her interview with Ms. Harrison of WRC-TV, taped not long after former Senator Gary Hart was alleged to have had an extramarital affair, she spoke of his wife, Lee.
''What about Lee Hart?'' she asked. ''What about the wife who stands beside him, who believes in him and who makes personal sacrifices?''

HEADLINE: First Victory in the Drug War

 BODY:
Just as President Bush was announcing his updated national drug control strategy yesterday, Democratic Senator Joseph Biden was distributing a drug control plan devised by the Senate Judiciary Committee. This was no quick rebuttal but a 236-page book based on a year of study and 24 hearings.
While Mr. Biden sought to demonstrate the inadequacy of the Bush plan with side-by-side comparisons, the most striking point was the similarity of the two documents. Read together, they outline a coherent policy on which both parties could unite. It would be a welcome triumph if the two sides could stop fighting each other and concentrate on the common enemy. 
A few differences stand out. The Administration proposal, prepared by William Bennett, national director of drug control policy, would extend capital punishment even to ''drug kingpins'' who have not committed murder, a grandstanding proposal that Mr. Biden rightly rejects as excessive.
The Biden plan calls for a tough Federal ban on public sales of U.S.-made military assault rifles, a step Mr. Bennett resists. And Senator Biden, unlike Mr. Bennett, would accede to mayors who want Federal aid sent directly, instead of through the states.
Beyond those points, though, the principal difference between the two plans is money. Mr. Bush would add about $1.1 billion, raising anti-drug spending to $10.6 billion. Mr. Biden would increase spending to more than $14.6 billion. Even so, there is remarkable agreement on how to spend.
Both plans recognize the need to help beleaguered state and local law enforcement reclaim neighborhoods devastated by drugs and violence. Both call for big new investments in drug treatment. Both emphasize help for drug-abusing pregnant women and babies born to addicted mothers.
Both proposals call for expanded use of the military to combat drug smuggling and both would do more to help Andean countries whose economies are dominated by the drug trade. Mr. Bennett would build on military and economic aid programs already in place for Colombia, Bolivia and Peru. Mr. Biden would offer debt relief if the savings financed drug enforcement.
The two plans converge on smaller issues as well. Both would restrict exports of chemicals used to produce finished cocaine, seize drug barons' assets and act against money laundering.
To be sure, the $4 billion difference between the two plans isn't trivial. But that ought not to obscure how much has happened in recent months. Less than two years ago, America had no drug policy to speak of, just a lot of politicians armed with empty slogans and a lot of Federal agencies scrambling for crumbs of funding.
Now, sensible basic priorities are clear, and endorsed by authorities in both parties: more resources to help local law enforcement make the cities secure; expanded treatment, especially for women and children; use of the military to improve the disappointing record on interdiction, and serious help for Andean governments.
It is possible to argue with points of the strategy, and only time will tell how well it works. But there is still good reason to celebrate an initial victory, over confusion.

HEADLINE: MT.A. Proposes to $15 Billion Plan to Improve and Add Service

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that up to $15 billion would be needed, starting in 1992, to continue improving service and to pay for the first major expansions of the region's subway and commuter rail systems since the early 1970's.
Among the proposals being considered is constructing a tunnel or bridge across the Hudson River.
The chairman, Robert R. Kiley, said in an interview last night that at least two-thirds of the $15 billion ''would pay for the continued effort to bring back the existing transportation system to what we say in the trade is a state of good repair.''
At the same time, he said, ''We're going to make some proposals for new markets that aren't met by the existing system, new needs that have emerged over the last 35 or 40 years.'' 
Those needs include, Mr. Kiley said, more capacity across the Hudson in both directions, connection of the 63d Street Tunnel to the Queens Boulevard line and direct rail access to both New York City airports. Also, he said, ''the much-maligned Second Avenue line, a good idea that was aborted early in its construction, should be continued.''
Mr. Kiley first outlined his proposals yesterday at a breakfast sponsored by the Columbia University School of Business. ''He talked about a trans-Hudson rail link, either a new tunnel or bridge,'' said John Cunningham, a spokesman for the M.T.A. ''One of the projects that has had some discussion has been extending the No. 7 line out to the Meadowlands in New Jersey.''
Mr. Kiley's remarks constituted the opening round of the M.T.A. campaign for its third five-year capital budget, a plan that would be subject to approval by the Legislature. Most of the money would come from the state.
''Wow, $15 billion, it's a big number,'' said Carl Carlucci, secretary of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee. ''Those are certainly expansion issues, not simply maintenance issues, and they would have to be looked at carefully.''
The proposed capital plan, which would cover 1992 to 1996, would nearly double each allocation in the first two five-year plans. The first budget, covering 1982 to 1986, was $7.7 billion. The primary focus of that plan, Mr. Cunningham said, was buying subway cars, buses and commuter rail cars.
The second budget, from 1987 through 1991, is $8.5 billion. ''It continued the purchase of new rolling stock, with heavy emphasis on restoration of track on both subway and commuter lines,'' Mr. Cunningham said. ''Obviously, that program had a great deal to do with our ability to clean the graffiti from all our subway cars, because we were buying brand new equipment.''
Mr. Kiley said that much of the money for the third plan, in contrast to the first two, ''will be in support facilities and structural problems that are not necessarily visible to the public'' -signal systems, modernization of power delivery, improvements at car barns and bus depots.
''That work has to continue in order to bring the system back to the point where everyone agreed it ought to be in the early 80's, when the first commitment was made to completely restore the system,'' Mr. Kiley said.
Also, Mr. Cunningham said, ''we are considering system expansion for the first time since the early 1970's, when the 63d Street Tunnel and the Archer Avenue line in Queens were begun.''
The tunnel, which opened last month after years of delay, connects the Sixth and Seventh Avenue lines in Manhattan to three stops in Queens, terminating at the 21st Street station in Long Island City.
''When it began,'' Mr. Cunningham said, ''the idea was that this would be one leg of a Queens high-speed express line that would run along an old Long Island Rail Road right of way out to Archer Avenue'' in Jamaica. The plan, which was scrapped for lack of funds in the mid-70's, was intended to relieve overcrowding on the E, F, G and R trains, which run along Queens Boulevard.
 
More Rush-Hour Trains
If, as proposed, the tunnel and the Queens Boulevard line were connected, Mr. Cunningham said, additional trains could run to and from Manhattan in rush hours.
''It would include what is known as reverse signaling,'' he said. ''Normally you have two tracks running in and two running out. With reverse signaling, you could have three running in during the morning and three out in the evening.''
In the era before the two capital budgets, 80 percent of the authority money was from the Federal Government. ''Now, that has almost totally flipped - 70 percent city and state, and only 30 percent Federal,'' Mr. Cunningham said.
Asked whether a request for $15 billion was not unrealistic, considering city and state budget problems, Mr. Kiley said: ''The no-tax-increase fever that the country is currently under is going to have to end. We really do have to deal with new needs, and when you factor in inflation, it's really not such a high number.''

HEADLINE: Benefits Approved for Koch Officials Under Eased Severance Rules

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

 BODY:
Severance benefits as high as $80,000 have been approved for dozens of senior officials in the administration of former Mayor Edward I. Koch under personnel rules liberalized by Mr. Koch four years ago.
Mr. Koch eased the severance rules for city managers in 1986 after tightening them when he took office in 1978 in the shadow of New York City's fiscal crisis.
Mr. Koch said yesterday that he changed the regulations to attract and retain high-level managers and to close the gap in severance benefits between those received by rank-and-file city employees and by their bosses.
Before the rules were changed, rank-and-file workers were entitled to larger severance packages than senior managers, ''which is intolerable if you want people to become managers,'' Mr. Koch said. 
 
Unused Sick Leave
Mr. Koch said the policy had benefited the city by retaining and attracting skilled managers.
Under the liberalized rules, officials may be entitled to severance that represents unused vacation and sick leave accrued during their years of city employment. Officials with more than 10 years of service can collect severance equal to a maximum of 120 sick days and 108 vacation days, plus any leave earned before becoming a manager. Officials with less than 10 years' service are entitled to severance pay equal to their accumulated vacation time.
The severance benefits cannot exceed one year's salary, a spokesman for the city's Department of Personnel, Daniel Andrews, said.
Some civic groups questioned the policy yesterday.
''This stuff makes folks very cynical,' said Gene Russianoff, a lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group. ''These top managers get paid a good deal, and they know what they're getting into. If you're worried about working nights and weekends, you don't go into government.''
 
'Somewhat Over-Generous'
Lenore Chester, associate director of the Citizens Union, a watchdog group, said her organization had ''mixed feelings'' about the severance policy. ''It's somewhat over-generous, the 108 vacation days and the 120 sick days,'' she said. ''But those are the guidelines, and they are entitled to it under the guidelines. If we don't like those provisions, we should try to change them.''
Leland T. Jones, who was a spokesman for Mr. Koch and serves Mayor David N. Dinkins in that capacity, said the severance policy, ''like many other items, will be up for review by this administration.''
The packages approved so far range from $3,450 for Luis A. Miranda Jr., an assistant to the Mayor and city employee for about two years, to $80,181 for James Brenner, Mr. Koch's lobbyist in Albany and a city employee since 1973, according to records provided by the Comptroller's office.
At least five other top Koch administration officials have requested payments and are waiting for a decision by Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
Hadley W. Gold, the Commissioner of the Department of General Services, has asked for $107,136 in severance, the largest request. Three officials convicted in the government corruption scandals during Mr. Koch's third and final term were denied benefit payments. Anyone convicted of a crime related to his government job is denied a severance package under the regulations.
The Comptroller's office is to certify the ''correctness of the calculation'' provided by the agency where the official works, a spokesman for Ms. Holtzman, Glenn S. Goldberg, said.
When Mr. Koch took office in 1978, the city was just beginning to emerge from the fiscal crisis, so the new Mayor quickly moved to tighten severance benefits for city managers.
He ended the practice of overtime pay for managers and tightened sick leave and vacation pay for departing senior officials to a maximum of 54 days. Managers who began working for the city before Jan. 1, 1978, were allowed to keep any accumulated leave.
Mr. Koch relaxed the rules, in part, Mr. Jones said, ''to compete with private industry.''
''There was lots of money to be made out there in the middle 80's,'' Mr. Jones said. ''The economy was booming. We had to compete.''

HEADLINE: Energy Project Imperils a Rain Forest

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PAHOA, Hawaii

 BODY:
Bulldozers and drill platforms have come here to the Wao Kele O Puna, the last big tropical rain forest in the United States, where a showdown over the fate of this jungle may ultimately determine the fate of modern Hawaii as well.
The roads that have been hacked through the humid forest form the rough beginnings of a plan to turn the east rift of the Kilauea Volcano into one of the world's largest geothermal power plants.
By tapping into the steam beneath the erupting volcano on the big island of Hawaii, political and business leaders hope to free themselves from a heavy dependence on foreign oil and to provide electricity for future development.
But critics say the plan to industrialize much of the forest would not only destroy an ecological treasure, but could also burden a generation of Hawaiians with unwanted real estate development and debt.
 
Pressures Pro and Con
''Why should America's last big tropical rain forest be sacrificed so all the new hotels can run their air-conditioners?'' asked one opponent, Russell Ruderman, a biologist. 
Gov. John D. Waihee 3d said the project had put tremendous political pressure on him. Environmental groups, led by the Rain Forest Action Network in San Francisco, are urging tourists to boycott the state to protest development in the rain forest.
Tourism, an $8 billion industry built around more than six million visitors to the islands every year, is the economic engine that runs Hawaii. Although Hawaiian government officials say they are not sure how much the boycott is hurting them, they are stung by the criticism.
''This is not Brazil or Peru,'' Governor Waihee said, responding to critics of tropical deforestation. He said he supported the development of geothermal plants as the key to Hawaii's energy future, but added, ''That doesn't mean geothermal power has an absolute right to destroy a rain forest.''
 
Small but 'Fascinating'
The forest is small by South American standards, with 27,000 acres much smaller than what is destroyed in South America each week. But the plan to cut roads, build power plants, and string electric transmission lines through Wao Kele O Puna (the name means ''green forest of Puna'') would tear up the ecological web that keeps it alive, critics say.
''We've got to be cautious with what is left here,'' said James Jacobi, a Federal botanist with the Fish and Wildlife Service. ''This place is so fascinating, so full of original species. But working here is frustrating because you virtually watch these species drop off the face of the earth. I fear these geothermal plants would accelerate that process.''
Mr. Jacobi said half the Hawaiian Islands used to be covered by rain forest, and 95 percent of the plant and animal species found in those woodlands are exclusive to the state. Sugar plantations, logging and urban developments have leveled much of the forest.
Governor Waihee said that in order to meet this fast-growing state's energy needs, Hawaii will probably have to decide between increased imports of foreign oil - thereby risking a catastrophic spill in its pristine Pacific waters - or cutting up parts of the rain forest on the lower slopes of an erupting volcano. He said the choice is further complicated because it presents a choice between the lesser of two environmental evils: oil burning power plants, which give off gases thought to heat the atmosphere, or geothermal power at the expense of forest, which tends to cool the air.
''It's not an easy debate,'' the Governor said. ''I grew up on the big island. I don't want to be known as someone who sacrificed the big island for energy grubbing people in Oahu,'' where 80 percent of the population lives.
 
Objections Based on Goddess
Nearly 10 years ago, when the state first announced plans to tap the heat of Kilauea, one of the world's most active volcanoes, the opposition came mainly from native Hawaiians who said the drilling would violate their goddess Pele, who is said to reside in the steaming caldera.
The native groups formed the Pele Defense Fund and challenged geothermal development in court as an attack on their freedom to practice their religion. ''We believe in nature gods,'' said Palikapu Dedman, president of the native group. ''The nature here is our god. Drilling in Puna is sacrilege, no different than trashing a Christian cathedral.''
The native Hawaiians lost the First Amendment argument in court, and the Supreme Court has turned down a request to hear the appeal.
As originally conceived, the state was going to allow drilling at elevations above the lowland rain forest. But then, in 1983, Kilauea started spitting hot lava with a fury that surprised even some geologists who had studied the area for years.
Kilauea, the centerpiece of Hawaiian Volcanoes National Park, is still erupting. Lava has covered roads and spilled into the sea on the southern tip of the island.
 
Land Swap Is Challenged
After lava up to 300 feet deep covered much of the private land that was to be used for geothermal drilling and power plants, the developers began to consider using the adjoining rain forest.
Negotiations led to an exchange in 1985 that kept the project alive. The state traded 27,000 acres, including parts of the Puna rain forest, to a private landowner, Campbell Estates, which gave up its 25,000 lava-covered acres. The land now owned by Campbell Estates is where the geothermal project is under way.
The swap is being challenged in Federal court in one of the remaining lawsuits that could still snag the project. Critics say the state gave away land that was supposed to be used as a trust for native Hawaiians in return for land that has been partially logged and is now virtually covered by lava.
''What we gave up was a treasure, land ceded for native Hawaiians, and what we got in return was useless,'' Mr. Dedman said. Governor Waihee said conservationists had urged the trade to protect the upland forest and are now trying to have it both ways.
Currently, only a few roads have been cut into the Puna forest, a rich reserve of giant ferns, full-canopied Ohia trees and plants most Americans see only in exotic greenhouses. True Geothermal Energy Company, of Wyoming, has a permit to develop power plants capable of producing up to 100 megawatts. That amount could provide energy for up to 100,000 homes, far fewer than now exist on the island of Hawaii, which, though the biggest of the seven main islands in the archipelago, is also the poorest. #40 Arrests for Trespassing The company has begun drilling and building roads in an area that native Hawaiians had used for gathering herbs and conducting religious rituals, and more than 40 people have been arrested on trespassing charges at the forest boundary in the last year. Some were attempting to conduct religious rites and others were protesting the project.
''You just can't take a forest away from the people who lived there for thousands of years,'' Mr. Dedman said.
Governor Waihee, the first native Hawaiian to govern the islands since Queen Liliuokalani was forced to abdicate in 1893, the last year of the Hawaiian monarchy, said some provisions should be made to allow religious worship in the forest.
The state has announced plans to develop enough geothermal output to generate up to 500 megawatts of electricity, which would then be sent through more than 150 miles of underwater cable to the more populous islands of Maui and Oahu. Various economists have estimated the cost at $1.5 billion to $4 billion, to be borne by electric customers, taxpayers and private companies, which might issue bonds or become partners in the project.
A consultant hired by environmentalists has compared the geothermal project here to the attempt in Washington state to build five nuclear power plants in the 1970's, which led to the largest municipal bond default in history. A report by the consultant, Northwest Economic Associates of Vancouver, Wash., said Hawaii's geothermal plan is fraught with risk and uncertainty that could triple its cost.
Governor Waihee said expense is his biggest concern. ''I have a lot of questions about the cost and just who going to pay for it,'' he said.
 
Debate on the Effects
If geothermal power were developed to its full capacity, the Puna rain forest would be laced with hundreds of drill platforms linked by high-voltage electric lines, roads and pipes, according to the developers' own environmental studies. Officials of True Geothermal have said they can develop power plants without ruining the forest. Only 300 acres would be cleared, they said, to provide platforms for drilling equipment needed for a 100-megawatt plant.
But scientists like Mr. Jacobi, who heads the Government's Hawaii Research Station, said the greater damage to the forest would come from the very introduction of so much industrial equipment, and the potential for large releases of hydrogen sulfide, a gas byproduct of the geothermal process. He explained that the Ohia trees that dominate the forest rely on birds to pollinate them, and if the birds are chased away by smell or noise, the forest's future would be threatened.
Many residents of the Puna district, where it rains more than 100 inches a year and the houses are built are stilts, say there is less need for large-scale power plants on the big island than almost anywhere else. They collect water from rainfall and generate power from solar energy cells atop their homes.
''This billion dollars they might have to spend on the cable would be enough to put solar energy in every home in Hawaii,'' said Bill Reich, a Democratic Party official in the Puna district.
Geothermal energy was once considered a safe and clean form of power generation, but Hawaii's experience with a small, experimental plant run by the state has not been good. The plant was closed last year after numerous accidents led to some evacuations and health problems. The plant, designed to generate only three megawatts, released smelly gases and caused some residents to complain of headaches and nausea.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); SOUTH AMERICA (92%); BRAZIL (79%); 

STATE: HAWAII, USA (97%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES

BYLINE: By Lawrence Van Gelder

 BODY:

The Mermaid's Voice
Not often in these days of media overkill does a film establish box-office records without the public being made privy to every detail of the life of the star, but that seems to be the case with one of the most durable hits of recent months, ''The Little Mermaid.''
The Walt Disney Pictures' animated film about Ariel, the daughter of an undersea monarch who falls in love with a terrestrial prince, took 52 days from the time of its release on Nov. 17 to become the top-grossing animated film in history. Its $56 million surpassed the record established by ''Oliver & Company,'' a 1988 Disney production that amassed $53.2 million in its initial release. (The ''Mermaid'' grosses are now in excess of $60 million.) But who's the real person behind the animated Ariel, who has won the affection of audiences and the plaudits of critics?
She is Jodi Benson, who was making her film debut in the role after a career as a stage actress in such Broadway, Off Broadway and touring productions as ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,'' ''Marilyn: An American Fable,'' ''Smile,'' ''Welcome to the Club,'' ''Sophisticated Ladies'' and ''West Side Story.'' 
Miss Benson said: ''When the picture came out, I thought, isn't that wonderful. Isn't that great. I'll go back to the theater and do another Broadway show.''
But Miss Benson, who had been involved in making ''The Little Mermaid'' for some three years, reckoned without Jeffrey Katzenberg, the intrepid chairman of the Walt Disney Studios.
Last September, Miss Benson said, Mr. Katzenberg telephoned and said: ''You are the character and the title character. You can best represent the film and educate the public about animation.''
So Miss Benson went on tour in October and November to introduce the film. She said her involvement with ''The Little Mermaid'' began when she received a call telling her that the Disney people were doing some casting. ''They were looking for an actress to sing and who would have the voice quality of a 16-year-old,'' she said. ''On stage, I play a lot of teen-agers and college kids, and I play young.'' So for her audition, she taped two scenes from the script and sang ''Part of Your World,'' a ballad from the film.
Weeks went by. The 27-year-old Miss Benson, who has made her home in New York City for the past five years, began to forget she had auditioned until one day she checked with her telephone answering machine from a telephone booth in the street. And she heard the voice of her agent, Nancy Curtis of Bret Adams Ltd. ''She sounded like she was having a heart attack,'' Miss Benson said. '' 'Oh, my God. Oh, my God. Please call me.' '' Miss Benson did. ''She said, 'You got the movie.' She was screaming.'' Miss Benson said that her initial reaction was disbelief. '' 'No, no, no,' '' she remembers saying. '' 'You're kidding.' So much time had gone by that I thought they must not like me. I walked on cloud nine for six months until I got to meet them.''
By way of preparing to portray Ariel, Miss Benson said: ''I researched all of Disney's famous animated films, looking for qualities in the inflections of the voices. You can't use your body.'' She rented videocassettes. She closed her eyes and listened to the inflections.
''That's a real art,'' Miss Benson said, ''to be a voice-over person. The tools I used when I got in the recording studio? I acted everything out physically, expanded and went uninhibited, like a kids' playroom. That's the way Disney likes it.'' Sometimes, to create a feeling of being lonely underwater, she would sit on a stool and close her eyes.
Now, as a result of the accolades for Ariel, Miss Benson has made a quick move to the Los Angeles area (without giving up her New York apartment).
At the Pasadena Playhouse, beginning with previews next Friday and opening Feb. 11, she's playing the energetic, determined title character in a revival of the musical ''Flora, the Red Menace.''
People told Miss Benson that the West Coast run would be good for her career. ''Since ''Mermaids' was my first movie,'' she said, ''this would be a wonderful thing to introduce me to the Los Angeles area and say, 'Hi, I'm the face behind the voice.' ''
Yes, Miss Benson would like more movies. ''Live, action, with my face in them,'' she said. But she wouldn't be averse to some more animation, either. The ''Mermaid'' experience has been fun - and more.
''It's been a whirlwind,'' she said.
 
Jersey as a Film Set
Superficially, Woody Allen and Sylvester Stallone wouldn't appear to have a lot in common. How about Roseanne Barr and Michael Caine? Meryl Streep and Sean Penn? Well, all of them - plus Robert De Niro, Harrison Ford, Anjelica Huston, Raul Julia, Sidney Lumet, Martin Scorsese, Alan J. Pakula and Donald Sutherland, to drop a few more names - are among the people who were involved in movies made in New Jersey during 1989.
According to the 12-year-old New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission, a record 354 film and video productions came to the state last year, benefiting the economy by a record $24.8 million - a 9.25 percent increase over the 1988 total.
Among the films that were shot at least in part on location in New Jersey were Mr. Pakula's forthcoming murder mystery ''Presumed Innocent,'' with Mr. Ford, Greta Scacchi and Mr. Julia; Susan Seidelman's ''She-Devil,'' with Ms. Barr and Ms. Streep; Mr. Scorsese's coming ''Good Fellas,'' a study of a Mafioso starring Mr. De Niro; ''Jacob's Ladder,'' the psychological thriller directed by Adrian Lyne of ''Fatal Attraction'' fame; ''A Shock to the System,'' a forthcoming black comedy starring Mr. Caine; ''Quick Change,'' a comedy directed by and starring Bill Murray; Mr. Lumet's forthcoming ''Q and A,'' with Nick Nolte as a cop and Timothy Hutton as a young prosecutor, and Mr. Allen's ''Crimes and Misdemeanors.''
According to Joseph Friedman, the executive director of the commission, the number of feature films made in the state declined last year to 31 from 35 in 1988. But, he reported, ''The features that shot in New Jersey during the past 12 months tended to be of higher budget and remained in the state for longer periods of time. So although 1989 features were slightly fewer in number, as a whole they entailed larger crews and amounted to more shooting days.''
 
The Magic of Cinema
With a screening of the prize-winning ''Cinema Paradiso'' for the benefit of the American Film Institute's National Center for Film and Video Preservation, Miramax Films will celebrate its 10th anniversary next Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall.
The honorary committee for the event, scheduled for 7 P.M., comprises such names as Martin Scorsese, Daniel Day-Lewis, Jean Firstenberg, Bridget Fonda, Jeff Goldblum, John Hurt, James Ivory, Andie MacDowell, Ismail Merchant, Liam Neeson, Paul Newman, Laura San Giacomo, Jim Sheridan, James Spader and Joanne Woodward.
The film, an Italian-French co-production directed by Giuseppe Tornatore, who will be on hand, spans the postwar years in a tale of the relationship between a film projectionist (Philippe Noiret) and a little boy who grows up fatherless in a small Sicilian town. At the Cannes festival last year, ''Cinema Paradiso,'' which opens its commercial run in New York on Feb. 2, was awarded a special jury prize.
Miramax Films is a distribution company that has released such films as ''My Left Foot,'' ''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' ''Scandal,'' ''The Thin Blue Line,'' ''Pelle the Conqueror'' and ''Crossover Dreams.''
Tickets, at $100, and additional information about the event, which is sponsored by Giorgio Armani, may be obtained by calling 489-6900.

The Bush Administration has refined its new savings plan and other programs that it hopes will address the lagging rate of savings and investment. HEADLINE: A.T.& T. Has a Profit; Nynex Reports Loss

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported strong profits for its fourth quarter, helped by cost-cutting measures, the removal of two important regulatory restrictions and modest revenue growth.
Meanwhile, the Nynex Corporation, which serves local telephone customers in New York and New England, reported a loss. Nynex said its results reflected the softening of the local economy, a 17-week strike by 60,000 employees and restructuring costs.
A.T.& T. earned $705 million, or 65 cents a share, in the last quarter of 1989, up by 18.8 percent from the $593 million, or 55 cents a share, that its regular operations earned in the 1988 quarter. 
In the corresponding period in 1988, the telephone giant took a special charge of $6.7 billion to cover the cost of modernizing its long-distance telephone network, which produced a net loss of $3.34 billion.
The company's revenues edged up by 1 percent, to $9.30 billion in the recent quarter, from $9.20 billion.
A.T.& T. also said 1989 was its most profitable year since the 1984 divestiture, producing a net income of $2.69 billion, or $2.50 a share, compared with a $1.66 billion loss in 1988.
Excluding the charge in 1988, the company's earnings would have been up by 19 percent. Its revenues for the year rose by 2.5 percent, to $36.11 billion from $35.21 billion.
''It was a year in which A.T.& T. became a trimmer, more responsive and more aggressive competitor,'' said Robert E. Allen, the chairman. He said the company had shed 21,000 employees during the year, leaving it with a work force of 283,500.
''The results show a strong company getting stronger,'' agreed Jack Grubman, who follows telecommunications companies for Paine Webber Inc.
The regulatory changes that helped the company during the year included the decision by the Federal Communications Commission to set ceilings on telephone call prices rather than on company profits, which allowed A.T.& T. to capitalize on efficiency gains. The commission also upheld the company's right to sell special networks to corporate customers.
The revenue gains came despite two cuts in the price of long-distance phone calls during the year and declining income from telephone rentals. The company's sales of communications services grew by 6.6 percent for the quarter and by 6.3 percent for the year. Sales of services totaled $5.6 billion in the quarter, sales of products $3.13 billion and rentals $571 million.
 
Nynex
Hurt by a regional economic slowdown, Nynex reported a quarterly loss of $43.7 million, compared with a net income of $342.2 million, or $1.74 a share, in the 1988 period.
The company was also hurt by its inability to install new telephone lines during a four-month strike that ended on Dec. 1 and by the loss of some business customers to competitors offering private networks. It took special charges totaling $325 million after taxes in the quarter.
Without the charges, the company would have earned $281 million, or $1.43 a share, in the recent quarter, down by about 18 percent from the last quarter of 1988. Nynex's revenues edged up by 3.7 percent, to nearly $3.36 billion in the latest quarter from just over $3.24 billion.
''The one-time charges are generated in part by our determination to position the company for the long term and set the stage for earnings growth,'' said William C. Ferguson, the company's chairman.
Nynex's net income for the year totaled $807.6 million, or $4.10 a share, down by nearly 39 percent from $1.31 billion, or $6.63 a share, in 1988. Without the charges, earnings would have been about $1.13 billion, or $5.75 a share, down by 13 percent from 1988. The company's revenues for the year were $13.21 billion, up by 4.3 percent from $12.66 billion in 1988.

HEADLINE: 43.46 Decline Leaves Dow At 2,561.04

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks plunged 43.46 points, to 2,561.04, yesterday, as upward pressure on interest rates and the flow of poor corporate profits kept many investors on the sidelines.
At the close of the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow was down 116.86 points, or 4.4 percent, for the week, and below the level of 2,569.26 it reached after the 190.58-point market plunge of Oct. 13. The blue-chip indicator was down more than 20 points shortly after 1 P.M. before regaining some ground and then plunging within the last hour of trading.
The Dow is now at its lowest level since July 18, when it stood at 2,544.76. A close below 2,600 is considered bearish for technical and pyschological reasons. 
 
Volume at 172.3 Million
Volume on the Big Board fell yesterday to 172.3 million shares, from 207.8 million shares Wednesday, and declining issues outnumbered gainers on the Big Board by 937 to 539.
Another bearish indicator was the 4.18-point fall, to 326.08, in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, below the index's Oct. 13 close of 333.65.
More important, the March futures contract on S.&P. 500 index closed at 326.75, down 6.35. Thus, the premium of the March 500 futures over the actual index was only 67, when it should have been 195, based on a formula that calculates the days left in the life of the nearest futures contract, as well as alternative investments like 90-day Treasury bills. A futures contract is an agreement to buy or sell certain amount of a financial instrument or commodity at a specified time and price.
Given this abnormal situation, many computer-guided program traders and arbitragers are expected to find the futures cheap relative to the actual index at the opening this morning. This normally leads to the selling of the relatively overvalued stocks in the index and the buying of the undervalued futures.
''As if the market's sentiment wasn't bearish enough, Fed chairman Greenspan's vague comments about the possibility of a new tax on foreign investors unsettled an already wobbly market and killed any chance of a late rally,'' said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/20-First Advisors Inc.
He was referring to Alan Greenspan, who in response to a legislator's question at a Congressional hearing in Washington said that a withholding tax on earnings of assets held in the United States by foreign investors was ''an interesting idea that should be looked at.''
Mr. Greenspan also noted that such a move would be ''a tricky trade-off'' likely to lower foreign investment.
 
Volatility Cited
Mr. Stovall added that many investors had abandoned the market in recent weeks because of the increased volatility of many issues. He attributed the volatility to overly optimistic earnings projections by some analysts, followed by overly pessimistic forecasts by others now.
But Martin E. Zweig, the publisher of a market letter that bears his name, found solace in the recent flow of poor forecasts. ''According to the many advisory services we monitor, the bearish ones now outnumber the bulls by 44.6 to 39.9 percent,'' Mr. Zweig said, ''which in our experience is good news for the market.''
But for the near term, he said the market would continue to labor under poor monetary conditions, noting the decline in Treasury bond prices and the attendant rise in yields. ''We also see Japanese bondholders lightening their porfolios of fixed-income securities as their interest rates rise,'' he said.
Indeed, the weak recovery overnight on the Tokyo Stock Exchange from the large decline the previous day also helped create a negative climate at the opening of the Big Board. The Tokyo exchange's 225-issue Nekkei index rose 190.13 points in light trading after plunging 599.04 points the day before.
Rising overseas interest rates notwithstanding, the initial offering of the New Germany Fund at $15 a share yesterday never traded below $20 and closed at $22 on the Big Board, where it led the most-active list on a turnover of 11.5 million shares.
 
Du Pont Down 2, to 37 3/8
Second most active was Du Pont, which fell 2, to 37 3/8, on 3 million shares after it reported a drop in quarterly earnings. The decline in Du Pont, which recently split 3 for 1, put further pressure on the Dow average.
Lubrizol, also active, fell 3 1/8, to 33 1/4, apparently because it reported a rise in earnings that did not satisfy analysts. Procter & Gamble, reporting relatively flat quarterly profits, dropped 3 1/2, to 62 3/4, in active trading. The troubled Bank of New England lost 1/2, to 3 1/4, Campbell Soup fell 2 3/4, to 47 3/4, after reports the company was not for sale but may have to divest itself of some units and lay off employees.
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, fell 3, to 158 1/2, after its chairman described 1989 fourth-quarter earnings as disappointing.
At the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 1.03, to 353.64. In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.42, to 425.24.
