HEADLINE: Selling Autos by Selling Safety

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 25

 BODY:
After years of insisting that safety features do not sell cars, auto makers have noticed that many prospective buyers think differently. Suddenly, many car ads talk of little else.
The new attention to safety is credited partly to the baby boomers, the largest generation of consumers in history, whose own safety concerns are being sharpened by parenthood. The car companies are also trying to put the best face on new Federal regulations requiring them to add safety features whether or not buyers want them.
The Chrysler Corporation, once a staunch opponent of air bags, now hails itself in many advertisements as the only American auto company offering driver's-side air bags as standard equipment in all of its 1990 cars sold in the United States. The Ford Motor Company raised the ante two weeks ago, with a pledge that air bags would be standard for both front-seat passengers by the mid-1990's in all Ford cars sold in the United States. 
Volvo credits its longtime practice of emphasizing safety in its advertising for raising its United States sales last year even as other European car makers suffered declines.
BMW, the first manufacturer to claim anti-lock braking systems as standard equipment on all of its models, now focuses on the steering, acceleration and braking capabilities of its cars as features that can help avoid accidents. Toyota and Nissan are telling consumers in ads that the sheet metal in their car bodies gives better structural integrity and crashworthiness.
 
Cadillac Safety Promotion
The General Motors Corporation's Cadillac division is even promoting the size and power of its luxury sedans as safety features. Cadillac recently tested the market appeal of safety with a series of ads that stressed features like anti-lock brakes and reinforced side-door beams. Sales increased twice as much in the 10 markets where the ads ran as in areas where the pitch was standard luxury appeal, according to Cadillac.
''Several of these features have been built into Cadillacs for several years,'' said William J. O'Neill, a Cadillac spokesman. ''But we elected not to talk about them because we thought it wasn't worth it.''
Many such ads are created with baby boomers in mind. ''They represent half of all car buyers, and many of them have families,'' said Christopher W. Cedergren, an analyst for J. D. Power & Associates. ''They are still interested in performance, styling and value, but now they also want safety, which has become a much more important issue now that they have children.''
Beyond the baby boomers, safety is increasingly a selling point, particularly among more affluent car buyers, analysts and auto executives said.
''There is an awareness of safety among the car-buying public,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney. ''People are willing to pay for safety features such as anti-lock braking systems.''
Marketing executives for the major auto makers have watched safety rise on the list of attributes prospective buyers consider important. In 1981, according to Ford market analysts, customers ranked safety near the bottom of a dozen selling points that include performance, styling and fuel economy. Last year, customers listed safety among their top seven considerations. Ford analysts noted that safety was the only attribute to rise on the list.
''It's almost a cultural change,'' said Robert Rosenfeldt, manager of occupant protection and impact dynamics at Ford. ''People are becoming more technically sophisticated, and they are getting bombarded with the safety message.''
 
New Laws a Factor
The new emphasis on safety also stems from a desire by some car makers to make the most of new Federal laws requiring some kind of passive restraint, whether it be the less expensive automatic seat belt or the more expensive air bag, in the driver's seats of all new cars sold in the United States, starting with this year's models. The Big Three have said that by choosing the higher-cost air bags for many models, they have had to raise prices for 1990 cars more than their Japanese competitors, which equipped nearly all their models with the less costly automatic seat belt. The Big Three raised their prices an average of $805, compared with $205 for Japanese cars.
''After being forced to make huge investments in passive restraints, the auto manufacturers want to point out how much safer their air bags or automatic seat belts are,'' Mr. Cedegren said.
Consumer awareness of auto safety features has also been raised by the discounts now offered by many insurance companies for drivers of cars equipped with air bags, automatic seat belts and anti-lock brakes. The discounts range as high as 60 percent off the personal injury payments and medical portions of the premiums for cars that have air bags, which translates into an annual savings of $10 to $35 for most drivers, according to the Center for Automotive Safety.
 
Big Three Started Slowly
The domestic auto makers have not always been so willing to market safety. In the 1980's, they dragged their feet on major safety advances, notably air bags, contending that customers did not want them and would not pay extra for an expensive feature that most would never use. General Motors offered air bags as an option in its full-size Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Cadillacs beginning in 1974, but abandoned them in 1976 after fewer than 1 percent of buyers opted for air bags. Analysts subsequently argued that the air bags flopped because they were poorly promoted with customers and dealers.
Lee A. Iacocca, now Chrysler's chairman and then president of Ford, said in 1972 that ''safety doesn't sell.'' But the growing demand for safer cars, coupled with technical advances that made air bags cheaper and more reliable, caused Mr. Iacocca to change his mind. Indeed, when Chrysler announced its commitment to air bags in 1988, the company ran ads with a picture of its well-known chairman, proclaiming, ''Who says you can't teach an old dog new tricks?''
 
Volvo's Strategy
Volvo has built its marketing strategy around the message that Volvo drivers can walk away from major crashes. ''Volvos have a track record for being tanks,'' Mr. Cedergren said.
The Swedish auto maker has increased its safety-related advertising; it now accounts for more than half of its advertising budget. Recently, the company has been hailing findings of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety that drivers in Volvo's most expensive models have exceptionally low death rates.
''For years, Volvo was advertised as 'the safe car,' and they have been very successful,'' a Ford executive said. ''You see a lot of companies now are marketing selective safety features, rather than taking Volvo's approach of pushing the overall safety of the car.''
Subaru ads now play off the Volvo commercials that offer graphic visual evidence of how passengers are protected by a steel cage when the front end crumples in a crash. Subaru wryly suggests that the braking system in its cars helps drivers avoid ever having to find out how the car performs in a collision.
But other Japanese car companies are largely absent from this arena.
''One reason the Japanese aren't advertising safety more is because they don't have much to say,'' said Brian O'Neill, president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
A number of smaller Japanese models have the worst safety records in a list compiled annually by the institute, based on insurance claims.
Mr. O'Neill said Toyota's Lexus, Nissan's Infiniti and Honda's Acura Legend, three luxury cars, are the only Japanese models equipped with air bags as standard equipment.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 1990, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Jan. 26 about automobile safety gave an incomplete list of the Japanese cars equipped with air bags as standard equipment. Besides Toyota's Lexus, Nissan's Infiniti and Honda's Acura Legend, the 1990 Toyota Supra and Celica models have air bags as standard equipment.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
States Weigh Use Of Pension Funds

BYLINE: By Sarah Bartlett

 BODY:
STATE politicians are increasingly eyeing the pension fund savings of state employees -which have grown to a mouth-watering $700 billion nationwide - as a means to promote local economic development.
How appropriate is it to tap state pension fund coffers to support small businesses or provide venture capital for new projects? Would that put those employees' savings at greater risk, or earn them lower returns than they could expect from the stock or bond markets? If local development projects are so attractive, why are private sources of capital not already mining those opportunities? Is the market so inefficient? These and other questions are addressed in a draft of a new study, entitled ''Competitive, Plus,'' by the New York State Industrial Cooperation Council. The final version is to be released in several weeks. The council was established in 1986 by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has been in the forefront of state officials trying to find innovative ways to promote economic development. 
The report's primary finding is that it is possible to invest in projects that produce market-level returns, yet at the same time satisfy social goals like the creation of jobs and economic development. The report presents a challenge to critics, mainly the managers of public pension funds, who have argued that such efforts smack of ''social investing'' and amount to a subsidy of politically attractive projects.
The draft report cites dozens of examples of state-promoted low-income housing, small businesses and venture capital projects that generate market-level returns while providing jobs and stimulating local business. It provides support for a recent Ford Foundation survey of public pension-fund managers who reported that 33 percent of their so-called economically targeted investments met their benchmarks - which were mainly market rates - while fewer than 4 percent failed. For the remainder, the managers either did not respond or did not know the result.
In one striking example, the New York study cites Michigan's public pension funds, which have committed or invested more than $700 million in venture capital projects. Michigan officials estimated that those investments had created about 3,500 jobs and had prompted private investors to commit an additional $200 million to Michigan businesses. So far, Michigan officials say the returns on investments in 42 companies are between 20 and 25 percent, or about the national average.
The New York report concludes that safe and profitable projects exist, but that public pension funds lack the staff and resources to find enough of them. The report endorses the establishment of a state investment bank that would help identify satisfactory projects; Governor Cuomo has favored such a bank for some time.
Tackling its critics head on, the report says a state bank would not ''develop investment programs that direct pension assets into projects with 'concessionary' below-market rates of return.'' It then goes on to suggest areas that New York's $100 billion pension fund might consider for investment. Besides housing, they include new plants and equipment for small and medium-sized manufacturers, resource-recovery plants that can no longer be financed on a tax-exempt basis, and high-tech investments.
The study concludes that ''once the new intermediary is well established,'' it could consider ''certain types of corporate financing,'' employee stock ownership plans, new-product developments, research and development programs, shared production consortiums and education loans.
As to why the market is not already satisfying such needs, the report suggests that ''there are simply fewer investment professionals at work looking for the kinds of public-purpose investments and mixed private-public-purpose investments that could strengthen a state's or region's economy.'' Free-market advocates are likely to find such an explanation wanting.
The report is sure to be examined closely by the public pension fund managers, who are concerned that such investment proposals represent nothing more than a cover for politicians trying to raid the cookie jar to enhance their political fortunes.
The Council of Institutional Investors, which represents 60 public pension funds with holdings of more than $300 billion, has taken a particularly hard stance on this issue. In December, it issued an attack on Governor Cuomo's position in a report entitled ''Our Money, Our Future.''
Sarah A. B. Teslik, the council's executive director, said that from what she had heard about this latest draft report, Governor Cuomo's aides had backed off considerably.
''It sounds much less scary than the original proposals,'' Ms. Teslik said. Nevertheless, she said she was still worried that pension funds could come under political pressure to invest in projects that might not be appropriate.

HEADLINE: Official Takes First Step For Better U.S. Statistics

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, yesterday announced the first step in an effort to improve the quality of Government statistics, from the monthly employment rate to the quarterly measures of the gross national product.
The program includes a 10 percent budget increase for the main agencies involved in gathering statistics and 25 recommendations for specific improvements in data.
The decline in the quality of Government figures is worrying economists and statisticians inside and outside the Government because the data are used in ways that touch the lives of almost every American. 
 
Incomes and Indexes
The data help direct the course of economic policy and if off base could make the difference between a recession and a recovery. Incomes of workers and retirees are tied to the inflation indexes and the distribution of billions of dollars in Government funds is based on formulas based on Government figures.
One reason for the decline in the quality of the data is the rapidly changing nature of the American economy. The gross national product, which measures the total output of goods and services, is better designed to measure the economy of the 1950's, when manufacturing was more important.
Now, the economy is dominated by the services sector, including banks, retail stores and insurance, and this is where Government measuring devices are the weakest.
The push for improvements in data comes after a year in which important statistics, like the gross national product's measure of the output of goods and services, underwent critical revisions during the year and, therefore, gave contradictory signals about the course of the economy. A main reason for the revisions is problems with measuring retail sales, which make up a large portion of the gross national product.
 
Increases Were Denied
In addition, many primary statistical agencies, including the Bureau of Economic Analysis and the Bureau of the Census, were first denied spending increases and then made cuts to help reduce the Federal budget deficit and to pay part of the cost of the Government's anti-drug program. In the last decade, spending for these agencies, which also include the Bureau of Labor Statistics, have been held constant after adjusting for inflation.
''We've turned things around, got a commitment to do a better job and some more money,'' Mr. Boskin said in a telephone interview from Washington. ''By the end of the year, we will have a more comprehensive program. But many of the data improvements will not be felt until the mid-1990's.''
But the success of the program will depend a great deal on Congress, which faces another year of budget-cutting under the goals set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget balancing law. Last year, the House and the Senate rejected President Bush's special request for $20 million more to help improve data collection.
The new money for the programs will be requested in the fiscal year 1991 budget that the President will send to Congress on Monday. The fiscal year 1991 begins on Oct. 1. Mr. Boskin yesterday did not give the details of the increase. But an official familiar with the budget request said it would be about a 10 percent increase in the spending for the main, or ''core,'' agencies involved in gathering statistics, which ranges from $400 million to $500 million, depending upon how it is counted.

HEADLINE: Foreign Investing in U.S. Helps, Greenspan Says

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that foreign investment in the United States spurred competition and new technology. He characterized as overblown concerns about a surge of foreign money invested in the United States.
The concern is understandable, Mr. Greenspan told the House Ways and Means Committee, because foreign investors sometimes disrupt established business patterns. But it is overblown, he said, because ''foreign investment in the United States spurs competition, provides infusions of new capital and technology into industries like steel, and speeds the spread of technological advances.'' $1.8 Trillion Invested The Government reported in June that total foreign investment in the United States increased to $1.8 trillion in 1988, from $220.9 billion in 1975. During that same period, assets owned abroad by companies based in and people living in the United States increased to $1.25 trillion from $295 billion, the Department of Commerce's Bureau of Economic Analysis said. 
But many analysts contend that many United States assets abroad are undervalued by the Government because they are listed at the purchase price of decades ago rather than present market value.
At one point, Representative Jim Moody, a Wisconsin Democrat, asked Mr. Greenspan whether he favored withholding taxes on earnings generated by foreign holdings of securities in the United States. ''It would be a tricky trade-off,'' Mr. Greenspan replied, ''because the aggregate amount would come down.''
Pressed by Mr. Moody, the chairman said, ''It's an interesting idea that should be looked at.'' That polite response seemed to stir anxiety in the stock and credit markets, where prices plunged.
Congress has been reluctant to approve legislation that would discourage the influx of foreign money. That suggests that the prospects of withholding taxes are remote.
 
The Largest Investors
Foreign private investors and governments now own $329 billion in such assets as factories and real estate, the Government reported. The rest is in portfolio investments like Treasury securities, stocks and bonds. The largest foreign investors are the British, followed by the Japanese, the Dutch and Canadians.
Mr. Greenspan noted that foreign purchases of United States Treasury securities surpassed $3 trillion in 1988, up from $100 billion to $200 billion earlier in the decade. He called this surge part of an inexorable trend toward the globalization of markets, which itself had been spurred by technological innovations and deregulation.
Such globalization ''benefits both the United States and the rest of the world,'' Mr. Greenspan said.
Representative Sander M. Levin, Democrat of Michigan, asked Mr. Greensapn if it mattered if foreigners own American assets. ''It does matter,'' Mr. Greenspan said. ''To the extent that properties are profitable, I'd prefer that ownership be American.''
The surge of foreign investment was largely a result of inadequate national savings and the Federal budget deficit, Mr. Greenspan said. He urged Congress to address these underlying factors rather than ''the symptoms -large accumulations of foreign assets in the United States.''
Representative Frank J. Guarini, a New Jersey Democrat, asked, ''Is there a point at which we should be concerned about losing our economic independence and political sovereignty?''
Mr. Greenspan replied that foreign investment in the United States was relatively low compared with that in Europe. He predicted that all foreign investment would increase because ''what we are seeing is the shrinking of the globe.''

GRAPHIC: photo: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, telling the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday that concerns about a surge of foreign investment in the United States are overblown. (AP)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Executive Team At Wickes Lumber

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Wickes Lumber Company, a major supplier of building materials, yesterday announced the appointment of a new management team: William A. Hensler, from inside the company, and Philip M. Chrusz, from outside.
Mr. Hensler, 60 years old, will be chairman and chief executive of the privately held operation, and Mr. Chrusz, 47, will be president and chief operating officer.
Until last June, the company had been run by Leslie Hagen, who retired at age 63. Hedrick & Struggles, the executive recruiting firm, conducted a search inside and outside the company and recommended Mr. Hensler and Mr. Chrusz. 
Mr. Hensler joined Wickes Lumber in 1960 as a long-range planner in the corporate treasury department and worked his way through the financial operations into merchandising and other areas. He is a graduate of Ferris State College in Big Rapids, Mich.
Mr. Chrusz comes from Ames Department Stores Inc., a discount store chain, where he was senior vice president for specialy retailing. Mr. Chrusz had earlier worked for the Grossman Building Materials Company. He is a graduate of Northeastern University in Boston.
Wickes Lumber, with annual sales exceeding $1 billion, operates 190 stores in 30 states. About 60 percent of its business comes from builders and the rest from individuals, Mr. Hansler said.
''We are driven by housing starts and interest rates and those types of things versus the true home center that concentrates on the retail customer,'' he said.
The company, based in Vernon Hills, Ill., was taken private in a leveraged buyout in 1988. It had been part of the Wickes Companies, which entered court bankruptcy proceedings in 1982 but emerged from bankruptcy before the buyout of the lumber operations.
Wickes Lumber, which is dependent on a healthy building industry and is struggling with a heavy debt from the buyout, could suffer a double blow in any major economic turndown.
Mr. Hensler said the company was not currently emphasizing growth. ''Inasmuch as we are a leveraged company, we've got other things to do first,'' he said. They include divesting itself of some unprofitable stores and redeploying assets in better-performing businesses, he said.
''If I had a wish,'' he said, ''it would be for two million housing starts and interest rates below 6 percent.''

HEADLINE: Phillips Reports Loss; Occidental Net Jumps

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The Phillips Petroleum Company said today that it lost $255 million in the fourth quarter because of regulatory delays and economic misjudgments involving its long-held stake in the Point Arguello project off the southern coast of California.
Phillips, the nation's 10th-largest oil company, said it also incurred $50 million in costs from an explosion and fire in October that killed 23 workers and stalled production at a petrochemical plant near Houston. It indicated that insurance would cover future losses, however.
The Occidental Petroleum Company, the ninth-largest oil company, reported a jump in fourth-quarter net income, to $30 million. The company's $7 million profit in the fourth quarter of 1988 was after a reduction of $45 million to settle a dispute with the Energy Department on ''windfall profits'' tax payments. 
 
Phillips
The fourth-quarter loss of $255 million compared with a profit of $135 million, or 55 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter. Revenues in the quarter rose slightly, to $3.03 billion from $2.86 billion.
For the full year, net income fell 66 percent, to $219 million, from $650 million in 1988. Revenues rose to $12.5 billion from $11.5 billion.
Most of the fourth-quarter loss resulted from a $280 million reduction in the value of Phillips's stake in the Point Arguello field. C.J. Silas, chairman and chief executive of the company, which is based in Bartlesville, Okla., attributed the write-down largely to ''protracted delays in gaining regulatory approval'' for production to begin at the field.
Without the Point Arguello charges, Phillips said it would have reported a $25 million profit from operations for the quarter.
In recent days, other major partners in the development, including the Chevron Corporation and Texaco Inc., announced that they had taken large charges to reflect both production delays and, since 1986, lower oil prices that have reduced potential profits from Point Arguello.
The 18 partners in the field have invested more than $2 billion. But after the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska last March, California regulators revoked a permit the partners needed to use tankers to transport processed fuel. Production from Point Arguello, with an estimated 2 billion barrels of recoverable reserves, initially was to begin in 1987.
The loss of Phillips's polyethelene plant near Houston reduced pretax profits in its chemical operations for the quarter to $36 million, from $144 million in the period a year earlier. Prices for petrochemical products, widely used in plastics manufacturing, declined in the period.
Phillips's shares gained 50 cents today to close at $23.50 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Occidental
The company's $30 million fourth-quarter profit, equal to 10 cents a share, compared with net income of $7 million, or 2 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter. Revenues fell slightly, to $5.05 billion from $5.28 billion.
For the year, net income declined 5.6 percent, to $285 million, or $1.03 a share, from $302 million, or $1.21 a share, in 1988. Revenues increased by 3.3 percent, to $20.07 billion, from $19.42 billion.
The large percentage gain in fourth-quarter profits was tied to Occidental's oil operations. The unit recorded a $43 million loss a year earlier after settling a dispute with the Government on a tax owed on so-called windfall profits made when the price of oil increased suddenly in late 1970's. The unit posted a profit of $13 million in the final quarter of 1989.
Pretax profit from chemical operations fell 16.4 percent in the quarter, to $214 million, from $256 million in the 1988 quarter. Similalry, operating profits at IBP Inc., a large meat processor that is 51 percent owned by Occidental, declined 36 percent, to $23 million.
Administrative and other expenses for the year increased to $209 million in 1989, from $148 million in 1988. The 1989 figure included an unspecified charge for a charitable contribution to an art museum being developed adjacent to the company's headquarters in Westwood, Calif., and named for Dr. Armand Hammer, Occidental's chairman and chief executive.
Occidental's shares fell 25 cents today, to $27.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Threat of Oil Shortage by '93 Seen

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company predicted today that oil supply shortages could occur as early as 1993 or 1994 because of OPEC's inability to expand production. A possible increase in demand for oil from Eastern Europe could add to the strain on supplies, he added. 
Robert M. Horton, who will become chairman of British Petroleum in March, also said that oil prices could average $20 a barrel this year because demand in the West is holding up better than many in the oil industry had anticipated.
Although the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries can now produce about 25 million barrels of oil a day, demand for OPEC oil is already about 22 million barrels and is growing annually by about one million barrels, Mr. Horton said.
To meet the additional demand, OPEC countries would have to spend $50 billion to $60 billion, an amount they cannot afford, he said. As a result, ''the crunch is going to be nearer in time than any of us thought,'' he said.
Mr. Horton urged Western governments to take heed of the situation and promote conservation. He also urged that they allow oil exploration in environmentally sensitive areas like the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska and offshore California and that they support increased use of nuclear power.
Mr. Horton said that if Eastern European countries continued to move toward democracy and rebuilt their economies, their need for Western oil could add ''another half-million barrels a day to demand quite easily.''
British Petroleum, the world's third-largest oil company, is interested in expanding its business in Eastern Europe and possibly in the Soviet Union, he said.

HEADLINE: President-Elect of Brazil Pushing Free-Market Ideas

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

 BODY:
Beginning a nine-nation tour to put a ''new face'' on Brazil, the country's president-elect, Fernando Collor de Mello, vowed in New York yesterday to restore growth to Latin America's largest economy through privatization, fiscal discipline and debt relief.
In a speech to 400 business executives and bankers, several of whom had said earlier that Brazil's high inflation and low growth in the 1980's had left them skeptical about its prospects, Mr. Collor put forth his ideas on developing a freer market in his country.
On his March 15 inauguration, Mr. Collor, a 40-year-old state Governor, will assume leadership of a country that experienced 1,775 percent inflation last year and stopped servicing its foreign debt. After enjoying one of the third world's highest growth rates in the 1970's, Brazil's economy slumped in the 1980's, averaging about 2 percent growth a year. 
 
Admirer of Thatcher
Mr. Collor, an admirer of British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's free-market policies, proposed restoring growth through increased foreign investment and deregulation of the economy.
''The inflation and stagnation paralyzed investments and discouraged the entry of foreign capital,'' Mr. Collor said in Portuguese to the luncheon sponsored by the Americas Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Echoing free-market advocates in other Latin American countries like Argentina and Mexico, Mr. Collor blamed Brazil's stagnation on ''the inhibiting and inefficient state, the inflation and financial speculation, the system of privileges that protects and rewards inefficiency.''
Last year, Brazil's Congress refused to approve an inflation-fighting package submitted by Brazil's President, Jose Sarney. The plan would have cut Government spending and the Government payroll. Mr. Collor, whose party controls only 5 percent of the seats in Brazil's Congress, did not say yesterday how he would muster political support in Congress to push through his changes.
 
Limits to Sacrifices
Addressing Brazil's debt problem, he warned the audience, which included representatives of New York's largest banks, that there were limits to the sacrifices Brazil could accept to make payments.
''We don't have the illusion of being able to unilaterally impose a path of negotiations,'' he said. ''But we cannot accept impositions - agreements which resemble loyalty oaths -blocking our growth and condemning us to backwardness and misery.''
Mr. Collor won general support from members of the audience.
''I have seen a lot of Latin leaders come through here,'' said one American banker who had crossed swords with Brazilian officials throughout the 1980's over their inability to service $110 billion in foreign debt, the largest in the third world. ''On a scale of 1 to 10, I put Collor at 9.5.''
Henry Kissinger, who also attended a closed-door meeting with Mr. Collor yesterday morning, said: ''I was very encouraged by what he said.''
From New York, Mr. Collor travels to Washington where he is to meet with President Bush and others. He will then travel to Tokyo, Moscow, Bonn, Rome, Paris, London, Lisbon and Madrid.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Move Downward

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A news service report about comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent shudders through the credit markets yesterday and pushed down prices of Treasury notes and bonds.
The report, sent out by Dow Jones, suggested that Mr. Greenspan had said he favored a reinstatement of the foreign withholding tax on American securities. His remarks came in response to a question by Representative Jim Moody, Democrat of Wisconsin and a member of the House Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Greenspan was appearing before the committee.
That suggestion, which was later strongly denied by Joseph Coyne, a Fed spokesman, prompted a selloff in the financial markets, and was a factor in the 43.46-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 
Idea Downplayed
''Mr. Greenspan threw cold water on the idea,'' Mr. Coyne said.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Moody said he had asked the Fed chairman ''if it would make sense to require foreigners to pay withholding taxes, as it used to be.''
''He didn't say yes or no,'' the Congressman said. ''He said it would present us with a dilemma.''
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan had called the idea a ''tricky trade-off,'' and after being pressed by Mr. Moody said, ''It's an interesting idea that should be looked at.''
The initial Dow Jones report was subsequently updated to include the additional comments by Mr. Greenspan as well as Mr. Coyne's denial that the Fed chairman supported restoring the tax, which was repealed in the mid-1980's.
But the updated reports did little to calm participants in the credit markets.
 
Market Called Very Nervous
''The market is very, very jumpy about Japanese interest in the refunding auctions,'' said James R. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities.
''The market was up during trading in Tokyo and then, when it gets some news that wasn't that bad, all of the gains were undone. Until the market demonstrates it can handle bad news, you have to be careful about buying.''
Analysts said there was little doubt what would happen if the tax were reinstituted.
''If the tax were reimposed, it would be wildly negative,'' said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America.
''You would have thought that the market would have recovered after the Fed denied the report. But the fact that someone in Congress voiced the thought raised the specter that there are people in Washington who are thinking along these lines.''
Robert Chandross, chief economist at Lloyds Bank, said: ''From a political viewpoint, one can envision how this would be popular. But I find it almost incomprehensible that Alan Greenspan would support an artificial barrier to capital movements that never worked in the past.''
In his remarks, Mr. Greenspan said that reinstating the tax would likely cause an ''extraordinary shift'' by foreigners from domestic securities.
 
Bellwether Bond at 8.45%
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 had fallen by more than half a point in price, to a late offered price of 96 14/32, to yield 8.45 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 96 1/2, down 9/32, to yield 8.40 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes auctioned on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.22 percent.
Rates rose modestly yesterday on Treasury bills.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.67 percent, up 2 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.60 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.47 percent, up 1 basis point.
Given the recent sharp selloff, many analysts have been predicting that the higher yields would attract buyers, and a rally would begin. Economic data to be released today were expected to encourage buying. But now some analysts are not so sure.
''For the past two days, I thought a correction was about to unfold,'' Mr. Moran said. ''But people are already expecting that the report on durable goods orders and on the gross national product will be soft. You could see a rally if those numbers are softer than what people expect, but now that is in doubt.''
 
Corporate Bond Prices Dip
In other developments, prices of most actively traded issues of investment-grade corporate bonds dipped by about one-quarter of a point, market participants said.
Activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was highlighted by the sale of $100 million worth of revenue bonds offered by the Salt River Project Electrical System of Arizona.
The bonds, which were sold at competitive bid, were won by an investment group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
The issue consists mostly of term bonds. Coupons on the term bonds are 7.25 percent on bonds that mature in 2019 and 7.30 percent on bonds maturing in 2030.
The issue is rated AA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Traders said that in the secondary market, prices of most municipal bonds fell by about one-quarter point.
In Washington, the Fed reported yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week that ended Jan. 15. The third measure, M-2, rose by $2.2 billion.

HEADLINE: U.S. Regulators Accuse Bush Son in Savings Case

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Federal regulators said today that they would file an administrative action against President Bush's son Neil, accusing him of conflicts of interest while he was a director of a giant Denver-based savings institution, the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association.
The accusation of misconduct concerning Mr. Bush's actions at Silverado, which collapsed in late 1988, is certain to embarrass the White House. Less than six months ago, the President signed the largest taxpayer bailout ever, to pay for losses that largely resulted from mismanagement and fraud in the savings and loan industry.
But the action, if upheld by a Federal judge, would amount to little more than a slap on the wrist for the sort of violation that is often handled in quiet negotiations with regulators and is not considered overly grave. Both sides said the case took on dramatically larger proportions because Mr. Bush is a son of the President. 
After weeks of speculation in the press and concern on Capitol Hill and in the industry about whether regulators might back off because of political worries, the Office of Thrift Supervision said it would seek a cease-and-desist order from an administrative law judge against Neil Bush, who is 35 years old. Mr. Bush is not accused of criminal wrongdoing.
The order would seek to stop Mr. Bush from engaging in certain financial practices and relationships if he became an officer or director of another savings institution.
While agency officials declined to provide details of the complaint, they said privately that it would contend that while Mr. Bush was a director of Silverado from 1986 to August 1988 he voted to approve large loans to at least one executive with whom he had a financial relationship.
State and Federal laws generally require that directors refrain from participating in such voting.
Agency officials said the case was one of its mildest enforcement actions involving former officers and directors of Silverado, which was taken over by the Government in December 1988 at an estimated cost of $1 billion. But they said Mr. Bush's ties to the President compelled them to handle the case more publicly.
 
'Imposing Very High Standards'
''This is a very narrow case of what are the rules of proper conduct for a director of an S.&L., and you will find we are imposing very high standards,'' Rosemary Stewart, the thrift office's director of enforcement, said today in an interview.
''We decided that because there was so much press attention and speculation that we had to go public with the case far earlier than we generally do,'' said Karl Hoyle, chief spokesman for the agency.
The announcement that the action would be taken against Mr. Bush came a day after he issued a statement saying he had broken off negotiations with the thrift office and had declined to enter into a settlement agreement.
From his office today, he denied any wrongdoing.
''I have refused to sign any agreement on the principle that I have done nothing wrong,'' Mr. Bush said in a telephone interview from Denver. ''I am not going to sign any document, no matter how impotent it is, that implies I have done anything wrong. I'm prepared to fight this, and will do so.''
Mr. Bush also suggested that because of the attention the savings and loan scandal had received and because of his father's position, the regulators ''felt they had to do something.''
Indeed, the ramifications of the case against Mr. Bush are complex. On its face, charging a son of the President with conflict of interest comes at an awkward time for the White House. It follows the implementation of the savings and loan bailout plan, considered one of the President's big successes in his first year in office.
 
President Monitoring Situation
The White House was both embarrassed and angered by the regulators' action today. Administration officials said the President was monitoring the situation.
Some financial experts said the action could be interpreted as an attempt to even the score between the thrift office and the White House, since the bailout legislation stripped the agency of much of its power and the President refused to stand up to Congress in its successful attempts to force M. Danny Wall, the agency's director, to resign. Ms. Stewart and Mr. Hoyle denied that their agency had acted in retaliation.
 
A Father's Advice
Neil Bush said that he had spoken with his father about the case and that the President had been supportive. But he said his father was not about to get involved.
''I have spoken with him as a son would speak with his dad,'' Mr. Bush said. ''My father has given me the same advice he has given me for 34 years: that is to do what is right. He wouldn't get involved, nor would I ask him to get involved. But as any son would with his father, I mentioned it to him and looked to him as a source of empathy. But the handling of this is in my hands.''
Anna Perez, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Bush, said: ''Mrs. Bush doesn't believe Neil has done anything wrong, so she feels for him. She knows it's a difficult period for him.''
The action against Neil Bush could be a continuing source of embarrassment, since the legal battle could take up to two years. President Bush will have to appoint a new director for the thrift office who will eventually decide whether to continue to press the action against Neil Bush in the Federal courts.
 
Five Are Banned
While there has been much interest in Neil Bush's involvement in Silverado and some of his business dealings, the regulators have taken the strongest measures against five former executives, barring them from ever again working for a bank, savings association or credit union.
The five, who admitted no wrongdoing but agreed that they would not return to the banking business, are Michael R. Wise, the former chairman and chief executive; Richard K. Vandapool and Robert M. Lewis, former vice chairmen; Russell M. Murray, former executive vice president for lending, and W. James Metz, a former director and majority stockholder.
The agency has said its examiners found that Silverado managers were deficient in assessing the creditworthiness of borrowers, concentrated too much of the institution's business in commercial loans amid a depressed market and conducted an exceptionally large number of problem transactions with insiders, including shareholders, officers and directors.
 
Other Investigations
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which has the power to sue directors and officers to recover losses, is also investigating Silverado, as is the Justice Department, which could bring criminal charges.
Though Neil struggled as a student through high school and was the first Bush son who did not attend the Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., he eventually earned a master of business administration degree at Tulane University. He did follow his father's footsteps in setting up his own oil company; he founded JNB Exploration in the early 1980's in Denver.
He served on the board of Silverado for almost three years, at a time when the Denver economy began to fall apart as energy prices plunged. He resigned in August 1988, two weeks after his father received the Republican Presidential nomination.
 
Focus on Two Borrowers
In particular, regulators are focusing on his business relationship with two large borrowers from Silverado who are also investors in JNB Exploration, Bill L. Walters and Kenneth M. Good.
Mr. Walters, who had initially invested $150,000 in JNB, held a passive 6.25 percent interest in the exploration company at the time he was seeking loans from Silverado. Mr. Good had a larger but unstated participation in JNB's financing and an active role in the company's management, while also being a large borrower from Silverado.
In the statement he issued late Thursday, Mr. Bush said that he had abstained from all voting on loans and transactions between Silverado and Mr. Good and that he had voted on the Walters transactions ''because I did not benefit directly or indirectly from any loan or transaction between Silverado and the businesses controlled by Mr. Walters.''
But regulators are likely to take a stricter view of the law, arguing that the fact that Mr. Bush had a business relationship with Mr. Walters was sufficient ground for him to abstain from voting on loans for Mr. Walters from Silverado. Regulators have also pointed to the fact that JNB had received a $1.2 million loan from a bank controlled by Mr. Walters as another indication that Mr. Bush should have excused himself from dealings between Silverado and Mr. Walters.
The case will now be heard by an administrative law judge, who will have to make a recommendation to the thrift office's director, most likely Mr. Wall's successor, on whether there is merit to the Government's accusations.
The agency's director would then have to make a final decision and could impose a cease-and-desist order. Mr. Bush could then appeal that decision to the United States Court of Appeals in Washington.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 BUDGET: BUSH'S PROPOSAL;
Bush Budget Sees Growing Revenue And Cut In Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
President Bush is preparing to send Congress a $1.2 trillion budget that envisions a dramatic decline in the Federal deficit to roughly half its level in the current fiscal year.
Mr. Bush's budget, being presented to Congress on Monday, proposes that the deficit for the next fiscal year be reduced to $63.1 billion. To accomplish that, the Administration would hold down the growth of spending and rely on its expectation of continued expansion of the economy, which would produce greater tax revenue, according to budget documents obtained by The New York Times. That deficit would be slightly below the level required by law.
In the new budget, Mr. Bush proposes to use the growing surplus in the Social Security trust fund to reduce the debt accumulated by the Federal Government over more than a decade. His proposal, calling for a ''Social Security integrity and debt reduction fund,'' differs sharply from the recent proposal by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan to cut Social Security taxes so the surplus would not be available for use in other programs. 
 
Lecture by Budget Chief
For the Pentagon, Mr. Bush's proposal seeks less money than would be needed to keep pace with inflation, representing a further slowing of the military buildup begun in the early 1980's. The budget documents also suggest that the President is more interested in reducing the deficit and holding down taxes than in broad new domestic initiatives.
The documents show that the budget director, Richard G. Darman, plans to present the Administration's proposal to Congress with a colorfully worded essay lecturing the lawmakers about their ''obligation to be serious.''
This essay, unlike any previous messages to Congress from a budget director, seems likely to fuel the conflicts that already exist between Democratic legislators and Mr. Darman because of its didactic tone and bursts of playful language.
 
Conflict May Be Greater
Even without such unusual tactics, Presidential budget proposals are always subject to extensive revision by Congress. The conflict may be greater than usual this year because of a growing sense among lawmakers that money can be shifted from military accounts to domestic programs as the threat of confrontation with the Soviet Union diminishes.
The Darman essay characterizes the Federal budget as ''the ultimate Cookie Monster,'' capable of gobbling up everything in its path, and exhorts legislators to be prepared for future expenses that he calls ''hidden Pac-Men,'' referring to a video game in which characters consume each other.
Without naming the Democrats, Mr. Darman says that those who talk about the ''peace dividend'' have ''trivialized'' the budget process, and he charges that they are driven by political greed and economic misunderstanding.
 
Growth in Tax Revenue Seen
In its specifics, the White House proposal assumes that because of growth in the economy, Federal tax revenue will increase three times as fast as Federal spending, so the deficit will decline in the 1991 fiscal year to $63.1 billion from $123.8 billion this year.
For the fiscal year 1991, which begins next Oct. 1, Mr. Bush proposes total spending of $1,233.3 billion, including $292.1 billion for the Defense Department, and he expects receipts of $1,170.2 billion. The resulting deficit is just under the goal required by law of $64 billion.
The experience of the last two years suggests that Mr. Bush's estimate of a 9 percent increase in Federal receipts is reasonable if the economy continues growing at roughly its current rate. But his projection of a 3 percent increase in Government spending appears unrealistically low based on Congressional action in the last few years. Federal outlays rose 6 percent in 1988 and 7.5 percent in 1989 above the preceding years.
The estimated deficit for the current fiscal year, $123.8 billion, is well above the $100 billion goal required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law. The deficit last year was $152 billion; the goal was $136 billion.
In his warning about hidden liabilities that he calls ''Pac-Men,'' Mr. Darman lists the rising costs of health care and social welfare benefits; the obligation to clean up radioactive waste at nuclear weapon factories; Federal loans and loan guarantees for college students, farmers, home buyers and owners of small businesses, and Government insurance for bank deposits and private pensions.
With the American economy in its eighth consecutive year of growth, Mr. Darman's essay says, the ''Federal deficit seems, at worst, to have stabilized.'' But, he adds, as the risk of superpower conflict declines, ''the relative importance of U.S. economic strength only increases.''
 
'Peace Dividend' Fantasy Cited
He says Congress has ''an obligation to be serious'' and not to drift into ''Wonderland'' with fantasies about a ''peace dividend,'' derived from cuts in Pentagon programs.
Mr. Darman says the historic shifts taking place in Eastern Europe - a ''giant leap of the human spirit yearning to breathe free'' - has been ''trivialized in its translation into public debate about the budget.'' The issue, he says, has been framed in such terms as, ''How big is the 'peace dividend'?'' and ''How can I get mine?''
Mr. Darman has a decisive influence over domestic and economic policy. He is one of the few Bush aides to express a long-term vision for the United States. He served for eight years in Ronald Reagan's Administration, which was often criticized by Democrats for policies they said rewarded greed and materialism.
The underlying message of Mr. Darman's essay amounts to a warning that substantial departure from the President's wish-list could endanger economic growth. A spending binge triggered by a largely illlusory ''peace dividend'' would limit growth, feed the deficit and undermine the United States' main advantage in dealing with change in Europe and the Soviet Union, Mr. Darman argues.
To reduce the ''burden of debt for future generations,'' Mr. Bush proposes in the 1991 budget the creation of the ''Social Security integrity and debt reduction fund.'' Each year the Treasury would deposit into the fund ''an increasing portion of the projected Social Security operating surplus, reaching 100 percent in 1996,'' the budget documents say.The money would be used ''to reduce Federal debt and thus leave a more manageable financing burden for future generations.''
 
Moynihan Plan Criticized
In his introductory chapter, Mr. Darman denounces Senator Moynihan's proposal for a cut in Social Security taxes. Supporters of the plan by the New York Democrat say that Social Security taxes have been used improperly to hide the true size of the Federal deficit.
Mr. Darman also ridicules the idea of a ''peace dividend.'' Any savings in the military budget will be ''smaller than is commonly assumed,'' he says.
''Washington entertains the notion of spending 50 times a dividend that has not yet definitively materialized - a true Wonderland phenomenon.''
If Federal revenue falls short of spending in any year, it creates a budget deficit, and the Government must borrow more money from the public. The accumulated total of such borrowing is the Federal debt. In general, there is no way to reduce the debt unless the Government operates at a surplus. The debt is a burden on taxpayers because the Government must pay interest on the debt.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that gross Federal debt will total $3.1 trillion at the end of the current fiscal year. That includes $807 billion held by Government trust funds.
The debt held by the public, a number with more economic significance, is projected at $2.3 trillion.
In a flight of fancy reminiscent of a speech he once gave denouncing self-indulgent ''now-now-ism,'' Mr. Darman describes the Federal budget as ''the ultimate Cookie Monster,'' because it has a huge appetite for consumption, like the character on the children's television program, ''Sesame Street.''
Mr. Darman says the budget ''might be understood as little more than a compilation of cookies received, cookies crumbled and crumbs spewed forth.'' But he says it actually is ''an implicit statement of values and expectations for the future.'' For too long, he says, Americans have neglected the future in a short-sighted pursuit of immediate gratification and consumption.
Mr. Darman expresses alarm about trillions of dollars in future Federal liabilities, which he describes as the ''hidden Pac-Men'' looming on the horizon. The cost of these obligations over the next 30 years is virtually certain to exceed $150 billion, he says.
 
Domestic Cuts Proposed
The Administration says that ''policy recommendations'' in the new budget will produce savings of $36.5 billion in 1991. The savings would result from proposed cuts in domestic programs, as well as from new fees charged for the use of Federal services.
Mr. Bush says that Federal receipts would increase by $96.7 billion under his budget request. The effects of inflation and economic growth account for most of the increase. With no change in current law, he says, Government receipts would rise $83.4 billion. On top of that, he says that new fees and legislation would increase Federal receipts by $13.3 billion.
Mr. Bush's budget emphasizes scientific research and development. Mr. Darman said the President was proposing a 24 percent budget increase for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, ''to a record $15.2 billion.'' Mr. Bush is also proposing tax incentives to encourage greater investment in scientific research by private businesses.
Under the Bush proposal, total Government spending on research and development would rise several billion dollars in the 1991 fiscal year, to slightly more than $70 billion.
Mr. Bush proposes a budget of $24.6 billion for the Education Department.
That is an increase of $500 million over this year's spending, or about half of what would be needed to keep up with inflation.
 
Pentagon Spending Increase
The new budget calls for an increase of 1.8 percent in Defense Department spending, from $286.8 billion this year to $292.1 billion next year. That is less than the increase needed to keep pace with inflation.
While the Administration will propose cuts in non-nuclear weapons and may try to close some of the country's biggest military bases, Mr. Bush is seeking a 20 percent increase in spending for development of an anti-missile shield. Administration officials said the President would seek $4.8 billion for this ''Star Wars'' program in 1991.
Mr. Bush has not made public the economic assumptions on which his budget is based. The Congressional Budget Office on Wednesday predicted inflation of 4.1 percent this year. It estimated that the economy would grow almost 2 percent this year and slightly faster next year. In the past, the President's budget often assumed slightly lower inflation and more robust economic growth than the Congressional forecast.

HEADLINE: Haiti's Ruler Says He'll Lift State of Siege on Tuesday

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Responding to international and domestic pressure, Haiti's military ruler said tonight that the 30-day state of siege he imposed last weekend would be lifted on Tuesday.
In a brief television address, Lieut. Gen. Prosper Avril made no mention of lifting press restrictions or permitting the return of political leaders who have been expelled in the last week.
General Avril had predicted on Thursday that he would lift the state of siege today. 
Haitian political leaders and foreign diplomats have said that they would consider a lifting of the state of siege only the first step toward diminishing the widespread belief that General Avril is consolidating power and entrenching himself as a dictator.
 
France Suspends Economic Aid
The United States, France and Canada have condemned the decree, under which dozens of political activists were rounded up and beaten.
France suspended economic aid to Haiti today. Officials in Washington said this week that the United States was reviewing its relationship with Haiti and that any resumption of economic aid was out of the question for the moment.
The United States cut off aid to Haiti in late 1987, when the country's first attempt at democratic elections in more than three decades ended in a massacre of voters in Port-au-Prince.
Reading from a text in a stern voice before the cameras of the state-run television station tonight, General Avril said he had imposed the state of siege because soldiers were ''in a fury'' over the slaying of an army colonel by unknown assailants last Saturday. He also complained of anarchism and violent crime.
Haitians were stunned last week by the declaration of the state of siege. They said they were unaware of any circumstances warranting the curtailment of civil liberties.
 
Says He Still Plans Election
General Avril said he planned to proceed with plans for elections this year. The Government has promised to hold elections for local offices in April, followed by voting for the National Assembly this summer and a presidential election in the fall.
In the last week, however, many Haitians have judged it extremely unlikely that General Avril will allow fair elections.
The military Government's Interior Minister, Gen. Fritz Romulus, said this week that the Government would consider allowing the exiled leaders to return to Haiti after the local and legislative elections are held.
Political leaders who are still in the country have rejected this plan, saying it would allow the Government to choose a National Assembly of its own making. Any candidate who returns from exile late in the year would begin the presidential campaign with a severe handicap, they add.
General Avril said he had decided to lift the state of siege after ''considering the postive results so far.''
Other Haitians have cited only negative results. The crackdown on dissent has drawn strong protests from business leaders as well as politicians.

HEADLINE: Iran Sees U.S. Hostages as Non-Issue, Official Says

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 26

 BODY:
A senior Iranian Government official says that the prospect of freeing American hostages held in Lebanon is no longer a matter that preoccupies Iranian leaders.
The official, who is touring a number of European capitals, said in two recent conversations that the Government of Iran's President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, had no plans for improving ties with the United States.
He said that a majority of Iranian leaders were far more interested in building strong economic and political ties to countries in Western Europe, which he said would ''dominate the decade of the 90's.''
''There is a profound conviction among senior members of the clergy and senior technocrats in Iran that maybe our generation will not see better ties with the United States,'' said the official, who insisted on anonymity. 
 
'We Do Not Need Them'
''The general feeling is that we do not need them,'' he said. ''As far as our technological and industrial needs in the years to come are concerned, we are confident we can do very well cooperating with Western Europe.''
Discussing the situation in the Persian Gulf, the conflict in Soviet Azerbaijan and the internal power struggle in Iran, the official, in two long conversations, made these points:
* Iran is convinced that the situation in Azerbaijan has slipped out of Moscow's control and can never return to what it was unless the Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is replaced ''with a Stalinist-like regime'' that rules with an iron fist, an unlikely possibility in Iran's view. The official said Iran would not interfere in the Soviet republic, but that it ''is now possible to think of open borders and industrial coopeation with Azerbaijan.''
* President Rafsanjani is firmly in control of the Government and is carrying out a program of economic and political liberalization with the full cooperation of a majority of the Iranian Parliament. He described militant radicals like former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, also a member of Parliament, as ''paper tigers basically useful in feeding the fantasies of the Western media.'' He said that no senior members of the ruling clergy opposed President Rafsanjani's views.
* Iran has made great strides in accumulating credits and indirect loans from Western European countries. These hard-currency loans, quietly extended by most Western European nations, are being used to reconstruct the Iranian economy and its industrial infrastructure.
* Even though the Iranian armed forces have substantially improved their air defenses and could withstand an attack by Iraq, the Iranian Government believes that opinion in Iraq and elsewhere in the world rules out a resumption of fighting between the two countries, which ended in 1988. Iran, the official said, has no plans for massive rearmament.
The official said after many false starts in trying to improve ties with the United States over the last decade, the issue had been relegated to neglect.
 
'A Closed File,' He Says
''You don't hear anyone in the top leadership saying anything about hostages anymore or better ties with the United States,'' he said. ''It has become a closed file for the foreseeable future.''
He said there was a ''genuine antipathy'' toward the United States among senior members of the clergy as well as senior Iranian technocrats, including those who are American-educated.
The reason, the official said, is that the United States has sought to use every opportunity for an opening ''either to spy on us or play domestic politics.''
Asked about the fate of the eight American hostages who are thought to be held in Lebanon by various pro-Iranian Shiite militias, the official said that Iran had distanced itself from the issue because it had little incentive to pursue their liberation and because the situation in Lebanon ''keeps on deteriorating.''
The official, who is a strong supporter and ally of President Rafsanjani, conceded that the various militias claiming an affiliation with Iran are increasingly in business for themselves, behaving more like mercenaries that could easily shift their loyalties to Libya, Syria or any other paymaster.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Spain;
Challenge to Madrid's Success Story

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Having flourished as Western Europe's economic success story of the late 1980's, Spain is now worried that it may lose out as wealthier members of the European Community turn their attention to Eastern Europe.
Along with the rest of the 12-nation European Community, Spain has welcomed political change in Eastern Europe and has backed community programs to provide credits to Poland and Hungary and even food to Rumania. It has even agreed to contribute to a new development bank for Eastern Europe.
But as former Communist countries adopt market economies, Spain also fears new competition for community resources, foreign investment and export opportunities. Ireland, Greece and Portugal, the other ''poor relatives'' of Western Europe, have expressed similar worries. 
''We are completely in favor of opening up to the Eastern countries, but obviously without forgetting the south,'' Portugal's Prime Minister, Anibal Cavaco Silva, noted recently.
 
New Foreign Investment
Until now, the community's four least developed countries have been the main beneficiaries of programs worth around $8 billion a year to raise living standards and provide infrastructure in backward regions with a view to reducing the huge gap between rich and poor in Western Europe.
Having liberalized its economy, Spain has also attracted huge amounts of new foreign investment - more than $10 billion in 1989 alone - which have enabled it to register the Community's highest economic growth rates over the past four years.
But with much of this investment coming from West Germany, France, Switzerland, the United States and Japan, Spanish officials recognize that Eastern European countries may well prove attractive to foreign corporations looking for low wage scales and markets begging for consumer goods.
''If West Germany was investing a lot in Spain, it may now think it more important to invest in Eastern Europe than Spain,'' said Pedro Solbes, Spain's Secretary of State for the European Community. ''A slowdown in investment is therefore possible.''
 
A Pessimistic View
Some pessimists here have even warned that a new economic and political axis linking East and West across northern Europe could reduce Spain to a ''peripheral'' position in Europe, above all if the Community eventually decides to open its membership to former Soviet bloc nations.
Within Spain's governing Socialist Party, there is also concern that the left-of-center parties of southern Europe may lose political influence if new Eastern European parties are allowed to join the Socialist International, the worldwide social democratic movement.
Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, though, seems determined to continue playing Spain's European card, not only because it has served the country well since joining the community in 1986, but also because it enjoys enormous public support at home.
Further, with the Community committed to accepting no new members until after a single European market is formed in 1992, Mr. Gonzalez has joined France's President, Francois Mitterrand, in arguing that acceleration of its integration process is the best way of keeping Bonn's attention focused on Western Europe.
 
Long-Term Loans to East
Noting that Spain's 27 percent share of the community's regional development fund is secure until 1992, Mr. Solbes said the community should help Eastern Europe's economies less through outright grants than through long-term loans and private sector participation.
''Czechoslovakia's per capita income is already higher than that of Greece or Portugal,'' he said. ''So it would be odd for these poorer countries to help its development. In Eastern Europe, good management is as important as money.''
Hoping to keep ahead of the game, the Spanish Government is trying to stimulate local businessmen to look for sales and investment opportunities in Eastern Europe, with which is currently carries on only 3 percent of its trade, against 61 percent with the European Community.
Last month, Spain's ambassadors stationed in Eastern Europe were summoned to Madrid for a strategy meeting on increasing commerce with the region. ''At present, we buy more from and sell more to the Ivory Coast than East Germany,'' said Spain's Foreign Minister, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez.
 
A Successful Model
The most critical test for Spain, though, will be to remain attractive to foreign investors looking for new opportunities in Europe's less developed countries.
''We have one great advantage which is the quality of life here,'' Mr. Solbes said. ''You'd be surprised by how much foreign investment has been drawn to our Mediterranean coasts.''
Oddly, Spain may have helped create the challenge from Eastern Europe by serving as a model for both peaceful transition from dictatorship to democracy and successful economic modernization.
Until recently, democrats in Poland and Hungary even looked to Spain for guidance. Now they are looking to West Germany and France for resources.
