HEADLINE: Calling Himself a War Prisoner, Noriega Says U.S. Can't Try Him

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 26

 BODY:
In an effort to avoid prosecution in the United States, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega asserted today that he was a prisoner of war in this country, and his lawyers demanded that he be taken to a neutral country to stand trial.
General Noriega, the Panamanian dictator who surrendered to American authorities after United States troops invaded his country last month, made his claim in a brief letter to President Bush written in Spanish and delivered today to the White House.
Defense lawyers cited the letter in a motion in Federal District Court here, which declared that the United States judicial system had no jurisdiction over the General.
But Judge William M. Hoeveler said he could not consider the motion immediately and reminded the lawyers that General Noriega was here for a bond hearing. After prosecutors presented evidence of the general's ownership of homes, sports cars and credit cards that they said could represent assets of as much as $30 million, making him a risk to flee the country if free, Judge Hoeveler ordered that the defendant continue to be held without bond on drug-trafficking charges. 
People closely involved in the case said tonight that General Noriega would be moved in the next few days from his cell in the courthouse here to a more secure site at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, a Federal prison south of Miami. A specially built cell is being prepared for General Noriega, these people said. The move to a nearby prison is apparently a compromise between defense lawyers and Federal officials, who wanted to move the general to a prison out of state.
 
General Is Called a Danger
The prosecutors also argued that General Noriega would be a danger to the community because he is expert in counter-terrorism and covert actions and still has loyal armed followers. ''It's alleged that Mr. Noriega used torture and violence when it suited his purposes,'' said Myles H. Malman, the deputy prosecutor in the case. ''Mr. Noriega is an extraordinary danger to the community.''
In asserting that General Noriega was a prisoner of war, defense lawyers argued that provisions of the Geneva Convention should allow him to be tried by an international tribunal like the World Court. General Noriega was captured ''as a result of an illegal military invasion by the United States,'' the defense motion said, ''against the sovereignty of the Republic of Panama.''
The defense lawyers said the brief letter to Mr. Bush was intended to put him, as commander in chief of the military, on notice that General Noriega was a prisoner of war.
Frank A. Rubino, the chief lawyer for General Noriega, insisted in an interview that the idea to claim prisoner-of-war status was a recent one and not the result of any deal or plan opening the way for General Noriega's surrender.
''Did I set it up long ago and far away?'' Mr. Rubino asked. ''No.'' The lawyer said he thought seriously about the prisoner of war argument ''ever since I saw him surrender,'' saying: ''It's classic. It's classic.''
A few days before the invasion in December, the Panamanian National Assembly of Representatives declared the country to be in a state of war against the United States because of American economic sanctions. General Noriega had appointed the assembly in October.
Mr. Rubino said he was seeking high drama with the disclosure of the letter to Mr. Bush, which was sent to the White House by overnight mail Thursday night, and the motion filed with the court today. He could not hide his glee after the proceedings.
 
'Reject the Arguments'
''Tell me they weren't upstaged today,'' Mr. Rubino said. speaking of the prosecution, adding, ''That was pathetic.''
But Mr. Malman responded to the defense declaration that General Noriega was a prisoner of war by telling the court, ''We categorically reject the arguments and the status he seeks for himself.''
The letter, citing specific articles on the protection of prisoners of war and of war victims, read, ''I, General Manuel Antonio Noriega, pursuant to Article 4 A (1) (3) of the Genera Convention III of 12 August 1949, and the 1977 Geneva Protocol I, additional to the Geneva Convention, hereby claim prisoner-of-war status.''
 
White House Dismisses Claim
A spokesman for the White House, Roman Popadiuk, said: ''Our response to the Noriega letter will be made in the court proceedings. However, this request will not affect our ability to prosecute Noriega.''
Some legal authorities, surprised by the letter, said it was a novel tactic and added that they could not predict how it might affect the case.
The courtroom was full of theatrics, with lawyers on both sides seeking to dominate the proceedings and often sparring with one another.
In his opening address to the court, Mr. Malman criticized the defense lawyers for being too public, accusing them of seeking to try the case in the news media. ''We are here today to bring it back in the courtroom,'' he said.
Rather than respond to the prosecution's assertion that General Noriega was a risk to flee the country, Mr. Rubino said the court had no jurisdiction. At one point, he stood up and told the court: ''His name is Manuel Antonio Noriega. His rank is four-star general. His serial number is 001. Thank you.'' He then took his seat.
In the courtroom for the third time, General Noriega tried to look the role of a foreign leader. While in his last appearance, he wore a cotton shirt, he was dressed today in a tan open-necked uniform with the four stars of a general on the sleeves and dark pants. His lawyers addressed him as ''Prisoner of War General Manuel Antonio Noriega.'' Prosecutors called him ''Mr. Noriega.''
The former Panamaian dictator, who sat stone-faced at the previous court appearances, was more animated today, laughing with his lawyers before the proceedings began and also during the session. At one point he broke out in a big smile when he caught the eye of the fiancee of one of his lawyers, who was sitting in the front row among the spectators.
For the first time in a courtroom, the Government offered evidence today that prosecutors said showed General Noriega's vast wealth and connections to foreign leaders, who conceivably could offer him asylum.
As an example, Mr. Malman said the Government would show that General Noriega has a $400,000 condominium in Paris and that $5.8 million in cash was found by American authorities in envelopes marked ''confidential to my General'' at his ranch in Panama. Mr. Malman also said the Government had frozen $20 million in assets of General Noriega, mostly in Europe.
The prosecutor also said that as evidence of General Noriega's ties to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, ''We were told that Mr. Noriega was the recipient of his and her Qaddafi watches.'' He added, ''Mr. Qaddafi certainly is not prone to return Mr. Noriega to the United States.'' Mr. Malman also said the Government had recovered photographs that show General Noriega's close relationship with Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader.
The Government also introduced photocopies of credit cards with General Noriega's name, including American Express, Visa and Chase Manhattan.
Although he refused to participate in the bond hearing portion of the hearing today, Mr. Rubino said in the interview that he would still file motions with the court pending a response from Administration officials on the prisoner-of-war claim.
Authorities in international law have generally said there was no legal justification for the seizure of General Noriega for trial. But they agreed that that would make little difference as to whether the defendant can actually be tried in United States courts. In a string of cases, courts in this country have consistently refused to look into how a defendant was brought into this country to stand trial. By RICHARD L. BERKE MIAMI, Jan. 26 - In an effort to avoid prosecution in the United States, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega asserted today that he was a prisoner of war in this country, and his lawyers demanded that he be taken to a neutral country to stand trial.
General Noriega, the Panamanian dictator who surrendered to American authorities after United States troops invaded his country last month, made his claim in a brief letter to President Bush written in Spanish and delivered today to the White House.
Defense lawyers cited the letter in a motion in Federal District Court here, which asserted that the United States judicial system had no jurisdiction over the General.
But Judge William M. Hoeveler said he could not consider the motion immediately and reminded the lawyers that General Noriega was here for a bond hearing. After prosecutors presented evidence of the general's ownership of homes, sports cars and credit cards that they said could represent assets of as much as $30 million, making him a risk to flee the country if free, Judge Hoeveler ordered that the defendant continue to be held without bond on drug-trafficking charges.
People closely involved in the case said tonight that General Noriega would be moved in the next few days from his cell in the courthouse here to a more secure site at the Metropolican Correctional Center, a Federal prison south of Miami. A specially built cell is being prepared for General Noriega, these people said. This is an apparent compromise between defense lawyers and Federal officials, who wanted to move the general to a prison out of state.
 
General Is Called a Danger
The prosecutors also argued that General Noriega would be a danger to the community because he is expert in counter-terrorism and covert actions and still has loyal armed followers. ''It's alleged that Mr. Noriega used torture and violence when it suited his purposes,'' said Myles H. Malman, the deputy prosecutor in the case. ''Mr. Noriega is an extraordinary danger to the community.''
In asserting that General Noriega was a prisoner of war, defense lawyers argued that provisions of the Geneva Convention should allow him to be tried by an international tribunal like the World Court. General Noriega was captured as a result of an illegal military invasion, by the United States,'' the defense motion said, ''against the sovereignty of the Republic Panama.''
The defense lawyers said the brief letter to Mr. Bush was intended to put the Administration on notice that General Noriega was a prisoner of war.
 
'It's a Classic. It's a Classic'
Frank A. Rubino, the chief lawyer for General Noriega, insisted in an interview that the idea to claim prisoner-of-war status was a recent one and not the result of any deal or plan opening the way for General Noriega's surrender.
''Did I set it up long ago and far away?'' Mr. Rubino asked. ''No.'' The lawyer said he thought seriously about the prisoner of war argument ''ever since I saw him surrender,'' saying: ''It's classic. It's classic.''
A few days before the invasion in December, the Panamanian National Assembly of Representatives declared the country to be in a state of war against the United States because of American economic sanctions. General Noriega had appointed the assembly in October.
Mr. Rubino said he was seeking high drama with the disclosure of the letter to Mr. Bush, which was sent to the White House by overnight mail Thursday night, and the order filed with the court today. He could not hide his glee after the proceedings.
''Tell me they weren't upstaged today,'' Mr. Rubino said. speaking of the prosecution, adding, ''That was pathetic.''
But Mr. Malman responded to the defense declaration that General Noriega was a prisoner of war by telling the court, ''We categorically reject the arguments and the status he seeks for himself.''
The courtroom was full of theatrics, with lawyers on both sides seeking to dominate the proceedings and often sparring with one another.
In his opening addressss to the court, Mr. Malman criticized the defense lawyers for being too public, accusing them of seeking to try the case in the news media. ''We are here today to bring it back in the court room,'' he said.
Rather than respond to the prosecution's assertion that General Noriega was a risk to flee the country, Mr. Rubino said the court had no jurisdiction. At one point, he stood up and told the court: ''His name is Manuel Antonio Noriega. His rank is four-star general. His serial number is 001. Thank you.'' He then took his seat.
In the courtroom for the third time, General Noriega tried to look the role of a foreign leader. While in his last appearance, he wore a cotton shirt, he was dressed today in a tan open-necked uniform with the four stars of a general on the sleeves and dark pants. His lawyers addressed him as ''Prisoner of War General Manuel Antonio Noriega.'' Prosecutors called him, ''Mr. Noriega.''
The former Panamaian dictator, who sat stone-faced at the previous court appearances, was more animated today, laughing with his lawyers before the proceedings began and also during the session. At one point he broke out in a big smile when he caught the eye of the fiance of one of his lawyers, who was sitting in the front row among the spectators.
For the first time in a courtroom, the Government offered evidence today that prosecutors said showed General Noriega's vast wealth and connections to foreign leaders, who conceivably could offer him asylum.
As an example, Mr. Malman said the Government would show that General Noriega has a $400,000 condominium in Paris and that $5.8 million in cash was found by American authorities in envelopes marked ''confidential to my General'' at his ranch in Panama. Mr. Malman also said the Government had frozen $20 million in assets of General Noriega, mostly in Europe.
The proseuctor also said that as evidence of General Noriega's ties to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, ''we Were told that Mr. Noriega was the recipient of his and her Qaddafi watches.'' He added, ''Mr. Qaddafi certainly is not prone to return Mr. Noriega to the United States.'' Mr. Malman also said the Government has recovered photographs that show General Noriega's close relationship with Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader.
The Government also introduced photocopies of credit cards with General Noriega's name, including American Express, VISA and Chase Manhattan.
Although he refused to participate in the bond hearing portion of the hearing today, Mr. Rubino said in the interview that he would still file motions with the court pending a response from Administration officials on the prisoner-of-war claim.
''We can still proceed representing him,'' he said. ''This is a problem that has to be addressed now by the State Department.''
The lawyer said copies of General Noriega's letter had been sent to the Secretaries of State and Defense.
The authorities in international law have generally said there was no legal justification for the seizure of General Noriega for trial. But they agreed that that would make little difference as to whether the defendant can actually be tried in United States courts. In a string of cases, courts in this country have consistently refused to look into how a defendant was brought into this country to stand trial.

PUB-DATE: January 27, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 4146 words

HEADLINE: THE 1991 BUDGET: Excerpts from Darman;
Darman Conducts a Tour of Wonderland: The Federal Budget

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Here are excerpts from an unpublished version of the introduction to President Bush's budget written by Richard G. Darman, head of the Office of Management and Budget, using his own chapter headings.
 
Green Eyeshades And the Cookie Monster
If anything were meant for viewing through proverbial green eyeshades, it would seem to be the Federal budget. The typeface is small. The text is tedious. Tables are seemingly endless. 
The sheer size of the budget makes it seem like a monster. It contains almost 190,000 accounts. At the rate of one per minute, eight hours per day, it would take over a year to reflect upon these. The budget's annual outlays are larger than all countries' economies except those of the United States, Japan and the Soviet Union. (The Federal budget is roughly the size of the entire West German economy.) Clearly, at some point, green eyeshades must be put aside. Detail must be considered, but the capacity to abstract should not be lost.
Of course, with or without green eyeshades, monsters do not naturally invite examination. Still, if a monster is present, one might address certain threshold questions: Is it threatening or potentially helpful, and how is one to tell? The answers are not always as obvious as the questions.
On ''Sesame Street,'' the children's educational television program, there is a wonderful character known as Cookie Monster. As all monsters are, Cookie Monster is initially intimidating. His manner is gruff. His clumsiness occasionally causes damage.
But quickly, Cookie Monster comes to be seen as benign - indeed, downright friendly. He has a few bad habits. He cannot resist gobbling up anything and everything that might be consumed, especially cookies. And he cannot quite control the way he spews forth crumbs. He is the quintessential consumer. Yet clearly, he means no harm.
The budget, for all its intimidating detail, might be seen similarly: as the Ultimate Cookie Monster. Its excessive tendencies toward consumption are not exactly ennobling. (It does not ordinarily present itself as seriously concerned with investment.) But at the same time, its underlying motivation is clearly not malevolent. What harm it may cause is largely unintended. Its massive presence might be understood as little more than a compilation of cookies received, cookies crumbled, and crumbs spewed forth.
Yet, apt though the Cookie Monster perspective may be, it does not suffice. It is not quite fair to either Cookie Monster or the budget. In reality, a budget is not just a monstrous mass of cookies and crumbs. It is more: an implicit statement of values and expectations for the future. Inescapably, it is headed somewhere - or other. To gain a meaningful sense of the whole, and where it may be headed, one must look beyond green eyeshades and the Cookie Monster. One must frame the budget from several broader (and more serious) perspectives. . . .
 
And the Wall Came A-tumblin' Down . . .
Looking a bit beyond Cookie Monster to the television news, one is struck with a rare impression: there may be a compelling pattern to the flow of current events. It is not represented in the budget detail by any quantitative ''baseline,'' nor any conventional statistical measure. It was captured visually by a single dramatic symbol, beamed around the world and etched in the mind of people everywhere: the fall of the Berlin wall.
To put the symbolic fact more clinically: State-centered, command-and-control systems seem to be decomposing. The Soviet Union has been forced to explore the virtues of restructuring, decentralization, and openness. Communist regimes in Eastern Europe have been falling like dominoes. The Iron Curtain has been opened. And the drama has not been confined to Eastern Europe. Just as liberated celebrants have cheered the opening of the Berlin wall and the decline of Communist dictators, so, too, have liberated Panamanians celebrated the fall of the dictator in nearby Panama.
While it would be naively euphoric to consider this pattern ''the end of history'' (even in the limited Hegelian sense), clearly the sudden and dramatic shift toward pluralist democracy has far more than the ordinary historical significance. The events of 1989 and what they will have unleashed may one day rise to the place with those of 1688, 1776, or 1789. This is not small stuff. It is another giant leap of the human spirit yearning to breathe free.
Yet this great historical shift has been almost trivialized in its translation into public debate about the budget. The issue has been framed as: ''How big is the 'peace dividend'?'' - and, in effect, ''How can I get mine?'' These are issues that the budget and the political system must treat. They are discussed further in the budget. But they are second-order issues at best.
Ahead of them in line, surely, ought to be these points:
* The favorable pattern of recent events has not been caused exclusively by the political and economic bankruptcy of particular state-centered regimes. It has also resulted from U.S. (and allied) military and economic strength. These, in turn, have resulted form market-oriented economic policies and sound public and private investment policies. It would be a highly unfortunate irony if - just as the world were affirming more market-oriented and investment-oriented principles - the United States were to do anything other than strengthen its commitment to these very principles.
* As the world moves away from an emphasis on the risk of traditional military superpower conflict, the relative importance of U.S. economic strength only increases. Increased economic strength is essential to inspire and to assist evolving lesser powers. And it is fundamental to success in the global competition with rising economic superpowers.
* Thus there is a first-order issue for the budget (and the economic policy it represents): How can it best preserve and build on America's strengths, while advancing the American economy toward even greater capacities for leadership and growth? If the ''dividend'' metaphor must be applied to the budget: How can policy best assure that there is a continuing growth dividend?
 
How Big Is the Deficit? Let Me Count the Ways
In considering this issue, many traditional analysts turn first to the size of the budget deficit. This is not necessarily as relevant a starting point as many argue. But it is relevant. Unfortunately, a meaningful answer to the question, How big is the deficit? is not quite as simple as the question. This budget attempts to answer the question from a wide range of relevant perspectives. . . .
The Treatment of Social Security. Current law defines Social Security as ''off-budget,'' but requires its inclusion for purposes of G-R-H deficit calculations. Social Security is also included in traditional ''consolidated'' or ''unified'' deficit estimates. There are many good and important reasons to continue to include Social Security in these calculations.
But in recent years a problem has arisen. The increasing annual Social Security operating surpluses have masked the true size of the underlying non-Social Security operating deficit. In effect, the surpluses have allowed more non-Social Security spending than might otherwise have been the case. If this were long to continue, it would result in an excessive burden of debt for future generations. It would thus undermine the effect of the buildup of reserves intended for retiring baby-boomers.
To address this problem, without doing violence to the traditional concept of a consolidated budget, the Administration proposes to establish a ''Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund.'' It would receive each year, as outlays, an amount equivalent to an increasing portion of the projected Social Security operating surplus (reaching 100 percent in 1996). It would be obliged to use these outlays to reduce Federal debt and thus leave a more manageable financing burden for future generations. This Fund would be linked with a continuing obligation to meet a Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit target of zero (i.e., a permanent balanced budget) starting in 1993. Thus, the proposal would effectively prevent the Government from spending Social Security receipts on non-Social Security purposes. . . .
Alternative Economic Scenarios. In considering the deficit - by whatever definition - it is important to consider its sensitivity to economic variables. . . . The single most important variable affecting the size of the deficit is probably the real economic growth rate. As a practical matter, the net deficit-reducing effects of economic growth (or its absence) are likely to be far greater than the effects of a so called peace dividend. . . .
The Administration first presented its own economic assumptions in July 1989, at which point they were also judged to be at the optimistic end of the credible range. Intervening performance has, in fact, been highly consistent with the Administration's forecast. But that does not mean either that macroeconomic science has improved substantially, or that the Administration will always be so fortunate as to be correct.
In developing the budget, the Administration formally considered several alternative economic scenarios. . . .
Deficit Effects of Capital Budgets. The current budget concept - essentially a ''cash'' budget - was developed to conform with the President's Commission on Budget Concepts (1967). The ''cash'' perspective is especially useful for determining needs for financing in the public debt market. Indeed, it is essential. . . .
Some have argued that the Federal Government should adopt one form or another of capital budget and/or a budget that better distinguishes between trust funds, governmental operating needs and activities conducted by Government-sponsored enterprises. . . .
While these additional perspectives are useful, it is clear that they too are not fully satisfactory. . . . They necessarily suggest, but do not satisfactorily settle, many difficult issues of definition as to what is and is not investment. They do not adequately treat ''intellectual capital'' and ''human capital,'' for example. And they do not provide a dynamic picture of expected future liabilities and future returns.
Stepping back from this surfeit of deficits - all differently conceived and defined -one might summarize where the collection of different deficit pictures suggests things may be, and where they may be headed.
First, by several different deficit measures, the consolidated Federal deficit seems at worst to have stabilized. If the President's policies were adopted, this pattern of stabilization would obtain, in the near term, even if Social Security were excluded from deficit calculation. The pattern of continuous erosion that characterized the early and mid-1980's seems to have been broken. By many measures, the deficit is headed toward improvement - assuming that economic growth continues. . . .
There is reason to suggest that the traditional notion of the inevitability of a tight business cycle may be overtaken. But, to underline the obvious: Growth is not automatic. It depends on growth-oriented policies being pursued not only by the Administrationbut also by Congress and the Federal Reserve.
But, second, stabilization of the underlying deficit should not lead to complacency. Complacency would lead to a loss of fiscal discipline. And even with stabilization, deficits mean rising debt. America's recorded Federal debt is already approaching three trillion dollars. . . . That is not necessarily bad per se. It depends on whether or not the debt is being used in conjunction with policies that will increase future productivity, growth, and capacities for debt service - and whether future hidden liabilities are being kept within reasonable bounds. Here, unfortunately, is where conventional Federal deficit accounting and budget presentation have been woefully inadequate. And here is where there is legitimate cause for concern. . . .
 
Hidden Pac-Men
The problem with relying solely on the consolidated cash budget - or even on that plus a capital budget - is that it does not give a full picture of the Federal ''balance sheet.'' . . .
One curious thing about future Federal liabilities is that many of them are not yet fully visible. There particular nature varies. But each is like a hidden Pac-Man, waiting to spring forward and consume another line of resource dots in the budget maze. . . . A few introductory points may help outline the problem:
Rising Costs of Health Care. A quarter of a century ago, health care expenditures consumed about 6 percent of America's gross national product. Now, that share has almost doubled, to 12 percent. . . . There are, nonetheless, increasing demands to assure health insurance coverage for those not now covered, and to provide better financing for long term care. Each of these could entail an additional multi-billion dollar annual bill. Yet the projected health expenditure obligations of current law are not fully covered by projected future receipts. The estimated present value of unfunded liabilities (the actuarial deficiency) for Medicare hospital insurance alone would be over $250 billion. . . .
Rising Claims of Mandatory Programs. In President Kennedy's Administration transfer payments to individuals comprised about a quarter of the Federal budget. Now they consume almost half. . . . (Mandatory programs plus net interest expenditures account for almost 62 percent of the budget.) Since these programs generally have broad-based and well-represented beneficiary populations, they tend to have a powerful claim on resources and grow faster than the economy as a whole. Yet again: It would seem obvious that this pattern of more rapid growth cannot be extended indefinitely. . . .
Unfunded Retirement Program Liabilities. There is much talk about the projected build-up-of-Social-Security-reserves to cover the anticipated obligations to the baby-boom generation when it reaches retirement. . . . This is a speculative matter with a high degree of uncertainty. . . . Somewhat less speculatively, there are clearly identifiable major shortfalls in unfunded Federal employee retirement programs - although these should be able to be serviced by future contributions. . . .
Obligations to Clean Up Federal Facilities. For a variety of reasons, the Federal Government historically has not been prompt in attending to environmental cleanup at many of its facilities. For reasons of both law and policy, the pattern of the past is now changing. But the bills are yet to be fully paid. The present-value cost of already-identified future clean-up obligations and waste management improvements at Federal facilities over the next 30 years is on the order of $140-200 billion. . . .
Contingent Risks of Federal Credit Programs and Government-Sponsored Enterprises. The Federal Government's direct and indirect credit subsidies are far more extensive than is commonly appreciated. . . . The purposes of all this credit support are generally worthy. But there can be no denying that there is an enormous and increasing Federal exposure - approaching one trillion dollars in direct and federally guaranteed loans alone. This necessarily involves a risk of substantial future claims against the government. These claims are virtually certain to be in the tens of billions of dollars. Without continued economic growth, and the credit reforms proposed by the President, the claims would be substantially higher. . . .
Contingent Risks of Federal Insurance Programs. . . . These formal insurance programs cover bank deposits, pensions, veterans life insurance, crops, floods, overseas private investment, nuclear risks, and war risks. The total face value of this insurance coverage (excluding Medicare) exceeds four trillion dollars. . . . The likely future claims are virtually certain to be in the tens of billions of dollars. . . .
But it is important to put this, too, in perspective. The claims do not come due all at once. Indeed, they come due over an extended period of time. If one assumed that the likely range of unfunded claims were spread smoothly over the extensive time period in which they are to come due, one would reduce the total to a much less intimidating - indeed, a manageable - level.
This is not to say that there is not a built-in shortfall. There is. It is to say, rather, that the ''amortized' annual amount of the projected shortfall may be on the order of one-half to one percent of G.N.P., assuming the problem is managed on an orderly basis.
Over the long term, there are five ways this shortfall could be handled:
* By reducing the growth of future obligations - through ''mandatory'' program reforms, credit reforms, and insurance reforms;
* By reducing spending on other Federal programs where returns on investment are judged to be of lower relative value;
* By increasing the government's managerial integrity and efficiency
* By pursuing growth-oriented economic and budgetary policies - investing in the future - so that future economic productivity and Federal receipts are higher than otherwise projected;
* By increasing the relative burden of debt and/or new taxes (these latter approaches are not a part of the President's program).
 
Investing in the Future
As noted, ''Investing in the Future'' is a theme given special emphasis in the Budget Overview. It was first introduced to the presentation of the budget by the President, last year, in Building a Better America.
The emphasis is consistent with three fundamental points: First, a budget must be viewed as more than a static snapshot; it necessarily influences the future, and the nature of that influence must be examined. Second, there is a generally accepted moral obligation to try to leave future generations in a better position than their predecessors. Third, the obligations for future expenditures and debt service are more manageable insofar as current expenditures and tax policy contribute to increased growth. Together, these three points argue compellingly for attention to the extent to which a budget (and its associated economic policy) encourage investment - investment in the future.
The President's budget encourages investment in a host of ways.
 
Wonderland Revisited - The Current Congressional Path
In the presentation of the first Bush Administration budget, a critique of ''Wonderland'' budgeting was offered. It focused on the curious Washington habit (indeed, legal requirement) of ''current services baseline'' budgeting. Under this system, a ''cut'' may really be an increase; and a deficit said to be going ''down'' may really be going up. With ''current services'' built-in bias toward increasing expenditures, it should be little wonder that the system has failed to bring the deficit under satisfactory control.
In the mid-session review of the budget, O.M.B. introduced a new budget projection; the ''Current Congressional Path.'' This was done in order to underline what some might think an obvious point. That is, the deficit is not determined, in the end, by either ''current services'' projections or by mathematical extensions of a ''President's Policy.'' Forecasts based on such projections are almost always bound to be wrong. Budgets are legislated Congressional action (or inaction) is, therefore, a fundamental determinant of actual deficits. In trying to forecast realistically, it is important to have some sense of the ''Current Congressional Path.''
Unfortunately, however, the Current Congressional Path is not entirely clear. Indeed, Wonderland seems to be running wild with attractive fantasies, but without yet having established coherent direction. One might consider, for example, the two big games now in play - and a third that is soon to be:
 
The Spend-the-Peace-Dividend Game. This is a new game, premised on the assumption of a substantial, near-term ''peace dividend.'' Then each player plans to spend the dividend in his or her preferred way. The sum of all such planned expenditures totals about ten times the over-estimated dividend, which is itself perhaps five times the actual dividend. Thus, Washington entertains the notion of spending fifty times a dividend that has not yet definitively materialized - a true Wonderland phenomenon.
In reality, the near-term peace dividend is likely to be smaller than is commonly assumed for three reasons: First, the true cost of the previously planned and Congressionally approved defense program is substantially higher than the current D.O.D. funding levels (and higher than ''current services''). Much of the dividend will have to be used just to adjust the previous program downward toward current levels. Second, this adjustment - while politically popular in the abstract -will not be politically popular in all its particulars. Third, any tendency to cut further would likely focus on reducing U.S. troop strength abroad at a more rapid rate than proposed by the President - a more rapid rate than consistent with preserving a strong alliance and negotiating equitable and enforceable agreements with the Soviet Union. Presumably, these countervailing interests will be better appreciated as the debate about the ''peace dividend'' unfolds.
The Cut-Social-Security Game. This is ordinarily a very dangerous game politically. But in its most recent form, it has started with a superficially attractive proposal: to cut Social Security taxes. Clearly, that would be desirable if it could be done without significant cost to the people paying the taxes and to the economy as a whole. Unfortunately, the most recent proposal to attract significant attention fails that test.
It is ironic in three respects. First, some of its advocates have argued, until recently that the Government was underfinanced (and undertaxed) not overfinanced. Yet few, in fact, can seriously argue that the Government as a whole is overfinanced. Second, the emerging conventional wisdom had been that one needed to do more to protect the capacity to pay future Social Security benefits, not less.
Cutting Social Security taxes now would mean giving up on that objective - giving up on the bipartisan commitment to build up reserves for the future retirement needs of the baby boom generation. Third, and perhaps most telling. Cutting Social Security taxes now would likely hurt the very people it is ostensibly intended to benefit today's workers. I would either force an increase in their non-Social Security taxes (to compensate for the enormous revenue loss $55 billion in 1991 alone or it would force a reduction in their future retirement benefits. . . .
The President's proposal to establish a ''Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund'' is a responsible way to protect the future interests of today's workers. But Social Security is a notoriously volatile subject when it enters the political domain; and whether rationality will prevail remains to be determined.
The Beat-the-Budget Game. This is the game that begins with the reaction to the President's budget. It has become an annual ritual. At the start, it is predictably partisan. Priorities are judged to be incorrect. Economic assumptions are ridiculed (but later adopted). Gimmicks are scorned (but later outdone). The failure of the budget process is lamented (but ideas for evasion proliferate). The refusal to raise ''new taxes'' is condemned (as proposals to cut taxes are advanced). Incentives for savings and investment are criticized for their alleged adverse effects on the deficit (as alternative proposals to increase the deficit are advocated). Stalemates are followed by ''heroic compromises'' that earn the parties self-congratulation, but somehow manage to leave much of the serious job to the future. And the public, understandably grows more skeptical.
It may be apt to view all this metaphorically as a set of children's games; the Budget as Cookie Monster; its future threatened by hidden Pac-Men; its path a journey through Wonderland. But at some point, it is appropriate to put games aside - at least for a while. At some point, there is an obligation to be serious. At some point, partisan posturing must yield to the responsibility to govern. Sooner or later, the American political system will rise to the responsibility to be serious; to complete the job of fiscal policy correction. It may do this in small steps or large. It cannot do it with sidesteps. This year's budget meets the responsibility to be serious. . . . This, of course, is not to assert that the budget will be treated seriously in the very next Beat-the-Budget Game. It is simply to suggest that it should be.

Darman, the budget director, whose introductory essay lectures Congress about its ''responsibility to be serious.'' (The New York Times/Paul Hosefros)

HEADLINE: The 1991 Budget: Military;
Lawmakers Scurrying To Protect Home Bases

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
D-day in the battle of the military budget came to Congress three days early as lawmakers mobilized today to protect bases in their districts that are among scores of candidates that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is considering for closure.
The news of possible base closings, always an alarming prospect for lawmakers whose districts benefit from the jobs and income they create, prompted a Congressman from Philadelphia to call a news conference at the gates of a shipyard that is on the list.
Republican legislators called the White House to complain, and members of Congress of both parties predicted a huge fight over which bases would actually be closed. ''So far, there are two questions asked,'' said one White House official. ''Is it true? And is there anything in my district?'' 
The Congressional anxiety over even the suggestion that some bases might be closed points up the paradox of the current fervor to cut military spending. While legislators are eager to spend what is sometimes called ''the peace dividend,'' it is another thing to find the money being taken from their home districts.
The list, which will be released on Monday, includes the possible closing of the Army base at Fort Ord, Calif., and Navy bases in the San Francisco Bay area as well as the Philadelphia Navy Yard. Among the bases and units being considered for extensive cutbacks are the Army National Guard's 42d Infantry Division in New York City and the Army base at Fort Hood, Tex.
While Bush Administration officials briefed members of Congress today on possible base closings, others were in West Europe telling leaders of allied countries about proposals for shutting down bases overseas.
 
Fighting Civilians' Decisions
Aides to the military service chiefs circulated through the corridors of the Capitol working against other cuts -these in jealously guarded weapons programs - that will be included in the Administration's military budget for the fiscal year 1991.
This leaves the military arguing against decisions made by their civilian bosses, a common practice that is likely to increase as military budgets get tighter. The practice enrages Mr. Cheney, who dressed down the Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Larry D. Welch, last year after the general's involvement in a delicate political negotiation on Capitol Hill was disclosed.
Mr. Cheney will present the Pentagon budget on Monday, but it is still not clear how much detail the budget will provide on President Bush's long-range objectives for the United States military at a time when the threat of Soviet power is receding.
The budget will be accompanied by the list of bases, which Mr. Cheney was personally reviewing today and could revise over the weekend as he consults with his staff and members of Congress, officials said.
Mr. Bush has promised that the new budget will reflect the beginning of the transition to ''a new strategy,'' but Mr. Cheney told reporters at a Pentagon luncheon today that the document would not propose fundamental changes. ''I don't think you need a new strategy,'' he said. ''I think you need some adjustments, some changes, but the overall strategic framework that we pursued for 40 years is basically sound.''
Still, Mr. Cheney said the 1991 budget will start the process of scaling back the military after the $2 trillion buildup under President Ronald Reagan.
For the first time, the Pentagon will propose an actual cut in military spending after accounting for inflation. That proposal will be for a decline of 2 percent, to $303.3 billion, Congressional officials said today. That includes $11.2 billion that will be spent by the Department of Energy on nuclear weapons production and the environmental cleanup of the weapons production plants.
Mr. Cheney would not discuss specific budget figures before his formal announcement Monday. But he said he was leaving the Pentagon's strategic programs largely intact, including plans to develop two mobile nuclear missiles.
The Administration, he said, was seeking a 20 percent increase in the budget for development of the ''Star Wars'' anti-missile shield. Other Administration officials said the 1991 proposal for the program would be $4.8 billion, up from $3.8 billion last year.
Development of the B-2 Stealth bomber is under review, Mr. Cheney said. Administration officials said the Pentagon would ask for five of the airplanes in 1991, but the overall program, which is under intense pressure in Congress because of its expected cost of $71 billion, is likely to be slowed or cut back.
The most significant cuts envisioned by the Administration are expected to come in non-nuclear weaponry and personnel. Mr. Cheney said today that if current military and political trends continue, he expects the Army's 28 divisions to be reduced to 23 and the 36 Air Force wings to be cut to 31.
There also will be ''significant reductions'' in the Navy, Mr. Cheney said. Those are expected to start with the retirement of two of the four battleships, but Mr. Cheney said he was not recommending a reduction in the Navy's 14 aircraft carrier battle groups.
Mr. Cheney's plans to make significant cuts in military bases were applauded by Representative John R. Kasich, a conservative Republican from Ohio who was a staunch defender of the Reagan buildup. He criticized members of Congress who oppose closing military bases. ''Everyone on Capitol Hill preaches that we don't have a World War II threat and we don't need this World War II military,'' he said. ''Fine, but that means you don't need all the troops and you don't need all the bases.''
Mr. Cheney's unorthodox methods stirred a great deal of anxiety on Capitol Hill. Normally, possible base closings are not made public until the last minute or political cover is given, as it was last year, when Congress approved closing or cutting back 86 other military installations, but only after the names were chosen by an independent commission.
''This is kind of crazy,'' said Representative G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery, a Mississippi Democrat with close ties to the White House. ''The Secretary hasn't even signed off on the list and it's just getting everybody stirred up, but maybe that's what they want to do.''
Representative Thomas M. Foglietta, Democrat of Pennsylvania, scrambled to protect the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard, which is in his district. He held a news conference in Washington, made an emergency call to Mr. Cheney, and then made another appearance at the shipyard.
''We realize that there are going to have to be cuts,'' Mr. Foglietta said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, whose list of possible base closings spurred lawmakers to protect bases in their districts. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: The Price of Fudging on S & L's

 BODY:
The savings and loan troubles became a crisis because Washington dawdled. Losses at just one thrift, California's big Lincoln Savings and Loan, topped $2 billion because regulators dawdled. Even after President Bush proposed remedial legislation, hundreds of insolvent S & L's bled needlessly last year while Congress dawdled some more. The bill is law now, but the cost continues to climb, this time because of Administration dawdling. 
The immediate issue is working capital - temporary funding until the Government sells the assets of bankrupt thrifts it bails out. Officials hinted to Congress this week that they will also seek additional permanent funding, but not until after the November elections. Meanwhile, as much as $100 billion in working capital may be needed.
These added billions will be paid out to depositors of bankrupt thrifts, and will be at least partially recouped some day. But until then, the Government must borrow the money. The political appearances of that borrowing, no matter how sensible and temporary, scare the socks off the Administration.
The fears were evident in the brouhaha last fall over putting the original $50 billion on-budget or off-budget. The Administration still wants desperately to look as though it is reducing the deficit without raising taxes. Thus, it prefers off-budget financing that isn't counted in official totals.
Congress balked last year. The Democrats weren't interested in burnishing President Bush's fiscal image. In the end they compromised, but key members insisted that future funding be on-budget. The Administration agreed to do nothing without their approval, and promised a plan by Jan. 15. It missed the deadline. Then, regulators outlined three plans - one on-budget and the other two off.
The on-budget scheme is clearly preferable. The Treasury's Federal Financing Bank would borrow the money and lend it to the Resolution Trust Corporation, the bailout manager. That's honest budgeting. It's also cheaper than the other two approaches because interest rates are lower when the Government borrows directly.
More weeks will pass before it's decided which way to go. Meanwhile, on Monday Mr. Bush will submit a fiscal 1991 budget that conveniently omits these billions, thus ducking the embarrassment of a deficit that isn't shrinking as much as he pretends.
Dawdling jacked up the cost of this crisis. Further dawdling threatens more of the same.

HEADLINE: Alternate Energy Sources Can Be Economical

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Northeast pipeline, proposed and scheduled, is a classic example of dealing with the symptom, not the problem (''In Northeast, a Battle Over Fuel,'' Business Day, Jan. 8). The pipeline, and the natural gas it will carry, provides only a temporary fix for the near future. 
As the demand for energy increases, the supply dwindles. One needs no degree in economics to know what happens to the price and availability of a limited resource when a handful of people control it and everyone wants it. Nor is natural gas the environmental messiah of electricity production. Compared with oil and coal it is relatively clean burning, but for every 1,000 megajoules received, 18 kilograms (39.6 pounds) of natural gas produce 50 kilograms (110 pounds) of carbon dioxide.
The long-term, cost-effective solution lies in substitution. For example, there is financially viable technology available today for solar hot water producton. With this technology, a family of four with average hot water use could purchase this system and realize total payback within five years. That's at current energy costs. With a 20-year life cycle, the return on investment is outstanding, without including any environmental benefits.
 
JAMES C. VANCE
President, Alternate Energy Group
 Butler, N.J., Jan. 11, 1990

HEADLINE: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 52;
A Respected Air Carrier Based in a Troubled Land

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Since its founding in 1919 by a group of former World War I flying aces from Germany, Avianca, the Colombian national airline, has been the object of international intrigue and a target of political violence. But it has maintained a respectable safety record throughout, aviation experts said yesterday.
In the late 30's the United States Government fretted that Nazi agents might be planning to use Avianca planes to bomb the Panama Canal and persuaded the Colombian Government to force out German investors and pilots.
A half-century later, large quantities of cocaine have repeatedly been found aboard Avianca planes, prompting renewed friction with the United States. And in the last several years, Avianca executives and aircraft have come under increased attack in the violent Colombian drug wars. 
A bomb destroyed an Avianca Boeing 727 shortly after takeoff from Medellin in November, killing 110 people in an attack widely attributed to drug lords seeking to kill police informers on the flight. A Boeing 747 belonging to Avianca crashed in 1983 about 15 minutes before it was scheduled to land at Barajas Airport in Madrid, killing 183 people.
 
Lauded by Experts
Yet Colombia's flag carrier retains a strong reputation for competency among airline experts. For 70 years, its pilots have made fairly few mistakes while flying in a mountainous country that often allows little room for error, said Daniel P. Hagedorn, a librarian specializing in Latin American aviation at the National Air and Space Museum in Washington.
Avianca, whose name stands for Aerovias Nacionales de Colombia S.A., does a good job of maintaining its equipment and has very competent maintenance executives, said William Worsham, president and chief operating officer of Greenwich Air Services Inc., an aircraft and engine-maintenance company in Miami. ''The people I know from Avianca are first-rate people,'' he said, adding that the Avianca jet engines his company had serviced ''were in good shape.''
Drug traffickers and money launderers have periodically tried to smuggle cocaine and large sums of money aboard Avianca flights. An Avianca Boeing 747 was briefly impounded in 1988 by the Customs Service after the discovery of 422 pounds of cocaine. In 1986, gunmen on a speeding motorcycle shot to death the security chief of the line two days after he had led an operation that found $5 million of cocaine on an Avianca cargo jet bound for Miami.
 
Headquarters in Bogota
Avianca has paid $500,000 in drug-related fines, said William G. Bell, a partner in a law firm in Miami, Holland & Knight. Mr. Bell is the outside counsel for Avianca for most of its litigation here. The company headquarters is in Bogota, and its stock is traded on the Bogota Exchange. Avianca has an extensive routes across South America, North America and Europe, with flights from Bogota to London, Paris, Frankfurt, Madrid, Miami and Los Angeles, as well as New York.
The line is insured through underwriters in London, Mr. Bell said. He declined to discuss the coverage, but said it was adequate to pay for suits that might result from the crash of Flight 52. ''They have a lot of insurance,'' he added.
Avianca lost money heavily in the mid-80's during the economic downturn in Latin America, but turned around after a series of management changes. The company posted a profit of $5.3 million on sales of $305.5 million in 1988, according to figures published by the International Air Transport Association in Montreal.
Avianca officials in Miami and Bogota did not return telephone calls yesterday about the finances.
The crash is unlikely to have a long-term impact on Avianca ticket sales, because bilateral treaties signed by the Colombian Government guarantee the line a large share of international flights to Colombia, said George W. James, president of Airline Economics, a consulting business in Washington.
He compared the effect of the crash to an increase in taxicab fares. ''People tend to boycott it for a while,'' Mr. James said. ''But after a while, they realize that's the game in town, and they go back to using it.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 27, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 President Bush is preparing to send Congress a $1.2 trillion budget that envisions a dramatic decline in the Federal deficit to roughly half its level in the current fiscal year. [Page 1.] Federal regulators said they would file an administrative action accusing President Bush's son Neil of conflicts of interest while he was a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. The Denver-based institution collapsed in 1988. The regulators' action is certain to embarrass the White House in view of the expensive bailout of the savings and loan industry. [1.] The nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 0.5 percent in the final three months of 1989, the weakest economic performance since spring 1986, but many analysts said the country is likely to be able to avoid a recession. Spending by consumers declined slightly, and only continued production of cars and other goods that ended up unsold kept the overall gross national product from shrinking. [35.] Orders to factories for durable goods, those expected to last more than three years, rose 2.5 percent in December. [36.] President Bush has decided to give Carla A. Hills, the U.S. Trade Representative, the lead role in negotiating a new trade treaty with the Soviet Union, rather than Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher. The decision caps weeks of fighting by the two Cabinet agencies, each eager to enlarge turf as the United States fulfills a pledge at the Malta summit to complete a trade agreement with Moscow by June. [35.]
 
 
 
Companies
 Eastern Airlines proposed a reorganization plan that would give unsecured creditors less than 50 cents on the dollar. The creditors, mainly banks and aircraft manufacturers, were said to be unhappy with the proposal. [35.] The Bank of New England has begun borrowing from the Federal Reserve. The Boston bank, which has to borrow to make up for the loss of large uninsured deposits, is believed to account for almost all of the $478 million lent by the Boston Fed. [47.] Texas Instruments said its fourth-quarter earnings fell 62.3 percent as sales of computer chips slowed and prices declined sharply in the period. The company also said it could report a loss in the current quarter. [37.] Rosewood Financial, the investment concern controlled by Caroline Rose Hunt, made a bid for First Executive. [36.] General Electric will join an investor from Salt Lake City in his effort to acquire Aristech Chemical. [37.] Nissan will invest $25 million in a project to make engines for a mini-van that will be built by Nissan with Ford. [37.] 20th Century Fox's request to the F.C.C. to change the rules that prevent television networks from having a financial interest in the programs they broadcast, has provoked an angry reaction from Hollywood movie studios. [36.]
 
 
 
Markets
 The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 1.81 points, to 2,559.23, continuing its decline. The average was down 118.67 for the week and 251 below the high set at the start of the year. [35.] Treasury bond prices fell to their lowest level since June 1 as investors anticipated further declines. [42.] The dollar fell against the pound and the yen, but rose against most other currencies. [43.] Gasoline futures prices rose sharply, leading the whole energy group to a higher close. [43.]

HEADLINE: Carla Hills to Lead Soviet Trade Talks

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
In a setback for Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, President Bush has decided to give the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, the lead role in negotiating a new trade treaty with the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today.
The decision caps weeks of fighting by the two Cabinet agencies, each eager to enlarge its area of influence as the United States fulfills a pledge made at the Malta summit meeting to complete a trade agreement with Moscow by June.
In terms of ideology, there is no particular difference between the officials, but the decision puts the trade representative at center stage in one of the hottest trade issues of the next few months.
There was no formal announcement, but an official who asked not to be identified said that despite the long personal friendship between Mr. Bush and Mr. Mosbacher, both former Texas oilmen, the President chose Mrs. Hills because he felt the United States would be better served by an experienced trade negotiator. 
''U.S.T.R. will drive a harder bargain with the Soviets,'' this official commented.
 
The Effect in Congress
 Sarah C. Carey, a partner in the law firm of Heron Burchette Ruckert & Rothwell, who closely monitors Soviet trade issues, said, ''It's a real plus for the U.S.T.R. to be taking the lead.''
In deciding in Mrs. Hills's favor, the President gave oversight to the Trade Policy Review Group, an interagency coordinating group led by the trade office. Commerce, Treasury, State, the Office of Management and Budget and Defense are among other agencies that sit on this committee.
The President's decision is likely to be popular in Congress, which gave added powers to the trade representative in 1988.
The agency is a coordinator of trade policy in the executive branch and a trade negotiator, points that Mrs. Hills made in her effort to win the job, officials said.
In the past other agencies, like the Treasury and the State Department, have encroached on the trade representative's negotiating functions.
Mrs. Hills, a former trade lawyer, already has a broad agenda as the Government's leading person for the Uruguay Round of international trade negotiations and for coordinating trade policies toward Europe and Japan.
 
Mosbacher's Case
 To support his case, Mr. Mosbacher, officials said, cited the expertise his department has built up both in promoting nonstrategic Soviet trade and in managing the export controls that deny the Soviets high technology that could be militarily useful.
The last time the United States and the Soviet Union sat down to write a trade agreement, in 1972, 1973 and 1974, the Commerce Department ran the show under Peter G. Peterson, now an investment banker.
Moscow stopped that pact after Congress passed the Jackson-Vanik Amendment to the Trade Act of 1974, which links trade concessions by the United States to human-rights progress by the Soviets.
Another argument advanced by Commerce was that it represents the United States on the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Joint Commercial Commission, a body set up in 1972 to foster trade links between the two countries.
Mr. Mosbacher, who met with his Soviet counterpart on the commission, Konstantin F. Katushev, in November in Washington, wanted the negotiations to be conducted in the framework of the commission.
Commerce is a huge, venerable, conglomerate agency employing more than 35,000 people. Besides promoting trade, it manages the weather forecasting service, prepares economic statistics and runs the patent and trademark office, among many other functions.
 
Cooperation Is Emphasized
 On the other hand, the trade representative's office is one of the smallest agencies, with a staff of about 135. It was formed in 1962. It has not had much of a role in East-West trade, although in recent years it has led in negotiations with the Soviets to write a long-term grain agreement.
Officials of both the trade office and the Commerce Department played down the empire-building aspects of their struggle over the issue.
''We're a team,'' Mrs. Hills said. ''We have worked and will continue to work hand in glove with Bob Mosbacher and his staff in this and in all matters. They are as essential to this process as U.S.T.R.''
She maintained that all the President had done was to continue interagency cooperation.
Marion Blakey, an aide to Mr. Mosbacher, said the trade representative had the authority for trade negotiations. ''In light of that, the decision that U.S.T.R. would lead the delegation is perfectly straightforward. There was no turf battle here.''

The move is seen as a setback for Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who was photographed with Mrs. Hills after they were named to the Bush Administration's economic team. (NYT/Jose R. Lopez)

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate Up by 0.5% In Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The nation's economy grew at a rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the final three months of 1989, the Commerce Department estimated today. It was the weakest economic performance since the spring of 1986.
Spending by consumers, who account for about two-thirds of economic activity, declined slightly, and only continued production of cars and other goods that ended up in unsold inventories kept the overall gross national product from contracting.
Nonetheless, the quarterly report on G.N.P., and a separate report that showed surprising strength in orders for durable goods in December, reassured many private-sector analysts that the economy could continue to avoid recession. Economic activity is likely to perk up, albeit gradually, in coming months, these analysts said. 
 
Sluggish Period Foreseen
''I read the combination of the two as saying the economy is skirting a recession but is in for further sluggishness,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago.
Administration officials offered similar assessments. The Under Secretary of Commerce, Michael R. Darby, told reporters that the G.N.P. report reflected ''temporary sluggishness and a number of soft spots in the economy, partly stemming from special factors.''
He and others cited a strike by Boeing Company employees that was estimated to have cut fourth-quarter growth by five-tenths of a percentage point and a steep decline in vehicle sales after a third-quarter buying spurt induced by manufacturers' incentive programs.
The fourth-quarter rise of five-tenths of 1 percent is a sharp falloff from the 3 percent gain posted for the third quarter.
 
Yearly Rise Is 2.9%
 For the year, real G.N.P. rose 2.9 percent, compared with gains of 4.4 percent in 1988, 3.7 percent in 1987 and 2.7 percent in 1986. Between the fourth quarter of 1988 and the fourth quarter of 1989 the increase was 2.4 percent, compared with 3.4 percent in the previous comparable period.
Today's G.N.P. report, which was in line with expectations, appeared to have little effect on the financial markets, but the 2.5 percent jump in durable-goods orders was said by traders to have been a significant cause of yesterday's rise in interest rates, contributing to another sharp selloff in stocks early in the day. By the close of trading, however, the stock market had regained much of its loss.
Economists said that unseasonably harsh year-end weather had a mixed effect on the report. The bad weather curtailed construction and mining, but raised spending on home heating by a seasonally adjusted $6 billion, after little change in the third quarter. The nation as a whole had its fourth-coldest December of the century, and it was the coldest December on record in the Northeast, Midwest and Southeast.
Department analysts said Hurricane Hugo and the Northern California earthquake in October had only small net effects on economic activity.
Even as the risk of imminent recession seemed to recede a bit, the G.N.P. report prompted speculation about a possible suspension of the deficit-reduction process mandated by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act. Under the act, if the economy grows by less than 1 percent for two straight quarters, Congress and the President may agree to waive its provisions requiring automatic cuts in Federal spending.
 
What Congress Might Do
 But a senior adviser to Congress on budget matters said that although some lawmakers might welcome a way to escape making budgetary moves that would further weaken a fragile economy, such a move could be offset by the Federal Reserve, which would be concerned over a loss of budgetary discipline and would probably move to tighten credit.
He added that he would not assume that a measure to suspend the balanced-budget law would be approved even if the fourth-quarter results, after probable revision, and the data from the current quarter made a suspension permissible. What really matters, he said, is the outlook for the economy later in the year.
The G.N.P. report did have some sobering figures on inflation. The fixed-weight G.N.P. price index climbed at a 3.8 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, up from 2.9 percent during the summer. This acceleration reflected higher prices of goods and services bought by consumers, the department said.
Another inflation gauge, the implicit price deflator, accelerated to 3.5 percent, from 3.2, but this is considered a less useful indicator because it measures a changing basket of goods and services. The fixed-weight index, with a base year of 1982, measures a basket whose composition does not vary.
The biggest drag on fourth-quarter G.N.P. was a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in consumer spending, the first contraction in two years. While this was small, just $800 million at an annual rate, it meant that the biggest force in the economy was contributing nothing to G.N.P.
 
Savings Rate Shows a Gain
 The cutback in spending did, however, allow the personal savings rate to rise to 5.8 percent, from 5.1. Raising the nation's savings rate is a key goal of policy makers. Initiatives to promote savings are expected to be presented Monday in President Bush's 1991 budget proposals.
Consumers' purchases of durable goods - costly items expected to last more than three years - fell during the quarter at an annual rate of $14.8 billion, in contrast to an increase of $11.5 billion in the third quarter. A wide swing in vehicle sales accounted for all the increase and the subsequent drop. Sales of nondurable goods fell $3.3 billion after rising $11.1 billion during the summer.
Fixed investment by business moved from an increase to a decline; the categories of net exports and Government purchases showed declines that were smaller than those in the previous quarter, and investment in housing rose a bit after declining in the third quarter.
When combined, these resulted in a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in real final sales, in contrast to a 2.7 percent increase in the preceding quarter. When the Commodity Credit Corporation's purchases of farm products are excluded, final sales dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent after surging 3.8 percent in the third quarter.
 
A Rise in Inventories
 Business inventories, dominated by unsold cars, jumped $32.6 billion after increases of $21.9 billion in the third quarter and $19.1 billion in the second. This meant that investment added $10.7 billion in the latest period, compared with $2.8 billion in the third quarter.
The report also showed that G.N.P., when expressed in current dollars rather than 1982 dollars, rose at a 4.3 percent rate in the latest quarter, down from 6.2 percent in the summer.
Real fourth-quarter G.N.P. was at a rate of $4.17 trillion, or $5.34 trillion when expressed in current dollars, the report showed.

HEADLINE: Chip Maker In Texas Has Profit Drop

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Texas Instruments said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 62.3 percent as sales of computer chips slowed and prices declined dramatically in the period.
Moreover, the company cautioned that it could report a loss in the current quarter. It cited a further slowing in chip orders, a slump in military orders, and large costs for new products and expanded chip production in Italy, Taiwan, Japan and at company headquarters in Dallas. 
Texas Instruments said it earned $35.9 million, or 33 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $95.3 million, or $1.04 a share, in the comparable period a year ago. Sales in the quarter fell slightly, to $1.72 billion from $1.73 billion.
 
20.4% Earnings Drop in Year
 For the year, earnings fell 20.4 percent, to $291.7 million, or $3.04 a share, from $366.3 million, or $4.05 a share, in 1988. Revenues rose a bit, to $6.52 billion from $6.45 billion.
Analysts said Texas Instruments' troubles would be temporary if the American economy continued to grow, but a recession and more price cutting would make 1990 a difficult year for the company and most other chip makers.
''The semiconductor industry is in a major downturn right now, which is acquiring momentum,'' said Richard L. Whittington, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody Inc. in New York. Referring to Texas Instruments, he added, ''They will certainly feel the pain.''
Texas Instruments Inc. is the nation's largest maker of memory chips and is second, after Motorola Inc., in total chip production.
 
Slowing in Global Sales
 Jerry R. Junkins, chairman and chief executive, said the slowing in worldwide sales of computers and other products that use large numbers of electronic components, like automobiles and telecommunications equipment, intensified in the fourth quarter and pushed chip sales below expectations.
Mr. Junkins added that he expected that the decline in sales in the current quarter would be ''sharper than normal'' because of a shift from production of aging products to newer ones. This deterioration ''could lead to a loss'' for the quarter, he added.
Prices for computer chips with 256,000 characters of memory plunged in the last 12 months to about $2 apiece, from $6. Newer one-megabit chips with one million characters of information also declined sharply in price, to $6.50 from $16, as producers around the globe raised their output.
 
Outlook on Output
 Jack Beedle, president of In-Stat Inc., a research firm in Scottsdale, Ariz., said worldwide output of the one-megabit chips would reach 550 million units this year. Output of the 256k chips will fall to about 400 million units, he said, from 620 million in 1989.
Texas Instruments anticipated the shift, spending heavily in the last two years. It is also preparing to begin mass production on a chip with four million characters of information in Italy, Taiwan, Japan and at its Dallas headquarters. Analysts say that chip will be in wide demand in 1991.
Analysts said two Japanese rivals, Toshiba and Hitachi, have a significant lead in production capability for the 4-megabit chip.
A spokesman, Stan Victor, said the company had cut 2,700 jobs worldwide in 1989, mostly through voluntary retirement programs.
Texas Instruments' shares were down $1.875, to $31.875, today on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Down Against Pound And Yen, but Up Elsewhere

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday, weakening against the British pound and Japanese yen but rising against many other currencies in heavy trading.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, an ounce of gold gained $4.10 to close at $420.10. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $420 an ounce, up $3 from Thursday. 
Most of the day's trading activity centered on the yen, which investors continued to buy aggressively. Analysts said the interest in the yen was partly spurred by optimism about the future of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party as February elections draw closer.
But the dollar suffered as investors sold the United States currency to buy yen. ''There are fears that foreigners are withdrawing from U.S. markets,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst at MMS International in Chicago.
He said traders were edgy in advance of the Treasury's quarterly refunding. Treasury officials are expected to announce next week their schedule for the sale of an estimated $30 billion in bonds, the proceeds of which are used to keep the Government running.
Foreigners, who have been attracted to United States investments by relatively high interest rates, need dollars to buy debt securities. But Mr. Chandler noted that rising interest rates in other countries - especially in Japan - had created fears that foreigners would shun the American bonds.
The dollar got a bit of a boost yesterday from a Government report that showed the gross national product grew at an annual rate of five-tenths of a percent in the final quarter of 1989. Although the figure, which represents the country's total output of goods and services, was the poorest showing since the spring of 1986, it was better than the market had expected and initially bolstered the dollar.
In New York, the dollar closed at 142.80 yen, down from 143.93 yen on Thursday. And it cost $1.6635 to buy a pound, more expensive than the $1.6600 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6865 West German marks, up from 1.6850; 1.4900 Swiss francs, up from 1.4850; 5.7290 French francs, up from 5.7255; 1,254.50 Italian lire, up from 1,253.75, and 1.1966 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1876.
