HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXIV;
Rich and Famous Can Take a Number

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Julio Iglesias needed a room at the Inter-Continental but there wasn't one. And Dale Dugan, a hotel official, couldn't worry about it. He had 500 Bronco fans to think about. Arriving simultaneously on three planes, they needed to be checked into the Inter-Continental without a tiresome wait.
To avoid ruffled feathers, the front office simply moved temporarily into the National Football League's big white tent in a parking lot next door to the downtown hotel and went to work, checking in 500 fans in 50 minutes. 
The $50,000 tent, 15,000 square feet, with electricity and wall-to-wall carpeting, will shelter the Broncos' $100,000 party after the game, win or lose.
Near the Superdome on Thursday night, the party tent was bigger, for 28,000 square feet of fried catfish, jambalaya, gumbo, jazz musicians, a grove of ficus trees twinkling with tiny lights and, as a city employee said as she leaned into a glass of champagne, ''2,000 of the media and all of the Mayor's friends.'' The Mayor, Sidney Barthelemy, head of a task force that threw the party, is running for re-election.
 
A Shot in the Economic Arm
Looking beyond the ficus trees and drinking black coffee, Jerry Dickhaus, a city official, smiled beatifically. He estimates the Super Bowl is worth $100 million to $125 million to the New Orleans economy. A trustworthy source has told him one party aboard a cruise ship will cost the Japanese host $12 million.
At the New Orleans Hilton Riverside and Towers, the executive pastry chef, George Cook, has been sculpting a 6-foot-long alligator made of marzipan and a twin made of tallow, for Barron Hilton and 2,500 other people, or, as a hotel employee put it, ''2,500 of his nearest and dearest.'' The guests, including O. J. Simpson and Muhammad Ali, will gather for Sunday brunch before the game.
There will be 24 bars, 2 beer stations, a wine station and 8 buffet stations with Cajun crawfish salad, grilled Louisiana quail, roasted rabbit, armadillo stew, crab claws, smoked alligator, roast pig with garlic, fried oysters, creole bread pudding with whiskey sauce and myriad other dishes. The brunch, the largest of dozens of parties at the hotel this weekend, will be one of hundreds throughout the city.
 
Serious Business
New Orleans is party town par excellence, as tourist officials here often say. But as Dickhaus noted, it's also serious business. With the oil economy down, tourism is New Orleans' biggest industry and the city government is working hard to please the thousands of people here for the game and thousands of others who came for the party.
To spare the eyes of visitors from unsightly views, the New Orleans International Airport, now under renovation and looking somewhat bombed out, has been swathed in banners, bunting, balloons and decorated with murals painted by Sheriff Charles Foti's artist-prisoners.
Even New Orleans city librarians have been pressed into service, with reference books and a phone hookup to the main library, ready to answer Super Bowl questions at the news-media center in the Hyatt Regency.
 
Leaving Home for Profit
Gail Cassagne, a business librarian, said she could understand why someone ''asked the price of tickets to Super Bowl I'' ($12, $10 and $6) or ''whether the Superdome is haunted because it's built on a cemetery.''
''But the full name of former President Tito of Yugoslavia?'' she asked.
The city is awash in stories about $450-a-night hotel rooms, four-night minimum, including a game ticket, and scarcity even at those prices. But Ro Mayer at Latter & Blum, a New Orleans real estate firm, is lamenting room surpluses. She and her seven co-workers recently worked all night collating files on 600 units, from apartments to Garden District mansions, available for up to $5,000 or so a night. The spaces have been proffered by New Orleans people eager to abandon their homes for profit. Where Are the High Rollers? The phones rang day and night, with calls from Hawaii, London, and elsewhere, but ultimately, Mayer said, ''the demand wasn't there,'' unlike the Super Bowl here four years ago, when the New England Patriots ''brought in the whole Northeast.'' She has concluded ''there are no high rollers in Denver, and the San Francisco high rollers just don't care.''
New Orleans upper-crust clients have presented problems, too. ''We had a three- or four-bedroom house, a restored Queen Anne, available for $10,000 for two nights,'' Mayer said. ''Someone wanted it for three nights and someone else for six nights for $20,000, but the owner refused. He would rent it only for two nights. He has kids and his wife said it was too much trouble to move. He told me it blew his golf game the next day thinking about losing all that money.''
More than 500 houses went begging along with a 53-foot-long 1952 motor yacht moored on Lake Pontchartrain: triple cabin, flying bridge, only $1,000 for three nights, sleeps six. Rooms have also languished at the Sportsmen's Inn in Bogalusa, La., $35 a night, an hour and a half's drive from the Superdome.
 
Restaurants Are Jammed
But the more famous New Orleans restaurants are fully booked. In the French Quarter, Antoine's, soon to be 150 years old, has been deluged as usual. Some private dining rooms and tables have been booked for four years. Creatures of habit, Antoine's clients like to return to the same private rooms and same tables Super Bowl after Super Bowl.
Last Tuesday, a representative for a certain v.i.p. telephoned Kermit Cosse, Antoine's associate manager, asking for reservations for a private room on Saturday night.
''What?'' asked Cosse, roomless and aghast. But he was rescued by a friend who had been holding reservations for four years in Antoine's Escargot Room. ''Take it,'' the friend said. ''Take the Escargot Room. Put us out in the main dining room.''
''Now that's courtesy,'' Cosse said, ''That's courtesy New Orleans style.''
As for Julio Iglesias, what did he do about getting a hotel room?
''I'm sure he found a room to sleep somewhere,'' Dugan said.

HEADLINE: DOMESTIC EFFORTS BEAR TOP BURDEN IN BUSH'S BUDGET

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
About half the $36 billion in deficit reduction that President Bush will propose in the budget he sends to Congress on Monday would come out of domestic programs, including some efforts in education, housing, transportation and health.
Much of the rest would consist of $13.3 billion in greater revenue. Included in this figure would be new fees for the users of Government services and property like national parks, and the continuation of excise taxes, now due to expire, on telephone calls and other items.
Only about $6 billion in deficit reduction would result from cuts in military spending, much of it from Army programs.
 
The First Bush Budget
These and other details of the President's budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, were gleaned from documents obtained by The New York Times, including an introduction written by the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, and from interviews with Government officials and lobbyists. 
Having just taken office at budget time last year, Mr. Bush was unable to do more than make minor adjustments to the budget that President Ronald Reagan had submitted for the current fiscal year. The new budget, therefore, is the first prepared under his stewardship. His proposals seem somewhat less ideological than those of Mr. Reagan, who repeatedly advocated large military increases and reductions in domestic programs.
But the first full Bush budget is still not likely to be acceptable to the Democratic-controlled Congress, which leans toward more money for social programs and less for the Defense Department.
 
Deficit of $63.1 Billion
Mr. Bush was required under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law to propose a budget that would reduce the deficit from the $100 billion ceiling of the current fiscal year to no more than $64 billion in 1991. His budget sets a deficit figure of $63.1 billion, the documents show.
The size of the actual deficit will depend to some extent on the level of economic growth, which leads to larger tax revenue, and interest rates, which determine how much the Government must pay in borrowing costs. The Administration is estimating somewhat more growth and somewhat lower interest rates than are most private economists and the Congressional Budget Office. #2 Percent Annual Cuts Under the President's plan, Pentagon spending would rise to $292.1 billion from $286.8 billion, an increase of $5.3 billion. But in the way budgets are calculated, that is a cut, because the new figure is about $6 billion less than what would be needed to keep up with inflation.
Since 1985, Congress has reduced the Pentagon budget by an average of 2 percent a year after accounting for inflation, despite requests for increases in spending from Presidents Reagan and Bush.
Given the improved relationship with the Soviet Union, Congress is expected to try to reduce the military budget by more than Mr. Bush wants, so that the deficit target can be met without cutting domestic programs so deeply.
In its budget presentation, the White House will project continued annual Pentagon cuts of 2 percent a year after inflation through the 1995 fiscal year, according to an Administration official.
That projection is also likely to be challenged in Congress, on the ground that much larger reductions will be possible once a conventional-forces treaty with the Soviet Union is signed.
 
More for Head Start
Among the other elements of the President's $1.2 trillion budget that are now available are these:
* The Education Department's budget would be increased by $1.2 billion, to $24.6 billion, slightly less than the amount needed to keep up with inflation. The budget includes increased spending for Head Start, the preschool program for poor children, and reduced outlays for student loans.
* More money would be made available for veterans' hospitals, but tighter credit terms would be applied to mortgage loans for veterans.
* An additional $2.5 billion would be allocated to the Federal Aviation Administration to modernize the air traffic control system. That is a 45 percent increase for those programs.
* The President will try once more to gain Congressional approval for what the Administration calls ''enterprise zones,'' neighborhoods where tax breaks and other advantages would be given to attract private business and jobs. This is a pet program of Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, but the idea has been rejected over the years by Congress.
* The budget will emphasize allotments for research and development, including new money for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, biotechnology, development of the giant atom-smasher called the superconducting supercollider and applied research on projects ranging from military weapons to agriculture programs to a high-speed rail system. The spending for basic research would rise by about $1 billion, to $12.3 billion.
* The President will propose more than $2 billion in new money to finance an environmental effort he calls America the Beautiful. It would include an acceleration of hazardous-waste cleanup, a reforestation program and acquisition of land for national parks.
 
Help for Poor Children
The White House said the $500 million increase Mr. Bush will seek for Head Start would be the largest single-year rise since the program was established 25 years ago. It would raise the Head Start budget to nearly $2 billion and would allow 180,000 more poor children to be served.
About 450,000 children are now served by Head Start. In addition to early education, the program provides nutrition, health and social services. Studies have found it to be one of the Government's most successful antipoverty programs.
By White House calculations, which some advocacy groups believe are optimistic, the new money would allow the program to reach nearly three-quarters of the nation's poor 4-year-olds.
Elsewhere in the education area, the budget would reduce funds for the guaranteed-student-loan program, which backs tuition loans from commercial banks for college students, and a program under which the Government lends money directly to low-income college students. But Mr. Bush will seek enough money for Pell grants, a scholarship program for poor college students, to enable it to keep up with inflation.
Federal assistance to libraries would be reduced, but a small amount of additional money would be provided for education programs in mathematics and science. Mr. Bush plans to renew his proposals for rewarding successful schools and establishing magnet schools, neither of which received attention from Congress when he offered them last year.
During his 1988 election campaign, Mr. Bush said he wanted to be known as the ''education President.'' But a New York Times/CBS News Poll taken two weeks ago found that only 16 percent of Americans thought he had made progress in improving education, while 68 percent said he had ''mainly just talked about it.'' The telephone poll, conducted Jan. 13 to 15 with 1,557 adults nationwide, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Changing the Pentagon
Mr. Bush has already said the new Pentagon budget will be the first step in a sweeping restructuring of the American military. But critics on Capitol Hill and within the Pentagon have said the spending plan postpones most of the tough decisions, opting for personnel cuts over the cancellation of expensive weapons systems like the Stealth bomber.
The Army is the service that would be cut most by the plan, officials said, and it is projected to shrink by two divisions, totaling more than 30,000 active-duty soldiers. While the Navy would keeps all its 15 aircraft carriers under the plan, it would mothball two battleships - the Iowa and the Missouri.
Potential base closings will not be included in the budget, although any significant shrinking of active-duty military forces would lead to the elimination of military bases around the country. The possible base closings will be submitted separately, officials have said.
Mr. Bush will also propose cuts in programs that help poor people weatherize their homes and pay heating bills. A similar proposal last year was rejected by Congress.
The budget, which will be presented in one large book this year instead of several smaller volumes as in the past, will go on sale Monday at Government bookstores for $38.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Mayoralty Raises Questions, While Jackson Ups the Ante

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The political galleries are full of people asking will he or won't he run for mayor here. But the Rev. Jesse Jackson, as he so often does, is playing a more elaborate political game, one in which his potential candidacy for office provides both a platform and his strongest bargaining chip.
While everyone else is focusing on the mayoral race, the coy non-candidate has been using the moment to deliver a blunt message:
The Democratic Party should find a way to win statehood for the District of Columbia, thus creating a Senate seat he can run for, or he will do the thing that strikes fear in the hearts of many Democrats. He will run for President again.
 
Simple Yet Complex Equation
''As I address Democrats,'' Mr. Jackson said in an interview this week, ''it's either D.C. statehood '91, or the nomination for 1992.'' 
But it's not quite that simple. Jesse Jackson's remarks are always more intricate then they seem. In the week since Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington was charged with possessing crack provided by an F.B.I. informer, Mr. Jackson has said many things about local politics. His comments were reported in a front-page article in The Washington Post to mean that he was leaning toward a run for mayor. But his comments persuaded a columnist for The New York Times, A. M. Rosenthal, that he was not running for mayor.
This confusing pattern - or pattern of confusion - is familiar to those who have known Mr. Jackson a long time. ''He's saying different things to different people within minutes,'' not just to reporters but even to friends and advisers, said a longtime associate.
Some of this is just the Jackson style. He is unusually accessible for a major public figure, and tries out ideas on whoever happens to be around.
But there is more. Mr. Jackson, his associates say, has not made up his mind whether to run, although most of his staff believe he is leaning against running. What is certain is that he will not let this moment pass without getting all the attention he can on his larger agenda, which includes a platform for his liberal views and what he calls ''options'' for higher office.
 
He Practices 'Leverage' Politics
Since his days in the civil rights movement Mr. Jackson has practiced what Frank Watkins, a friend and longtime associate, calls ''leverage'' politics. For example, the threat of an economic boycott produced the leverage to pressure auto makers to grant dealerships to blacks, and these dealers remain among the core of Mr. Jackson's financial contributors.
In the spring and summer of 1988, when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts had the Democratic nomination locked up, Mr. Jackson carried on his campaign for President because it gave him leverage to negotiate things like his travel budget for the fall Democratic campaign and changes in party rules that could help a Jackson Presidential candidacy, if there is one, in 1992.
This style of politics has often led to the misplaced question, ''What does Jesse want?'' As in any bargaining situation, what he wants is the best deal he can get. The only way to find out is to exert pressure in various directions, or use leverage, and see what happens.
That is what is going on now. And Mr. Jackson says he has ''no plans'' to run for mayor, giving the field-tested response of candidates who are not ready to say they are candidates. A television reporter demanded of Mr. Jackson why he did not make a simple declarative statement that he was not running. ''Why should I in public service give up leverage and options to satisfy some urge?'' he replied.
Two things give Mr. Jackson leverage now. The first is that as long as he puts off a decision on running for mayor, he has the attention of those who want him to run and those who do not. The second is the question whether he will run for President for a third time.
To comprehend Mr. Jackson's plan requires an understanding of his view of another Presidential campaign. Simply put, though many Democrats think he can never be nominated, Mr. Jackson seems to believe he can be.
 
'I Expect to Win'
''If I run in '92, I expect to win,'' he said Thursday night in a televised interview with Larry King, the talk show host. ''I got 3.5 million votes in 1984. I got 7 million in 1988. I believe I could get 10 million in 1992 and that's enough to win.''
So, in Mr. Jackson's mind, any choice other than running for President in 1992 means giving up a chance to be the first black Presidential nominee of a major political party.
Those who have discussed the subject with him say Mr. Jackson understands that his chances of beating George Bush would be slim. But Mr. Jackson knows, too, that even the prospect of another campaign for the nomination terrifies many Democrats. They fear he would at the least draw more attention than they would prefer to the liberal wing of the party, and at most win a place on the ticket and thus drive off voters who would reject a black.
Some fear that Mr. Jackson would lead the party to a devastating defeat in which they would lose not only the Presidential race, but also control of the Senate and perhaps the House.
That gives Mr. Jackson leverage and brings the political discussion back to the District of Columbia. While the Democratic Party platform officially supports statehood, there has been little movement in Congress. The District's government is reviled on Capitol Hill as inefficient and corrupt, and Mr. Barry's arrest has only worsened the situation.
But Mr. Jackson is hoping that the prospect of another Presidential bid will help focus the attention of other Democrats on the statehood issue.
 
Applying Pressure on Statehood
Mr. Jackson's office has sent a survey to every member of Congress asking where he or she stands. And he says he plans to campaign for statehood around the country and against those who oppose it. Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Paul Simon of Illinois said on Friday that they planned to introduce a statehood bill.
Even if he rallied Democrats, there is another problem: the Republican Party. On the face of it, the Republicans have opposed admission of a state that would send two Democratic senators to Capitol Hill and remove Mr. Jackson from complicating the 1992 Presidential race for their rivals.
But there is a new wrinkle that Mr. Jackson is trying to exploit.
President Bush has endorsed an effort to offer statehood to Puerto Rico, where Republicans feel they have a chance of capturing Senate seats and other offices. Mr. Jackson might try to link the two, forcing Mr. Bush to veto both, or approve both.
In the meantime, there is the mayor's race. In the long-shot prospect that the District is admitted as a state, there seems little doubt that it would be Mr. Jackson's preference to ''desegregate the Senate,'' as an aide put it, rather than serve at City Hall. But he might have to decide before the prospects of statehood are clear.
 
Mayoralty Seen as a Trap
While most in his inner circle view the mayor's race as a trap that would only derail his career, a few have argued that it would offer a chance to dispel the criticism that he has never held elective office.
When Mr. Jackson talks about why he does not want to be mayor, he is sending a message that those who want him to run have to make a better case. He contends that this is ''an occupied'' city under the control of Congress and the President.
From those who think he can truly help the city, Mr. Jackson wants assurances of wide support. Several other candidates who have already announced are sure to brand Mr. Jackson, who moved to Washington from Chicago last summer, as a carpetbagger.
In any case, Mr. Jackson has no reason to rule out a mayoral race now. For one thing, Mayor Barry has yet to say if he will seek re-election. And Mr. Jackson would need Mr. Barry's many supporters to win.
Mr. Jackson is off to South Africa next week and hopes to be there if and when the South African Government releases Nelson Mandela, a possibility that has drawn the attention of the world press. Mr. Jackson is not expected back until the third week of February, which, it happens, is when Mayor Barry is to complete his program at a drug and alcohol abuse treatment center in South Florida.

LENGTH: 1937 words

HEADLINE: In Small Steps, Program Puts Homeless Into Jobs

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

 BODY:
As hundreds of communities struggle to check the spread of homelessness, an ambitious program to steer Louisville's homeless into jobs and stable lives has shown some real success. But success comes in tiny steps, and at the same time, failure abounds.
Now in its second year, the Louisville program, Project Worth, includes remedial schooling, vocational training and lessons in conventions of living and working like keeping budgets and getting to work on time.
 
Seeds For A National Policy
It is among 46 community programs that the Federal Government supports with grants, typically a few hundred thousand dollars each, through a 1987 law to promote housing for the homeless. The aid to Project Worth has been extended a second year, an indication that the Government sees in the program some seeds for a national policy at a time when surveys indicate growing public concern about homelessness and dissatisfaction with the response of government. 
But Project Worth also illustrates the challenge that helping the homeless presents. Between a third and a half of the participants are thought to have drug or alcohol problems. The school system of Jefferson County, where Louisville is, administers the program and recently completed a study of the results of the program's first year, which ended in September. It showed that just 10 percent of the people who enrolled made it all the way through and into a job that they kept at least three months.
By the standards of the experiment here, 25-year-old Michael Howell is a winner. But his case also shows how poverty, family traumas or the abuse of drugs or alcohol can haunt the homeless long after they get on their feet, and how employers must make allowances if the Michael Howells here are to keep their jobs.
 
New Start and Some Slipping
When Mr. Howell was 4 and living in Washington State, his mother said she was going to the movies and never came back. At 8, while living with his father, who had remarried and moved to Michigan, Mr. Howell said, he began smoking marijuana he bought with the money he earned from a newspaper route. Hooked on drugs at 15, he said, and failing in school, he left home and began drifting from city to city. He found an occasional menial job but could not keep it.
A little more than a year ago, Mr. Howell landed in Louisville at one of the city's 33 shelters for the homeless. He underwent a month of detoxification treatment. Chagrined that he could not hold a job, he said, ''I thought possibly, maybe, drugs had something to do with it.''
Mr. Howell enrolled in Project Worth, specializing in bookkeeping. He completed the course, and for nine months he has been earning the minimum wage, plus full benefits, as a clerk and errand runner for the Capital Holding Corporation, a large insurance and financial services conglomerate downtown. He is taking business courses at Jefferson Community College.
One day, Mr. Howell did not show up for work. He had slipped back to drugs. But Barbara J. Laski, the treasurer of Capital Holding and Mr. Howell's boss, let him return. Indeed, she and her staff went out looking for him and hauled him back.
''He thought he had fallen from our graces,'' Ms. Laski said. ''We knew that if we could get to him that week, we could get him back,'' she said. ''Bumps along the way I kind of expected. Your benchmark has to be reasonable. He does have rough edges, but he's moving in the right direction. We are talking career with him, not just a job.''
 
Admitting 264 People, Program Puts 42 in Jobs
The first-year report on Project Worth says 264 people, about 70 percent of them women, were admitted to the program from Louisville's homeless population of 3,500. Half dropped out. Of those who stayed, the study said 42 took courses leading to the equivalent of a high school diploma. Twenty-seven took the final exam, and just 11 passed.
The report says that 42 students were placed in jobs after an average of 26 weeks of schooling, and that their average wage was $4.49 an hour, 79 cents more than they earned in their last jobs. But after 13 weeks, 24 of the graduates, roughly 1 in 10 of the starting class, still had the jobs. And since completion of the first year, in September, the project coordinator, Marlene Gordon, said about half of those 24 had left their jobs.
Ms. Gordon said that when some participants started the program they were strapped for money and quit classes to take jobs that paid less than those they might have found later. Some left town or fell back into drugs and drinking. ''We had one woman get a good job in construction,'' Ms. Gordon said. ''She got back with her drug-addicted boyfriend and got pregnant and had twins.''
However modest the results, the experience so far has been valuable, said Roberts T. Jones, an Assistant United States Secretary of Labor. ''It's going to be a long time before there's any significant evidence of the value,'' he said, ''But the value is there.''
 
Battling Economic Strain With Little Preparation
For the second year of the Louisville project, the Labor Department has raised its subsidy to $351,000, from $279,000 in the first year. State and local agencies provide about 10 percent more, and many churches and charities in the Louisville Coalition for the Homeless help in a variety of ways, big and small, whose cost no one has quantified.
Teresa Cochran, who at 26 is the mother of three children 4, 5 and 7 years old, landed in a shelter and is now in Project Worth. Like many participants, she has more problems than just homelessness. She has left her husband, she said. Before that, she said, she kept losing jobs. ''I couldn't find a regular baby sitter,'' she said. ''It became a problem. We got behind in the rent.''
The economic strains seem especially acute in Louisville. Wages here have fallen even more than they have nationally because of the city's shift, well along now, from a high-wage manufacturing center for cigarettes, baseball bats, Ford automobiles and General Electric appliances to a service industry city of health care and insurance businesses that pay lower wages.
In addition, Kentucky's schools have left its workers ill prepared to learn the skills that changing jobs can require. The 1980 census showed that only 49 percent of all adults had high school diplomas, the lowest percentage for any state.
Project Worth recruits its participants at emergency shelters, where the homeless can stay for a month or so upon promising to stay off drugs and alcohol. Upon getting jobs, people move into halfway houses, where they pay for some of their keep.
 
Life Is Cramped And Runs on Shoestring
Like the people they serve, most shelters run on a shoestring. Much of the shelters' food comes from Kentucky Harvest, a nonprofit organization that retrieves surplus food from restaurants, stores and vending machines, and churches supply the shelters with clothes. Many single people live in barracks-like wards in the shelters, and parents with children crowd into single rooms along halls with communal bathrooms.
Room No. 4 of a Volunteers of America emergency shelter is smaller than most. A mother, a father and two children sleep on two sets of bunk beds in a space about 7 by 12. There is room for one chest of drawers, a respectable Victorian antique of oak that somebody donated. The television set is kept at the foot of a bottom bunk. Newly washed shirts, underwear and blue jeans are folded and stacked on an upper bunk. This is the family's home.
Once admitted to Project Worth, students take school buses provided by the school system and the American Red Cross to a former junior high school on the outskirts of the city for their courses. Women can bring their young children along because the project provides day care.
Some students left school so early that a high-school-equivalency diploma is unattainable during the year with the project, so for them the teachers set a goal of raising their proficiency by two grade levels. In one class recently, the teacher wrote the vocabulary words for the day on the blackboard: wholesale, wholesaler, retail, quantity, quality.
At the other extreme are students like John Ramey, a 20-year-old from Indianapolis who lost himself on marijuana in his first semester at Franklin College. ''I don't even have any credits,'' he said. ''That's how drugs screwed me up.'' He said his parents talked him into getting treatment.
While taking the course, Mr. Ramey became the project's computer guru. He does programming and tests the word processing systems for secretarial courses. Now he is paid $2 an hour for tutoring, and next month, he will start a full-time job at $5.33 an hour as a teacher's aide for the project. From that he said he hopes to move to a still better job and eventually back to college.
 
Project Shows Success With Help of Mentors
One lesson of the project's first year, Ms. Gordon said, is the importance of a mentor for the students. Michael Howell found one in Ms. Laski, who discovered him on a recruiting mission at the project. Bob Peterson, 43, found his in Ms. Gordon. An alcoholic and the father of three children, he was divorced 17 years ago.
''I lost everything I had,'' he said, ''and I just hit the road.'' Ms. Gordon, he said, ''is about the only person I've seen in a program like this that takes a personal interest in you.'' He said in an interview on what he said was his 147th day without a drink that his dream was a job as an automotive engineer but that he could be happy returning to his old work as a house painter.
James Farley, a 44-year-old son of an alcoholic father, says he has gone 15 months without a drink and attributes his progress to Project Worth.
He has gone to work as the maintenance man at the Jefferson Street Baptist Center, a mission where he also lives, and he has a similar job at another mission. People close to him say he has taken his first job at the mission because he is being cautious about going back into an unprotected world and a job as an engine mechanic because of the fear of backsliding.
 
'A Lot of Breaks Have to Go Your Way'
''A lot of breaks have to go your way for a long time,'' the Rev. Michael Freeman, the minister at the center said. ''A lot of these guys get going strong, then nothing happens in their lives. They say, 'Why should I stay sober?' ''
A failing of the program and one reason so few graduates stay on the job, Ms. Gordon said, is the relatively brief period, 13 weeks, that the project keeps tabs on and counsels the people after they leave the school. She said she would like to stretch it to two years. Another shortcoming, she said, is money. Because the students have so little, she would like to give them a stipend to help them stay through the course.
Another problem is screening. In recruiting last year, the project report said, ''The staff was hesitant to elicit information on prior or present substance abuse problems. Staff feared that this information would seem irrelevant to the education process and would be offensive to the student. This was a mistake.''
For the homeless who want jobs, there is some hope in demographic trends. In Louisville, as in many other cities, entry-level workers are becoming scarce because of the plunge in the birth rate two decades ago. Hiring Michael Howell, Ms. Laski said, was not charity.
''This was not a contribution to the church,'' she said. ''Corporations are thinking, 'How do you attract people?' You're going to see them picking the best and the brightest from among the disadvantaged.''

HEADLINE: For Work Force, 2 Million Who'd Quit Retirement

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Nearly two million nonworking Americans 50 to 64 years old are ready and able to work, a new survey shows.
''The excitement of this study is that the pool of qualified older workers is so much larger than anyone knew, and with everyone worrying about the labor shortages forecast for early next century, that's very important,'' said Thomas W. Moloney, senior vice president of the Commonwealth Fund, the New-York based philanthropy that commissioned the study.
''This study,'' he went on, ''disproves the conventional wisdom that there are not many people in this age range ready and able to work, that they aren't healthy enough to work, or aren't prepared to take the jobs that there is a demand for.''
Since there are only about two million new people entering the labor force each year, he said, it is significant that the survey produced an estimate that there is a pool of another two million qualified older workers. 
 
The Numbers Game
That estimate, based on a survey by Louis Harris & Associates, is more than three times the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimate of 630,000. Bruce Klein, a bureau economist, says both estimates may be right since the Government number does not include workers not seeking jobs.
The survey, conducted by telephone last March through last September, covered 3,509 older Americans - 1,751 men 55 to 64 years old and 1,758 women 50 to 59. The women were younger because women leave the work force earlier than men; the survey tried to focus on the years when workers typically leave the work force.
In portions of the survey not yet analyzed, those surveyed were also asked when and why they left work and how they fared outside the work force.
From the participants' responses the researchers inferred results applicable to the 21.5 million Americans in those age brackets. Of that group, 13.3 million are working, 4.7 million do not want to work, and 1.6 million are unable to work, mostly for health reasons. The remaining workers, nearly 2 million, are ready and able. #1.1 Million Pass All Tests The projections of the data were done by Harris and I.C.F., a District of Columbia consulting company.
About 800,000 of the estimated 2 million people were not prime candidates for new jobs. the researchers said, but more than 1.1 million would be highly qualified and motivated since they have reasonable wage expectations, would accept difficult working conditions, and have interest in available jobs: managerial, computer, sales, home day care, teacher's aide.
The survey has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus seven percentage points. The participants were asked how far they would be willing to commute, what jobs and job conditions they would accept and for what pay. The reasons that these people are not working include employer discrimination against older workers and the workers' perceptions of the employers' attitudes.
 
Comparison of Incomes
''As ready and willing and capable as these people are, 60 percent are discouraged from seeking employment, and the most frequently given reason is that they don't think people want to hire them,'' said Mr. Moloney.
The study found that only 6 percent of the qualified older people had incomes of $50,000 or above, as against 25 percent of employed older people.
Two-thirds of the qualified older workers would work full time, and 86 percent said they would work part time. The researchers reported that three-quarters of the qualified older workers were high school or college graduates, as against 85 percent of the working older people. Sixty-four percent of the available workers had five or more years of experience on the last job, against 77 percent of older people now employed.
''There's a skill bust coming because the education and skills of the workers coming up are not up to the levels of the current work force,'' Mr. Moloney said, ''so it is very good news to find that there are so many capable committed older workers available.''

HEADLINE: Salvador Promises Quayle Full Inquiry on Jesuits

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The President of El Salvador assured Vice President Dan Quayle today that he would investigate the killings of six Jesuit priests to see if the evidence implicated anyone ranking higher than the nine military men accused in the slayings.
The Salvadoran President, Alfredo Cristiani, offered the assurance at a breakfast with Mr. Quayle. Both men were here for the inauguration of the President of Honduras, Rafael Leonardo Callejas, who was elected in November to succeed Jose Azcona Hoyo.
The six Jesuit priests, all proponents of a negotiated solution to the civil war in El Salvador, their housekeeper and her daughter were shot to death on Nov. 16. Eight military men, including a colonel and three other officers, were arrested this month. A ninth military man accused of involvement remains at large. 
Asked at a news conference today whether he expected the arrest of more military officers, Mr. Cristiani replied:
''That's not something you can say ahead of time. I think we've been able to get the investigation down where we have those who directly were involved in the assassination and, with their testimony, those who gave the order to commit the crime. But during the judicial process, there might be new testimony coming out that has new leads, and the investigation would follow those leads to see if there is any more involvement.''
 
'Have to Set an Example'
Mr. Cristiani said ''we have to set an example in El Salvador'' to show that such crimes cannot be committed with impunity.
Many members of the United States Congress and human rights advocates have said they doubted that any military officers would be convicted of the killings because the Salvadoran system of justice has been unable to hold military men accountable in the past.
But two members of Congress traveling with Mr. Quayle - Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, and Representative G. V. (Sonny) Montgomery, Democrat of Mississippi - told Mr. Cristiani that Congress was closely watching the case. They indicated that Congress might restrict or reduce aid to El Salvador if there was not a full investigation of the killings of the Jesuits.
El Salvador gets $1.4 million a day in American aid.
Among those arrested is Col. Guillermo Alfredo Benavides Moreno, the head of the Salvadoran military college. A person who attended the breakfast with Mr. Cristiani quoted the Salvadoran leader as saying he wanted the investigation to proceed at a deliberate pace to determine if any officer higher than Colonel Benavides had been involved.
 
No Record of Abuses
The colonel is not known to have committed human rights abuses in the past, American officials said.
Mr. Quayle said Mr. Cristiani ''wants to get to the bottom of this'' case and ''has assured me that he will.''
A major purpose of Mr. Quayle's trip is to repair diplomatic damage done by the American invasion of Panama. The Vice President assured Latin American leaders today that the additional American troops sent to Panama last month would be withdrawn ''as soon as possible.''
His mission was somewhat awkward because while trying to regain the trust of Latin American countries, he also told them that fiscal constraints in Washington would probably compel Congress to reduce their foreign aid allocations.
President Bush ''is committed to pulling all the troops out, to the level that we had before the intervention, as soon as possible,'' he said. ''In my judgment, that will hopefully be in a time period of weeks rather than months.''
Mr. Quayle's commitment to ''get the troops out as soon as possible'' was more specific than any such commitment by American officials in the past.
 
Salvador Recognizes Endara
Mr. Cristiani said today that El Salvador was recognizing the new Panamanian Government headed by President Guillermo Endara.
Mr. Cristiani, a staunch ally of the Bush Administration, generally supported the American invasion of Panama as a means to promote democracy. But today he also said, ''U.S. troops should be pulled out of Panama as soon as possible.''
At the peak of their strength, American troops in Panama numbered 27,000 last month. Bernard W. Aronson, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, who is traveling with the Vice President, said the United States had withdrawn 10,000 of those troops, leaving 17,000 in Panama.
Administration officials said the number of troops would be reduced to 13,600, the level just before the invasion, and might be cut back to 10,000, the level before a gradual buildup was begun more than a year ago.
Mr. Quayle said the purpose of his visit here was not to apologize for the invasion of Panama, but to consult with Latin American leaders about ''how to build democracy in Panama'' and throughout the Western Hemisphere. The Vice President's trip was scaled back because a few nations, including Mexico and Venezuela, suggested that Mr. Quayle should not visit at this time.
 
Quayle Meets 5 Leaders
In his effort to mend fences, Mr. Quayle met here with Mr. Callejas, with Presidents Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela, Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica and Vinicio Cerezo of Guatemala and with Prime Minister George Price of Belize.
Mr. Callejas, 46 years old, grew up in a wealthy land-owning family and holds degrees in agricultural economics from Mississippi State University.
Even as Honduras inaugurated him as President, American officials advised the new Government that they were holding back much of the foreign aid earmarked for this country. Honduras was supposed to get $85 million in economic aid last year, but the United States is withholding $70 million because Honduras has not carried out the economic austerity measures recommended by the International Monetary Fund and other lenders.
American officials said Honduras stood to lose one-third of its $85 million cash allocation this year for the same reason.

HEADLINE: To Many in Panama, the New President Is an Enigma Wrapped in a Smile

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Jan. 27

 BODY:
To many people who know him only from afar, Guillermo Endara Galimany, a 53-year-old lawyer with a dimpled smile and a quick laugh, is something of an enigma.
Unlike many of his predecessors in the 21 years of military rule, Panama's new civilian President, who sometimes jokes about his weight problem, often seems altogether too guileless and self-effacing to believe.
Although many Panamanians think he is the perfect man for the job, others wonder if he has the political skill to rebuild the devastated economy, create an effective police agency to replace the Panamanian Defense Forces and still generate the popular support that his Government will need when the euphoria over the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega subsides. Among other things, the circumstances under which Mr. Endara and his two vice presidents took power - as the invasion by United States troops began last month - is certain to be used against them as Panama's traditionally anti-American nationalism reawakens.
In a particularly complex Panamanian play of race and caste, Mr. Endara is also likely to find himself denounced as the leader of the privileged few against the vast ranks of the poor. 
 
On the Night of Dec. 19
But there are aspects of the new President's personality and career that suggest that he may be able to rally the country in what many agree will be the difficult months of reconstruction ahead.
Mr. Endara said that when American officials told him late on Dec. 19 that the invasion was imminent and that they wanted him to take the oath as President, ''I felt like I had been hit in the head with a sledgehammer.''
''It would have been very easy for me to say, 'I'm not going to take this job under occupation by American forces,' '' Mr. Endara said in a recent interview in his office overlooking the Pacific. ''But I knew that I couldn't do that. I had to assume the responsibility of Government - the people chose me to be President. I couldn't simply tell the U.S.: 'You pick the Government. You are the occupying power and you do what you want.' ''
''History may speak horribly of me,'' he said of his decision. ''I certainly knew that Latin Americans weren't going to be very fond of me. But morally, patriotically, civically, I had no other choice. I had to do it.''
 
A Reputation As a Great Lawyer
 A year ago, before he agreed to run as the civilian coalition's nominee for the presidency against General Noriega's candidate, Mr. Endara was virtually unknown as a political commodity, except for two things.
Political insiders knew him as the longtime behind-the-scenes secretary for his idol, Dr. Arnulfo Arias Madrid, the charismatic, Peron-like figure whose presence and views - a curious mix of socialism, fascism, racism, mysticism and resistance to United States domination of the Panama Canal - dominated Panamanian politics for half a century.
But in the capital's financial center, bankers, businessmen and would-be businessmen knew Mr. Endara in a more pragmatic incarnation, as one of the best corporate lawyers in town, smart and well-connected.
Both pursuits seem to have taught him the fine art of quiet compromise, a skill he has reportedly put to use in recent weeks settling differences between himself and his First Vice President, Ricardo Arias Calderon, leader of the formidable Christian Democratic Party; and the Second Vice President, Guillermo (Billy) Ford of the Nationalist Liberal Republican Party, a splinter group known by the Spanish acronym of Molirena. Under a pact said to have been signed Dec. 21 by the three men, decisions are being made not by Mr. Endara alone, but by consensus of all three.
Some politicians say the country is apparently being run by a less-than-efficient junta, not a president. ''They're trying to play the piano with six hands,'' complained one critic, Carlos Ivan Zuniga, an opposition politician who heads a small, conservative political party known as Papo.
But others are hopeful about Mr. Endara's skills at conciliation.
''Over the years, I've seen him act many times as a bridge between competing groups,'' said Fernando Manfredo, who began serving this month as the first Panamanian administrator of the Panama Canal Commission, although in an acting capacity. In 1983, Mr. Manfredo recalled, Mr. Endara, representing Dr. Arias's Authentic Panamanian Party, managed to get a roomful of bitter political adversaries, including a Communist group, to agree on a complex change in the Constitution.
 
Brilliance at School, Success at the Office
 Mr. Endara, an only child, was born May 12, 1936, to upper-middle class parents in the capital. By all accounts a brilliant student, he attended secondary schools in Argentina and a now-defunct military academy in Los Angeles, Calif., eventually graduating first in his law class at the University of Panama.
He also studied law for a time at New York University, returning home to open a law practice in 1963 with an older lawyer, Galileo Solis. Mr. Endara was 27 at the time.
The firm, now called Solis, Endara, Delgado & Guevara, had always specialized in corporate work, although in its early growth years, ''they took on just about anybody who walked in the door,'' said a Panamanian lawyer familiar with the firm.
Solis Endara was thus well-positioned to take advantage of the explosion in commercial activity in Panama that occurred after the military coup of 1968, which toppled President Arias on his 11th day in office; it was the third time he had been deposed by the military since 1941.
Much of the success of Panama's financial center in the 1970's and 80's, Mr. Endara readily acknowledges, was a result of the Latin American drug cartels, which brought billions in cocaine and marijuana profits to be laundered in Panama. But the President says that neither he nor his law partners ever knowingly worked with drug traffickers or accepted their money.
In the interview in his newly renovated office at the presidential palace, which only a month ago had been occupied by American combat troops, Mr. Endara also dismissed press reports in the United States that Second Vice President Billy Ford's brother, Henry Ford, was associated with a Miami accountant who was convicted of laundering money for the Medellin cartel.
Others familiar with Mr. Endara and Billy Ford, from childhood friends to longtime political adversaries, say that whatever their faults, they are not corrupt.
''I know Billy Ford since we were 10 years old,'' said I. Roberto Eisenmann Jr., a businessman and publisher of the fiercely anti-Noriega newspaper La Prensa. ''I know basically everything he's done in his professional life, including all the temptations he has had, and I know he has never broken under them.''
Mr. Endara said of his own law firm: ''We did legal work under the dictatorship without any help from the Government, but we have done no business with narcotraffickers or anything like that that we know of.''
''But,'' he said, ''like any lawyer, I cannot vouch that every client who comes through our doors is a saint.
''Like many other law firms in Panmama, we are often asked to do company work, such as incorporating companies,'' he went on. ''It's possible that we might help someone incorporate a company - and then maybe they would use the company for something else.
''The fact is, I'm not sure of everybody I do legal work for, but I do try to avoid shady characters.''
According to a presidential spokesman, Louis Martinez, Mr. Endara remains a partner of the firm, but suspended his working relationship at the beginning of the political campaign last year. ''He will not be returning until he leaves public office,'' the spokesman said.
 
A Close Friend And an Atlanta Arrest
 Mr. Endara said he remained ''close friends'' with Carlos Eleta, a wealthy Panamanian businessman who was arrested in Atlanta last April on charges that he conspired to set up a major cocaine smuggling ring. He was released on bail pending his trial.
People here who know Mr. Eleta remain puzzled by his arrest, saying that the idea of drug smuggling seems totally out of character for him. Some Panamanians, like Guillermo Sanchez Borbon, political columnist for the daily La Prensa, suggest that he may even have been set up by General Noriega or people close to him.
''Carlos Eleta is a friend, but we have nothing in common with him in the sense that we are not partners with him in anything, anything that I know of,'' Mr. Endara said, ''although he may have shares in some company that I might have shares in.
''He's a friend, but I have many friends in Panama.''
The law firm's current clients, Mr. Endara said, include a cross-section of major Panamanian companies.
''We're not a big firm,'' Mr. Endara said. ''In addition to the partners, we have another lawyer and some secretaries. In all, 12 people working in the office.''
Asked whether he had felt apprehensive about being offered the presidential nomination last year, Mr. Endara sighed heavily. ''I was not apprehensive, I was surprised,'' he said. ''I had not sought this nomination.
''A group of politicians felt that somebody representing Dr. Arias - his prestige, his authority with the masses - should be on the ticket.''
Nearly two years after his death in Miami at the age of 86, Dr. Arias - or simply ''Arnulfo,'' as Panamanians commonly refer to him - still exerts an eerie gravitational pull on public life here.
After Dr. Arias's young widow, Mireyea, turned down repeated offers that she run for the presidency as the candidate of the National Civic Crusade, Mr. Endara said, the job was thrust upon him. He says he accepted it philosophically.
''I remember Dr. Arias always saying to me and to others that responsibilities for the country were things that came upon oneself by force of destiny.
''It's sort of like karma. You know about karma? I'm not an Orientalist, I'm not a Buddhist, I'm not anything like that. But I've read books, and I learned that karma was something that you have to accept. I was surprised, but I felt an obligation to do my best, to finish the work of my teacher, my maestro, my mentor. And that is still my thought here.''
Mr. Sanchez Borbon of La Prensa said he believed that whatever his political skills, Mr. Endara's easy-going ways might be exactly what the country wanted right now.
''After all the horror we've had, I think he is a good choice,'' Mr. Sanchez Borbon said. ''He's a very humble man, very placid - anything but charismatic. But he may surprise people.''
 
A New Friendship And a New Life
 Some would say he already has. A few weeks ago, Mr. Endara was observed in a booth of the Marriott Hotel coffee shop with a dark-haired young woman who, reporters agreed, was definitely not Marcelita, his 26-year-old married daughter.
Soon after the much-talked-about sighting, Mr. Endara announced that he was dating the woman, 24-year-old Ana Mae Diaz. He has been a widower since June, when his wife, Marcela, died of a heart attack, a month after the abortive May 7 elections that were followed by street clashes in which her husband was beaten by paramilitary toughs.
Mr. Endara and Miss Diaz had met in September, when she went to visit him during his two-week hunger strike against the Noriega Government. At the time, Mr. Endara, who says he lost 30 of his 265 pounds on the liquid-only diet, was usually flat on his back on a hospital bed in the window of a downtown office building, where skeptics could see for themselves that he wasn't eating.
''We're still getting to know each other,'' the President was quoted as saying of Miss Diaz this week.
That is a good description, many Panamanians say, of the relationship between Mr. Endara and the people of this close-knit country of 2.4 million as it struggles to reconstitute itself as a independent civilian democracy.
''In essence, I really don't care what reputation I acquire,'' President Endara said, sounding a bit like his beloved mentor. ''What is important to me is to do my duty to the Panamanian people, to act in their interest and according to their will.''

HEADLINE: Nicaragua Approaches an Election That May Rise or Fall on Its Fairness

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Jan. 27

 BODY:
With less than a month to go before Nicaragua's elections, leaders of the governing Sandinista Front and their opponents are entering the final phase of what all sides say will be a decisive referendum on a decade of Sandinista rule.
Sandinista leaders say the elections, scheduled for Feb. 25, will prove the legitimacy of their revolutionary effort and help them rebuild Nicaragua after years of civil war. Their opponents, also convinced that the moment is right, are expecting the repudiation of a system they say has brought their country to the brink of ruin.
And for the hundreds of diplomats, observers and other dignitaries who will monitor the voting, the key test will come in the election process itself. After a decade of warfare, they say, the election's success will be measured not by its outcome but by its fairness and the willingness of both sides to accept the results. 
''The electoral process serves to pave the way for national reconciliation,'' said Angelica Hunt, spokeswoman for the 200-member United Nations team assigned to observe the vote. ''However divided the country may be, the elections start the process of burying the hatchet.''
 
A Toss-Up, Many Say
Most experts consider the vote a toss-up. Opinion polls have produced widely varying portraits of the country's diverse, divided electorate.
But after some initial violence, campaign rallies and organizing efforts are now proceeding smoothly. And many diplomats and other foreign specialists are hoping that the process will produce quick, tangible improvements in the country's situation, whichever side wins.
If the elections are widely perceived as fair, they assert, they could be expected to put an end to the civil war, either by removing the rationale for any further American aid to the contras or by removing the Government that the rebels oppose. Such a result, the diplomats and specialists say, would also permit foreign countries, presumably including the United States, to normalize relations with Nicaragua on the assumption that the Government had popular support.
''The most important thing is to show the will of the Nicaraguan people,'' said Alfonso Lopez Michelsen, a former President of Colombia who is here as an election observer.
 
Leaders on Display
In the bright billboards and colorful ads that have sprung up in even the most remote villages, the campaign has centered on the two major presidential candidates: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, who is seeking re-election from the Sandinista National Liberation Front, and Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, from the 14-party National Opposition Union.
Mr. Ortega, 44 years old, has abandoned the uniform and stern bearing of his early years in office and is now shown jogging and hugging babies. Images of Mrs. Chamorro, a 60-year-old widow, have stressed the sacrifices of her husband, Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, the most famous victim of the struggle against the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
Picturing Sandinista leaders as disciples of a failed Marxist ideal, the opposition leaders have focused their attacks on Nicaragua's sharp economic decline. Government statistics show that in more than 10 years of Sandinista rule, the Nicaraguan economy has shrunk by half. Since 1981, private consumption has fallen by 70 percent, and real wages, eroded by inflation, are more than 90 percent lower, forcing large numbers of people into serious poverty and leaving many unable to afford more than one or two meals a day.
''In any other country in the world,'' a European diplomat said, ''an incumbent government would not have a prayer of re-election with this kind of economic situation.''
 
Managua Sees U.S. Instigation
Government leaders, who say they have now stabilized the crisis, say it was created by the contra war and by a United States trade embargo, rather than mismanagement or official policy. In recent weeks, Government economists announced that annual inflation in 1989 had fallen to 1,700 percent, down from 36,000 percent in 1988.
And Sandinista strategists have used their economic battles with the United States as part of a broader national campaign against Mrs. Chamorro, whom they describe as a stalking horse for Yankee imperialism.
They have relentlessly attacked her coalition, saying it has connections to the contras and to the Somoza dictatorship. The opposition leadership includes several well-known former contra officials, and the Sandinistas have accused dozens more of hiding their contra connections or membership in Mr. Somoza's widely despised National Guard. And they have accused the estimated 3,000 contras still inside Nicaragua of waging a war of ''armed propaganda'' on behalf of Mrs. Chamorro.
Those nationalist themes were sharply underscored on Nov. 1, when President Ortega announced that the Government was suspending a 19-month cease-fire with the contra army because of what he described as a rebel plan to disrupt the elections.
And they were further highlighted after the United States invasion of Panama, when the Government mobilized troops throughout the country. The Defense Minister, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, declared that the Government would execute local opposition figures, presumably including leaders of the opposition coalition, if the United States made any attempt to extend its intervention to Nicaragua.
 
'84 Withdrawal Recalled
Sandinista officials have also asserted that opposition leaders are considering withdrawing from the campaign, as they did in a 1984 election under what the opponents said was pressure from the Reagan Administration.
Most anti-Sandinista leaders still assert that the conditions of the 1984 vote made a victory by the opposition impossible. But many say the decision to withdraw was an error that, by cutting off any anti-Sandinista political option, thrust the nation into the worst years of the contra war. And all the principal opposition leaders say they are determined to follow the current campaign through to the end.
The coalition ''is firm and is not going to withdraw,'' Mrs. Chamorro declared flatly in a recent interview at her Managua home.
Perhaps the most controversial issue in the election campaign thus far has been the Bush Administration's decision to send $9 million in aid to help the opposition's political campaign. Sandinista leaders have seized on the aid as proof that Mrs. Chamorro's coalition is a ''rented opposition,'' and have alleged that as much as $30 million more has reached opposition parties through secret channels over the last five years.
 
Sandinista Predominance So Far
But the majority of the United States aid, which under Nicaraguan law must be split between the opposition coalition and Government bodies administering the vote, has still not reached Nicaragua. And diplomats and foreign experts agree that the great bulk of campaign spending and advertising so far has been by the Sandinista Front.
''The perception abroad is that the opposition is the one with the money,'' said an envoy whose country has been neutral in the long contra war. ''But one look out on the streets will tell you that it's just the opposite.''
Although Sandinista leaders generally dismiss the possibility of an opposition victory, they have stated that they will accept the verdict of the voters, and hand over control of the government if they should lose. Opposition leaders, as well, have publicly committed themselves to abiding by the outcome of the election.
As provided in a February 1988 Central American peace accord, the voting process will be supervised by the United Nations and the Organization of American States, each of which will field approximately 200 trained election observers on voting day. That effort will be augmented by separate, officially accredited monitoring groups from several countries and a team of dignitaries led by former President Jimmy Carter.
Under Nicaraguan law, all citizens 16 and older, including military personnel, may participate in the elections. In a four-week registration period in October, 1.7 million people, or more than 90 percent of those eligible, signed up to vote, according to Government figures.

HEADLINE: Jennifer A. Leahy To Marry in April

 BODY:
Jennifer Anne Leahy, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Vincent Francis Leahy of Newton, Mass., and Ronald Joseph Kim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hyung Kim of Glens Falls, N.Y., plan to be married in April.
The prospective bride, 29 years old, is a senior account executive at Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass. She graduated from the Newton Country Day School and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. Her father is a judge of the Middlesex Probate Court in Cambridge, Mass.
The prospective bridegroom, 30, an associate in the Boston law firm of Goodwin Proctor & Hoar, graduated from Colgate University and received a master's degree in international political economy from the University of Chicago. He received a J.D. degree from Fordham University. His father is a surgeon at Glens Falls Hospital.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jennifer Leahy

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Swarthmore;
Students Forgo Part of Vacation To Study Diversity

DATELINE: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

 BODY:
More than 100 students voluntarily cut short their winter vacations to join a workshop at Swarthmore College last weekend intended to promote tolerance for diversity on and off campus.
Called ''Exploring a World of Difference,'' the workshop was held primarily to prevent serious incidents of discrimination.
''We wanted to take on issues that are important to the college community and not wait for an incident,'' said Eva Travers, the associate dean. 
Janet Dickerson, the college's dean, said the weekend was also ''a means for people to focus on their personal assumptions and identities.'' She said it is ''part of a larger program to provide a context for students to acquire a deeper understanding of themselves and a greater appreciation for their potential role in society.''
Participants began the two-day workshop with films on racism and homophobia. In groups of 15 to 20, they engaged in role playing and other exercises through which they examined destructive uses of language and their own assumptions and stereotypes about people.
 
A Diverse Staff
The workshop explored several dimensions of diversity, including race, gender, socio-economic class, handicaps and sexual orientation, but always at the personal level.
''Through social conditioning and lack of exposure to equal contact with people who are different, many are not trained to see, analyze and figure out the impact of their actions,'' said Thomas A. Gordon, director of Interface Associates, a private consulting firm hired to conduct the workshop. He said an effort was made to show that diversity can be an asset rather than a liability.
Reaction from workshop participants has been largely positive.
''I was excited to have an opportunity to talk about my background,'' said Charissa Ahlstrom, a sophomore from New York City who described her background as Christian.
Heather Hill, a sophomore from Glastonbury, Conn., said the workshop helped her accomplish her goal of ''making people who are different from me feel comfortable and feel that I am not putting them on the spot.''
About half of the paricipants met last week to discuss ways to continue what the weekend had started. Some of the small groups have also started meeting to explore issues of discrimination. Many students expressed interest in educating others and promoting institutional changes, including requiring all students to take a course on diversity.
''There was a sense of real energy and individual growth that came out of the workshop,'' Ms. Travers said. ''The question now is how much of that energy is going to result in systemic changes or ongoing discussions.''
How much of that energy results in similar activities campuswide, Ms. Dickerson said, depends largely on the budget. She said preliminary estimates put the cost of the workshop at about $25,000, which was paid out of the president's discretionary fund.
