HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Can the Old Spirit Of the MTM Studio Be Recaptured?

BYLINE: By NEAL KOCH; Neal Koch is a senior editor of Channels magazine.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Television viewers may soon wonder if their favorite kitten has returned home. By spring, MTM Entertainment, whose meowing logo became synonymous with quality programming in the 1970's through the mid-80's, will, after a fallow period, have new shows on each of the big three commercial networks.
Having its premiere tomorrow night at 8:30 on CBS is ''City,'' starring Valerie Harper as a city manager in Ms. Harper's first MTM show since ''Rhoda'' ended in 1978. ABC has tentatively scheduled for a March launch ''Capital News,'' an hourlong drama centered around journalists at a Washington newspaper; David Milch, former co-executive producer of ''Hill Street Blues,'' is one of the series' creators. Also in March, NBC will put on its schedule ''FM,'' a half-hour sitcom set in a public-broadcasting radio station, which had a short run on that network last year; its creators include Allan Burns of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''Rhoda'' and Dan Wilcox and Burt Metcalfe of ''M*A*S*H.''
These shows will join MTM's ''Newhart,'' now in its eighth season on CBS. This fall, MTM plans to launch a syndication division that will offer original programming, starting with a cooking show featuring Graham Kerr, the former ''Galloping Gourmet.'' 
At MTM, ''morale is enormously high,'' says James Gatward, chairman and acting chief executive, as well as chief executive of TVS Entertainment, the British broadcasting company that purchased MTM in 1988.
Nevertheless, Hollywood insiders caution viewers against getting their hopes up too high. The old MTM, or at least its distinctive spirit, they say, is gone. In part, it's the victim of the changing economics of television that are squeezing many small studios. But to a larger extent, its disappearance is the story of how a former talent agent and personal manager and an attorney took a creatively driven company and endangered its financial health by weakening the soul of what once may have been Hollywood's most sought-after workplace for writers.
''Those men created an atmosphere of suspicion, mistrust, anger,'' says the writer/producer Stephen Bochco, who was fired from MTM in 1985 and later sued over his ''Hill Street Blues'' earnings. ''They behaved despicably. And my guess is that they don't even perceive it as such. I simply don't think there was, in a business sense, any ethical center to the company.''
The men - Arthur Price, chief executive and president, who left last fall after the company's projected financial loss was disclosed, and Mel Blumenthal, senior executive vice president - deny any lapses or insensitivities that have alienated talent, though they admit to more hard-nosed tactics than were previously employed by the company. To the contrary, they argue, MTM may be on the verge of unprecedented success.
Not everyone agrees. For instance, Mr. Milch of ''Capitol News'' is expected to leave for a rival studio, Columbia, when his contract ends in a few weeks, and this is probably the last season for ''Newhart.'' Moreover, studio morale suffered late last year when TVS-directed cost-cutting chopped the list of writer-producer teams under contract to 15 from 22 and eliminated the jobs of some senior staff members.
Before its decline, MTM was by many accounts the closest Hollywood has come to Camelot in recent years. In the 1970's, the studio turned out a raft of lighthearted, sophisticated character comedies for television, including ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''The Bob Newhart Show.'' Later, it drew devoted audiences with such multilayered dramas as ''Hill Street Blues'' and ''St. Elsewhere.'' All this was possible, say many MTM alumni and their associates, because the small, privately held shop was built around the love and respect for writers that Grant Tinker, the company's president, became known for.
For a time ''it was Valhalla for a writer,'' says Jay Tarses, creator of ''The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd'' and ''The 'Slap' Maxwell Story'' and co-creator of ''Buffalo Bill.'' Mr. Tarses left MTM in 1978.
Recalls Mr. Bochco, whose other shows have included ''L.A. Law'' and ''Doogie Howser, M.D.,'' ''We would always find an excuse to wander up to the [administration building's] fourth floor once a day, because Grant was this wonderful, easygoing guy who was the touchstone for us all.''
By several accounts, when Mr. Tinker, his then-wife Mary Tyler Moore and Mr. Price, the actress's business manager, began building MTM in 1970 to do ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' Mr. Tinker declared that their main goal should be to have fun. If that aim ever eluded them, he added, they should fold their tent.
So, MTM pioneered the practice of putting writers in control of their own creations by making them producers. Many writers worked in a two-story building on MTM's intimate campuslike lot in the San Fernando Valley, wandering in and out of each other's shows, offering jokes and making suggestions. If a show failed and writers turned glum, Mr. Tinker was known to remind them that mankind did not hang in the balance - it was only television, he would say, and then move on to ask about their ideas for their next show.
As word about that approach spread and the quality of the programs became apparant, promising but inexperienced talents sought out MTM, where Mr. Tinker was often willing to nurture them. For instance, Hugh Wilson, who would later create the series ''The Famous Teddy Z,'' ''Frank's Place'' and ''WKRP in Cincinnati,'' gave up the presidency of an Atlanta advertising agency to work for $200 a week at MTM.
But with success in the late 1970's the studio grew larger and less intimate. At the same time, others caught on to what Mr. Tinker was doing. In 1977, Paramount, one of the largest studios, raided the core of Mr. Tinker's comedy shop. It offered the writers the opportunity to do movies, as well as much larger ownership rights in the TV shows they created. Paramount lured away James L. Brooks, Ed. Weinberger (who whimsically uses a period after his first name), Stan Daniels and Dave Davis, who together then created ''Taxi.'' Others followed, including Gary David Goldberg; his series ''Family Ties,'' produced at Paramount, is expected to earn him between $70 million and $100 million.
Although a drain of MTM's talent had begun, the studio's reputation still attracted new writers, such as Mr. Bochco and Bruce Paltrow, co-executive producer of ''St. Elsewhere,'' who were eager to break television's tired conventions.
But then in 1981, Mr. Tinker left to run NBC. ''Suddenly,'' says Mr. Bochco, ''there appeared on every office door on the fourth floor one of those electric door closers, and suddenly all the doors were closed.''
A mood of complacency set in. Despite the emergence of few new hits to replace the studio's past successes, Mr. Price and Mr. Blumenthal did relatively little to recruit fresh talent. ''MTM had been so used to writers coming to them,'' says Hugh Wilson, ''I guess they just presumed - or hoped - they'd just keep showing up.''
But they didn't. Moreover, relationships between the writers already at MTM and the fourth floor, which housed the executive offices, worsened. In 1985, Mr. Price fired Mr. Bochco after taking personally their strong differences of opinion, according to Mr. Price and others. More recently, MTM declined to pick up its option on Mr. Paltrow's contract. MTM executives say it was because of the failure in 1988 of Mr. Paltrow's series ''Tattinger's,'' and his desire to do another drama that they didn't consider sufficiently commercial. Mr. Paltrow disagrees, saying, ''It was personal. They resented me because I felt they behaved unethically.'' Ms. Moore, the only founder of MTM to retain a financial interest in the studio through her holdings in TVS, says that some firings were necessary because, in her words, the ''near autonomy'' given the studio's writers ''seems to have gotten out of hand.''
Distrust spread among the writers, several of whom claim that financial dealings with MTM became distressing. Although Mr. Price and Mr. Blumenthal deny it, some writers and their agents say that they found it extremely difficult to obtain profit statements on series in which the writers held interests - a problem common at some other studios but unexpected at MTM.
''My business manager has many times requested profit statements on 'St. Elsewhere,' and we've gotten nothing,'' says Mr. Paltro. ''The pattern was that they would do terrible things and when you called them on it, they would get outraged. It was sick.''
In response, Mr. Blumenthal says, ''Bruce has gotten profit participation statements on every show he's had profit participation in.''
Regardless, the atmosphere, particularly in money matters, often became rancorous. ''It just wasn't pleasant doing business with them,'' says Franklin Rohner, a Los Angeles lawyer who represents several prominent writer-producers, including Mr. Bochco, for whom he says he had to go to court to inspect MTM's accounting books. Mr. Bochco eventually obtained a settlement.
Perhaps most sorely felt was the lack of Mr. Tinker's personal touch. For instance, Mr. Tinker - who declined to be interviewed for this article - used to accompany his writers into dreaded meetings with network executives, who typically second-guess the writers' script and casting choices. Mr. Tinker went along to throw his weight behind his writers. ''The times he felt you had been wronged creatively,'' says Mr. Goldberg, ''he was a bear.'' The much shyer Mr. Price hired subordinates to handle such tasks. MTM's fortunes suffered. By the 1987-88 season, the studio's executives began to question whether they had lost the ability to put shows on the air, and the company was sold. An uneasy feeling spread among some in Hollywood's creative community when veteran employees, officers of MTM, and even Mr. Tinker, didn't share in any of the $320 million in proceeds. (To avoid any conflicts of interest, Mr. Tinker had sold his share in the studio after joining NBC.) Instead, the money was split among Mr. Price, Mr. Blumenthal, Ms. Moore and, to a lesser extent, one other executive, Thomas Palmieri.
Now MTM finds itself in both creative and financial difficulties, having lost roughly $11.7 million in fiscal 1989 and projecting another loss for this year. Nevertheless, Mr. Price and Mr. Blumenthal acknowledge only minor changes in MTM's work atmosphere under their leadership. They attribute the frictions that did develop with some of the creative talent to a harsher industry economic environment and to misperceptions.
Mr. Price contends that in substance he's been just as supportive of talent as Mr. Tinker, and a few writers agree. ''The tone of the company hasn't changed, I don't think, from its start,'' says Allan Burns, who has been at MTM from its inception, ''or I wouldn't be here.''
The perceptual problem, Mr. Price contends, arises from his inability to shake his earlier role as head of MTM business affairs, when, he says, Mr. Tinker cast him as the bad cop to Mr. Tinker's good cop. That's a typical Hollywood management style aimed at maintaining a creative executive's ability - despite hard-nosed handling of business affairs - to lure talent back for the next dance. ''All the good news comes from me,'' Mr. Price quotes Mr. Tinker as once telling him. ''All the bad news comes from you.''
Under Mr. Tinker, says Mr. Price, ''we were perceived as a very paternalistic company, and Grant was perceived as the padrone. I held on to as much of it as I could,'' Mr. Price adds with evident mixed emotions. But, ''with the press, nobody is as good as Grant. I was envious.''
Mr. Price and Mr. Blumenthal say they were also the victims of increasingly difficult industry economics. Paramount began bidding up the price of writers in the late 1970's, about the same time that network fees paid to studios for their shows began falling behind soaring increases in studio production costs. For instance, when ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' had its premiere in 1970, CBS paid MTM about $18,000 per episode, more than it cost to make the show, according to Mr. Price. Today, a half-hour situation comedy can run $150,000 in the red per episode. ''It's very easy to be gracious when on the [American] network run you're walking out with $20,000 profit,'' says Mr. Price, ''and then you have Canadian runs and foreign runs.''
Mr. Gatward, a former soap-opera director, says he's committed to making quality shows. But he is under considerable pressure from stockholders at home in England who now question whether he overpaid for MTM. Following TVS's announcement last September of MTM's expected loss for 1989, TVS's stock fell 26 percent. At the time, Mr. Gatward was already moving to mollify stockholders by accumulating capital for a bid to retain TVS's lucrative broadcasting license in the United Kingdom when it will be auctioned off in 1991, under Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's privatization program.
So, he slapped ceilings on the budgets of new MTM series programming, introduced the cooking show, laid off employees and hopes to start making 12 Movies of the Week annually to spread the studio's expensive overhead. And he's looking for a new studio chief - as well as a major investor willing to pump in cash in return for up to 49 percent of MTM.
Even critics concede that MTM might prosper again, but for now, observes Mr. Bochco, ''MTM's mandate is different. It's no longer a closely held boutique.''
''It may be,'' adds Mr. Goldberg, ''that MTM as Camelot could only exist in a time of more innocence.''

HEADLINE: How 'Annie 2' Skidded Off a Bumpy Road To Broadway

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
The sun came out on Monday morning, Nov. 6, 1989, and so did the reporters and television news crews, for the first day of rehearsal of ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge.'' The $7 million musical continuation of ''Annie,'' which was one of the most successful shows in Broadway history, had been announced with much hoopla in June, and anticipation was high.
Even before this first day, the show had received enormous nationwide attention: attention based on ''Annie,'' which had opened on Broadway in 1977 and closed in 1983 after 2,377 performances. ''Annie'' had cost $800,000 and had made a profit of $20 million, including a $9.5 million movie sale, not bad for a musical about a comic-strip orphan. Many people believed that ''Annie 2'' could be just as profitable, and the interest and publicity it was receiving did little to engender any doubts.
What was to happen in the next three months, however, would provide a classic example of how difficult it is to try to create a hit Broadway musical. Events would clearly illustrate that there is no sure thing, that what looks fantastic in small scale at a backers' audition in someone's living room may not work on a stage in front of a large audience. 
Events would also reflect Broadway history: that the most experienced creators can still come up with a bomb. Even the best - Rodgers and Hammerstein, Stephen Sondheim - have written shows that failed critically, financially, or both.
The members of the ''Annie 2'' team have, among them, hundreds of years of experience in the theater. Many had worked on ''Annie.'' They include Martin Charnin, the show's director and lyricist; Dorothy Loudon, reprising her role as Miss Hannigan, Annie's archenemy; Thomas Meehan, who wrote the book; Charles Strouse, the composer, who also worked on ''Bye, Bye Birdie'' and ''Applause''; David Mitchell, the scenic designer; Theoni V. Aldredge, the costume designer; and Lewis Allen, one of the producers. Harve Presnell, who has the part of Daddy Warbucks, wasn't the original (Reid Shelton was), but he played the role on Broadway for hundreds of performances. ''Annie'' won the Tony Award for best musical in 1977, and Mr. Charnin, Ms. Loudon, Mr. Meehan, Mr. Strouse, Mr. Mitchell and Ms. Aldredge also garnered Tonys for their work.
The schedule for ''Annie 2'' called for six weeks of rehearsals, with preview performances beginning at the Kennedy Center Opera House in Washington on Dec. 22. The New York opening was set for March 1 at the Marriott Marquis Theater. Previews in New York were to begin Feb. 5.
They won't. On Jan. 15, after disastrous Washington reviews, hundreds of changes in the script and the score, and thousands of words of advice from friends and colleagues, the producers announced that ''Annie 2'' would not be coming to Broadway this season.
Work is to continue on the show and a revised version is to be tried out in late spring or early summer at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn. The idea, the producers say, is to bring a new version of the musical to Broadway in late fall or early winter. They are facing heavy odds: few if any shows have canceled a scheduled Broadway opening and then made it to Broadway the next season.
The producers said on Jan. 15 that they hoped to bring a revival of the original ''Annie'' to Broadway in the spring, but eight days later, they announced that plans for the revival had been delayed. Many productions close out of town before reaching Broadway, but few have the advance publicity of ''Annie 2.'' This is the story of what went wrong: the hard-knock life of ''Annie 2.''
 
No Sequel or Prequel But a 'Continuation'
 ''It's a very heartening moment,'' Mr. Charnin says that early November morning in a rehearsal studio at 890 Broadway, just before the cast begins to pose for photographs and answer questions from the press. ''The first time 'Annie' surfaced, back in 1976, at the Goodspeed Opera House, there was one lady who took a Polaroid - which didn't come out.''
The road to success for the original ''Annie'' was not an easy one. It had its problems out of town. But between Goodspeed and its opening in 1977 many changes were made. And when it opened in Washington, it was an instant hit; it was an even bigger hit in New York.
Plans for ''Annie 2'' were first announced by Mr. Charnin in 1982, when the original ''Annie'' was still running, with the hope of opening on Broadway in 1983. He also mentioned the idea on stage the night that ''Annie'' closed. Those plans were delayed, but finally, last June, ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge'' was announced. It would not be a sequel the producers said; it would be a continuation, beginning six weeks after ''Annie'' ended, with Miss Hannigan in prison plotting revenge.
Media response was immediate. At the open auditions for the new Annie in New York in September there were almost as many reporters and photographers as little girls. When the young actress - 11-year-old Danielle Findley of Lee's Summit, Mo. - was chosen, not from the open calls but from a private audition held later, she soon found her face on the cover of Life magazine.
The producers put their belief in the show into a huge, enormously expensive advertising campaign. But by the middle of this month, the advance was only $3.7 million - which may sound like a lot but pales beside the $19 million for ''Phantom of the Opera'' and translates into perhaps six or seven weeks of tickets.
 
A Script Marked 'Confidential'
 Mr. Charnin gathers everyone around a piano, and for the first time the cast sings the new show's theme song, the song everyone hopes will be for ''Annie 2'' what ''Tomorrow'' was for ''Annie'':
''When you smile, I smile,'' they sing. ''Your smile makes my smile.'' Everyone is smiling. It is the afternoon now, and time for the first reading of the script, which many cast members have not seen. They are handed a large, red-covered volume with the word ''Confidential'' on it. The press is gone except for two reporters who are pledged to silence, for now. ''There is a secret in the thing,'' Mr. Charnin says. ''It's very important that this little trick not be talked about, not be given away.''
He begins with a warning. ''Musicals are still excruciatingly difficult to do. They are still handmade, molecule by molecule, joke by joke, step by step.'' But then he adds that he is optimistic. ''We're very liked in Washington. I have a feeling we'll take Washington by storm.''
No one in the room knows, of course, that by the time the show closes in Washington on Jan. 20, each of the script's 145 pages will have been changed.
The plot, in brief: The curtain rises on the Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village, with Miss Hannigan in prison scheming for revenge. She soon escapes during a fire. Meanwhile, Congresswoman Marietta Christmas tells Warbucks it is illegal for an unmarried man to adopt an 11-year-old girl and unless he marries she will see to it that Annie is removed from his custody. He decides to hold a contest for a wife - any single woman interested in a bald, middle-aged man with protruding ears and $900 million is eligible. Miss Hannigan reads about the contest and decides to disguise herself and try to win.
The secret? Miss Hannigan discovers another orphan, who looks just like Annie and who will be trained to take over when Miss Hannigan pulls a switch. The fake Annie will choose Miss Hannigan as her mother.
Even before the end comes in Washington, Scene 1 will no longer exist; Miss Hannigan will never be in prison. It will be revealed that after ''Annie'' ended, Warbucks gave Miss Hannigan a one-way steamer ticket to Argentina. In Scene 2, we will learn that she has jumped ship and is back in New York plotting her revenge.
After the reading, a few small doubts are expressed. One of the show's producers says there is not enough Annie. Someone else wonders why there are no orphans. It's not that kind of show, the members of the creative team say. It's not a repeat of ''Annie.'' The thought is that this show must be more sophisticated, must have more appeal for adults, in order to succeed. That, they will say later, was their first mistake.
 
Speaking Openly, Behind Closed Doors
 ''I did not want to do this show,'' says Charles Strouse, the musical's composer, ''as I did not want to do the first one. I didn't want this to be a piece that was just an expression of greed.'' It is Nov. 17, a week later, and Mr. Strouse is sitting behind a closed door in a small room off the rehearsal studio and expressing the first real doubts anyone has spoken of openly. He is afraid of what the critics and his peers on Broadway will say. ''It's not a musical in which characters discuss their psychological underpinnings,'' he says. ''And I feel as though a lot of people are going to ask, 'Where have you been for the last 45 years?'
''We had a free ride in two ways on 'Annie,' '' he says. ''I think it was a good show. But we had 10 weeks to work on it in a very economical situation, at the Goodspeed Opera House. The even bigger free ride was that it was the end of the Watergate era. The week we opened there was an editorial in a New Mexico newspaper that said last night on Broadway a jaded New York audience leaped to its feet when a little girl, instead of taking off her clothes and saying four-letter words, said, 'I love you, Daddy.' I believe we were helped very much by the feeling that people all over the country wanted to say that it's a new time.'' He sighs. ''I don't know whether that's in the air now.''
Later that day, Thomas Meehan, the author of the show's book, is in the same room. Mr. Meehan, a former writer for The New Yorker, is subdued and soft-spoken. He, too, has his doubts.
''I think it's a risky enterprise,'' he says. ''We're certainly going to get a lot of people who say we're just trying to cash in.'' But Mr. Meehan likes what he has done so far and he adds that he does not think the show is just ''a lollipop - Martin and Charles and I, we're all very political.'' One number, he says, expresses that feeling. It's called ''One Tough Town.'' ''To me,'' he says, ''it's a very important song. Even though the show is set in 1934, the song is really about New York now, which is one tough town.''
Mr. Meehan knows there is much work in store for him. The out-of-town schedule is crazy, he says. You rehearse all day, do the show at night, have a meeting after the show for an hour or two, get up in the morning and start to write. ''People always say it's a nightmare to be out of town. But it's not. I like it.''
Dorothy Loudon is on a break. ''This time there's a lot more responsibility on me,'' Ms. Loudon says. In the original ''Annie,'' she had two numbers. The responsibility is worrying her. ''I'm not getting very much sleep,'' she says. ''I wake up at night sort of screaming.''
 
The Stories Audiences Tell
 It is Dec. 12. In two days, the company leaves for Washington and the first performance on Dec. 22. A number has been cut: ''One Tough Town,'' the one Mr. Meehan felt was important. ''Martin walked in the other day and said it was out,'' Mr. Meehan says, ''and as soon as he said it, it was like a light. Because it doesn't serve the show. And now we feel it's flowing just right.'' Mr. Charnin will leave for Washington a day before everyone else. ''It's ready to go,'' he says. ''The audience, of course, may ultimately tell me a whole other story.''
Disaster. The audience has ultimately told another story. Fifteen minutes into the first preview, those involved in the show agree, they all knew that everything was wrong. There is too much Miss Hannigan and very little Annie. The idea that Miss Hannigan would kidnap Annie and plan to kill her, which was not meant to be taken seriously, is now largely viewed as inappropriate.
That night was the first time anyone had seen the complete show on stage with all the sets and costumes. The loading of the scenery had taken longer than expected, and many of the costumes were late, so there was no full dress rehearsal.
The reaction is almost immediate. The official opening night is postponed a week, from Dec. 28 to Jan. 4. About 20 minutes are cut. The first two scenes are switched - the play now opens in Warbucks's offices with a song about 1934, instead of in prison with Miss Hannigan. A new song has been added for Annie called ''Changes,'' about how swiftly changes occur when you are young. It is generally considered one of the best things in the show. 'We Outsmarted Ourselves'
It is Thursday, Jan. 4, a few hours before the opening; the reviews will be out tonight, and everyone expects to be devastated. Mr. Charnin is sitting on a bench in the lobby of the Kennedy Center Opera House, and he is thinking of the last two weeks.
''Up until that first preview,'' he says, ''we - and I'm speaking for Charles and Tom and myself and all the producers - were putting on a show that was for our intellect, and our cynicism, and our supposed sophistication, as opposed to our heart and our spirit. We outsmarted ourselves.
''Because at the first preview there were 700 children in the audience who could not care less about this un-Annied ''Annie.'' Who came to re-experience, or to experience for the first time, this mythological thing that ran for decades in the comic strip. And by virtue of the fact that 700 kids were not having a wonderful time, the 700 sets of parents who came to see their kids have a wonderful time were not having a wonderful time. And there were no real warnings along the way. Nobody said anything.''
On Monday, he says, he is going to New York to audition young girls to play the orphans - Annie's friends from the orphanage are going to come to the mansion. ''She wouldn't have abandoned them,'' he says.
Mr. Charnin is very concerned about the reviews. ''There's only so much you can do,'' he says. ''This musical has not found its character yet. You're limited by the hours of rehearsal. And you're limited by how many brain cells you can produce that can come up with ideas.
''We can get creamed or we can get constructive reviews,'' he adds. ''I just want to be allowed not to act out of desperation.''
It is 11:30 that night, and the first review is in. It is not good. Or rather, it is awful. David Richards of The Washington Post says the show is ''preposterous.'' '' 'Annie' was a musical to take to your heart,'' he writes, ''but you'll want to take a paddle to 'Annie 2.'
''What was so disarming the first time around,'' he adds, ''has become witless and belabored.''
Other reviews will be the same, or worse. The print and television critics will react negatively to practically all elements of the show. The only praise will be for the costumes and sets. The scene is the opening-night party, at Duke Zeibert's restaurant in downtown Washington. Mr. Charnin has taken the Washington Post review into a stairwell to read in private. He returns, sipping a drink, and begins to talk. ''The review is accurate,'' he says. ''I think I would have been appalled had he decided in print that what we were doing didn't need to be worked on.''
The most unfortunate aspect of the review, he says, will be ''its impact on the company and on the audiences, because the audiences who read it are going to come in looking at it through the filter of the criticism.''
There is also the word-of-mouth on Broadway - ''many people on the street are going to be jumping up and down with glee,'' he says, ''thrilled that we got creamed, because that's the way things are on Broadway.''
Later in the evening, he will tell the cast that he was responsible, and the performers should not feel bad. He will say that he got them into the hole and that he and the rest of the creative team will get them out.
But now, he says, ''Never forget that you are talking to the man who wrote 'Tomorrow.' The sun will come out tomorrow. Bet your bottom dollar.''
 
Is There a Doctor In the House?
 It is just before noon the next morning, and the Opera House is practically deserted backstage except for a stagehand working with props. ''I hear Mike Nichols is coming to take over,'' he says.
The Mike Nichols rumor has been with the show since the problems began. Mr. Nichols was a producer of the original, and contributed much to that show. He will appear, but only to see a performance and offer brief advice.
Two hours later, Mr. Charnin is backstage rewriting and cutting. He will take 20 minutes more out of the show. This ebullient and optimistic man appears distracted. He thinks it is likely that the show will not open as planned on March 1 in New York. He needs at least two more weeks.
It is Jan. 15 and there have been many changes. Miss Hannigan has abandoned her distasteful talk of killing the orphan, though what she will do with Annie has been left up in the air. The orphans have been chosen and are about to take their place in Warbucks's mansion. The romance between Miss Hannigan and her partner in crime, played by Ronny Graham, has cooled to a friendship. The contest through which Warbucks was to choose a wife - a scene critics thought was absurd - has been deleted.
The review in the trade newspaper Variety has come out, and it, too, is not good: ''Almost every ingredient that made 'Annie' such a delight for both children and adults is missing.''
In addition to Mr. Nichols, among the friends who have come in at the invitation of the producers and Mr. Charnin are Tommy Tune and Peter Stone. The advice, the producers say, was simple: Go for the truth. ''Mike Nichols said that wherever you're true it's good, and wherever you're not it stinks,'' Mr. Meehan recalls.
Suddenly, late this afternoon, comes surprising news that will be reported all over the country. After hearing the advice and talking among themselves, the producers have decided not to bring the show to Broadway this season. It will close at the Kennedy Center after 36 performances.
Work is to continue and a revised version is to be tried out over the summer at Goodspeed. The producers say if things work well at Goodspeed, they hope to take the show to Broadway in the late fall or early winter.
They add that they want to bring a revival of the original ''Annie'' to Broadway in the spring and hope the investors will put the remaining $2 million of ''Annie 2'' 's $7 million toward it. (Eight days later, word will come that plans for the revival have been delayed. The producers also say they may add another out-of-town stop for ''Annie 2'' after Goodspeed.)
 
Decisionmakers In Velvet Dresses
 When the decision was made not to go to Broadway there were two who argued against it. ''Martin and I were the only ones who felt we could make the New York date,'' Mr. Meehan says, two days after the announcement. But there were other factors, he adds. ''I think Charles Strouse really thought he couldn't do it. He felt written out on the show.''
He pauses. ''I realize now that it was the biggest mistake to call it 'Miss Hannigan's Revenge' and focus on adults. The sense of disappointment here, when the little girls in their velvet dresses came to see Annie, and didn't see Annie, was unbelievable.
''We wanted to do a whole new show,'' he says. ''I think part of it was the feeling among all of us that maybe we were looked down upon by certain people in the theater, that in 'Annie' we'd done something just about orphans and dogs, and it was just for the money, and it was just for a child audience, it wasn't a serious show. So we said, we can write a real grownup show, too. And that's what we did. And we were really stupid.'' Mr. Strouse confirms Mr. Meehan's statement about his doubts. ''I told the producers that I felt myself not knowing what I wanted to do. I said I just did not understand the show.'' He says he is not certain he will rejoin the show at Goodspeed. He has a commitment to work on the musical ''Nick and Nora,'' which is scheduled to come to Broadway in the fall. ''I'm hoping I can work it out,'' he says.
''The thing that attracted everybody about 'Annie 2' originally was that we thought it was self-mocking, and mocking about the original 'Annie,' '' Mr. Strouse says. ''There was a kind of zaniness about it, like the Marx Brothers. We had gone through the sweetness and light thing about Annie, and now we were really sophisticated. The fact is, though, that when it was put on, instead of everybody laughing at ourselves, they found it mean-spirited. We had forgotten how much of a legend the original show had become.''
Later that afternoon, Mr. Charnin is sitting in the bar at the Terrace restaurant upstairs at the Kennedy Center, a drink in his hand and hope in his heart.
''It's ain't over,'' he says. ''This saga is going to 'sahg' for a while.''
 
A Very Expensive 'Workshop'
 It is Jan. 19, and back in New York the producers are talking about their role in what went wrong, and their role in the future of ''Annie 2.''
''What went wrong is one of those great mysteries,'' says Margo Lion. ''There's an article in The Times today about set design. It talks about how you see something on a perfectly bare stage, and there's this incredible magic. And then the set comes up around it, and sometimes the magic is gone.
''And that first night in Washington, we looked at each other and we thought, 'What is this?' It was like taking a miniature and blowing it up, and every flaw was so apparent.'' Roger Berlind believes ''the show is getting better rapidly.'' ''We could have come in to New York with an extended preview period,'' he says. ''And if I didn't think this show could get dramatically better, that might be what we would have done. But I still think this can turn into a megahit, and I want to give it a chance to do that.''
Lewis Allen says that, in retrospect, a key mistake was not planning a run in another city after Washington, before coming to New York. ''Doing that had been the original plan. But it cost so much, and the show was already so expensive, we decided we could do it with just one city.''
Now, Ms. Lion adds, the writers need to retrench. ''They learned a lot,'' she says, laughing. ''It was a very expensive workshop. I know that the cost of education has skyrocketed, but $5 million for one semester is a little much.''
It's over - at least for now. ''Annie 2'' closed in Washington on Saturday night, Jan. 20. Dorothy Loudon, who had been out sick, made it back for the last performance. It was sold out, standing-room only. There was at the end, as is usual on such occasions, a standing ovation.
It is early Sunday afternoon, and Ms. Loudon is talking by telephone from her room at the Watergate Hotel. She does not know what she will do about the summer run at Goodspeed, she says. ''It's so far away. It's hard for me to decide.'' She coughs. Her bronchitis has not completely gone away.
''I really had such high hopes for this,'' she says. ''Everybody did. And I'm just stunned. Stunned.''
It is Tuesday in New York. ''I stayed in Washington yesterday to kind of recover from the whole episode,'' Mr. Charnin says. ''I was feeling a little sorry for myself. I went into a coffee shop and had a cup of coffee, and when I came out there was this musician, looking a little shabby. He parked himself in front of the coffee shop, opened up a trumpet case and began playing.
''And what he was playing was 'Tomorrow.' I asked him if he played it often, and he said, 'Every chance I get.' And I said, 'I'm the guy who wrote that song.'
''So he introduced himself. And then he saw the 'Annie 2' T-shirt I was wearing, and he said, 'What happened, man?' ''
''And I proceeded to tell him, and he started to play 'Tomorrow' again, and then he stopped. And he told me it was going to be all right.''

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Big Quandary Over Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Like Blanche DuBois, the American capital system now finds itself dependent on the kindness - or at least the money - of strangers.
The fear that Japanese investors were not going to keep providing the cash was a big part of last week's sharp declines in the stock and bond markets. Worries over the shaky economy, and fears that the Federal Reserve finds itself in a quandary with no good options, also played a role in the Dow Jones industrial average's fall of 118.67 points, or 4.4 percent, to 2,559.23. It was the worst week for the index since it lost 7.8 percent in the week ending Oct. 13, and left the Dow at its lowest level since July. 
The Government's report on fourth-quarter economic growth showed that business was merely limping along as 1989 ended, a fact being discovered anew virtually each day on Wall Street as one profit disappointment follows another. So far, the fourth quarter is shaping up as the year's worst in that regard. Tom Doerflinger of Paine Webber calculates that just 9 percent of companies reporting so far are doing better than the consensus forecast a month into the quarter, while 41 percent produced negative surprises.
What kept economic growth positive in the final three months of the year was not consumer demand. That was lower. Nor was any help provided from the trade deficit, which worsened. The secret of economic growth in the fourth quarter was that businesses built up inventory, perhaps because they were having trouble finding buyers, and consumers spent more money heating their homes in an unusually cold December.
Government officials rushed to say the weakness shown by real growth, at an annual rate of 0.5 percent, was only temporary, and that things would improve by the middle of the year. But traders are dubious about that forecast.
The next big test for the bond markets will come with the Treasury's refunding next month. That is when Japanese buyers will be offered the chance to step up and buy bonds with the money they failed to spend last week on the 40-year bonds earmarked for the savings and loan bailout. With a dearth of buyers, the yield rose to 8.77 percent by week's end, from a surprisingly high 8.64 percent at Tuesday's offering. Thirty-year Treasuries topped 8.5 percent for the first time since June.
Rising interest rates around the world have helped to put the Fed in a bind. Easier credit is the recommended course for an economy sputtering along as this one seems to be. But pushing interest rates down could send needed capital fleeing to Europe and Asia, which are willing to pay more for money than they have in years. It is, as they say, a quandary.
For much of the 1980's, a key element in the bullish economy and the stock market was that recessions only came when the Fed decided they were needed, and that there was no reason the Fed would want one. Inflation is not so high that the Fed would want a recession now, but the fear is growing that in the new international world of investments and capital, the future depends on the kindness of foreigners, not of the Fed.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Waiting for the Fed's Next Move
The stock market is falling, interest rates are rising and the Federal Reserve seems afraid to budge. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 118.67 last week, to 2,559.23 - down 9 percent from a high of 2810.15 three weeks ago. It's no irrational panic - just a broad retreat based on rising interest rates, a weakening economy and falling profits. United States Government bond yields rose last week to the highest levels in more than six months. The Federal Reserve can't stoke the economy or the markets by easing credit as long as interest rates are rising abroad. The Government deficit requires huge, continuing investments from foreign countries, especially Japan. But a 40-year, $5 billion Government offering last week to help bail out the savings and loan industry attracted few buyers.
 
G.N.P. Doldrums
New evidence of a slack economy came from Friday's figures on the Gross National Product. The G.N.P. grew just five-tenths of 1 percent in the last quarter of 1989, the worst showing since the spring of 1986. True, Hurricane Hugo, the San Francisco earthquake and strikes at Boeing and Nynex all retarded growth. But only the production of cars that remained unsold kept the G.N.P. from going negative. 
 
Boost in Labor Costs?
Labor costs are likely to head higher as unions won their most generous contracts since 1982 last year. The Labor Department reported that major labor pacts reached in 1988 will raise wages 4 percent in the first year and 3.3 percent annually over the life of the contracts. Union members haven't done as well since their 1982 contracts gave them 3.6 percent annual increases. Overall, industry's labor costs rose 4.8 percent n 1989. Lacy Hunt, chief economist at Carroll McEntee & McGinley said a higher social security tax and minimum wage will boost labor costs more than 6 percent in 1990.
 
Gaining on the Deficit?
Lagging corporate research has put the nation's edge in high technology at risk. In 1989, spending on research and development fell behind inflation for the first time in 14 years. The takeover binge of the late 1980's has gotten much of the blame.
* President Bush has a new plan to encourage Americans to save. Special new accounts would pay interest tax-free, but the deposits themselves would not be deductible. The costs to the Government would be delayed - an advantage for an Administration straining to reduce the deficit.
 
Durable Durables?
Durable goods orders by factories rose a healthy 2.5 percent in December, after a strong gain in November as well. Some economists say that manufacturing has bottomed out. Rosanne Cahn, a First Boston economist, squares the durable goods figures with low G.N.P. growth by noting that the G.N.P. covers the whole quarter. ''My guess is, if you had monthly G.N.P. figures, they would have been worst at the end of the third quarter, the beginning of the fourth quarters,'' she said. ''As the quarter progressed, it got better.''
 
Presenting the Budget
President Bush is preparing to send Congress a $1.2 trillion budget proposal that would dramatically cut the Federal deficit, to about half its level in the current fiscal year. The idea is to cut military spending, hope for higher tax revenues from a prosperous economy and use the growing Social Security surplus to reduce the debt.
 
A Question of Conflict
Federal regulators said Friday they would file an administrative action against President Bush's son Neil, charging him with conflicts of interest while he was a director of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver.
 
COMPANIES
 
Earnings, More or Less
Of all companies, Merrill Lynch should know enough not to disappoint the analysts. But last Monday came a surprisingly large $470 million charge against earnings for consolidating offices, pruning operations and laying off as many as 3,200 employees. The quarterly loss was $361.8 million. For the full year, Merrill lost $213.4 million, in conrast with income of $463.2 million in 1988. William A. Schreyer, Merrill's cheif executive, said the company had made ''the right strtegic decisions.'' Merrill estimates the savings at about $100 million a year. Analysts douted the savings were large enough to justify the charge, which is the largest in the company's history. Moody's responded by cutting several of Merrill's debt raitngs and investors reacted by pushig the stock to new 52-week lows.
* Elsewhere on Wall Street, merchant banking profits helped raise Morgan Stanley Group Inc.'s quarterly earnings 37.2 percent to $148.6 million. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. earned only $3.5 million, better than the $13.5 million loss in the fourth quarter a year ago. Shearson's parent, American Express, gained 11.3 percent to $257.2 million.
 
Accounting's Ups and Downs
The oil companies have evidently found new leaders for their fight against pollution: their accountants. In the last quarter of 1989, pollution control and cleanup costs were blamed in Chevron's $833 million loss and Exxon's 43.1 percent earnings decline to $785 million. Phillips Petroleum lost $255 million, also for reasons having to do with pollution. Mobil cited higher crude oil costs for causing a 3.2 percent decline in quarterly profits, to $447 million.
 
Income by the Area Code
 
Phone company earnings rose or fell depending on regional economic health and one-time charges. Nynex lost $43.7 million in the fourth quarter, after a $325 million charge for strike costs, an early retirement program and the write-down of some assets. Regulatory changes and price cuts helped A.T.&T. earn $705 million, after a loss last year. BellSouth gained 11.9 percent to $469 million and U S West, 26.8 percent to $344.4 million. Bell Atlantic's quarterly income fell 80.9 percent to $57.9 million and Southwestern Bell's fell 2.7 percent to $297.2 million.
* Eastern Airlines proposed a reorganization plan that would give unsecured creditors less than 50 cents on the dollar, according to people who have seen the plan. The plan to take the airline out of bankruptcy proceedings was presented to the unsecured credits committee Thursday. Executives of Texas Air, which owns Eastern, have said in the past that all creditors would be paid in full.
 
Samurai Spaghetti, and Sayonara
 
Mamma-san Leone? Restaurant Associates, the operating and consulting group that turned eating into entertainment, has been sold to the Kyotaru Company of Japan. The new owners plan to bring New York theater-district Italian and other dining concepts back to Japan.
* W. Michael Blumenthal said Friday that he will step down as chief executive of the Unisys Corporation to join Lazard Freres & Company. Blumenthal, a former Treasury Secretary, leaves behind a company that lost $639.3 billion in 1989.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Japan's European Move
As Japan moves more money into Europe, American markets are bound to suffer. ''That's becoming a burning issue for the financial markets in 1999,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds. Japanese money managers say they find West German stocks especially attractive since Germany can benefit from the region's economic unification and the opening of Eastern Europe. And real returns on West German bonds surpass those on U.S. Treasuries.
 
Lunar Lite in Japan
First, economy cars. Now, the economy moonshot. An unmanned Japanese rocket cheapskated into space Wednesday with a $41 million budget and heavy corporate backing. ''The space equivalent of a compact Toyota,'' one official said. And just as their auto makers have expanded into luxury cars, the Japanese aerospace industry is working on space shuttles and missions to Venus and Mars.
 
The Clamor Abroad Hits Home
American computers, telecommunications equipment and machine tools could soon begin flowing to Eastern Europe. The Bush Administrations announced plans last week to relax export curbs, as American businesses and West European allies had urged. But the restrictions will remain on technology transfers to the Soviet Union.
* The United States Ambassador to Hungary, R. Mark Palmer, said last Thursday he will resign to manage a new investment firm in Eastern Europe. Who can blame him, with Albert Reichmann and Ronald S. Lauder for partners? First purchase: half a Hungarian bank, for $10 million. ''The gold rush is on in Hungary,'' Mr. Palmer said. He also plans to target Czechoslavakia.
* Oil users around the world are likely to pay the costs of the conflict in Azerbaijan. Ethnic strife has disrupted production of oil industry equipment in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer.

PUB-DATE: January 28, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 734 words

HEADLINE: World Markets;
How Long for German Funds?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
''Being a Scotsman, it goes against the grain to spend $1.50 to buy a $1,'' said Gavin Dobson, president of Murray Johnstone International, a Chicago money manger. He was explaining why he did not buy into the New Germany Fund Inc., which was launched last week. Plenty of other people did buy. The German stock market has fallen 4 percent since it hit a record high on Jan. 3, propelled downward partly by jitters over the outlook for the economic development of Eastern Europe, which have replaced much of the euphoria of last fall. But the New Germany Fund opened at 21 7/8, more than 50 percent above the initial offering price minus underwriting fees. On Friday it traded even higher, closing at 24, which meant buyers were paying an even higher premium of 72 percent. Those who bought more than 19 million shares over the two days - 76 percent of the fund's 25 million shares - were paying $1.57 to $1.72 for $1 of equity. 
Adding to proof of the demand - some analysts say foolishness - the already existing Germany Fund also rose Thursday and Friday in much thinner trading, closing at $24.50. Investors who bought that fund were paying $2.03 for $1 invested, or a premium of 103 percent. Such premiums exist because the closed-end funds sell a fixed number of shares at the initial offering. This means that when the stock is traded it can be priced above or below - at a premium or a discount - to the underlying value of the fund.
There is no disagreement among the analysts who watch these and other single-country closed-end mutual funds that this bubble has to burst.
Thomas J. Herzfeld, president of Thomas J. Herzfeld Advisor Inc. in Miami, says that such funds historically have traded at a discount and that he does not expect the two German funds to sustain the premium. For the investor, this means the following: If the stocks the New Germany Fund invests in increase in value by 50 percent in the next year or two, the investors who scrambed to buy on Thursday and Friday could still make no profit. That is because the premium could fall if interest in the fund wanes, wiping out most or all of the gain in the underlying value of the fund. The greater the premium, the greater the risk.
So why is there so much demand? West Germany still looks to reap the chief benefit from economic development of Eastern Europe. And skilled salesmen are quick to convince investors that the funds appear to be the easiest way to get a slice of the German action. In addition, the newest fund said it will invest in East German equities when that is possible. And, the new fund, at a $1.72 for $1 on Friday was a better deal than the old fund at $2.03 for $1.
But people interested in Germany can get in the game at a much better price, sometimes even at a price that provides more than $1 in equity for a $1 investment.
For example, they can invest directly in the West German market simply by calling a stockbroker. But Adolphe J. Warner, the senior adviser to both Germany funds contends that the premium paid for the funds is worth it, because they give smaller investors access to the West German markets. Buying stock directly in West Germany, he said, is likely to require as much as $60,000 to get a variety of stocks at the average price of regular-sized purchases. In addition, he said the premium also accounts for the expertise of the funds' management in picking the right German stocks now and those in East Germany in the future.
But another approach that would produce some German exposure, along with stocks in other markets around the world, would be to invest in global closed-end funds. Many of these are selling at a discount, which makes them cheaper and much less risky than the Germany funds.
The Clemente Fund Global Growth Fund has stocks from Germany, the rest of Europe, Japan, Indonesia and other Asian countries. It closed on Friday at 9 3/4, which is about a 14 percent discount to the value of the stocks it owns. The Worldwide Value Fund, Inc. has a large position in Siemens, the large German electronics manufacturer, as well as investments in Great Britain, the United States and Italy. It closed Friday at 17 7/8, a discount of about 12.9 percent of the value of its stocks.
Of course, buying into such funds provides less intense an exposure to Germany and, presumably, to East Germany in the future. But the global funds carry far less risk.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Will Perestroika Cost Us More at the Pump?

BYLINE: By ARNOLD NADLER; Arnold Nadler is an energy consultant in Salem, Mass.

 BODY:
Pumping 12 million barrels a day out of a global total of 63 million, the Soviet Union is the world's largest petroleum producer. It is also No. 1 in natural gas. Should economic and political disarray hinder Soviet energy production, the ripples would reach from Houston to the Persian Gulf. 
The Soviets export about four million barrels of oil a day, second only to Saudi Arabia. Roughly half of Soviet oil exports go to Western Europe, generating about $10 billion a year, more hard currency than from any other export. The other half goes to Eastern Europe and other allies.
Even before the heightened violence in Azerbaijan, Soviet petroleum production in the six months ending in September 1989 was down 3.6 percent from the comparable period in 1988. By the end of 1989, oil and gas exports to the West had fallen sharply. Although the production decline is not quite 1 percent of world output, during previous price surges each 1 percent cut in oil supplies has raised prices about 10 percent.
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries can thank the Soviet Union's lower production for helping to keep prices up. Prices plunged in 1988 when OPEC output reached 23 million barrels a day, but today, with OPEC production just as high, prices have recovered and stabilized.
Soviet oil output is hobbled by worker slowdowns, shoddy equipment, high production costs and environmental pressures. As Petroleum Economist, a British publication, quotes First Deputy Minister Vladimir Filanovsky: ''It's sickening to see the once flourishing oil sector fall apart.''
Because the district of the Azerbaijan capital, Baku, is a major manufacturing center for oilfield equipment, the fighting threatens petroleum output nationally. During unrest a year ago, strikes and transportation tie-ups blocked shipments of oilfield equipment. Azerbaijani oil production of about 270,000 barrels a day is concentrated offshore, in the Caspian Sea. Last May, fires on three offshore platforms burned for almost three weeks.
To modernize its energy industry, the Soviet Union is showing interest in joint ventures with foreign partners. For the United States, joint ventures could raise prickly policy questions about technology transfers: Will a stronger Soviet oil and gas industry help stabilize energy markets? Might the Soviet Union join with OPEC to create a more powerful cartel?
The Soviet Union is also the world's second-largest oil user, accounting for 14 percent of world consumption. Artificially low domestic fuel prices lead to substantial waste. Raising prices at home would free more oil for export, but the political risks impede such a move.
If perestroika increases Soviet auto ownership, domestic energy demand could rise sharply. Reaching rates of auto ownership equal to Spain's would add 60 million cars to Soviet roads - enough to lift world petroleum consumption about 3 percent. More cars are probably coming: Fiat has signed a joint venture to build a $1.4 billion factory southeast of Moscow to produce 300,000 cars a year. As the Soviet Union revamps its economy, its impact on the world's energy markets could be greater than ever.

HEADLINE: The Coming Rebound - and Risk - in Municipal Bonds

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Four years after changes in the tax code knocked the wind out of municipal bonds, the market appears poised for a big turnaround. For Wall Street, scrambling more than ever for new sources of income, a jump in market volume can't come soon enough. For investors and issuers, however, the expected surge in activity may be fraught with risks.
Fueling the market revival of the 1990's is the continuing deterioration of the nation's bridges, tunnels and roads and the growing need of state and city governments to issue new bonds to finance billions of dollars in repairs.
But issuers will have to offer higher rates of interest to attract investors now, in part because the demand for municipal bonds was so sharply curtailed by the 1986 tax changes. And because taxpayers are increasingly loath to approve general obligation bonds, which are backed by the issuer's full taxing authority, more and more so-called revenue bonds will be used. These are supported only by the revenues produced by the very structures being financed or, in some cases, by nothing more substantial than the promise of revenues from the development of raw land. 
Those factors are already leading to warnings that defaults will climb as some issuers and investment bankers push at the edges of public finance with questionable deals.
''Issuers in the 1990's will generally be forced to do more financings that are riskier in nature,'' said James F. Lynch, editor of the New York-based Lynch's Municipal Bond Advisory, ''and investment bankers will generally be willing to accommodate them.''
Added Ralph Horn, executive vice president of the First Tennessee Bank and vice chairman of the Public Securities Association, an industry trade group based in New York: ''The danger is that the more innovative you get and the more removed you get from good solid tax coverage on a deal, as is the case with some revenue bonds, the more the credit risk goes up.''
Whatever the risks, Wall Street, at least, is raring to go, still smarting from the effects of the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
The Government used that legislation to limit the catagories of investors who could claim an exemption from paying Federal taxes on municipal bond interest. Left out in the cold were property and casualty insurers and commercial banks, the two biggest groups of bond buyers. While mutual funds and individuals were not affected, demand was sharply reduced. The volume of new municipal issues fell to $120.5 billion last year, from $205.3 billion in 1985.
For Wall Street, the contraction was a disaster. Public finance departments, like most departments in the large investment houses, had boomed during the early 1980's. With the sudden decline in new issues, these departments had scores of investment bankers and support staff with little to do.
At first, most firms delayed cutting staff and the competition for the remaining business forced commissions down drastically. The biggest indication of how unprofitable things had become was the decision by Salomon Brothers Inc., then the No. 1 underwriter in the business, to pull out of municipal finance altogether in 1987.
Since then, other firms have cut back hard on municipal finance but there are still too many bankers chasing too few deals. Now, some firms say much of that will change as state and local governments confront their worsening infrastructure problems.
The firms are counting on substantial growth in the volume of new issues and fatter underwriting commissions. In addition, they are also expecting an increase in the number of complicated deals, a source of lucrative fees for the investment bankers who put the deals together.
''On the supply side, I think we're talking about as much as $140 billion in volume in 1990,'' said Robert N. Downey, the partner in charge of public finance at Goldman, Sachs & Company. In 1989, the firm underwrote $13.7 billion in deals in which it served as lead manager, the most of any investment bank, according to Investment Dealers' Digest.
''I don't think anyone will say that Washington is going to finance public works the way they used to,'' Mr. Downey said, ''so municipal bonds will have to be the source to rebuild the infrastructure.''
The states and cities are now spending about $45 billion to $50 billion annually on capital improvements on the infrastructure, according to Joseph M. Giglio, senior vice president of Chase Securities. ''By the year 2000, the total amount of spending on capital improvement should increase to about $95 billion to $100 billion,'' he said.
The underwriters should get a separate boost by the middle of the 1990's, Mr. Downey said. That is when many outstanding municipal bonds will be called. A call provision allows the issuer to retire a bond before maturity. Issuers often want to do this because interest rates in general have fallen below the rate that the bond is paying. The calls reduce the number of tax-exempt bonds outstanding and increase the market's appetite for new issues.
''By the middle of the decade we are going to see a quarter of the $700 billion in municipals paid off,'' Mr. Downey said.
But he acknowledges that the market will see some new and questionable financing techniques by then as well.
''It used to be plain vanilla in the 1970's, but the 1980's saw all kinds of new creatures and that should continue in the 1990's,'' Mr. Downey said. ''Investors should be very careful, for in many cases they are not rewarded enough for shaky credit.''
The problem is finding a revenue stream to pay for all the rebuilding, said Austin Koenen, managing director in charge of municipal finance at Morgan Stanley & Company and chairman of the Public Securities Association.
Political pressures against raising taxes to service general obligation bonds are forcing municipal issuers ''to think about how they can create new structures that will shift more of the risk over to the buyer,'' Mr. Koenen said.
''In California, we used to pay for facilities like sewers and roads through general obligation bonds,'' said Paul Rosenstiel, a managing director in the First Boston Corporation's California public finance department. ''Now what you are seeing is financing mechanisms that rely on assessment of land that has yet to be developed.''
Those mechanisms can get particularly dicey when they are used by the many small but growing municipalities, mostly in the West, that have modest revenue bases but a big need to raise money to finance further expansion. Issuers like these sometimes offer bonds that are backed by raw land and projections of further growth.
Putting together bond offerings of this sort earns higher fees for investment bankers, said Carl M. Eifler, a managing director in public finance at First Boston. But he adds, ''If in the 1990's we are going to have a lot of financing requirements and less revenues to do it with, we are going to push everything to the edge. That will also mean some things will be pushed over the edge.''
Indeed, although the rate of defaults on municipal issues has remained constant for several years at about 1 percent of net new bond issues, many people in the business expect it to accelerate among revenue bonds, said Richard Lehmann, president of the Bond Investors Association, a trade group based in Miami Lakes, Fla.
Mr. Lynch, editor of the Municipal Bond Advisory, is among those who note that many investment bankers came into the municipal bond business in its heyday just before 1986 and that some lack the experience to handle the sophisticated new financings. That means that some deals could go forward that shouldn't.
''A lot of the younger people were not adequately trained and as a result they don't see those yellow lights that would indicate to someone who is more experienced that you should step back and do more homework on a deal,'' Mr. Lynch said. ''I imagine we're going to have some of these deals put together by these people blow up in the 90's. There could be some real surprises.''
 
DO MUTUAL FUNDS REALLY SERVE AS A SAFETY NET?
Managers of tax-exempt mutual funds like to argue that they are the best safeguard against buying into a shaky municipal issue. As professional investors, they say, they have the know-how and resources to screen new bond issues.
Of course, some of that is true. Most individuals who buy municipals don't have cadres of analysts reviewing prospective purchases and most municipal bonds that end in a default are too small to interest the funds so they are sold directly to individuals.
But as the funds scramble for retail customers by offering higher yields and by creating new tax-exempt vehicles, they face strong temptations to lower their standards, some experts say. ''I very definitely disagree with anyone who says that these funds will not take on lower-level merchandise,'' said James F. Lynch, editor of Lynch's Municipal Bond Advisory. ''If you take a look at a lot of what they've bought over the past few years, you'll find that in low-volume times they'll reach for lower-grade merchandise to put in their portfolios.''
On the other hand, Richard J. Franke, president and chief executive of John Nuveen & Company, which runs some of the largest tax-exempt mutual funds in the country, says that the volume of risky issues that might wind up in a typical fund's portfolio is insignificant. ''They're not going to pass the scrutiny of the professional investor,'' Mr. Franke said.
Still, critics continue to voice warnings, contending that professional judgments sometimes give way to bottom-line pressures.
Too often, these critics say, fund managers are inclined to take risks in the hope of raising payouts. Given their huge portfolios, the managers may feel confident that the risks can be easily contained.
''The worrisome thing about the funds is that everything is hunky-dory as long as the fund managers have money coming in,'' said John Peterson, senior director of the Government Finance Research Center of the Government Finance Officers Association, a Washington-based group of state and local finance officials.

HEADLINE: All About/Cellular Telephones;
A Gadget That May Soon Become the Latest Necessity

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Once gadgets of the rich and powerful, cellular telephones are moving into the mainstream. Still primarily business tools, the phones are increasingly showing up in the cars, handbags and pockets of the elderly, housewives, outdoor enthusiasts and others who need instant communications.
Consumers are signing up for cellular service in record numbers, attracted by declining equipment costs and new portable phones small enough to fit into shirt pockets. Some industry analysts predict that portable telephones (which, unlike mobile phones, can be carried outside cars) will become as common, by the next decade, as videocassette recorders and microwave ovens. ''We are looking at the dawn of an explosion in cellular telephone usage that will lead to stiff competition and better, more innovative products and services for consumers,'' said Steve Sazegari, an analyst with the Dataquest market research firm of San Jose, Calif.
With demand for cellular service increasing rapidly, equipment makers and service providers are scrambling to capture a larger share of the market. Service providers are offering discounts, and the cellular carriers are installing digital equipment to serve the deluge of new subscribers. 
Equipment manufacturers have reduced the average price of a car, or mobile, phone to about $400 including installation, from about $2,000 six years ago. They are battling to produce phones that are smaller, more powerful and safer to operate while driving. Sales from cellular service are expected to top $4.4 billion this year, up from an estimated $3.3 billion in 1989. Equipment sales, $620 million in 1989, should reach $655 million in 1990.
The United States had more than 2.7 million cellular subscribers - mainly doctors, lawyers, executives and other professionals - in June 1989, according to the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association. In 1988, subscribers increased 67 percent, to 2.06 million.
Still, the price of cellular service will have to drop substantially before there is a phone in every car or pocket. A typical cellular customer now pays about $100 a month. Cellular carriers recently introduced discount plans that allow heavy users to pay a high monthly charge of $35 to $50 and low usage rates of about 30 cents to 40 cents per minute. Low-volume users can pay a low monthly charge, about $10 to $15, and high rates of about 60 cents to 90 cents.
 
EWQUIPMENT
 
Motorola Leads in Miniaturization
 Since the first cellular telephones were introduced six years ago, manufacturers have sought to emulate the tiny shoe phone used by secret agent Maxwell Smart in the 1960's television series ''Get Smart.'' The latest phones are small enough to be slipped into a shirt pocket or purse, if not in side a shoe.
Out front in the race to miniaturize is Motorola Inc. Last year, Motorola introduced Microtac, a hand-held phone the size of a wallet or checkbook with the same performance as larger mobile phones. At 12.3 ounces and 13.5 cubic inches, the Microtac is the smallest, lightest portable phone on the market. Performance carries a price: currently, $3,000 for Microtac, but less for a no-frills version to be introduced in February.
Motorola, the electronics giant in Schaumburg, Ill., said that its researchers spent five years reducing the size and weight of the phone's components - in particular, the oscillator and the duplexer, which allow a caller to talk and listen at the same time.
Herschel Shosteck, whose Herschel Shosteck Associates Ltd. is a cellular telephone economics firm, called the Microtac ''a technological and administrative tour de force'' because of the teamwork between Motorola's engineering, design, manufacturing, and marketing divisions. ''I expect no other manufacturer to duplicate the size and weight of the Microtac within the next three to four years,'' said Mr. Shosteck.
Analysts said that Motorola has remained the leading manufacturer of cellular phones in the United States despite strong competition from the Japanese and other foreign producers. Motorola invests heavily in research and development and advanced manufacturing processes. The company announced plans last year for a $50 million research facility near Chicago to develop cellular technology. ''This is an industry where we will never be able to let down our guard because competitors are always right behind you charging full speed ahead,'' said James Cail, director of marketing for Motorola's cellular group.
Analysts estimate that North American manufacturers, which also include General Electric and Novatel, control about 30 percent to 40 percent of the United States market - more than for most consumer electronics products. Foreign producers include NEC, Hitachi, Mitsubishi, Oki, Uniden and Toshiba.
Novatel Communications Ltd., a cellular phone maker based in Calgary, Alberta, is the leading cellular supplier in Canada and a growing presence in the United States. The privately held firm doubled its sales in 1989 to about $300 million with the success of such products as Action Pac 4, a portable phone in a case. It can be moved from one vehicle to another, drawing its power from dashboardcigarette lighters.
Del Lippert, Novatel's president and chief executive, said that the company might integrate other devices like answering machines and clockradios into cellular telephones. He expects the phones to become a mass market product towards the end of the decade as more consumers use them for emergencies like keeping in touch when their cars break down in areas far from any other phones.
To improve cellular safety, most manufacturers have introduced models with voice-commanded automatic dialing, speakers and microphones that allow the driver to keep both hands on the wheel while talking.
 
SERVICE PROVIDERS
 
At Times, Capacity Is Overwhelmed
 To meet the explosive demand for cellular service, carriers are converting their networks to digital technology that will provide three times the capacity of current analog systems at lower cost.
The most dramatic growth in cellular subscribers is in metropolitan areas with large, car-bound populations. Carriers are quickly reaching capacity.
In some areas, including Los Angeles, customers dialing during rush hour often get responses only from the ''system not available'' lights on their phones. The networks in the New York City, Chicago, San Francisco and Washington D.C. areas are also near their limits.
The new digital equipment converts calls into the computer language of simple 0's and 1's, which can be transmitted with less distortion than the more complex radio signals for analog equipment.
The first digital networks, expected to go into operation in 1993, will offer cellular customers clearer calls and a wide variety of new services, like facsimile transmissions, error-free data transmissions and access to data bases. Because the new networks can transmit their simpler signals with less power, they are expected to lower the cost of cellular service perhaps 30 percent to 40 percent.
Current cellular telephones are not compatible with the new digital systems, but carriers said that they plan to operate both analog and digital systems until all their customers have switched to digital.
 
FUTURE NETWORKS
 
 Digital Systems Will Require New Phones
 New, digital systems will require new phones. Manufacturers plan to introduce dual-mode cellular phones, usable on both systems, for about $1,400 late next year, compared with $800 for portable analog phones. Industry executives said analog phones will not become obsolete.
The incentive for consumers to trade in their analog equipment for dual-mode phones is that they will be more likely to find lines available during peak calling periods.
While most of the major cellular phone companies are not profitable, they are among the most sought-after stocks on Wall Street because of the anticipated growth in subscribers.
Those with the most subscribers - no precise figures are available - are the Pactel Corporation, a division of Pacific Telesis Group; McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. and Bell South's Southwestern Bell cellular unit.
 
BEAM ME UP, SCOTTY
To cash in on the growing popularity of cellular telephones, several companies are planning to offer a new type of wireless phone network that will compete with existing cellular service in the United States and overseas.
The new systems, known as personal communications networks, would allow residential and business customers to make and receive calls on lightweight wallet-sized phones that will look like the communicators used on ''Star Trek.'' The networks would operate at a higher radio frequency than cellular phones, and so have a shorter range but lower costs.
The British Government recently awarded licenses for building three personal communications networks to international consortia that include Pacific Telesis Group, U S West Inc., Cable and Wireless P.L.C. and Millicom Inc. In Britain, the personal communications devices are expected to cost $200 to $300.
Millicom, based in New York, has asked the Federal Communications Commission to set aside a portion of the radio spectrum allocated to cellular so that the new service can be offered in the United States. Major cellular companies oppose the service, saying it will harm their signals. Millicom says the companies are merely afraid of competition. If the F.C.C. approves, company executives say, a system could be operating by 1993.
Whether personal communication's prospects are as bright in the United States as in Britain will depend on whether cellular customers are satisfied. Herschel Shosteck, an industry analyst, said that cellular service in the United States is so widely available and high in quality that a competing service stands little chance. ''The cellular situation in Britain is vastly different from that in the United States,'' he said. ''Britain's cellular is undeveloped, second-rate and in need of competition.'' Shelby Bryant, Millicom's president, disagrees, saying that Britain's cellular system is strong and that personal communications is an attractive alternative in either country. In the United States, he said, ''it will cost less than half the price and accommodate much more capacity and offer a variety of intelligent services.''
