HEADLINE: FORUM;
Coming to Terms on Health Care

BYLINE: By STUART M. BUTLER; Stuart M. Butler is director of domestic and economic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation.

 BODY:
Unlike the great industrial wars of America's past, the recent strikes against the Pittston Company and the Nynex Corporation were not over wages or even work conditions, but over health benefits. Such disputes are becoming commonplace. Union officials view health insurance as a basic necessity. As one of the Nynex strikers' picket signs put it, ''Cutting Our Health Benefits Is Sick.''
Yet employers say they can't afford the increasing cost of health care. Health benefits are already reducing corporate profits by a fourth, according to a report by the National Association of Manufacturers. And this year, American companies will spend an average of $2,745 per worker on health care, up 16.5 percent from 1988 and more than three times the general rate of inflation. Next year, medical insurance is expected to climb an additional 25 percent. 
But the solutions put forth by business and labor are shortsighted. Employers fear they could provoke a strike if they force workers to economize on health-care services by cutting benefits or by making them bear more of the cost. So instead, many executives, in an about-face, are lobbying for the Government to assume the burden by creating a national health service, modeled after Canada's, that is financed by taxes. The Canadian system, however, is no utopia. With the heavy demand for ''free'' care, and the supply of such care limited by budget restraints, shortages and rationing of health care occur.
Fortunately there is a way out of the problem - a solution that would benefit both industry and labor by controlling health-care costs while assuring that all Americans can afford to get sick.
Under a proposal recently put forward in a monograph, which I co-edited, at the Heritage Foundation, company-provided health benefits would no longer be treated as tax-free income by employees. Employer-paid premiums would be considered taxable income on each worker's individual income-tax form.
That would encourage the head of every household to buy his or her own health insurance. As a further incentive, the employee would get a tax credit to offset the cost of purchasing such insurance. At a minimum, under our plan, the insurance policy would have to cover so-called catastrophic expenses. The credit would be adjusted to take into consideration such factors as family size and medical history, so all families - with tax help - could afford decent coverage. Under our plan, which did not estimate costs, families would be required by law to purchase at least basic coverage. Unemployed workers would receive higher tax credits, because of their reduced incomes, and people on welfare would continue to be covered by Medicaid. Changing the tax code this way would have advantages for employers and employees.
First, employees would no longer be locked into a plan that does not meet their needs. For example, a 55-year-old widow probably does not need maternity benefits, but may want better optical coverage. Consider also the case of a financially strapped company that needs to cut back on benefits. Workers could opt out of the plan, buy their own insurance, and get the same tax credits as under the company plan. Opting out today means losing those benefits. Second, under the new system, all workers and their families would have equal access to health-care coverage, regardless of their place of employment. The tax code would treat the self-employed plumbing contractor or graphic artist the same as employees of small mom-and-pop businesses and Fortune 500 companies.
Third, workers would have an incentive to shop wisely for health benefits, since they would be paying for them. Workers would have more incentive to shop around for the plan best suited to their circumstances and insurers, pressured by a consumer-oriented market, would have to offer the most possible benefits at the least possible price or lose the business.
The Treasury Department subsidizes employer-provided benefits that are limited only by a company's ability to pay - or its unions' ability to make it pay. This encourages the healthy and wealthy to demand excessive insurance, while leaving millions of others with no protection at all. Under our proposal, special tax assistance would be targeted to those needing help the most: those with a large family or a chronic medical condition, for example. Unions and employers battling over health benefits does nobody any good. Instead of finger-pointing, both sides need to recognize that the root cause of their dispute is the tax system, which pits workers against managers, and rewards health-cost inflation while denying help to millions of Americans who need it.
The way to cure these problems is to change the system to one based on consumer choice within a competitive health-care market.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Justice in Anti-Dumping

BYLINE: By JAMES BOVARD; James Bovard, the author of ''The Farm Fiasco,'' is working on a book on ''The Myth of Fair Trade.''

 BODY:
While American politicians lecture the world on fair trade, our dumping laws are an inquisitorial nightmare for foreign companies, making a mockery of due process and justice at every turn. In the last 17 years, Congress and the Commerce Department have repeatedly expanded the definition of dumping. Between 1980 and 1986, the Commerce Department found only 6 percent of all imports it investigated not guilty of unfair trade practices.
Dumping occurs when a company charges a lower price for a product in an export market than in its home market. But anti-dumping laws are a relic of the days of fixed exchange rates. The Commerce Department will convict a foreign company for a price difference as small as one-half of 1 percent between its American and its foreign prices - yet the dollar routinely fluctuates 10 or 15 percent in value a year. Although Commerce Department officials treat dumping as a self-evident crime, it is often solely the result of fluctuating currency exchange rates that may be totally unrelated to trade trends. 
The Commerce Department allows itself great latitude in how it administers the dumping law. In 1984, an Italian company was convicted of a dumping margin of 1.16 percent on its exports of pads for woodwind instruments. The Commerce Department deduced the 1.16 percent by comparing the prices of a smaller woodwind pad sold in the United States with a larger woodwind pad sold in Italy. Since the smaller pad sold for a lower price than the larger pad, Commerce Department found the Italian company guilty.
Even if a company sells its products in the United States for exactly the same prices as in its home market, the Commerce Department can nail the company for dumping. How? It compares the average foreign price over a six-month period with individual American sale prices. Naturally, product prices vary over time and in different locales. If any of a company's American prices fall below the average foreign price, Commerce can slap a duty on all its imports.
In the 1980's, the Commerce Department has increasingly relied on cost-of-production proofs to prove that foreign companies are dumping their products in the United States at below the alleged cost of production. But, Commerce Department cost analyses are straight out of ''Alice in Wonderland.'' American trade law requires that the Commerce Department always assume a foreign company makes an 8 percent profit. If a foreign company shows a profit of 7 percent, then the Commerce Department convicts the company for selling at a loss of 1 percent.
Once a company is convicted of dumping, the Commerce Department can effectively keep the company under economic house arrest for the next 15 years. While Australian and Canadian dumping laws have sunset provisions that automatically end the protection provided by dumping duties after five years, the Commerce Department has succumbed to domestic political pressure to perpetuate dumping orders long after the alleged dumping has ended.
To be hit by a dumping order can easily cripple a foreign company, especially since the Commerce Department can inflate the dumping margin in an annual review. In August 1989, the Department announced that a Japanese ball-bearing company must pay duties of 67 percent - for bearings it exported between 1974 and 1979.
Commerce is judge, jury, prosecuting attorney, and executioner, as Washington trade lawyer David Palmeter told this author. The Commerce Department can demand practically an infinite amount of information - and any refusal to comply is taken as a confession of guilt, after which it imposes the highest possible dumping margins. The Commerce Department collects vast amounts of confidential information from foreign businesses and has frequently allowed this information to fall into the hands of American competitors.
While other nations are calling for a General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreement to trim or gut dumping laws, the American Government is almost alone in advocating making dumping laws more punitive and protectionist. Yet, outside the United States, American companies get hit by dumping penalties more than any other nation's companies. The more oppressive our dumping laws become, the more likely that it is that foreign nations will copy our laws and clobber American exporters.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Finally, Some Muscle for the Yen

 BODY:
The Japanese yen, which has been chronically weak against the dollar, finally found some muscle last week. Betting that the Japanese would raise interest rates after the Parliamentary election on Feb. 18, traders bought yen aggressively last week for the first time in months. By the end of the week, the dollar had fallen to 142.85 yen, down from 146.00. At the same time, the Canadian dollar continued to fall sharply against the American dollar as interest rates in Canada appeared to be headed even lower. Since the Bank of Canada signaled in mid-January that it would allow interest rates to fall, investors have been dumping their Canadian dollars. Two weeks ago, the Canadian dollar was worth 86.3 cents. Now it is down to 83.6 cents.

HEADLINE: Helsinki II, Road Map for Revolution

SERIES: Designs for Europe: An Occasional Series

BYLINE: By Joseph R. Biden; Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, is chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on European Affairs.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Eastern Europe's rush to freedom has inspired hope for a trans-European partnership. The superpowers concur that Europe's ''common house'' should extend from Moscow to Washington. But mixed with optimism is fear of a backslide, as democracy and free markets struggle to take root.
In search of ''architecture'' to buttress a new order, the Bush Administration has stressed existing structures:
NATO, the Common Market and the Helsinki Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. 
Yet, in their tepid response to the Gorbachev proposal for another Helsinki summit meeting, American policymakers seem hesitant to place much faith in a mechanism they regard as unfamiliar and unwieldy.
This is shortsighted. We must capitalize on the key institution spanning the East-West divide. In 1975, the first Helsinki meeting committed the NATO and Warsaw Pact nations, as well as 12 European neutrals, to continuing talks on three tracks: military, economic and political. This diplomacy has worked. Indeed, its promotion of human rights layed the groundwork for the revolution of 1989.
Now, the 35-nation format can achieve more. With energetic American engagement, a binding Helsinki II treaty could provide a needed blueprint for Europe's common house.
The military track is critical. The conventional-arms pact expected this year primarily will reduce Warsaw Pact forces. Helsinki II should promptly set a goal of further cuts: 50 percent or more on both sides.
The worry that deep cuts may undermine NATO's forward-defense strategy should diminish as the long-exaggerated specter of a Warsaw Pact invasion fades away. A real risk, however, is that, in the absence of a collective plan, the shedding of military burdens could produce a dangerous imbalance in forces. By contrast, negotiated reductions offer predictability, fairer burden-sharing and even lower force levels.
We must be clear on the differences between NATO, a voluntary collaboration, and the Warsaw Pact as an instrument of Soviet coercion. While negotiations will involve the two blocs, the treaty should not enshrine their status. Helsinki II could set a point for each nation to decide whether to join any alliance and whether to evict foreign troops. This mechanism could lock in the Soviet promise to withdraw from Eastern Europe and convert the Pact to a political role.
Verification in the common house means more than a guard against cheating. Extensive monitoring would institutionalize openness, engaging national militaries in an enterprise of systematic on-site and aerial (''open skies'') inspection. A common emphasis on each nation's rights and obligations would build confidence that any violation would be collectively opposed. This regime, replete with cooperation and information, would constitute a new European security system, resistant to rivalries long checked by cold war division.
Helsinki II should erect a framework for Western trade, investment and aid in Eastern Europe that will assure a rapid, successful transition to market-based economies. Such actions are the West's most cost-effective form of ''defense'' spending (this has eluded those who would aid Europe's new democracies meagerly, at the expense of U.S. allies elsewhere).
A treaty also could resolve concerns, aroused by Western Europe's economic integration in 1992, that the European Community may become a protectionist fortress. Helsinki II should commit all parties to extending the E.C.'s single market, East and West, throughout the common house - including the U.S.
Politically, the overriding question is German unification. Helsinki II should set an agenda that reassures both Germans and their neighbors, and accommodates the reality that the Germanys are the most densely militarized territory in history.
An agreed pause of, say, five years would enable East Germany to develop democracy, the two Germanys to expand interaction and the Helsinki participants to set military limits in Central Europe and reaffirm a unified Germany's eastern borders. Then, formal unification could proceed by popular referendum. This timetable would help forestall radicalism in East Germany and assuage concerns about instability.
Finally, a parliamentary institute should be founded in Berlin, where legislators from Helsinki member countries could profit from an exchange on democratic procedures and policy. A multinational network of ties among legislators would fortify the peace we hope to build.
A Helsinki II treaty could guide Europe's revolution. American diplomacy cannot be conceived in fear of this uncharted terrain, for only there can the common house be built.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed; Series

HEADLINE: Limit Capital Gains Tax Cut to New Issues;
Wiser Countries

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In response to recent editorials on the Bush Administration's proposal to reduce the capital gains tax (''A Poor Way to Save,'' Jan. 22, and ''Who's Demagoguing Capital Gains?'', Jan. 11):
How do you arrive at such economically unsound, divisive and just plain poor recommendations? Why do most of our trading partners-competitors have such high savings rates, two to three times ours?
By encouraging long-term investments with low to nonexistent capital gains taxes: Canada's rate is 17.5 percent; France's, 16 percent; Japan's, 5 percent, while West Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, South Korea and Taiwan leave capital gains tax-exempt. 
Your policies on capital gains are not competitive and would be damaging to our economy and to entrepreneurial activity. Certainly, reasonable forms of individual retirement accounts will be helpful, but 95 percent of long-term investments come from those in the high brackets.
Why don't you, I ask, approach this matter without demagogy and politics?
 
DON DOUGLASS
 San Antonio, Jan. 22, 1990

HEADLINE: Limit Capital Gains Tax Cut to New Issues

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Who's Demagoguing Capital Gains?'' (editorial, Jan. 11) exposes some of the fallacies in President Bush's insistence on the reduction in the capital gains tax. There is yet another major fallacy that you did not mention. 
Mr. Bush justifies his position by claiming that a reduction in the capital gains tax would create jobs and encourage economic growth. I would like Mr. Bush and his voodoo economists to explain how the purchase of stocks and bonds from someone who already owns them gives companies the funds needed to invest in new plants, new production equipment and research and development.
I can understand how money invested in the original public offering of stocks and bonds can give companies the money needed to do all the wonderful things that Mr. Bush claims for the reduction in the capital gains tax. If so, why shouldn't the reduction in the capital gains tax be limited to new issues of stocks and bonds? The same rationale applies to the purchase of new homes as against homes that are resold.
Limiting the reduction in capital gains taxes to the first purchase of new issues of stocks and bonds and of new homes would cause the reduction to apply to a very small fraction of all capital gains transactions, and thus it would counteract the enormous reduction in revenue that Mr. Bush's proposal will cause in the long run. It would also encourage the kind of investment that would truly invigorate the economy.
 
NORMAN H. PALTER
 Novato, Calif., Jan. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: To Save Social Security, Save

 BODY:
Washington Week is here: President Bush presents his new budget tomorrow; on Tuesday, he reports to Congress on the State of the Union. Yet even with these main events at hand, public debate remains preoccupied by a dazzling, poorly understood preliminary, the Moynihan plan.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York says his recent proposal to cut the payroll tax would stop an unconscionable diversion of Social Security revenues. President Bush and other critics say the proposed tax cut would threaten future retirees. Both sides are dissembling. Cutting the payroll tax wouldn't help or hurt future retirees. Benefits are not tied to payroll taxes and need not be in the future. But tax cuts - of any kind - would drive up the Federal deficit and thereby divert money from the savings needed for private capital formation. What's really at stake is not the health of the Social Security system but the health of the whole economy. 
The baby boomers will start retiring around 2020. Though no longer working, they will be consuming - with the help of checks from the Social Security Administration. Will the economy be able to produce all the hamburgers and microwave ovens these retirees expect to buy?
That is the question that a Social Security reform commission, headed by Alan Greenspan, tried to answer in 1983. It recognized that future taxpayers would pay for future retirees no matter how Social Security was funded. But how much those taxes would hurt would depend on economic growth. If personal incomes are high, taxpayers won't mind paying the necessary taxes. If personal incomes are low, they'll shout.
For the economy to grow, the nation needs to invest in better machinery and in better educated workers. But such investments won't happen if escalating Federal deficits continue to divert private savings. So the Greenspan commission recommended a series of tax increases to lower the deficit, specifically, payroll tax hikes.
Things did not work out as planned. For starters, Congress passed the Gramm-Rudman law, which fixed annual targets for the deficit. That undid the commission's plan. Higher Social Security revenues allowed Congress to spend more elsewhere while staying within the fixed target. In this respect, Mr. Moynihan's accusation is just. Social Security revenues are not lowering the deficit; they are paying the Government's ordinary bills.
The Greenspan commission misled the public into a false sense of security. It described its proposed tax hikes as necessary to build up a trust fund from which future retirees would be paid. That was right in principle, but not in actual practice.
Most citizens assumed that the trust would take future taxpayers off the hook. But the trust accomplishes no such magic. The surpluses generated by the payroll tax are lent to the Treasury. When the baby boomers retire, the Treasury will have to pay back the Social Security Administration. Where will it get the money? From taxes.
In effect, the Greenspan commission hoped to raise national savings - and thereby provide for economic growth - the only way that is known to work: lower the deficit. And it planned to do so by raising the only tax Congress would touch. Because the public erroneously believes Social Security benefits only come from Social Security taxes, it accepted the commission's recommendations.
That was politically possible but unjust. In effect, the commission tried to solve the nation's savings problems with the least fair tax. Payroll taxes hit all wage income equally up to a maximum of $51,300. Above that, high earners get off scot-free. In combination with the Reagan-era reductions in marginal tax rates, tax burdens have shifted away from the rich and onto average workers.
What the nation's future needs now is tax increases, not cuts. A strong economy demands high investment. That means lower deficits. The important task is to set an overall target for the budget that is consistent with the nation's need to save and then set taxes at efficient, fair levels. In his new budget plan, Mr. Bush offers a ''Social Security integrity and debt reduction fund'' that, by default, does set such a target. The effect would eventually be a budget in surplus by more than $100 billion. Many economists would consider that draconian. It also rules out lowering the unfair payroll tax.
Congress could reduce the deficit, yet lower the unfair payroll tax. But that requires making up for the lost revenues. Mr. Moynihan's proposal is right because it seeks to help the low-paid. It is wrong because it refuses to pay the price.

LENGTH: 1135 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Canadians Buy a Share of the American Dream

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

 BODY:
CANADIANS have for decades been accustomed to sleeping in Holiday Inns, eating Kentucky Fried Chicken and getting their Fords fixed at Midas, and many of them have come to resent the widespread presence of these and other American companies.
But in recent years the corporate shoe has been moving to the other foot. The recent multibillion-dollar bankruptcy by Federated Stores Inc., the parent of nine American retailing chains controlled by Robert Campeau, a Canadian developer, underlined only one facet of the growing economic integration of North America.
Canada, with 26 million people, and the United States, with 250 million, have forged the largest bilateral economic relationship in the world. Every year nearly $200 billion in goods and services are exchanged across the 5,524-mile border, producing a regular trade surplus of about $20 billion in Canada's favor. The two countries are, by far, each other's largest trading partners. Canada takes about 20 percent of all American exports; the United States buys nearly 80 percent of Canada's. A year ago this month, a Free Trade Agreement went into effect that is to abolish virtually all remaining duties and tariffs between the countries over 10 years. Within weeks, negotiators agreed to speed up the timetable. 
As the Campeau bankruptcy illustrated, the integration has a far-reaching economic and political impact. Such intimate links put some American workers in the unaccustomed role of being subject to decisions like layoffs and plant closures made in foreign headquarters.
For their part, many Canadians fear a loss of identity and the jeopardizing of sacred social programs in a harshly competitive continental economy dominated by Americans. They cite any job losses - some Canadian manufacturers move their plants across the border because American labor is cheaper - as proof that Canada will suffer more from free trade than it will gain through access to cheaper foreign products and a larger market.
While some Canadians fear becoming the 51st state, however, some American states like Tennessee advertise themselves as the 11th province, so eager are they for investment. And whatever the fears, the drive for markets and profits sees Canada and the United States owning ever larger chunks of each other.
 
Just Behind the British
The United States had long been the largest foreign investor in Canada, with about $62 billion of direct investment there in 1988, up from $54.5 billion in 1987. But now, according to the Canadian Government, Canada has $34.5 billion of direct investments in the United States, up from $30.3 billion in 1987. With less comprehensive counting, the United States Department of Commerce put the Canadian direct investments at $27.4 billion in 1988, up from $11.7 billion in 1982, ranking the Canadian stake fourth behind that of the British, Japanese and Dutch.
''The Free Trade Agreement merely ratified a major economic movement that was already well advanced,'' said Seymour M. Lipset, a Stanford professor and author of ''Continental Divide: The Institutions and Values of the United States and Canada,'' which is due out in April. ''In fact, on a per capita basis Canadians own far more of the United States than vice versa.''
While much concern has been expressed in recent months about Japanese acquisition of American properties, growing Canadian ownership has gone relatively unnoticed. Canadians including the Reichmann family of Toronto, which owns the huge Olympia & York Real Estate Company, have acquired more than 25 million square feet of Manhattan office space, one square foot for each Canadian citizen.
Kenneth Thomson, the son of Lord Thomson, the Toronto newspaper magnate, owns 117 daily newspapers in the United States from Valdosta, Ga., to West Covina, Calif., plus dozens of trade publications. Another Toronto entrepreneur, Conrad Black, owns 54 American dailies. The Bank of Montreal owns Chicago's mammoth Harris Bank, which produces nearly a quarter of the parent bank's annual income, while Canada's Cineplex Odeon, the continent's second-largest theater chain, controls 1,882 movie screens in the United States.
A good example of the economic integration under way is Northern Telecom, which has headquarters in suburban Toronto and is the second-largest telecommunications company in North America. It has 21,721 employees in Canada and 21,638 employees in the United States. The American operation produces 62 percent of its $5.4 billion annual revenues. The first major purchase of foreign phone equipment by the Japanese national telephone company, N.T.T., was a $250 million deal with Northern Telecom, which will manufacture most of the equipment at its North Carolina plant. ''It's really all about the development of a single North American economy,'' said Gerald Levitch, a company spokesman.
 
A New Breed
Experts attribute Canada's emerging economic aggressiveness to the need for new markets to augment stagnant earnings from domestic markets that have essentially reached their limits of growth. In addition to the attraction of cheaper American labor in some cases, there is also the advantage of taking home profits in more valuable American dollars. Canada has also seen the rise of a new class of entrepreneurs, many of them the offspring of immigrants, like the Reichmanns or the president of the Four Seasons hotel chain, Isadore Sharp, who did not attend the exclusive prep schools and universities that traditionally produce the leaders of Canada's tightly knit, insular business clans. The Reichmanns are also among the top Western investors in Eastern Europe, as is another Toronto businessman, Andrew Sarlos.
Alan Rugman, a University of Toronto economist, sees continued growth in Canada's conglomerates beyond the United States into Africa and the Pacific Rim. Four Seasons, for instance, has 10 new foreign projects, including ones in Tokyo and Singapore. He sees his country's guaranteed access to the vast American market as an enticement to foreigners like the Japanese, who may fear eventual American trade restrictions, to open operations in Canada as a way of gaining back-door entry. Many American companies used the same tactic decades ago, building plants in Canada to gain duty-free access to the larger markets of the British Commonwealth.
The opportunities some Canadian companies find in the United States can produce interesting anomalies. Moosehead, the New Brunswick beer that is the sixth most popular imported brand in America, is available in all 50 states but in only four of the 12 Canadian provinces and territories. And if the Denver Broncos win the Super Bowl tonight, Americans will have to adjust to the fact that the championship team of American football is owned by a Canadian, Pat Bowlen.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Other Walls May Fall, But in Fortress Cuba Castro Stands Firm

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
THE changes sweeping Eastern Europe are stirring hopes here and in some quarters of Havana that Fidel Castro's long reign over Cuba may be coming to an end. ''We are sure something has to happen in our sad country,'' a dissident in Havana wrote to a friend in the Miami area, where more than 500,000 Cubans have fled since Mr. Castro took power in 1959. Anticipation in Miami has reached such levels that the police have prepared plans to control celebrating crowds of Cuban exiles on the day Mr. Castro falls.
But many experts on Cuba, including Bush Administration officials, say the anticipation represents only the dreams of Mr. Castro's enemies. ''We don't see much in the way of political change in Cuba in the wake of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union,'' said an Administration official who wishes Mr. Castro only the worst. ''My guess is that Castro is relatively secure.'' 
The hopes that the Cuban leader is on the decline are based on his isolation as the only Soviet ally outside Asia to resist a trend toward market economies and increased personal liberties. In addition, the Soviet Union may be less willing to bolster the struggling Cuban economy, making life more austere.
Indeed, 75 percent of Cuba's trade is with the Soviet Union and most of its economic aid, about $13 million a day, comes from Moscow, much of it in the form of subsidies. The Soviets buy Cuba's main export, sugar, at more than double the world price and provide petroleum at special low prices, which allows Cuba to sell some of it for hard currency.
An abrupt end to the economic assistance would be catastrophic. Moscow's diplomats say that a decline in aid and trade is likely as Soviet industry becomes more profit-oriented and more cash is required for domestic development. But they insist that any reduction will be gradual. Experts on Cuba say this is likely to hold true because Moscow still wants the use of Mr. Castro's island for electronic surveillance of the eastern United States and as a base for reconnaissance planes and naval vessels. Further, the experts say, the Soviets do not want to be seen as abandoning a socialist ally, particularly one with the potential for rallying criticism of Moscow in the third world.
The impact of the decline in Soviet support will depend in large part on Mr. Castro's success in finding new trading partners, some of whom will have to be induced to accept barter, given his shortage of hard currency. A few weeks ago he signed an agreement for increased trade with China, and he has been stepping up business in Latin America.
 
The View From Home
At home, many Cubans still consider Mr. Castro their hero, even though they live with chronic shortages. For them, he remains the revolutionary who forced out a corrupt dictator 31 years ago, guaranteed education, health care and basic food and housing, and turned Cuba into a mini-superpower that has commanded the attention, if not the respect, of much of the world. Dissidents are kept in check by Mr. Castro's security apparatus, and American officials say there is no evidence of significant organized opposition. Mr. Castro ended a brief period in which some freedoms were permitted, and his most vocal critics, the leaders of a few small human rights organizations, have been jailed.
To be sure, several thousand Cubans continue to leave the island every year, and the United States treats them as political refugees. But many of them say privately that their strongest motivations are reuniting with family members and availing themselves of greater economic opportunities. Gillian Gunn, a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said that during a visit to Cuba in December she saw no evidence of ''that seething energy beneath the surface'' that had been reported in Eastern Europe before it was swept by popular change last fall. ''Castro,'' she said, ''is still adored by a lot of Cubans.''
An area where some experts see a remote potential for trouble for Mr. Castro is in the armed forces. The execution last summer of Maj. Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez, whom Mr. Castro's Government accused of drug smuggling, is believed to have generated some ill will among fellow officers. All of Cuba's senior officers have spent time in the Soviet Union and some might be receptive if the Soviets instigated a push against Mr. Castro. But any such move would run against nationalistic instincts in Havana and would require extremely deft maneuvering because the head of the armed forces is Mr. Castro's brother, Raul.
If Cuba's position as a Soviet ally invites comparisons to the Eastern European countries, there are also huge differences, one being that socialism was not imposed from the outside in Cuba. Its arrival with Mr. Castro's home-grown revolution was not an act of submission to a powerful neighbor, but rather a form of defiance of the United States. ''The Eastern European leaders never had any real legitimacy,'' said Wayne S. Smith, a former head of the United States diplomatic mission in Havana. ''There was never any question of Castro's legitimacy.''
 
Socialism's 'Last Defenders'
Most scholars suspect that Mr. Castro, now 63 years old, opposes the changes in the Soviet Union because he recognizes that such changes would reduce his power. ''We owe everything that we are to the revolution and socialism,'' Mr. Castro said in a speech last month. ''Destiny assigns us the role of one day being among the last defenders of socialism.'' Were capitalism to return to Cuba, Mr. Castro declared, ''our independence and sovereignty would disappear forever.''
When Mikhail S. Gorbachev was introducing the first changes in the Soviet Union in early 1986, Cuba was going the other way. Mr. Castro had experimented for several years with limited capitalism in the form of farmers' free markets; the flow of produce had never been better, but he abandoned the effort, suggesting that high profits for some were threatening his stated goal of a classless society. He then began a ''rectification of errors,'' eliminating material incentives and calling for greater efficiency and production.
A confrontation between the United States and Cuba is likely next month when a branch of the Voice of America starts test broadcasts of television news, sports and soap operas to the island. Mr. Castro has threatened to respond by using huge transmitters in Cuba to disrupt commercial broadcasting in the United States, and at the same time is expected to use the issue to rally nationalism and divert Cubans from their daily woes.
Jaime Suchlicki, a specialist on Cuba at the University of Miami, says Mr. Castro may also have a few tricks up his sleeve for the Communist Party congress in March. ''He's going to survive this crisis,'' he said. ''He's very clever.''

HEADLINE: BUDGET OUTLOOK;
The Process That Ate Washington

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY

 BODY:
Arrival of the President's budget on Capitol Hill creates what is charitably known as the Congressional budget process. In truth it is less a process than a Rube Goldberg nightmare of unrealistic deadlines, overlapping jurisdictions and competing mandates involving every committee in Congress. The numbers, contradictory and ever changing, will be irrelevant by September, when the decisions that matter are made. Budget making often consumes an entire legislative session.
In some years, the process has been supplanted by ''budget summits,'' where White House and Congressional leaders behind closed doors work out the pivotal decisions on taxes or military spending in advance. If logic ever dictated a year for summitry it would be 1990, when reshaping the Pentagon budget and proposals for cutting the Social Security tax promise to play havoc with both politics and bookkeeping. But Democratic leaders, who believe they were snookered in the back rooms last year, and who face rebellion from committee chairmen excluded from the summits, have vowed to work within the system this time. 
That is, of course, unless the process itself is overhauled. Some lawmakers want to remove the Social Security trust fund, now in surplus, from the calculation of the deficit. Others want to revamp the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced-budget law, grafted onto the process in 1985 to force annual cuts in the deficit and to bring it to zero by 1993.
The deficit target for the 1991 fiscal year is $64 billion. Here is a guide to the tortuous process by which Congress and the Administration are supposed to reach it.
 
Jan.-Feb.: Political scorekeeping
The President is supposed to submit a budget on the first Monday after Jan. 3; this year it will be Jan. 29. The Congressional Budget Office recalculates that budget using its own economic assumptions. Congress and the Administration, already $37 billion apart on estimating the 1990 deficit, argue over who has cooked the books.
 
Feb.-March: The best-laid plans
House and Senate Budget Committees hold hearings and decide separately on their budgets, which set total spending and revenues, resulting deficit, and spending ceilings for 22 broad categories.
 
April-May: Whose budget is it, anyway?
House and Senate pass budget committee bills; differences are worked out in conference. Congress is supposed to approve the final budget by April 15; no Presidential signature is required. Budget committees instruct other authorizing committees - Armed Services, Ways and Means, etc. - to find spending cuts or tax increases needed to meet the deficit target. These committees submit recommendations for cuts to the budget panels.
Meanwhile, the House and Senate Appropriations Committees, which actually decide how much money will be spent on a particular program, begin work on the 13 major spending bills that Congress must pass each year. The 13 appropriations subcommittees handle the bills. In the House, the turf-conscious chairmen of these powerful panels are known collectively as the College of Cardinals.
 
June-Aug.: Whose ox is gored?
The budget panels combine recommendations for cuts and tax increases. These politically painful measures are known as - what else? -Reconciliation Bills. These, too, must be melded in conference, approved by each house and then sent to the President. Approval deadline is June 15. Last year, it happened in late November, as Congress adjourned. Late December is not unusual.
The House is supposed to be finishing the 13 annual spending bills, which may or may not agree in spirit and arithmetic with the reconciliation measures. As each is approved, it goes to the Senate, then to conference, to final approval on each floor, and then to the President.
 
Aug.-Sept.: What's in a number?
On Aug. 15, the Administration reassesses the economic forecast on which its January budget numbers were based and issues the forecast on which all the remaining decisions will be made. Changes in the economy can throw previous action out of kilter and may require more cuts or tax increases to reach the deficit target. On Aug. 25 the Administration, tallying the cost of legislation passed to date, calculates automatic spending cuts that will be needed if Congress does not meet the goal.
 
Sept.: Gridlock and green eyeshades
The unpassed spending bills, stalled initiatives and thwarted political wills inevitably collide. Talk of budget summits revives and decision-making moves to the back rooms. About Sept. 30, the $3.1 trillion limit on the national debt will be reached, and the Treasury Department must seek Congressional approval to keep borrowing. Now a bargaining chip in the budget negotiations, the debt bill becomes a magnet for other pet bills. Congress and the Administration accuse each other of bringing the country to the brink of default.
 
Oct.: Days of reckoning
On Oct. 1 the new fiscal year begins. All spending bills are supposed to be signed by then. (Congress has managed to approve them all by that date only once since 1977.) If not, Congress may have to pass a ''continuing resolution,'' a stopgap spending bill for agencies-in-waiting. In some years, the entire budget has been handled this way. On Oct. 15, the President orders automatic spending cuts if Congress has not met its deficit target.
 
Nov.-Dec.: The bottom line
Congress sorts out the budget debris in a mad rush to hit the deficit target and adjourn by year's end. Elections this year will mean early adjournment, but many lawmakers predict a lame-duck session after the balloting. By the time the books are closed, ''emergency'' and ''dire emergency'' spending will have added billions to the deficit, but by then next year's target is what's important.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Chronology

HEADLINE: BUDGET OUTLOOK;
Numbers Tomorrow, To Be Followed By Heavy Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Gradually over the last several weeks, the basic elements of the budget President Bush will send Congress tomorrow have seeped out.
He will propose spending $1.2 trillion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, leaving a deficit of $63.1 billion. He will ask Congress to approve $295 billion for the Pentagon, $4 billion more than this year but about $6 billion, or 2 percent, less than what would be needed for the Pentagon to keep pace with inflation.
He will suggest a large spending increase for drug control and a small one for education programs. He will ask for a cut in the capital gains tax and a new kind of savings account to encourage Americans to put money aside. Invoking the theme of ''America the Beautiful,'' he will recommend modest new programs to protect the environment. And he will advocate changing the Medicare law, so the medical insurance program for the elderly and disabled would cost the Government billions of dollars less. 
Of course, he will seek no new taxes.
The prospects are dim that the new budget will be taken more seriously than those in the past few years. The debate over military spending, for instance, will not be over whether to cut President Bush's request but over how much to cut it by and whether to trim spending on personnel or weapons systems. The new savings account Mr. Bush is proposing will have no more standing than competing proposals by several lawmakers.
As soon as they see Mr. Bush's budget, the Democrats will begin demanding more money for drug control, education and other areas popular with their constituents. Mr. Bush is certain to oppose and even veto measures throughout the year on the ground that they exceed his budget levels. So the budget will serve one essential function. It will be the main battleground for the election year's political wars.
In terms of money, the Federal budget is larger than all other countries' entire economies except those of the Soviet Union and Japan. The book with all the numbers is larger than the Manhattan telephone directory. But despite the months of work that went into putting the documents together, they will probably gather dust once they are delivered to Congress.
Until relatively recently, Presidents' budgets were a blueprint for all Government activities. Working from the master plan, Congress made minor changes, taking small amounts from some areas and putting the money in others. But as is the case in parliamentary democracies, the Government ran mostly according to the initial proposals of its chief executive.
But in the last decade, Presidents' budgets have become, in the words of Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, ''more of a wish list than a series of proposals that can be adopted.''
There are two main reasons for the declining importance of Presidential budgets.
First, Congressional budget procedures put in place in the mid-1970's gave Congress the structure and expertise to challenge Presidential priorities. Until then, the executive branch had all the computers and analysts, and Congress had no choice but to accept their judgments. In addition, rivalry among Congressional committees prevented a unified assessment of spending and taxes. But the establishment of budget committees in the House and Senate and the creation of the Congressional Budget Office with its staff of more than 200 economists and other professionals put Congress, to whom the Constitution gives the power of the purse, on an equal footing.
Second, and probably more important, the Reagan and Bush Administrations turned their budgets into openly political documents that they knew stood no chance of adoption. Every year since 1985, for example, the Presidents have proposed large increases in military spending; Congress has reduced the President's Pentagon budget request by an average of 2 percent a year. Year after year, the Presidents proposed abolishing or trimming the same domestic programs, including mass transit subsidies, the Legal Services Agency and the Economic Development Administration; each year Congress continued the appropriations. Last year, President Bush made modest education proposals like rewarding successful schools and recognizing superior teachers; Congress never paid them a glance.
''We've been led down the primrose path so often that their budgets are just dead on arrival,'' said Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee. Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, said Mr. Reagan's ideological approach to the budget made the document ''less relevant and far more cantankerous.''
The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law, which sets mandatory deficit ceilings each year, has further reduced the significance of Presidents' budgets. ''Gramm-Rudman sets a total no one can possibly hit with serious policy proposals,'' said Joseph White, a budget expert at the Brookings Institution. As a result, Presidents and lawmakers resort to accounting tricks like moving paydays from one year to another and leaving out of the budget much of the money being spent to rescue savings and loan institutions.
''Presidents' budgets crossed the line into total unacceptability when they had to deal with deficits,'' said Edwin L. Dale Jr., a top aide to Richard G. Darman, the budget director. He emphasized that he was talking about previous budgets and not the one that will go to Congress this week.
Many economists are skeptical of Mr. Darman's contention that continued economic growth can be counted on to whittle away significantly at the budget deficit. The Administration's economic assumptions are somewhat more optimistic than the consensus of private economists for this year, and they are much more optimistic in the years ahead.
In an unusual essay that Mr. Darman wrote to introduce the new budget, he maintained that the Administration's economic forecasts were not ''outside the credible range.'' This budget, he wrote, will be ''seriously presented'' and should be ''treated seriously.''

CORRECTION-DATE: January 29, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article in some copies yesterday about the Bush Administration's proposed budget for 1991 misstated the Administration's estimate of the deficit for the fiscal year 1990, which ends Sept. 30. The estimate is $123.8 billion.

HEADLINE: Where Lewis and Clark Wintered

BYLINE: By WILLIAM B. WHITMAN; WILLIAM B. WHITMAN is a career diplomat based in Washington.

 BODY:
AS a hopelessly provincial Easterner I had always thought of Astoria as (a) the last name of a well-known New York hotel, (b) the only name of an area of New York City or (c) the title of a half-forgotten travel book by Washington Irving. Recently, however, I visited (d) the real thing - a handsome and historic city situated where the mighty Columbia River meets Oregon's thundering Pacific coast. I soon found to my delight that visitors to this Astoria can, within the space of only a few days or miles, relive the wild days of the early Northwest, wander through a neighborhood of superbly preserved Victorian houses and explore some of America's most magnificent coastal scenery.
Astoria's modern history began in December 1805, when the Lewis and Clark expedition, sent out by Thomas Jefferson to explore routes to the Pacific Northwest, arrived at the mouth of the Columbia River after an arduous 4,000-mile trek. After building Fort Clatsop, a rough log stockade named for the local Indian tribe, the expedition spent the winter of 1805-06 under drenching rains, battling both chronic illness and armies of fleas. 
The trailblazers' return to the East stirred enormous excitement throughout the young republic, especially in the New York offices of John Jacob Astor, an immigrant from Germany (the town of Waldorf to be precise), whose fur trading empire had made him America's richest man. According to Washington Irving, whose ''Astoria'' became the official history of the project, Astor immediately saw the intersection of the Columbia and the Pacific as the ideal spot for a chief trading house where pelts from other Western outposts along the Missouri and Columbia could be collected for shipment to China.
Astor's project was short lived. In 1811 his supply ship arrived from New York to found the outpost, making Astoria both the first United States settlement west of the Rockies and New York City's only colony. A second Astor expedition arrived overland from St. Louis in 1812, and Astoria began to flourish, but only briefly. During the War of 1812, threats of British attack forced the sale of Astoria to rival British fur interests, who promptly renamed it Fort George. Although Astoria was restored to the United States after the war, Astor's ambitious dream was over.
The best place to begin your own expedition to Astoria is at the top of the 125-foot Astoria Column, a copy of Trajan's column in Rome, just behind the city, for a spectacular overview of the region. Just below the observation deck, a neighborhood of pristine Victorian homes unfurls down Coxcomb Hill to Astoria's bright and tidy business district, and then on to the broad and choppy Columbia, with its busy traffic of fishing boats and freighters. Over on the Washington side, at the entrance to the Columbia, lurks hook-shaped Cape Disappointment, the much-feared Graveyard of the Pacific, where treacherous tides, sudden storms and strong winds have claimed hundreds of ships over the centuries. On the near shore another peninsula marks the beginning of Oregon's coast of deserted beaches, rocky headlands and evergreen forests stretching 400 miles south to California.
The merchant princes, timber barons, cannery kings and other 19th-century commercial nobility left behind a rich architectural legacy. Their graceful and splendidly maintained Victorian homes, mainly situated on or near Franklin Street, are an eclectic mix of period styles that include Queen Anne and Italianate; 32 of Astoria's Victorians are listed in the National Register of Historic Places and several are bed and breakfasts. This enclave, brimming over with curlicues, cupolas and verandas, dramatic views of the Columbia and colorful gardens, makes a perfect place to stroll. Don't miss the Hobson House at 469 Bond Street, lived in by members of the family since 1863, the Queen Anne-style Martin Foard house and its four turn-of-the-century neighbors at the corner of 16th Street and Grand Avenue and the Cherry House at 836 15th Street, built in 1883 for the British consul at what was then a major trading port.
Although most of these homes are private and closed to the public, the beautifully restored Flavel house, at Eighth and Duane Streets, is now a museum that vividly re-creates upper-crust life in the Astoria of 1890. The Queen Anne villa's elegant furnishings, 14-foot ceilings, six elaborate fireplaces and wrap-around verandas make it easy to imagine that Captain Flavel and his family have stepped out for only a moment Admission tickets to the Flavel House are also valid for the Heritage Center Museum, at 16th and Exchange Streets, with its collection of historical artifacts and exhibits. A block away, at 15th and Exchange, on the site of the original Astoria, a small park contains a replica of one of the fort's log blockhouses.
At the foot of 17th Street the Columbia River Maritime Museum brings together a large and fascinating collection of hands-on exhibits and nautical lore from Astoria's long sea-faring history. Here children and more ancient mariners can peer through submarine periscopes or take the helm of a World War II destroyer.
If you visit Fort Clatsop on a bright and clear day, as we did, it is hard to imagine how this idyllic spot, bursting with wildflowers and thick with evergreens, could have been the scene of so much misery for Lewis and Clark. Behind the Park Service Visitor Center stands a copy of the original seven-room fort, complete with precise reproductions of the expedition's clothing, furniture and personal belongings. In the enlisted men's quarters, where 27 men once crowded into three small rooms, rough-hewn bunk beds covered with skins are clustered for warmth around stone fireplaces, and clothing, as if still soggy from the miserable winter of 1806, is stretched out to dry over the fire.
Next to Lewis and Clark's Captain's Quarters is the fort's only private room, where the expedition's French trapper-interpreter, Toussaint Charbonneau, lived with his wife, Lewis and Clark's Shoshone guide, Sacajawea, and their small child. Out on the now dry and sunny parade ground, you will often find a park ranger dressed in buckskin and a coonskin cap using period tools to fashion the rough wooden boxes and bowls used by the expedition. Leaving the fort, you can follow quiet trails, edged with the same plants noted in the expedition's journals, down to the canoe landing where Lewis and Clark first arrived and the spring that gave the expedition its fresh water.
A short drive away, at the mouth of the Columbia, stands Fort Stevens, originally a Union Army stronghold established to keep Confederate gunboats out of the river and now a large and attractive state park. Although the fort's Civil War role proved theoretical, massive concrete gun batteries were added later and Fort Stevens was used for coastal defense and training duty in two world wars before being de-activated in 1946. Today it offers miles of bicycle and hiking trails, campgrounds and ocean beaches.
FORT STEVENS' martial past is well represented by a small and interesting military museum with Civil War and World War II artifacts, many of which recall the night in June 1942 when the fort was fired on by a Japanese submarine.
Astoria is also an ideal base for day trips along the coast. A few miles from town, U.S. 101, coastal Oregon's flower and evergreen-lined Main Street, swings south to the resort and convention center of Seaside and then on to Cannon Beach, a charming community with attractive shops and a splendid nine-mile beach. Ecola State Park, just north of Cannon Beach, offers panoramas of the coastline and views of Haystack Rock, an offshore bird and aquatic refuge; the park is a place of tranquillity where visitors can watch sea lions sunbathe, beachcomb or hike the Oregon Coast Trail. At Tillamook, Oregon's cheese capital, signs on U.S. 101 mark the turnoff for the Three Capes Loop, a 35-mile winding road through evergreen forests and unforgettable seascapes. The Three Capes drive ends at Pacific City, a silent and remote village where dory fishermen push off to sea from deserted and seemingly endless beaches.
 
INTO THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST
 
Getting There
If you are coming from Portland, allow about two hours driving time along U.S. 30. The trip from Seattle usually takes four hours.
 
Things to See
The Greater Astoria Area Chamber of Commerce maintains a visitor center at 111 West Marine Drive. Mailing address: Post Office Box 176, Astoria, Ore. 97103; For travel information on the coast, write to the State of Oregon's Economic Development Department at 595 Cottage Street, N.E., Salem, Ore. 97310 or call 800-547-7842.
The Astoria Column, on Coxcomb Hill Road, is open every day from dawn to dusk. The Flavel House museum (503-325-2563) is open daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. in the summer, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. the rest of the year. The $3 entry fee (children 75 cents) includes the Heritage Museum, which keeps the same hours.
The Columbia River Maritime Museum (503-325-2323) is open daily from 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M., but closed Mondays from October to April. Admission is $3, but children under 6 get in free.
The Fort Clatsop Visitor Center, on Alternate U.S. 101 five miles from Astoria, offers exhibits, expedition route maps and film showings; open from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. in the summer, 8 to 5 the rest of the year. Admission is $1. Call 503-861-2471 for information.
At Fort Stevens, just off U.S. 101, the museum is open from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. in the summer, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. the rest of the year. Donations requested. The campground is open all year; reserve by phoning 503-861-1671. Bike rentals at Fort Stevens are available at 316 Russell Drive in the village of Hammond; 503-861-0937.
 
Where to Stay
One of the best motels is the Red Lion, 400 Industry Street; 503-325-7373; 800-547-8010. A room for two costs around $75. Other possibilities include several bed and breakfasts in historic Victorians, including K.C.'s Mansion, 3652 Duane Street (503-325-6172), where rooms begin at $65 for two with breakfast.
 
Where to Eat
In Astoria, the Pier 11 Feed Store at the foot of 11th Street (503-325-0279) offers grilled salmon and Dungeness crab. Expect to spend about $35 for dinner for two with wine. The Ship Inn, also on the river at the end of Second Street (503-325-0033), specializes in fish and chips platters. Dinner here runs about $30 for two, wine included. The Columbian Cafe at 1114 Marine Drive has a strong local following for its pastas, crepes and fish, including poached salmon and smoked halibut. Around $25 for two with wine. Hours are slightly eccentric, so call ahead (503-325-2233).
In Cannon Beach, the Whaler at 200 North Hemlock (503-436-2821) is a good choice for fish, as is Dooger's Seafood at 1371 South Hemlock (503-436-2225); both are in the $15 to $20 range, wine included.
Pacific City is a logical lunch destination for day trippers from Astoria. The Riverhouse at 34450 Brooten Road (503-965-6722) offers steamed clams, grilled Chinook salmon and super fish chowders; about $20 a person including a choice Oregon white. Nearby, in the tiny crossroads community of Otis, the quintessential American roadhouse, the Otis Cafe, is renowned for enormous breakfasts, high-cal fruit pies and towering sandwiches. Under $5 a person.
 
Special Events
Every June the city throws a Scandinavian Festival, complete with nonstop folk dancing and music, plus a Miss Scandinavia contest. The 1990 version is planned for June 15 to 17. Another major event is the annual Astoria Regatta, which will be held Aug. 8 to 12; a day of Victorian house tours is traditionally part of the festivities. There is a parade of 40 to 50 boats, and a sailboat race with about a dozen entries. - W. B. W.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By CARL SOMMERS

 BODY:

Machu Picchu
Q. We are planning a trip to Machu Picchu, Peru. Is there a rainy season? What time of year is best? Are there problems with terrorist attacks on tourists? - A. B., Douglaston, Queens
A. There is a rainy season at Machu Picchu, Inca ruins set amid forested mountains 50 miles northwest of Cuzco. Some time between mid-September and mid-October, clouds begin building up, impeding views, and there is occasional light rain until December. From December through March there are several hours of rain each day. From April to at least mid-September, skies are clear, with daytime temperatures in the 70's, dropping to the lower 30's at night. Most people visit in June, July and August; if you can visit in April, May or early September, you can get good weather and smaller crowds. 
The United States State Department has a travel advisory in effect for Peru, warning of terrorist activities by the Shining Path and the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement groups. Because of terrorism, a large part of central Peru, from the the department of San Martin in the north to Ayacucho in the south is a military zone that is off-limits to travelers. The department also says that difficult economic conditions have led to increased crime in tourist areas, including Cuzco and the train from Cuzco to Machu Picchu. Visitors to ruins near Cuzco and in the Sacred Valley, an area of ruins to the northwest, should not stray from well-traveled roads, the department says.
A spokeswoman at the Peru office of the South American Explorers' Club, which supplies information to travelers, also says that there is a problem with crime. The office advises travelers that there is no terrorist activity in the Cuzco area and that train travel is safe.
There is a backpacking trail between Cuzco and Machu Picchu, the Inca Trail. Both the State Department and the Explorers' Club advise those who take the trail to travel in groups.
Because the situation in Peru is tense and unstable, it is best to get the latest information. One source is the United States office of the South American Explorers' Club, Post Office Box 18327, Denver, 80218; 800-274-0568. On arriving in Peru, United States citizens are advised to check with the consular section of the American Embasy in Lima at 346 Grimaldo del Solar, Miraflores; telephone 443621 or 443921.
The Lima office of the South American Explorers' Club is also a good source in Peru for updates on safety and trail and weather conditions: Avenida Ev Portual 146, Brena; 314480. The country code for Peru is 51, the city code for Lima is 14.
 
Cruising With Car to Europe
Q. I am planning to spend several months in Europe. I would like to take my car with me on a ship that would take me as a passenger too. - L. M., Glendale, Ariz.
A. Here are two ways to do it: the plain and the lavish. The plain way is to ship your car and go along as a passenger on a freighter operated by Polish Ocean Lines, which leaves Newark every Monday evening, calling at Baltimore, Wilmington, N.C., Le Havre, Rotterdam and Bremerhaven, a trip that takes 8 to 10 days. First you should book passage for yourself; passenger space is tighter than cargo space as the ship takes only 8 to 10 passengers. One-way passenger cost from Newark is $1,010 or $1,105 a person, depending on the cabin, which must be shared. The cost of shipping a car varies by its weight and dimensions. The range can be $300 to $1,500, according to a representative from Gdynia America Line, which represents Polish Ocean Lines in the United States. The cost of shipping a BMW 520, a medium-size car, recently was $550, the representative said. Reservations: Gdynia America Line, 39 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10006; 212-952-1280.
On a larger and more lavish scale, the QE2, with about 1,900 passengers, takes automobiles in a 60-car on-board garage. The ship makes nine trans-Atlantic sailings in each direction between July and mid-December. The cost for cars up to 5,500 pounds (which would include most autos) is $1,850 one way and $2,995 round trip, plus a $50 port charge. The vehicle may not exceed 6 feet high, 20 feet long or 6 feet wide. The car's underside must have been steam-cleaned before boarding. There must be no personal effects or baggage in the vehicle. Passenger fare starts at $1,410 a person in double occupancy, and usually includes return by air but can also include a return cruise on specified dates. The garage fee must be paid for a return cruise in any case. Reservations: travel agents or Cunard Line, 555 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; 800-221-4770.
 
C.D.W. and Charge Cards
Q. I am contemplating auto rental in the United Kingdom. Will paying for auto rentals there with a gold card provide collision damage waiver? - R. L. O., Trevett, Me.
A. American Express green, gold and platinum cards, Visa and MasterCard gold cards and all Diners Club cards provide collision damage waiver on rental cars. This includes rentals in Britain and most other overseas locations. Cards must have been issued in the United States. To be covered by the card, you must decline the C.D.W. offered by the rental companies. Such coverage may be primary, that is, cover the cost of damage to a car incurred while you were renting it, regardless of your own car insurance. Or it may be secondary, which means it makes up for costs your own insurance does not cover, like a deductible and anything beyond a top limit of payment.
Overeas rental coverage by Visa gold cards and American Express is secondary; Diners Club and gold MasterCard coverage is primary. In some cases Diners and MasterCard directly pays repair shops rather than reimbursing renters for the repair costs.
 
Boston Pops
Q. I will be traveling to Boston in the spring and would like to attend a concert by the Boston Pops. How do I get its schedule? - J. C. C., Woodhaven, Queens
A. Opening night for the Boston Pops this year will be May 8, and the orchestra will continue to perform at Symphony Hall to mid-July. Performances are Tuesday to Saturday at 8 P.M. and on Sunday at 7:30 P.M., with none on Monday. The program schedule will not be available until early March. If you write or call now (Boston Pops, Symphony Hall, 301 Massachusetts Avenue, Boston, Mass. 02115; 617-266-1492) and leave your name and address, you will be mailed a schedule when it becomes available.
