PUB-DATE: January 28, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4470 words

HEADLINE: A Story of Love or a Tale of Deceit?

BYLINE: By David Margolick: David Margolick covers legal affairs for The Times.

 BODY:
ON THE MORNING OF SEPT. 16, 1986, George Gardner picked up Patricia Nicely at a nursing home in Roanoke, Va. Only a year earlier, Nicely, a wealthy woman of 58, had been a high-level official at the National Science Foundation. Now, apparently in the grip of Alzheimer's disease, she had grown so incapacitated that a local judge had made Gardner, a 65-year-old lawyer and friend of Nicely's, her legal guardian. Today he would become her husband, too.
Gardner and Nicely drove to Washington. There, as the couple sat in Gardner's Mercedes, holding hands across the padded leather console, a pastor in the back seat performed the Methodist marriage ceremony. (Presumably by this point, Gardner, as both groom and guardian, had asked himself for permission to wed Nicely.) Too debilitated to utter - and, perhaps, even to understand - her wedding vows, the bride remained mute. The only threshold she crossed on her wedding night was the one leading back into the nursing home, where, nine months later, she died. Only when death did them part would the world learn that Gardner and Nicely had married. Patricia Nicely's obituary doubled as the only wedding announcement she would ever have. 
Gardner grieved for his wife, publicly and profusely. But, because she had died without a will, he was also about to become a millionaire. That was when his new in-laws took him to court, trying to reclaim her $1.1 million estate, as well as her remains, her maiden name and, as they saw it, her honor.
In Washington, barely an hour from Roanoke on the Piedmont Airlines commuter flight he so often took, George Gardner is a friend of the powerful, a counselor to corporations, a figure on the city's ''Social List,'' a pillar of Georgetown's most venerable Episcopal church, and an escort for some of the city's most prominent widows, including the wives of Dean Acheson, Potter Stewart and Walter Stoessel, who was the American Ambassador to the Soviet Union.
Most Sundays, he drives Mrs. Acheson to St. John's Episcopal Church, where he serves as register of the vestry. When Gardner was baptized at the church last spring, his sponsors included Mrs. Acheson and Mr. and Mrs. Edward Burling. Edward Burling is a founder of Covington & Burling, one of Washington's most famous law firms. Mrs. Burling calls Gardner ''a family man, a good man, a church man.'' Mrs. Stoessel describes him as a ''very thoughtful intellectual,'' while to Mrs. Acheson, he is ''as nice a character as he could be.'' But in April 1988, in a Roanoke court proceeding few of Gardner's Washington friends knew about, a different view emerged. Thomas T. Lawson of Roanoke, one of two lawyers representing the Nicely family, called Gardner ''a scoundrel, an interloper and a gold digger,'' who pillaged an estate while ''holding himself out with remorseless unction as the benign instrument of the law, the selfless protector of his afflicted friend.'' For an attorney, he said, ''very little offends generally accepted standards of decency and morality more.''
Is Gardner the consummate con man and social climber, who faked friendship, fabricated documents, staged a sham marriage, lied under oath, shed a torrent of tears, all in an diabolical play for money and respectability? Or is his story one of extraordinary love and loyalty to a pathetically debilitated woman, followed by a vendetta on the part of a spiteful family, avaricious lawyers and an embittered former lover? These questions divide the people who loved Pat Nicely, who nursed her, who worked with her, who went to Vassar with her 40 years ago and had remained close ever since. Some were wary of Gardner from the outset. Others say he brightened her final days, caring for her when no one else, including her own family, would.
But the law must make a choice, and after more than two years of litigation, that process will soon be complete. Tomorrow morning, Gardner goes on trial for perjury and forgery. If convicted, he could spend his last years in disgrace, and at least some of them in jail. ''I know that what I did I did out of love,'' he said in a recent interview, sobbing. ''This thing has just about destroyed me, and I feel it's terribly unjustified.''
GEORGE GARDNER, A NATIVE OF NEW CASTLE, PA. , set out to be a clergyman. He spent three years at Harvard Divinity School during World War II, and though he never graduated, he went into the ministry and led several small congregations in Massachusetts and Ohio. He had always been interested in law, however, and in 1948 he graduated from Cleveland's Western Reserve Law School. He was admitted to the Ohio bar and became a railroad lawyer, battling unions out of offices in Cleveland, Elmira, N.Y., and Richmond before coming to Roanoke in 1954.
Three times, Gardner married, though his first two marriages were short-lived. Four times, he applied for admission to the Virginia bar, and four times his application was denied, always without explanation. It left him a marginal figure on the Roanoke legal scene, and forced him into other fields - first personnel, later, labor relations. His specialty was polling employees for management, and his clients included Colonial Williamsburg, Hershey Foods and Stouffer's. A 1979 article in the Roanoke Times & World-News described him as a man who ''manipulates the consciences of corporations in 22 states.'' Gardner divided his time between Roanoke, where he was affiliated with the firm of Gardner, Moss & Rocovich, and Washington. There, he served on the board of Guest Services Inc., the company that runs concessions at the National Gallery, the Smithsonian Institution and many national parks.
Nicely, too, had religious roots: her father was the longtime pastor of Rochester's Brick Presbyterian Church. From her earliest days, when she(Continued on Page 40) took a black student to her senior prom, she did things her own way. Bright, charming, with a fresh beauty and magical smile that recalled Ingrid Bergman, she was one of those prematurely extraordinary women of the prefeminist era. At Vassar, she edited the student newspaper, enlisted in the Progressive campaign of Henry Wallace, and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa (though, characteristically, she refused to collect her key). She then moved on to Harvard in 1948, where she studied social relations under Talcott Parsons, the sociologist. It was a time when Harvard fancied itself the intellectual center of the American empire, and Pat Nicely became part of the gilded set around then-professor Henry Kissinger, who each summer would import future foreign leaders to Cambridge for his seminars.
Extremely competent but intensely insecure, exuding a vulnerability that made her more appealing still, Patricia Nicely became involved with a series of men who, a friend later recalled, invariably fell into one of four categories: handsome blonds, Boston Brahmins, intense Jewish intellectuals, or cosmopolitan foreigners. Just as invariably, the relationships fizzled. The pattern continued once she joined the National Science Foundation, whose Congressional liaison office she eventually headed. Twice engaged, she never married.
Nicely had just emerged from one such relationship in 1980 when she met Gardner. She was 52; he was 59. Over the next several months they began seeing each other regularly. They were a peculiar match: she, a liberal Democrat, statuesque and worldly; he, a short, paunchy, balding Reagan Republican with limited intellectual range. But friends detected a change in Pat Nicely, a good change. She seemed to glow.
Sometime in 1982, Gardner later said, they began drafting a marriage contract, what he called ''a continuing road map to our life together.'' Much of the document - Gardner furnished a copy to the court following Nicely's death - was taken from a marriage manual. The addenda, he said, came only after long discussion, negotiation, introspection. In the contract, the two vowed to marry in the fall of 1985, following Nicely's scheduled retirement. He said they signed the agreement - ''with mutual love and high hopes for the future,'' it stated - on May 5, 1983. ''We ask God's blessing on our covenant,'' the document concluded. Considering themselves, as he later told a friend, ''mostly married,'' they traveled abroad, at one point staying in the ''honeymoon suite'' of Oslo's Grand Hotel.
For Nicely, however, there were other, more ominous developments. As early as 1983, colleagues detected changes in her. Her efficiency began to suffer. Her eating habits and hygiene, always impeccable, deteriorated. She started stumbling and slurring her speech. She became restless and told associates that a certain ''Mr. McGuire'' was stalking her - even on a trip she and Gardner took to Africa. She carried photographs of her late father everywhere, placing one on the dashboard of her BMW. She watched children's television shows rapturously and doted over her stuffed animals. And she grew increasingly devoted to - and dependent upon - Gardner.
When Dr. Trey Sunderland, a Washington physician, examined her in February 1986, she arrived for her appointment 90 minutes early and told him Richard Nixon was President. His diagnosis was probable Alzheimer's disease; the prognosis, continued decline, with death in 6 to 10 years. In April, a Roanoke judge named Gardner her guardian, a decision in which Nicely's family concurred. ''You seem utterly devoted to Pat and far more patient than I would have been,'' her brother, William Nicely of Phoenix, wrote him.
Gardner sold Nicely's house in Georgetown, which had been on the market for several months, moved most of her belongings to Roanoke, and placed her in Friendship Manor. A few days later, he sent out the first of a series of letters apprising her friends of her condition. ''I have known Pat for five happy years, and many of you have known her much longer, so you will understand the magnitude of my loss and the depth of my sorrow to lose this lovely, warm and talented woman to such a terrible disease,'' he wrote. After five weeks in the home, she had lost 16 pounds. By mid-June she could barely speak and had difficulty swallowing.
Gardner became a familiar sight at Friendship Manor. ''Frankly, I would guess 90 percent of families do not care for a patient with Alzheimer's disease as compassionately as Mr. Gardner cared for Ms. Nicely,'' Dr. Lawrence K. Monahan, her attending physician, later testified. But other aides say that they found Gardner disconcertingly indifferent to his ward, at least when he thought no one was watching. While still able to speak, she told one nurse's aide that Gardner wanted her only for her money. On another occasion, when the aide prodded her to eat, she declared: ''Starving is a better way to die than the way he's trying to kill me.'' Once, she wrote a note. ''Call my brother,'' it stated. ''Someone's trying to hurt me.''
Though Nicely took all of her medications orally, several aides at Friendship Manor spotted what they thought were needle marks on her - in one instance, on an arm, in another, between her toes. From that point on they inspected her thoroughly whenever she returned from her outings. (Gardner says he never administered any injections to Nicely, and that what the aides noticed on her arm was the mark from her premarital blood test.) By September 1986, Nicely was refusing to eat, could no longer dress herself or brush her teeth, disrobed in public, paced constantly, was occasionally incontinent and did little more than grunt. Gardner maintains, though, that he could still communicate with her, in part by reading her lips. She told him, he said, that she still wanted to get married, and soon. ''I'm only going to get worse, George,'' he says she told him. ''I don't want to die single. I want your name.''
GARDNER HAD ALERTED the Friendship Manor staff that he planned to take Nicely out on Sept. 16, 1986, and they had readied her by the time he arrived. The two of them, along with the nurse's aide he'd hired for the day, headed for Washington, listening to Nicely's favorite music - Beethoven's violin concerto, according to Gardner - along the way. During a stop in Charlottesville, he says, Nicely walked into a convenience store and, he maintains, bought him his favorite snack: a ham and cheese sandwich. Around noon, they'd checked into the Key Bridge Holiday Inn outside Washington; Gardner then drove to the Marriott to meet the Rev. Edgar U. Hoover, an old friend of Gardner's who had flown up from Roanoke that morning. The two men fetched the marriage license while Nicely and the aide remained in the hotel room. At one point, the aide said, Nicely tried to leave and had to be restrained.
When the men returned, they left the aide at the hotel and drove with Nicely to Montrose Park in Washington, a pleasant greensward near Dumbarton Oaks where, Gardner said, he and his fiancee had spent some of their most memorable moments together. ''George, does Pat know what we're about?'' Hoover recalled asking. ''Oh, yes, indeed she does,'' he said Gardner replied. ''She has been looking forward to this for years.'' Hoover then turned to Nicely. ''Pat, do you want to marry George?'' he asked. She shook her head from side to side, he later remembered, as if to say no. But Hoover said he knew that Alzheimer's patients occasionally got their wires crossed, and he took that to be a yes.
The minister began the ceremony. When the time came, Gardner later said, Nicely squeezed his hand and mouthed the words ''I do.'' But the minister, seated behind the two, later recalled, ''Pat didn't nod her head, she did nothing. She said zilch.'' Still, from what he saw as her ''cheerful mood'' and ''body language,'' he assumed she'd consented. ''Pat, I want to be the first to call you 'Mrs. Gardner,' '' he told her when the ceremony ended. Once more, the bride said nothing, although, recalled Hoover, she was smiling brightly. Before returning to Roanoke, Gardner told Hoover that no one, not even Gardner's own four daughters, was to know about the marriage. Otherwise, he explained, Nicely's brother would attempt to ''queer'' the union. ''It really at that time should have waved a red flag, but you know I am so trusting of George for 31 years, you know, my buddy and shipmate and all that good stuff,'' Hoover later testified. ''If he told me two and two were three, I would act on it, even to the detriment of my children.''
A day and a half later - around the time Gardner subsequently said he'd had his last sexual relations with her - Nicely was considered so sick she was moved to another facility at Friendship Manor where she could receive care around the clock. Over the next several months, in periodic ''Dear Friends'' letters steeped in religiosity and sentimentality, Gardner related her decline and his vigilance. ''Pat knows that she is surrounded by love and when she puts her hand in mine or gives me one of her sweet smiles my world brightens up,'' he wrote in September 1986. In December, he told of their plans to combine Christmas ornaments, listen to a recording of carols he'd made while in the Harvard Glee Club, and exchange gifts. ''We will be thinking . . . of the child whose life has inspired so much tenderness and good will,'' he wrote. The following April, he described how, on Palm Sunday, he'd made a cross out of his palm leaf and given it to her. ''She contemplated it, holding it for a while and then with a smile, put it in my suit pocket. . . .
''Through all of this her basic sweetness of character shines through,'' he went on. ''Every time I visit her she hands me a little stuffed dog I gave her on our first Christmas together and points to the words between his outstretched front paws which say 'I wuve you this much.' ''
Many found the letters profoundly moving. Others wondered whether they were written to convey information or, rather, to build a record. Some details - like a description of some risque underwear Nicely had purportedly bought him for Christmas - were almost embarrassingly intimate.
At around the same time, the Nicely family's inquiries to Gardner went unanswered. And, within weeks of the wedding, Hoover twice spotted Gardner with another woman, once at Gardner's house, cooking him his breakfast. The woman, a Roanoke resident named Barbara Bryan, knew that Gardner was caring for Nicely, but not that he'd married her. Indeed, so impressed was she by his apparent piety, integrity and good deeds that she nominated him for an award from the Virginia Cultural Laureate Society.
Gardner and Bryan spent the evening of May 26, 1987 at Roanoke's First Baptist Church, listening to an organ recital. At 6 the next morning, she drove back to his house, made him breakfast, then took him to the Roanoke airport, where he was to fly to Washington. Late that afternoon, Friendship Manor left word with Bryan that Patricia Nicely had died (from ''progression of dementia of Alzheimer's type'' with ''nutritional insufficiency'' as a secondary cause, according to the death certificate). After contacting Gardner, Bryan stopped by his house, picked up the royal-blue bathrobe he had given Nicely the previous Christmas, met his plane and drove him to Friendship Manor. Only then, in the parking lot, did a tearful Gardner reveal his secret to her. ''By the way, you are the first to know,'' he said. ''Pat and I were married.''
Unfazed - or perhaps dazed - by the deception, Bryan, a onetime newspaper reporter in North Carolina, composed Nicely's obituary, which also disclosed the marriage. She also took dictation as Gardner composed a double-barreled telegram to William Nicely: ''PAT DIED UNEXPECTEDLY THIS EVENING. WE HAD A GOOD VISIT TUESDAY AND SHE SEEMED ALERT WE WERE MARRIED LAST SUMMER AND SHE EXPRESSED HER WISH TO BE BURIED WITH ME IN MY FAMILY PLOT THERE WILL BE A MEMORIAL SERVICE HERE THIS WEEKEND.'' Others learned of the marriage in equally unusual ways; several found out when they read the obituary Gardner placed in the Harvard alumni magazine. He also sent out one last letter to Nicely's friends. ''I wanted all my life to meet someone like Pat and she said the same about me,'' he wrote them. ''Pat was beautiful even in her illness and while . . . I learned a great deal about fear and suffering, I learned a great deal more about love. If I never had another happy moment in my life I have had more than my share.''
No autopsy was ever performed, despite Nicely's relative youth for an Alzheimer's victim, the rapidity of her decline, and what Dr. Sunderland calls the uncertainty of any Alzheimer's diagnosis; a doctor handling the case in Roanoke, Leslie Gunzenhauser, said there was no need for one.Within 20 hours of her death - in fact, before her next of kin had been reached - Nicely, wearing Gardner's gift bathrobe, was cremated. On May 30, a scorching Saturday afternoon, she was laid to rest at Roanoke's Evergreen Burial Park. The 10 or so people at the gravesite were given printed programs, with ''In memory of Mrs. Patricia 'Pat' Nicely Gardner'' typed on top. As Gardner, who had arrived late in Nicely's BMW, sat weeping, Hoover began reading, first the passage from the Book of Proverbs about the ''woman of valor,'' then from Wordsworth: ''Nothing can bring back the hour,/ Of splendor in the grass, of glory in the flower.''
Nicely's ashes were divided in three portions. One remained in Roanoke, beneath the impressive Barre granite monument Gardner bought. ''Patricia Nicely Gardner. Feb. 26, 1928 - May 27, 1987. A Good Woman, Beloved Wife,'' it read, with ''George Victor Gardner, June 13, 1921'' carved beneath. A few weeks later, Gardner sprinkled another portion on Caspian Lake in Greensboro, Vt., where the Nicely family had long spent its summers. And in November, before many of Nicely's old colleagues, a sobbing Gardner scattered the remaining ashes around what he said was their favorite red beech tree in Montrose Park. Within a few weeks, some who had attended the burial say they spotted Gardner squiring other women around Washington.
IN 1985, GARDNER'S law partner, John Rocovich, had drawn up a will for Nicely, which left nearly everything to her nieces and nephews. For some reason, she'd never signed it. As her husband, Gardner appeared entitled to her entire estate.
The Nicely family's only remedy was to ask the Circuit Court for the City of Roanoke to invalidate the marriage, which, under Virginia law, is all but impossible to do after the death of a spouse except in cases of incest or bigamy, or when an underaged partner is involved. But the Nicely family's lawyers - Thomas Lawson, and John C. Lowe of Charlottesville - argued that if Patricia Nicely was fit for marriage, so too was a corpse. Gardner continued to argue her competence and her devotion to him, producing a veritable inventory of cards, gift tags, ribbons, candy boxes and pieces of wrapping paper he'd amassed over the years. He also pledged to give away whatever he received, principally to Vassar.
The offer was nonbinding and, largely due to Barbara Bryan, would quickly become moot as well. Bryan had continued to date Gardner, but now, she later explained, prompted less by affection than curiosity. Her goal, she says, was to expose him. If, as the state's slogan declared, ''Virginia is for lovers,'' it should be for honest lovers only, she said.
She began going through Gardner's files, sifting through his trash, poring over and (with a rented portable Canon) photocopying his past. She also retraced his pastoral career, and learned of his other troubled marriages. The first, in 1943 to a 18-year-old girl, when he was 22, lasted less than two years; in divorce proceedings, she testified that when she was pregnant, he'd made her work in a meat-packing plant and tried to induce a miscarriage by forcing her to take pills. (Gardner insists the divorce was amicable, and that his wife fabricated facts to satisfy the state's stringent divorce requirements.) Gardner's second wife, an 18-year-old Radcliffe student, quickly had their marriage annulled. Another marriage followed, which ended in divorce 32 years later. ''One would tend to feel that Gardner was a selfish, egotistical, cold human being,'' the referee in that case concluded.
Rummaging through Gardner's garbage, Bryan was able to show, from scraps of paper she retrieved, that Gardner had actually cut and pasted together the ''marriage contract'' - supposedly drafted in 1983 - after Nicely died, and that a mysterious splotch over Nicely's signature (Gardner said Nicely had spilled some of her fingernail polish on it while reading it over) actually covered up Gardner's own clumsy attempt to repair her signature, which was missing a letter. Gardner now concedes the document was drawn up posthumously, but insists it duplicated a document Nicely had in fact signed, but later lost. The revelation, made during Bryan's deposition in November 1987, prompted Gardner's lawyer to walk off the case. A few days later, Gardner's law firm in Roanoke announced he had ''retired'' from the firm. It has since removed his name.
Gardner promptly dropped all claims to Nicely's estate. But two issues - the validity of the marriage and custody of her remains - remained contested, and went to trial in April 1988. There, as one side spoke of ''Patricia Elliott Nicely'' and the other of ''Patricia Nicely Gardner,'' the story of her ''marriage'' began to emerge. ''If all you had to do to get married is to sit in a car with a woman and have her shake her head 'no', I probably would have been married three or four times before I turned 17,'' Lawson said. Gardner retained Virginia's largest law firm, Hunton & Williams, to defend him, but did not testify. In the end, Judge R. William Arthur of Wytheville said he was persuaded ''beyond peradventure'' that the marriage was bogus. Within a few days of his decision, a workman at Evergreen Burial Park dug up Nicely's ashes (known in funeral argot as ''cremains'') and handed the cigar-box-sized container to Layne Ridenhour, a paralegal at Lawson's law firm. It was leaking. Soon after, the headstone was also carted away. It now sits in the stonecutter's back lot, where it will either be sanded down and used again or dumped in the local landfill.
NER was indicted by a Virginia grand jury on three counts of perjury, one count of forgery and one count of ''uttering'' - representing a forged document as genuine. Soon the legal points will be resolved, but the debate over Gardner and his motives will likely continue.
To Barbara Bryan, The enigma of George Gardner has a simple explanation. ''He has a literally insatiable desire for social stature and acceptability, and women provide a vehicle for that,'' she says.
But some of Nicely's friends still maintain that in his grief over her illness and fear that Bill Nicely would inherit her estate, George Gardner simply lost his head. ''It could be that George was an extraordinary conniver who pulled the wool over everyone's eyes, including Pat's, but I don't think so,'' one of them, Joseph Doherty of Chestertown, Md., said. ''He didn't need Pat's money. He just lost his normal cautious lawyer's approach and did a very, very stupid thing.'' ''I don't give one tinker's damn whether George ought or ought not to have married Pat or whether his devotion and care were play acting with ulterior designs,'' wrote Cynthia Taft Morris, a Vassar classmate and economics professor at Smith College, in a letter to William Nicely. ''Since Pat believed in him, he made the difference between night and day during the final year of her life.''
More than two years have passed since Patricia Nicely died, and still, Gardner says, he is haunted by her memory. Certain places - the Kennedy Center, her house on Q Street, the lake house in Greensboro - remain psychologically off limits to him. He keeps three pictures of her in his living room, the most prominent an elegant portrait from her Vassar days. Whatever the outcome, Gardner says, he will have spent some $200,000 on lawyers by the end of his case. Still, he says he plans to give a piece of whatever is left of his own money to Vassar, in Pat Nicely's memory. Already, he has donated $25 in her name to the memorial garden for local residents across the street from Willey's general store in Greensboro.
As for Patricia Nicely, she is finally at rest in Greensboro, in the cemetery overlooking Caspian Lake. This time, her tombstone bears no epitaph save for her newly restored maiden name. The closest equivalent is the inscription carved on her mother's grave nearby, words from Virginia Woolf that Patricia Nicely herself selected a decade ago. ''Hers was a divine mentality,'' it states. ''She adored life.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1023 words

HEADLINE: 'WHAT DO YOU WANT FORM AN UNDERTAKER?'

BYLINE: By JONIS AGEE; Jonis Agee is the author of two collections of short fiction, ''Pretend We've Never Met'' and ''Bend This Heart.''

 BODY:

HELL-BENT MEN AND THEIR CITIES
By Susan Dodd.
240 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.
Susan Dodd's new collection of short stories offers an intelligent, sympathetic and sometimes satirical look at life in America at the end of the 20th century. Like most fin de siecle art, her stories are about things drawing to a close and are imbued with an almost instinctual desire to preserve something of the past. What sets Ms. Dodd's work apart is that her characters not only struggle to endure, but also manage to keep one another's spirits up, and thus defy the fragmentation and loss at hand. 
Some of the best stories in this collection explore the lives of aging men whose hard-earned wisdom is delivered in crusty, economical phrases. Rendered in language that ranges from meticulous description (''my father's footsteps seem to mend the frayed edge of the corridor carpet with fine stitches. He is thin as thread'') to the almost surreal (''two skeletal gents catnap in the shape of question marks on top of the covers, their pink chenille bedspreads prudently turned down''), these are lives caught between tragedy and cartoon.
While there is necessarily a melancholic aspect to some of these stories (one can't, after all, deny the inevitability of death), there is also an upbeat wit that keeps the characters from self-pity and the tone from morbidity. Ms. Dodd, who teaches writing at Harvard University and who has written two novels and a previous collection of stories, has a real ear for the sounds of old age, for the almost vaudevillian routines people use as a shorthand for their experience of feeling pain and fear while being full of life and wit.
Jake, a florist, calls up his friend Phil, a mortician: '' 'You got any wakes tonight?'
 
'' 'Why?' Phil said. 'You available?'
'' 'You're no Myron Cohen in the comedian category,' Jake said. '' 'What do you want from an undertaker?' '' 'A straight answer, maybe?' '' The frequent references to music, brand names, television shows and movie stars remind us that ours is a society that fills the desires of a few, while constraining most of us to live small lives, make do and die without much preparation or help. One character, contemplating entering a retirement home, remarks, ''A real wiseacre, that Sinatra'' after hearing Old Blue Eyes croon ''I'll Get By.''
While Ms. Dodd's characters' lives lack heroic scope they are brave people whose gestures symbolize hope beyond the hopelessness of their situations. In ''Don't Get Around Much Anymore'' an unemployed father, a victim of Reaganomics, waters his lawn in defiance of a ban and gives his daughter travel brochures to encourage her dreams, while his wife spends her nights crocheting toilet-paper covers and watching reruns of television cop shows. ''This lawn's not going to hell,'' he says to his daughter. ''You got any objections?'' Challenging society and life as well as his daughter, he refuses to cave in even as his world erodes. And this, Ms. Dodd suggests, is the best response to the loss and fragmentation of one's world.
Like the people in the fiction of Ann Beattie and Raymond Carver, Ms. Dodd's characters manage to create and preserve something out of the pieces of their lives, and to establish connections with others. She urges us to see that behind the quiet facades of middle-class American houses beat hearts in need of succor, and hearts sometimes willing to give it. For many of her characters, it is only fear that threatens to keep them inarticulate or alone.
The woman in the collection's title story, ''Hell-Bent Men and Their Cities,'' for instance, tries to maintain a safe distance from men and life by retiring to the country. When she meets a man, a fellow guest at the home of mutual friends, ''fear masquerading as good manners prevented her from examining his belongings.'' Torn between the freedom to run away, which terrifies her, and the prospect of loving him, which also makes her want to run away, she is ''caught . . . pierced by the pinpoints of light in his eyes.''
Only a couple of the stories seem less than successful, and these are the ones in which Ms. Dodd sacrifices her sturdy characters for an experimental form that renders the world abstract and lifeless.
Finally, the heroes in Ms. Dodd's work are those who invent the words and gestures that convince others of their love. In ''Undeniably Sweet-Talk,'' one of her most joyful stories, the male character, with ''his soul . . . draped around his knees like underpants with shot elastic,'' builds a scale replica of their future house on his beloved's lawn to persuade her to love him. His declarations force the woman, for whom ''everything she knew had to fit on a three-by-five card,'' to learn about loving. As Susan Dodd's vision suggests, what we are about here on earth is decoding the language, revealing ourselves and being revealed by our experience so that we can come to terms with change and loss and preserve something from life - love - as evidence that we have lived.
 
REQUIEM FOR A BASSET HOUND
 It was the saddest damn thing I ever saw, that small pretty woman all alone out there with nobody to help her, burying her dog.
 I would have been glad to lend a hand, of course, once I realized what she was doing. But I had a feeling she needed to do it herself.
 She had a real struggle getting him out to the yard. Basset hounds are squat but heavy. He was stretched out on his side, stiff-legged already, on a fuzzy pink bath mat, the kind that's supposed to look like fur - if you can imagine pink fur. She slid him down the three steps from the back door. The way the carcass bumped down those steps made me grit my teeth. She was crazy about that dog. She dragged the mat across the grass toward the far corner of the house. Her eyes were closed. . . . The clock on the stove said a quarter to eight. I put the coffee on to perk. Then, very quietly, I went out the front door and circled around the north side to the back. From behind a bank of gone-by lilacs, I could see her. She'd already started digging.
 
From ''Hell-Bent Men and Their Cities.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1615 words

HEADLINE: HOW TO ENCOURAGE NEW HERESIES

BYLINE: By MARCIA BARTUSIAK; Marcia Bartusiak, the author of ''Thursday's Universe,'' is writing a book about how astronomers discovered the composition of the heavens.

 BODY:

DISCOVERING
By Robert Scott Root-Bernstein.
Illustrated. 501 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $35.
Seeing that science, with its exponential growth, has blossomed a millionfold since the 1600's, why are we not witnessing a millionfold increase in the number of fundamental discoveries, Robert Scott Root-Bernstein wonders in ''Discovering.'' Scientific revolutions, the kinds of upheavals that dramatically alter our view of nature, spring up at a rather constant pace, he claims. Where are the thousands of Newtons, Darwins and Einsteins that should now be walking the earth? The modern publication explosion in science has arrived without a commensurate explosion in astounding revelations. Has science, in all its manifestations, now become so bureaucratic that it ends up sabotaging those who would discover? 
At the age of 27, Mr. Root-Bernstein, a biochemist and historian of science, received a MacArthur Prize in 1981. It enabled him to search for the blueprint to scientific discovery, a venture he believes is too unconventional to have won financing from customary sources. The 19th-century British biologist Thomas Huxley once noted that new truths in science often begin as heresy, advance to orthodoxy and end as superstition. Mr. Root-Bernstein considers how we can encourage new heresies, especially in the face of institutional grant systems that tend to fund exploration of the orthodoxies. Investigators confident of their own notions of how science is done will likely dismiss the book's approach as foolhardy and superficial. They will have a point: while refreshingly frank, Mr. Root-Bernstein has a chip on his shoulder, which makes it difficult to trust some of his assessments. Others, though, might judge the book as bold and imaginative, for it is far from the dry, scholarly tome one expects on such a subject.
Mr. Root-Bernstein unveils his propositions and counterarguments through the voices of six fictional professionals who take part in a colloquium on discovering that extends over six Saturday mornings. Ernest, a biologist and scientific gadfly, better known as Imp, is the instigator of the project. ''In matters intellectual he's like a child with a newfound toy,'' according to his wife, Jenny, a historian of French culture. Then there is Hunter, a down-to-earth chemist and history of science buff; Ariana, an endocrinologist, who as a photographer and amateur cellist brings her artistic predilections to the debate; Constance, a patent attorney and historian of science; and Richter, Imp's colleague, who serves as the resident curmudgeon and traditionalist. This group attempts to determine whether discoveries are inevitably unpredictable stumbles and sudden flashes of insight, as commonly assumed, or the result of reproducible methods or a bent of mind that might be taught and applied. They seek this elusive algorithm in the childhoods, educational backgrounds, correspondences, hobbies and laboratory notebooks of celebrated scientists.
Anecdotal evidence does suggest that certain creative habits can be acquired. J. J. Thomson, the discoverer of the electron and a recipient of the Nobel Prize in Physics, trained nine Nobel Prize winners, 32 fellows of Britain's Royal Society and 83 professors of physics. And Mr. Root-Bernstein marshals good arguments that many mythical chance discoveries were not lucky breaks at all, but more like unanticipated detours in well-designed research efforts. In this regard, ''Discovering'' is a good detective story. Take the case of Alexander Fleming. As the legend goes, a stray penicillium mold lands on a bacteria-filled petri dish in Fleming's laboratory. About to discard the dish, Fleming suddenly notices that the mold has dissolved the bacterial colonies. Voila! Antibiotics. But Imp deduces from circumstantial evidence that Fleming merely noticed at first the errant mold's mild antiseptic properties; only after deliberately culturing the mold did he clinch that the bacteria were being wiped out. ''Fleming clearly experimented with anything he could lay his hands on, wherever he found it,'' Imp points out. ''That was part of his research style. Playing.'' Good scientists seem to design experiments that will yield surprises; they foster the conditions. Examinations of a host of notable achievers in science show them to be broadly educated, with more than a passing interest in art, music, poetry and literature. Often making their mark in previously unfashionable or neglected areas of research, they retain a childlike curiosity about the world.
Does this book's fictional approach succeed? Yes and no; the device wears thin after a hundred pages. That the author has done his homework cannot be doubted. But the characters spew forth nuggets of wisdom in machine-gun fashion. Perhaps only Mr. Spock could carry this off with elan. Moreover, the reader can never really be sure where Mr. Root-Bernstein himself stands. Richter calls Freud a charlatan and relegates computer science to mere number crunching, apparently dismissing the seminal work of John von Neumann and Alan Turing. Are these the author's own thoughts, fanciful comments or opinions he has heard in the scientific community?
As a historian, he overromanticizes the lone scientist arriving at profound insights with third-rate equipment. ''The atom was split by Otto Hahn in 1938 using apparatus that fit on a desktop,'' it is noted, suggesting that the best science is nearly always this simple. More disturbing is the air of cynicism that pervades the book, evidently springing from Mr. Root-Bernstein's personal battles with ''Big Science.'' A running subplot, overly technical and incomprehensible to the nonspecialist, has Imp attacking molecular biology's most cherished dogmas; the footnotes reveal that Imp's challenge is based on the author's own biological research. From off-the-record comments I hear among researchers, the scientific bureaucracy indeed seems to need shaking up, but the author's digs at the workaday scientist may alienate the very audience he must persuade.
It is only in the last quarter of the book that Mr. Root-Bernstein convinces. Coherence finally replaces frantic fact-tossing. His findings are billed as controversial, but I do not find them as far removed as he does from past explorations of this issue. He presents an evolutionary model of scientific development: Ideas in science are selected or retained through a form of natural selection. As new species often arise in regions of geographical isolation, so too are many great discoveries made on the peripheries of science. A scientific revolution's ''paradigm shift'' (a concept introduced in 1962 by Thomas Kuhn in his ''Structure of Scientific Revolutions'') could then be viewed as the sudden emergence of the new species on the broad plain of science. All too short, this 25-page section should really be extended into a more standard work. Mr. Kuhn cannot be effectively challenged in a fictional setting.
The author concludes with a long list of prescriptions for encouraging discovery. He recommends no less than a complete overhaul of how science is funded and taught. Demolish the system of students marching lockstep through a succession of prerequisites, he says; the diversity necessary for scientific advancement is lost with such cloning. And fund people, not projects. Of course, this strategy raises many problems. How will grant givers differentiate between the self-deluded and a bona fide visionary? Someone in the end will have to make the decision, creating a whole new form of Big Science. Mr. Root-Bernstein is certainly not the first to make many of these statements on cultural evolution and the revamping of funding procedures, and he does credit his predecessors. What he adds is a cry of urgency: ''Could Darwin carry out his twenty-year program to restructure biology within the present academic system? . . . Would anyone read Einstein, publishing from a patent office? . . . I say that unless we start making provisions for such rare and valuable scientists now - for learning, thinking, and doing individually and eccentrically; for the disorganization of science - we'll have no great scientists in the future, and no great scientific breakthroughs, either.''
''Discovering'' is sometimes frustrating, chaotic and, in several places, obscure, but it is also surprising and thought-provoking. Perhaps it could be a much-needed catalyst for discussion. The odds are astronomical against one book's sundering the entire bureaucratic structure of science. But Mr. Root-Bernstein has lifted his hammer high to try for a good slam.
 
SO NOW WHAT HAPPENS?
 Let me make some predictions. . . . First, the great inventions and discoveries will take place in countries having expanding economies that support the institutional growth or reconfiguration necessary to accommodate mavericks. Second, these mavericks can be expected to be oddly trained hybrids combining old and new theories, data, and techniques. . . . Third, they will most likely be trained at new and peripheral institutions or they will work in newly emerging fields. . . . Fourth, cultures . . . that promote educational and ideological pluralism, intellectual freedom, and idiosyncratic behavior . . . will have a higher proportion of inventors and discoverers. . . . Fifth, the period preceding any great breakthrough in science will be characterized by the elaboration of a tremendous diversity of possible solutions. . . . Sixth, consensus will be found only in the codified fields of science in which little or no research is presently being done.
 
From ''Discovering.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1036 words

HEADLINE: Safety in Lower Numbers

BYLINE: By GLORIA DUFFY; Gloria Duffy's most recent book is ''Compliance and the Future of Arms Control.''

 BODY:

MEETING GORBACHEV'S CHALLENGE
How to Build Down the NATO-Warsaw Pact Confrontation.
By Jonathan Dean.
445 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press.
Cloth, $45. Paper, $16.95.
 
CONVENTIONAL ARMS CONTROL AND EAST-WEST SECURITY
Edited by Robert D. Blackwill and F. Stephen Larrabee.
491 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. 
Cloth, $67.50. Paper, $19.95.
Since their December 1989 summit in Malta, Mikhail Gorbachev and George Bush have brought negotiations to control conventional military forces in Europe to the forefront of Soviet-American relations. At their meeting, the two leaders agreed to conclude a treaty limiting NATO and Warsaw Pact forces.
These two books review the issues the Soviet and American negotiators will have to address, offering recommendations about the scope of the talks in Vienna and the shape of the final pact. They present an interesting counterpoint.
Jonathan Dean was the Carter Administration's chief negotiator at the Mutual and Balanced Force Reduction talks. In session for nearly two decades, from October 1973 to February 1989, these earlier Vienna negotiations failed to yield an East-West conventional arms-control agreement. ''Meeting Gorbachev's Challenge'' is a rather urgent how-to manual for the current diplomats, drawing on Mr. Dean's own frustrating experience in search of a treaty, and exhorting his successors to make deep cuts in NATO and Warsaw Pact forces.
''Conventional Arms Control and East-West Security'' is a collection of essays by Western, Soviet and East European experts (including Mr. Dean). One of the editors, Robert D. Blackwill, is currently the senior National Security Council staff member responsible for Soviet and East European affairs, and among the key figures shaping the Bush Administration's positions for the Vienna talks. The other editor, F. Stephen Larrabee, is the vice president and director of studies of the Institute for East-West Security Studies, the organization that sponsored the volume. Together, in their introduction and conclusion, they exhibit a cautious, go-slow approach.
The main points of contention between Mr. Dean and most of the Western contributors to the volume of essays are what NATO's objectives in the Vienna talks ought to be, and how quickly the Western alliance should pursue significant reductions with the Warsaw Pact. At present, the Bush Administration seeks a decrease in Warsaw Pact forces to NATO levels in offensive weapons - primarily tanks, artillery and armored troop carriers. Then a small cut, of 5 or 10 percent, would be made on both sides. The Western contributors to the essays, drawn primarily from the Rand Corporation and European organizations such as the International Institute for Strategic Studies, generally support this approach.
These experts see the problems inherent in reaching an agreement more clearly than they see solutions. A key issue to be resolved before a treaty can be reached is the fate of NATO's forward defense strategy, if forces are to be pulled back on both sides of the frontier and cut significantly, thinning the NATO forces available to defend against an attack. Two Rand analysts, Edward L. Warner 3d and David A. Ochmanek, contend that the offensive forces targeted for reduction in the negotiations are so integral to NATO's defensive strategy that any reductions must be highly asymetrical, favoring NATO.
While the essays raise questions, Mr. Dean's book offers answers. He argues that the West should seek immediate 50 percent cuts in weapons and manpower on both sides, once the Warsaw Pact reduces to NATO levels. His rationales include the need to cut Western defense costs, and the shakiness of Mr. Gorbachev's position in his own country. The sense of a fleeting opportunity during the Soviet leader's tenure in office leads Mr. Dean to advise NATO leaders to obtain Warsaw Pact cuts while they can.
Mr. Dean has very detailed objectives for the Vienna talks. In addition to the 50 percent cuts, he advocates a zone free of offensive forces along the Central European front. The remaining forces would be restructured for ''non-offensive defense,'' preventing either side from fielding enough offensive forces to prevail over the defensive strength of its adversary. Mr. Dean argues that NATO's forward defense can be retained even with 50 percent cuts by maintaining rapidly movable armored divisions as an operational reserve.
The primary reason the interminable Mutual and Balanced Force Reduction negotiations in Vienna never progressed was the lack of high-level political pressure on both sides. In Mr. Dean's call for an ambitious initial agreement, one detects the frustrated former negotiator, who sees the attention of political leaders finally focused on the problem of conventional forces in Europe and is anxious that the opportunity be seized before their attention drifts away.
The rapid democratization of Eastern Europe, and Mr. Gorbachev's encouragement of this trend, support Mr. Dean's proposal for deep cuts. It is increasingly difficult to conceive of an issue that would provoke a NATO-Warsaw Pact confrontation in Europe. In this light, the size of the NATO and Warsaw Pact armies is increasingly out of proportion to the threat of war.
Indeed, the extraordinary debate about military forces and strategy taking place within the Warsaw Pact today is more interesting than the discussions among Westerners about the talks on conventional forces. Ten essays by Soviet and East European analysts in ''Conventional Arms Control and East-West Security'' open a window into this debate. The arguments that such leading experts as Andrei A. Kokoshin and Alexei G. Arbatov are raising in Moscow in support of reducing and restructuring Soviet conventional forces are presented here, including Mr. Kokoshin's suggestive historical analysis of how Soviet defensive tactics succeeded in the Battle of Kursk during World War II. The way in which these civilian analysts are shaping the debate over military forces in Moscow - and reshaping Soviet defense policy - is yet one more aspect of the intellectual ferment within the Soviet Union that is currently changing the course of world events.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 13, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 764 words

HEADLINE: About Cars;
Justy Is a Quality, High-Tech Econocar

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
When you spend a lot of money for a car, certain things are to be expected. You get fancy trim, maybe leather. You get performance. And, generally, you get high-tech electronics and mechanical doodads.
When you spend a pittance, as we all know, you get none of these things. 
But we are all sometimes wrong, too, as in the case of Subaru's minicar, the Justy, whose econocar persona carries some very exotic technology indeed.
The Justy was introduced as a two-door hatchback in 1987 and revamped for 1989 to house America's only constantly variable transmission, known as a CVT, or, in the electronically controlled Subaru version, as an ECVT.
The idea goes back to the late 1800's and is a neat one, transmitting power through a belt that rides on variable-diameter pulleys. The advantages are compact size, few moving parts, low weight and an infinite variety of ratios to perfectly match vehicle loads to engine speeds, all without shifting gears.
Years of experimentation meant little, though, in the absence of other highly advanced technology, and as with so many things, it is the computer that has made the CVT a practical invention.
Subaru, produced by Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan, came to the United States in the 70's and has long been something of a technological maverick, what with pancake-flat engines, hill-holder manual transmissions to prevent the vehicles from rolling backward on an incline, and the first passenger cars to sport four-wheel drive.
For 1990, Justy also has been given optional all-wheel drive, which means that Subaru is the only company to offer both front-wheel and four-wheel drive versions of every car it sells. This year, Justy also adds a four-door to its line, as well as a ''Fun Justy'' that takes aim at the younger subcompact buyer.
Fuel injection now feeds gas to the three-cylinder engine, eliminating cold-start and driveability problems and reducing exhaust emissions as a nice side benefit. Power is up by more than 10 percent, and while there are still only 73 horses under the hood, the tiny engine is one of the few that puts out one or more horsepower per cubic inch.
Actual displacement measures 1.2 liters, and the engine takes fuel in genteel sips. Depending on the model, the transmission and whether the car has front-wheel or four-wheel drive, the mileage figures range from 29, city, to 37, highway.
With only three cylinders, the Justy is a long way from being a hotrod, but it is reasonably competent on the road. Larger wheels and tires were part of last year's re-do, and the car is no longer bouncy or skittish.
There are bucket seats up front, and interior room has been increased. Still, the Justy is only 12 feet long, and that makes it perfect for city driving, while the added power makes it usable, if not ideal, for trips.
Fully dressed, the car weighs only 2,090 pounds, and acceleration from 0 to 60 m.p.h. takes about 12 seconds with the standard five-speed transmission. The ECVT is about a second slower, but the trip is interesting.
The difference between a transmission with gears and an ECVT without them is like the difference between a three-way light switch and one with a dimmer control. The constantly variable transmission uses stepless ratio changes and there is a smooth and uninterrupted flow of power.
To work its magic, the transmission uses a pair of pulleys and a metal belt that runs in the valley of each pulley. One flange of each pulley is anchored to its hub, but the other slides in and out, expanding and narrowing the V, thus moving the belt up and down to alter the drive ratios. Hydraulics, controlled by a computer, move the flanges.
Perhaps even more amazing is the magnetic-powder clutch that connects the ECVT to the engine. It consists of a drum that is bolted to the engine's crankshaft and that houses a rotor and a cargo of fine steel powder. The rotor is connected to the ECVT. A magnetic coil is mounted on the drum, and when it is activated by a computer the magnetism solidifies the powder, locking drum and rotor together. Demagnetized, the powder is once more just dust, and the rotor is free to spin. When a driver presses the accelerator, the clutch locks up. When the car slows to a halt, the clutch disengages. Simple, what?
The ECVT option adds $540 to the Justy's base sticker of $5,866. Four-wheel drive costs another $700, and air-conditioning is the other big-ticket item at $750. So you can figure that a loaded four-door will roll out of the dealership for about $9,300.
These days, that is what we mean when we talk pittance.

HEADLINE: Buyers Hang Back in Muddled Market

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A TWO-YEAR slump in property values has pushed down home prices in the New York region and mortgage interest rates also have fallen, but the reductions show little sign of attracting the huge numbers of buyers who were locked out of the region's giddy real estate market in the mid-80's.
Economists point to one main reason, demonstrated in several recent studies: Prices remain sky high compared to the incomes of most New York area residents. That price-income gap puts homeownership, or a move up to a better home, out of reach.
The price and interest-rate drops are being offset by higher taxes and insurance costs. And in a region that is already one of the nation's most expensive, other bills paid by both owners and renters, including those for fuel and utilities, are forcing people to reach deeper into their pockets. 
Nor have income and employment gains kept pace with the rising household expenses.
''It is not that the economy is falling apart, but the important missing element is the kind of economic expansion we had,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the New York Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. In contrast to the mid-80's, when New York City and its suburbs were gaining 150,000 new jobs a year, the growth has slowed to 50,000, he said, adding: ''That kind of slowdown is bound to have an impact on housing demand.''
The result is a confused, contradictory and frustrating housing market that confounds expectations. Ordinarily, when house prices and loan rates fall, sales rebound. But most households are facing rising costs, families hoping to move up are struggling to find buyers for their current residences and the feverish boom atmosphere of the mid-80's has segued into a cold new environment.
It is a market with signposts pointing in several directions, giving pause to both sellers and buyers, and many are choosing to postpone decisions until the picture clears. If there is a watchword in the market, it seems to be ''hesitate.''
Adding to the confusion are brisk sales at some new developments and sales so weak at others that their builders are offering the units for rent.
''IF you bought a house at the end of 1987 you might feel like this market is the end of the world,'' said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which reported the median house price in the region hit a peak of $196,000 in 1988 and has since fallen 7 percent, to $182,400, but still too high for those who might consider buying their first home. ''Affordability just hasn't gotten much better,'' she said. Indeed, the median family income of people living in New York City and its suburbs - $30,867 - is less than half the $63,020 required by most lenders to qualify for the mortgage on the region's median-price house - even after making a 20 percent down payment, according to the National Association of Realtors, a trade group.
The real estate slump is being aggravated by the changing psychology among those who might buy a house, even those who can afford the high prices of the New York region. Many of them, young professionals in their 20's and 30's who had watched home values soar for a decade, have adopted a skeptical view of future gains.
''Buying into this market is a real gamble,'' said Scott Fortini, a marketing manager at Guiness Brands who was transferred from southern Florida to the company's headquarters in Stamford, Conn., in November. He received approval early this month for a mortgage loan to buy a $220,000 town-house condominium in Brookfield, Conn., but, having spent more than two months in the New York region, has decided not to buy. ''It will be safer to rent for a while,'' he said. To be sure, lower interest rates are providing a strong incentive to some buyers. Fixed-rate, 30-year mortgages are widely available at slightly under 10 percent, down from 11 percent a year ago.
''We have probably hit bottom or come close to it,'' in housing demand and prices, said Rae Rosen, an economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York. She added that the one-percentage-point decline in interest rates means that the buyer of a $185,000 home, close to the median price in the New York region, would now pay $100 a month less in mortgage payments than a year ago.
Ms. Rosen added, however, that a recovery from the real estate slump ''will be long and slow.''
Business executives have maintained for years that a period of flat or declining home prices would be needed to encourage long-term economic growth. Large employers complain of the difficulty of transferring executives into the region because its home prices are too high, and many of the suburbs face an acute shortage of lower-paid support personnel who cannot afford to buy or rent anywhere near office centers.
''Housing costs are still an issue, but we see reasons for optimism in this market,'' said John Raffaeli, general manager for compensation for the Continental Can Corporation, based in Norwalk, Conn.
Continental Can now finds it somewhat easier to persuade executives to transfer to the Norwalk headquarters from other offices around the country, he said. Secretaries, computer programmers and others already stationed in Norwalk are also likely to benefit from the weak housing market, he added, particularly if they are able to buy cut-rate homes in a state program, announced in December, in which Connecticut plans to purchase unsold condominiums and offer them to low- and middle-income families.
And in a region where far more people rent - and pay much higher rental bills - than in most other parts of the of the nation, most experts maintain there remains a large reservoir of potential buyers. Most rental bills have been gradually rising, creating more incentive to buy among those who can afford it.
SOME developers report robust sales of new homes and apartments, despite the sluggishness that pervades most of the region. In Floral Park, Queens, 72 percent of the apartments in Parkwood Estates have been sold since the building was converted to cooperative ownership from rentals in June, according to Blare Realty, sponsor of the conversion. Prices in the project are below those of most new New York City cooperatives, beginning at $86,000 for a one-bedroom apartment.
In Manhattan, the developers of the Coronado, a new condominium at 71st Street and Broadway, said 49 of the 120 apartments had been sold since their sales office opened late in September. Prices there are more typical of fashionable new Manhattan properties, beginning at $175,000 for a studio and at over $700,000 for some larger apartments.
And in Stamford, the developer of 12 new detached homes, Warwick Malkin, said half had been sold since they were completed in January 1989. Homes in the project, Sterling Lake, begin at $620,000.
Still, according to economists, real estate executives and frustrated sellers, the New York area market remains in a slump.
In Brooklyn, where housing demand and prices in Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, Park Slope and some other neighborhoods were buoyed by booming business on Wall Street during the mid-80's, hopeful sellers now must contend with the impact of reduced wages and thousands of layoffs at banks and securities firms.
''We have a market that doesn't exist,'' said Carl Peek, owner of Prudential-Carl Peek Real Estate, which deals in the Brooklyn neighborhoods. ''Everybody is trying to will this market to turn, but things won't change, even with lower interest rates, until people realize they are dealing with a different set of numbers.''
And even in the market for high-priced Manhattan homes, many would-be buyers have retreated to the sidelines after concluding that the only apartment worth considering is one they can negotiate down to a fire-sale price.
''The only people buying now are the ones who have convinced themselves they are getting a steal,'' said Barbara Corcoran, the principal in the Corcoran Group, which deals in expensive Manhattan co-op apartments and condominiums. In an analysis of sales of 297 apartments in December, she said prices had been negotiated down from what the sellers asked by an average of 17 percent, compared to reductions of 4 percent a year earlier.
The National Association of Realtors said the affordability ''index'' has changed little in the New York region. The only metropolitan areas in its study that were less affordable were San Francisco, where the median family income was $43,815 and the median price of a home had soared to $269,400, and Los Angeles, where the median family income is $36,558 and the median home price had risen to $224,600. In both California cities, people making the median family income have even less of a chance of qualifying for a mortgage on a median-priced home than those in the New York region, it said.
In contrast, the study found that in and around most major cities - Washington, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Miami, Cleveland and Detroit among them - median incomes were more than enough to qualify for median-priced homes.
A STUDY by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey of prices in New York City, southern Westchester, northern New Jersey and Long Island showed how the market boomed earlier in the decade and has stumbled since early 1988. Beginning in 1983, when the median price of a home in the area was slightly over $80,000, prices surged 15 to 30 percent a year until 1987, when increases slowed sharply. By the end of 1988, values had started to sink, it said, declining 5 percent by the end of 1989.
In contrast, the nationwide median price of a home - $95,000 last year - has been rising steadily, but far more gradually, since 1983. It remains less than half the median price in the New York region, the study showed.
The cost of renting an apartment or house in the New York region, while going through far less volatile swings than the price of home ownership, has been steadily rising in most cases. The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which surveys households on changes in consumer prices - including the cost of shelter - said a typical renter in New York and Northern New Jersey paid 6.5 percent more at the end of November than a year earlier.
In New York City, where more 800,000 apartments are rent stabilized, most rent increases have been slightly lower - currently 5.5 percent on one-year leases and 9 percent on two-year leases.
In setting the limits on rent increases, the city's Rent Guidelines Board analyzes operating costs paid by landlords. It found that for the fiscal year ended last April 30 operating costs rose 6.7 percent, with the cost of taxes, fees and permits a major culprit, rising 15.8 percent, and utility bills up 12.4 percent. The year earlier, the board found overall costs up 6.4 percent, with fuel prices leading the way, rising 12.6 percent.
Despite the increased costs of landlords, however, rents for many better apartments in Manhattan have declined, even on apartments where slight increases would be allowed under stabilization laws, as landlords have sharpened their competition for tenants.
A survey of Manhattan rentals by Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental agency, found that almost all rents on studio apartments that were turned over to new tenants by her agency in 1989 had lower rents than in 1988, and that the reductions occurred in both rent-stabilized and nonstabilized buildings.
Some of the larger apartments analyzed by Ms. Packes also had slight declines in rents, while others increased.
Examples from her survey included stabilized one-bedroom apartments in Upper West Side buildings without doormen, which had an average rent of $1,400 in 1989, down from $1,575 in 1988; market-rate two-bedroom apartments in East Side buildings with doormen, which averaged $3,600 a month in 1989, up from $3,150 in 1988, and stabilized three-bedroom apartments in Upper West Side buildings without doormen, which averaged $3,175 a month in 1989, down from $3,275 a month in 1988.
For those considering buying, the shifts in housing prices present a predicament. Some have concluded that the real estate downturn has created a long-awaited opportunity to buy while others are put off committing themselves in a market that shows no immediate sign of turning up.
''You can get caught in a bind,'' said Andy Helsand, a 33-year-old Manhattan lawyer who has bought a one-bedroom apartment in the East 60's for $200,000. Recently married, and living in the cramped quarters of a nearby studio, he and his wife plan to move into the new apartment this month.
BUT Mr. Helsand is not a first-time homeowner, and like thousands of others in the New York region, he has found that putting a home up for sale can be a frustrating experience. His studio, first advertised for sale last July, still hasn't sold, so he is now planning to rent it out to cover his costs.
''In this market you may be winning when you buy but getting killed when you sell,'' he said, adding that even though several people came to the open houses he had advertised to sell his studio, ''nobody seemed serious - it was like they were just out for a walk on a Sunday afternoon.''
Mr. Fortini, the marketing manager in Stamford, said he had started his search for a home in November fully aware that the market was weak, and seeking a bargain. ''I was looking for a real distressed situation,'' he said.
He found it in High Meadow, a small complex of new condominium town houses in Brookfield that had been taken over from its developer in a bank foreclosure. Although the bank had not discounted the asking prices in the complex, Mr. Fortini said it was offering something almost as appealing - financing far below market rates, with a mortgage guaranteed at 4.9 percent interest for seven years.
Still, he said, he and his wife, Kelly, do not savor the prospect of living indefinitely in a two-bedroom town house 40 miles from his office and planned to move on to another home in two to four years. Since applying for his mortgage two months ago, he said, he has given much thought to what would happen if the current slump in the market lasts much further into the 1990's.
''Everybody is second-guessing this market, me among them,'' Mr. Fortini said. ''At the moment, my best guess is that if one doesn't plan to stay in a house for five years or more, it is not worth the risk.''
