HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Cooperative Conversions;
The Problems of Sponsors and Owners

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
CLOUDS have begun to drift over the market for those co-ops and condominiums in which conversion sponsors still own large numbers of apartments occupied by rent-regulated tenants.
Reports that some co-ops have had to raise maintenance charges sharply to cover monthly payments not made by sponsors are worrying both shareholders and prospective buyers, and the concerns are growing. But so far the extent of the delinquencies is unclear. Are the problems likely to affect the sponsors alone, or will they also create serious difficulties for the buildings and their owner-occupants? Can these problems be worked out by the co-ops themselves and their lenders? And are there weaknesses in the rules governing the conversion process itself that need correction by law or regulation?
Fifteen years ago, during a real estate recession in New York City, the noneviction conversion system emerged as an ingenious method of allowing rental buildings to be sold to co-op corporations without disturbing the long-term residency rights of regulated renters. The buildings would become ''true'' co-ops over time - with genuine control by the residents in occupancy - as the regulated apartments were vacated and sold. 
The system was designed to avoid the anguish and antagonisms then prevalent in the conversion process, when people who refused to buy were threatened with eventual eviction. Noneviction conversions seemed to offer the best hope of gradually putting much of New York City's crippled rent-regulated housing stock on a sound long-term basis. In the rising market of the 80's, it worked beyond expectations.
Not only did individual unit buyers profit by taking advantage of the spread between the rent-regulated value of space and its true market value, but professional converters came into the picture to do so on a mass basis. But then came the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which shrank the sponsors' market for the shares representing renter-occupied apartments. On top of that came the general slowdown in the housing market in the late 80's.
There now appear to be about 139,500 owner-occupied apartments in New York City in 3,838 buildings that had converted from rental status by last fall. Most of the buildings were converted under noneviction plans. In many, conversion sponsors hold only a small number of apartments or none at all.
The concern of Frederick K. Mehlman, assistant attorney general in charge of the Real Estate Financing Bureau, is that there may be problems in buildings that were converted fairly recently, and particularly in those where the sponsors still own the vast majority of apartments and there is a large gap between the payments they receive as rent and what they must pay the co-op for maintenance.
''I don't know how bad the problem is,'' he said last week. ''It's premature to call this a crisis.'' He said he had 40 pending investigations of complaints of sponsor delinquencies in co-op or condominium buildings in New York City.
It was the filing by Time Equities, a major conversion organization, of a change in the financial position of its principal, Francis Greenburger, that set off the tremors in the marketplace.
Mr. Greenburger has interests in about 50 buildings in New York City. No complaints have been received that his payments to cooperative corporations or condominium associations are not current, Mr. Mehlman said.
IN some cases, Time Equities owns only a small number of shares in the buildings. At the condominium at 302 West 12th Street, for example, only 16 of the 129 residential units are in the hands of the West Village Equities Group, an entity that is 80-percent owned by Mr. Greenburger.
At another building, 1045 Park Avenue, the sponsor, also an entity 80 percent owned by Mr. Greenburger, owns only two of 41 apartments.
Buildings with such a small proportion of sponsor-owned shares should be immune from whatever problems may beset others. Even where sponsors own most of the shares, there are not necessarily problems. In many properties, the sponsor has an institutional partner with the strength to ride out slow markets. In condominium buildings, managements do not have to worry about collecting funds to repay an underlying mortgage.
What Time Equities appears to have done is to make a disclosure of a ''change in financial condition'' that it considered to be required by law, even though the problems have not affected the carrying charges due to the buildings in which it owns apartments.
In the past, some sponsors experiencing financial difficulties have managed to sell their renter-occupied apartments to new investors. It is unclear whether, prior to these sales, amendments were filed by the sponsors to report a ''material change in financial condition.'' The sales may have forestalled such problems, or they may have been simple business decisions. Some lawyers say that disclosure filings were not considered necessary until ownership actually changed hands.
For example, conversion practitioners say that Robert Shapiro, now a home builder on Long Island, divested himself of his interest in as many as 50 properties to other partners. D. B. G. Property Investors, at one time an active conversion sponsor in New York City and elsewhere, similarly is reported to have sold its interests in at least six Manhattan buildings after the 1986 tax act undermined the syndication and resale of unsold apartments.
Efforts to obtain comments from the principals in the sales were unsuccessful.
IN the widely publicized case of Gerald Guterman, a converter who lost his interest in several major properties in a bankruptcy filing, lenders took over payments to co-ops or condominium associations.
In any event, last month, after the receipt of the Time Equities filing on a change in financial condition, Mr. Mehlman sent lawyers active in the conversion field a letter reminding them that they must disclose any ''material change'' in a sponsor's financial condition. Accordingly, sponsors now may feel obliged to file statements before transactions are completed.
The sponsors' sales of renter-occupied apartments have typically been to other converters and investors who are able to wait out the market until the apartments become vacant and their value can be realized in a sale. In some cases banks that had made loans on the occupied units have taken over the shares. Payments to co-op corporations and condominium associations have continued.
But in other recent cases, co-op boards have reported delinquencies. On paper, the boards of the co-ops have strong legal recourses. They can seize the rent payments being made to a sponsor. And their claims to the shares of sponsor-held apartments take precedence over the claims of a bank that has lent money to the sponsor based on the value of the shares.
But this is not to underestimate the plight of shareholders living in a building mostly occupied by regulated renters, where the sponsor owning those apartments is falling behind on maintenance payments to the corporation, where owner-occupants are weakly represented on the board, and where it appears that legal action may have to be taken to enforce the shareholders' rights and interests.
Enforcing those rights and protecting those interests may take time, may be costly and may require at least temporary increases in monthly costs or special assessments. And while a legal battle is proceding, apartment values may fall and owners who want to move may not be able to sell without loss.
Sometimes, in these situations, the Attorney General's office itself has asked banks and other lenders to step in. Their role in assuring that sponsor obligations to the co-op are met can be crucial.
In the 70's, some co-op corporations themselves became the purchasers of unsold shares, at prices that turned out to be bargains. Over time they were able to resell the apartments after they had been vacated, and ease the maintenance budgets for their shareholders.
For the future, Attorney General Robert Abrams last week announced legislative proposals designed to strengthen owner-occupants' position in newly converted co-ops. Even without new legislation, some co-op lawyers say, Mr. Abrams can strengthen regulations to protect shareholders.
Far greater disclosure of the financial position of sponsors could be required, with periodic updating. There could be more information in the offering about the business background of conversion sponsors. This information is usually extremely limited.
Sponsors could also be obliged to state whether they were putting money in escrow to assure maintenance payments on the sponsor-held, renter-occupied apartments.
Computerized records of the Attorney General on buildings and units converted, matched against the Rent Stabilization Association's data on regulated apartments, show there still is a long way to go before shareholders replace renters and fully occupy converted buildings. There are about 131,400 rent-regulated households still living in converted buildings in the city. Of the total, 50,000 are in Manhattan.
But of 117,100 apartments in converted Manhattan buildings, it appears that 67,000 have been sold, primarily for owner-occupancy. In Queens, where 76,900 apartments have been converted, there have been about 39,900 purchases.
To continue successfully, the conversion system will have to demonstrate that it can protect the interests of shareholders in a slow market as well as in a strong one.
 
CHANGES SOUGHT IN CONVERSION LAWS
THE New York State Attorney General last week called upon the Legislature to enact a series of changes in the laws affecting conversions of rental property to co-ops or condominiums and said that he was studying still others.
Some have been proposed for years, but generally have been caught up in broader disputes between the housing committees of the Assembly and the Senate and have failed to pass.
Once again Robert Abrams, the Attorney General, is proposing that to obtain a noneviction conversion - in which nonbuying renters are entitled to stay on as renters after conversion - a sponsor be required to obtain 25 percent, rather than the current 15 percent, of tenant purchasers. ''This would avoid the creation of sham co-ops that have no significant involvement by interested on-premises owners,'' the Attorney General said.
Another change would allow sponsors to utilize only 5 percent of vacant apartments, instead of the current 10 percent, toward meeting the minimum purchasing requirement for conversion. By manipulating vacancies under current law, the Attorney General says, sponsors often can convert a building without selling to even one tenant.
The following other proposals are under study:
* Requiring that a sponsor provide some form of financial security sufficient to cover its financial obligations for a certain period of time after a building is converted.
* Increasing the guaranteed net worth a sponsor must demonstrate before undertaking a conversion. The current level of $5,000 has not been raised since 1963, Mr. Abrams said.
* Requiring that if a sponsor defaults on maintenance payments for units it owns, the rents from nonpurchasing tenants living in the apartments be paid directly to the co-op corporation or condominium association, not to the sponsor.
* Shortening the time period in which sponsors may continue to control co-op or condominium boards. The current period in a noneviction conversion is five years after the conversion date, or after the sponsor sells 50 percent of the shares (or units, in a condominium), whichever comes sooner. Also, requiring that every board include a member who is independent of the sponsor, even if the sponsor owns a majority of the shares.
* Authorizing the Attorney General to reject amendments to offering plans aimed at substantially reducing or altering any terms of the plan. Examples are amendments that increase the size of a building's mortgage, or cancel a promised improvement, the Attorney General said.
The object would be to limit the ability of sponsors unilaterally to increase the financial burden on shareholders after they have purchased. Some courts have held that under current rules such amendments must be accepted.

HEADLINE: Harlem Rehab

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A Posting on Jan. 7 headed ''5 Renovations for Harlem'' was fundamentally inaccurate.
The article implies that the Ziegelman Organization and Harwin Corporation have received a sizable Participation Loan from the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development to undertake the renovation of five privately owned properties in West harlem. The fact is, they have never applied for any such loan or even engaged in preliminary discussions on this matter with H.P.D.
The agency's Participation Loan Program allows owners to upgrade properties by providing low-interest loans for the moderate rehabilitation of multifamily rental properties. These loans assist both tenants and owners in that the useful life of a building can be prolonged for years without burdening the property with unmanageable debt.
It is not the intention of the program to enable rental units to be converted to market-rate co-ops and condos. While the Ziegelman-Harwin joint venture may very well be intending to begin rehab work soon, it will not be done with a Participation Loan.
 
FELICE MICHETTI
 Manhattan
 
The writer is Acting Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
A $20 Million Center on the Housatonic

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
AFTER the B. F. Goodrich Company plant in Shelton was firebombed in an insurance fraud scheme 15 years ago, the company decided not to reopen its Connecticut operation and 4,500 jobs were lost. An already weak economy looked as if it might die until local officials worked to create a new and different Shelton, competitive with the rest of Fairfield County.
Since 1977, more than 5 million square feet of office space has been built, housing 125 corporations, many of whose employees live in the 3,000 condominiums constructed to accommodate them.
But Shelton's success was somewhat dimmed by boredom. The only movie theater, showing pornographic films, was closed in the early 80's, and humdrum shopping along Howe Avenue was not what new residents were accustomed to. 
In stepped Edward Fantegrossi, a Boston teacher-turned-developer, with a plan for a $20 million retail center on 8.8 acres overlooking the Housatonic River and similar in concept to the South Street Seaport in Manhattan and Quincy Market in Boston. He paid $3.2 million for the property last October, named it Mariah's Way after the song with the line, ''they call the wind Maria,'' and took an option on another 21 acres north and south of it.
The proposal was approved by the city and construction is expected to begin this spring for an April 1991 opening. The land purchase was financed by the Mechanics and Farmers Bank in Bridgeport and construction loans are being negotiated privately. Do H. Chung & Partners of Stamford are the architects.
''I felt this would be a recession-proof form of development,'' said Mr. Fantegrossi. His research showed that growth in the city left it shy of 2,000 restaurant seats at lunchtime, and that the nearest specialty shopping was at the Trumbull Mall 15 miles to the southwest.
He plans to build about 35 shops and 10 restaurants in five buildings stretching from River Road to the Housatonic. A circular building will have a food court and a 10,000-square-foot pavilion on the second floor for free weekend entertainment by mimes, musicians, dancers, artists and storytellers.
Looking at Quincy Market and the South Street Seaport, both of which are larger than the planned Shelton development, Mr. Fantegrossi concluded that ''entertainment attracts people who shop, and retail brings in people who enjoy entertainment.''
During the week the pavilion will be used for events like aerobics classes, civic displays, corporate and community meetings, educational programs and chamber music concerts, all managed by We Associates, the Fantegrossi company based in Southport.
An ice-skating rink will be built opposite the pavilion. Visitors arriving by boat may tie up one of 35 moorings and use launches along a 600-foot boardwalk.
''It's the first project of its kind on our riverfront,'' said Mayor Michael Pacowta. In earlier times, Naugatuck Valley riverfronts were dominated by brick factories, several of which still stand in Shelton, candidates for conversion to condominiums and offices.
''MARIAH'S WAY puts a positive complexion on an area that has received a black eye - the landfill adjacent to it,'' said the Mayor, referring to a 110-acre, 145-foot-high mountain of garbage covered with residual ash from the Connecticut Resource Recovery Agency's waste-to-energy process. ''We are in court with the State Department of Environmental Protection in an effort to prevent expansion of the site.''
The landfill is a charcoal-gray cone with young pine trees planted at intervals up and down its sides.
''The C.R.R.A. is required by the state's Coastal Management Plan to come up with innovative landscaping and public uses for the site,'' said John England, environmental analyst for the environmental agency's waste bureau in Hartford.
Mr. Fantegrossi, the city and the recovery agency have been cooperating in what they believe is the first attempt to transform a landfill into a public site.
Jogging and hiking trails will be built and educational kiosks will be installed on the landfill when dumping stops there in about four years. Until then the department wants to allow the landfill to grow two more acres in width and 170 feet in height, Mr. England said. The recovery agency can sell the site afterward, but the owner must maintain it as a landscaped public place and test it for leaching and erosion.
''I WOULDN'T rule out the sale and profitable use of its waterfront and lagoon as a marina,'' said Mr. England, ''and the view from the top is spectacular.''
Expansion of Mariah's Way to 500,000 square feet on 30 acres will depend upon how well the complex fares. Its location is rural, minutes from office and research parks and condominiums.
Barely five miles from downtown, it is also close to a new Residence Inn, a Ramada Inn under construction and a Sheraton to be built next year.
James E. Ryan, executive director of the Shelton Economic Development Corporation, a private nonprofit group formed in 1983, said:
''We do not feel that the Fantegrossi project will threaten our downtown area. The current weak mix of retail needs to be bolstered by a downtown residential population.'' To that end the city has approved the old Goodrich site of 7.5 acres for 320 condominiums overlooking the river in two buildings of about 10 stories. A developer is being sought for the project.
The property is on the market for $1 million an acre, said Elaine Liberto, director of development for the city. While local construction has slowed, approvals have already been granted for the construction of another 3 million square feet of offices, according to Ms. Liberto. ''We are still getting applications from developers,'' she added. Shelton will never go back to full-scale manufacturing. Even small companies wanting to come in now cannot find suitable space.
''We have 31 percent of the state's labor pool within a radius of 15 miles,'' said Ms. Liberto. ''What we need is manufacturing buildings under 60,000 square feet.''

HEADLINE: When Takeout Is Quail And Rack of Lamb

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
FOR many commuters constant travel means tedium and exhaustion. But for Patty Cassidy of Greenwich, a long train ride led to a new business.
There were many nights, Mrs. Cassidy said, when she would get off the train and ''crave a good meal, not just a fast-food takeout.'' But Mrs. Cassidy, who commuted two or three times a week to Washington in her job at National Geographic, would be too tired to dress up and go out to a restaurant like Jean-Louis or Bertrand, both in Greenwich. 
Her husband, James, also traveled to Washington several times a week for his government-relations job at U.S.T., a Greenwich producer of smokeless tobacco and wine. ''We thought,'' she said, ''wouldn't it be nice if we could eat some of that terrific restaurant food at home? And that's how the idea evolved.''
The idea became Butler's Tray, Mrs. Cassidy's 10-month-old food-delivery service, which combines the pleasure of dining at a fine restaurant with the comforts of eating at home.
Customers who call Butler's Tray order dinner from a brochure that lists the menus of 11 participating restaurants in Greenwich. The order is faxed to the restaurant and within a specified time a uniformed Butler's Tray driver collects the meal from the restaurant in a large heat-retaining container and delivers it to the customer. Each item is packed in a container that can go into the microwave.
Butler's Tray began with three restaurants, Jean-Louis, Bertrand and La Maison Indochine. Mrs. Cassidy, 27 years old, solicited her first customers by having a brochure inserted in newspapers sold to commuters at the Greenwich train station.
On her list now are two Italian restaurants, Conte and Da Vinci's; a Japanese establishment, Kagetsu; a Mexican restaurant, Fonda La Paloma; a steakhouse, Manero's; a New American establishment, Tapestries; a pasta place, Pasta Vera, and a restaurant specializing in omelets and other egg dishes, Le Peep. The list gives customers considerable variety and price range.
While working couples are an obvious market for Butler's Tray, its customers, Mrs. Cassidy said, also include retired couples who enjoy good food but do not want to cook, young families who feel more comfortable dining at home with their children or who cannot get baby sitters, and local celebrities who want to enjoy great food in private.
One devotee is Louis Rukeyser, peripatetic traveler, economic commentator and host of ''Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser'' on PBS, who said he has used the Butler's Tray menu so often he has ''memorized parts of it.''
''For those of us who live deep in the country it gives us some of the conveniences of urban living,'' Mr. Rukeyser said. He commended Mrs. Cassidy for ''seeing a business opportunity and seizing it, in the good capitalist tradition.''
In cold weather Butler's Tray has a special appeal to retired couples like George and Betty Ashforth who are accustomed to dining out. ''I don't really enjoy cooking,'' Mrs. Ashforth said, ''and with the weather so bad, we can have a really nice restaurant meal three or four times a week right at home. I've used certain restaurants so much I wish they'd get a new menu.''
Considering that Butler's Tray restaurants include some of Greenwich's most well known, one might expect the service to be expensive. Actually, Mrs. Cassidy said, ''it is the same price - and sometimes even less so - as you'd pay at the restaurant itself.'' Thereis no restaurant tip to pay, although most customers tip the Butler's Tray driver. Butler's Tray charges a flat $7 delivery fee, with a 10 percent surcharge for deliveries outside Greenwich.
The food is the same as that served in the restaurant, although dishes that do not travel well are not on the Butler's Tray menu.
While most callers order a dinner for two, at an average cost of about $50, Butler's Tray gets an occasional request for a dinner party.''Our largest order so far,'' Mrs. Cassidy said, ''was $1,000 for a dinner party for 15 from Tapestries.''
One night there was a call from a woman who wanted dinner for 20 to be delivered in an hour. It was. ''I could only speculate as to why she'd order so last-minute for a dinner party,'' Mrs. Cassidy said. ''Maybe her ragout burned or the souffle fell.'' Some 20 couples order regularly from Butler's Tray once or twice a week. Many of the regular customers are loyal to specific restaurants; one couple order a smoked salmon appetizer and filet of beef from Jean-Louis every Friday night. Others, like the Rukeysers, run down the list, trying different meals from different restaurants.
Despite some experimentation, Mrs. Cassidy said, ''it is a good bet that on an order for two, one of the entrees will be chicken or duck.,'' And there are favorites from individual restaurants, like the salad with goat cheese, confit of duck and spring roasted chicken with rosemary and thyme from Bertrand, La Maison Indochine's spring rolls (''one night we got an order for 100 of them'') and chicken-in-eight delight, Jean-Louis's warm shrimp vichyssoise, deboned quail and warm, thin apple tart, and Tapestries' rack of lamb with fresh mint and roasted garlic, shrimp and scallops Provencal and chocolate mousse cake.
What makes a well-known restaurant like Jean-Louis subscribe to a food-to-go service, the chef-owner, Jean-Louis Gerin, said, is helping customers who ''enjoy good food at home without getting all dressed up.''
''They can eat our food on their own china and drink their own wines,'' Mr. Gerin said. ''Some of our best customers eat here once a week and order our food from Butler's Tray twice a week as well. It's a fun experience for many people, especially those with children.''
It is so much fun, he said, that he and his wife use the service themselves. ''With a new baby, it saves the problem of getting a sitter, and we enjoy the experience.''
The success of Butler's Tray has not gone unnoticed. Mrs. Cassidy has received calls from people in Chicago, San Francisco and New York who are planning similar businesses. As far as she knows, hers is the first.
Overhead is low, Mrs. Cassidy said. ''Once you've sold the restaurants on joining the service,'' she said, ''you have a few initial investments such as supplying each restaurant with a fax machine and with a steady complement of containers. You need to print a menu list, have a phone bank and a corps of reliable drivers and trained phone operators.''
And does Mrs. Cassidy ever use the service herself? ''Of course,'' she said. While her husband has changed jobs at U.S.T. and no longer commutes, both have irregular hours. And with their first baby expected in late February, the Cassidys are obvious candidates for the Butler's Tray service. The only difference: she doesn't have to dial 629-8878 to place her order. She's already there.

HEADLINE: Parasitic Mites Imperil Honeybees

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
A PARASITIC mite that preys on honeybees has invaded hives in four towns in the state, forcing the authorities to destroy the colonies in 11 hives.
Some of the affected areas have been quarantined to prevent the spread of the infestation, Louis A. Magnarelli, the state entymologist, who is overseeing attempts to control the infestation, said last week.
The mite infestations have been found in apiaries in Naugatuck, Seymour, Watertown and Woodbury and hives involved in commercial honey production and crop pollination were purposely destroyed in those towns by applications of an insecticide called Pyrethrum. 
 
$500,000 Industry
The infestation, if it spreads, could cause serious economic losses in the $500,000 bee industry in Connecticut, bringing hardship to beekeepers who depend on sales of honey and to farmers who depend on honeybees to pollinate their crops.
The mite, Acarapis woodi, preys on honeybees by piercing the trachea, or windpipe, and laying eggs there. When they hatch, they suck the bee's body fluids, weakening the bee and reducing its honey-making and pollination capabilities. The infestations also seriously impair the bees' ability to survive the winter.
Controlling the spread of the mite is difficult, according to entymologists, because approved insecticides strong enough to kill or repel the mite could also harm the bees or contaminate their honey. Dr. Magnarelli said he was weighing whether to test new types of pesticides. The mites are not known to be harmful to other creatures.
 
Watertown-Woodbury Quarantine
The mite was first found in hives in Watertown and Woodbury last fall, and a quarantine was ordered. ''We examined 13,600 honeybees from 36 apiaries in the Watertown and Woodbury areas and found no further evidence of the tracheal mite, so the quarantine has been lifted,'' Dr. Magnarelli said. ''I'm confident we've eradicated it from those two sites.''
But a few weeks ago, infected bees were found in Naugatuck. In this case the infected bees were native to Connecticut; the other infected hives were from out-of-state, he said. The infected colonies were destroyed and the area was quarantined and no bees were permitted to be shipped in or out, pending further inspection. ''We will have the results in a couple of weeks,'' Dr. Magnarelli said.
Dr. Magnarelli's concern is that the spread of the mites could occur rapidly because of the mobility of the bee industry. Beekeepers regularly ship colonies from state to state. Such shipments are largely responsible for the spread of bee mites.
Connecticut now prohibits importation of bees and apiary equipment from dozens of states where infestations of the mites have been found. But that prohibition is often ignored, Dr. Magnarelli said. The president of the 250-member Connecticut Beekeepers Association, Charles Howe of Goshen, said last week that he hoped beekeepers would tailor efforts to curb the spread of the mites.
 
'A Serious Threat'
''This is a serious threat,'' Mr. Howe said. ''If you are growing apples, and you don't have enough bees to pollinate them, you'll get fewer apples or lopsided apples. Also, the second major aspect is fruit for wildlife. Birds depend on wild blueberries, blackberries and raspberries, which depend on bees for pollination.''
''People are buying bees from where they shouldn't be buying them,'' he said. ''In some cases, it is ignorance; in other cases, it's simply a case of trying to avoid the regulations.''
Dr. Magnarelli said he would broaden inspections of hives in northwestern Connecticut. He added that he hoped beekeepers in Connecticut would voluntarily seek inspections of their colonies. There are now 644 beekeepers registered with the state, and 2,703 hives.

HEADLINE: State to Offer Loans To Home Buyers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A NEW round of low-interest loans will become available next month that could make 1,500 Connecticut residents homeowners.
The offering of $162 million in mortgages will bring to $491 million the total made available under the program since January 1989. 
The money will become available after Feb. 5, Gov. William A. O'Neill said Wednesday, and income guidelines have been slightly relaxed, making more people eligible. The income guidelines will vary by county.
 
'A Double Bang'
Not only will it make homeownership a possibility for 1,500 families, Governor O'Neill said, but it should also help the sagging housing market in Connecticut, ''giving us a double bang for the same dollar.''
''We hope that it will help jump start the housing market although that is not the specific intent,'' he said. ''The specific intent here is to have 1,500 more families owning their new homes across the state of Connecticut.''
The money will be spread among existing homes, new homes and new or existing condominiums.
 
8 Percent Mortgages
While conventional 30-year mortgages are available at interest rates of about 10 percent, the rates under the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority program will be 8 percent for those in the lower income limits and 8.15 percent for those of slightly higher means.
''On average, if a person is borrowing $100,000, we expect this program to save the homebuyer $134 a month, compared to a conventional mortgage,'' Mr. O'Neill said. The savings, he said, would total $48,000 over the life of the mortgage.
The $162 million comes from state bonds issued by the Housing Finance Authority.
Commissioner John F. Papandrea of the State Housing Department said applicants would also be eligible to apply for down-payment assistance loans. Information will be available from participating banks beginning Feb. 5.

HEADLINE: Shoreham Asset: Land and Location

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
THE Herculean labor involved in building the Shoreham nuclear-power plant may have been largely a waste, but a group of energy experts in Midland, Mich., hopes to convince Long Islanders not to overlook the value of an indestructible component: the land on which the plant sits.
Never mind the $5 billion reactor, they say. Instead, think of Shoreham as a large piece of land already connected to the power grid, and with a source for cooling water and a clutch of permits that would be difficult to duplicate anywhere in New York.
The entrepreneurs are the developers of the Midland Cogeneration Venture, a failed nuclear project that is being repowered with natural gas to supply electricity and industrial steam, a process called cogeneration.
The project, 110 miles north of Detroit, is scheduled to complete a 23-month metamorphosis next month. About the time it enters into commercial operation, its builders, led by CMS, the corporate parent of the utility that built the Midland reactor, will probably be starting a campaign to persuade Long Island to let them do the same with Shoreham. 
 
Siting of New Lines a Problem
''Siting new transmission lines is an abomination,'' William T. McCormick Jr., chairman of CMS, told a group of visitors from Long Island earlier this month.
Making use of existing permits for water use, and of the decision more than 20 years ago to use the site for power generation, will save years in building another plant, he said.
Matthew C. Cordaro of Long Lake Energy agreed. Said Mr. Cordaro, a former vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company, whose company hopes to participate in a conversion:
''I don't know where you could site a generating plant in Nassau County or western Suffolk.''
Lilco itself, however, is unenthusiastic. One reason is that conversion of Shoreham by third parties like the Long Island Power Authority and the Michigan utility would turn Lilco into an electricity buyer and reseller, rather than a producer and seller.
 
Intense Sales Effort
CMS put on an intense sales effort for the visitors, members of the Long Island Power Authority. The pitch included a videotape on conversion with a sound track that a CMS official said sounded like ''co-gen Rambo.''
For the Power Authority officials, the trip to Michigan had some coincidences. The chairman, Richard Kessel, told Mr. McCormick over dinner at the Midland Country Club that he also served as chairman of the Consumer Protection Board in New York.
''My job is to kick utilities,'' Mr. Kessel told Mr. McCormick. ''I'm good at it.''
Shoreham is so unpopular, he said, that a converted project would probably have to be renamed. He mused about holding a contest to pick a new title.
The main source of opposition to a conversion is not likely to be the partisans of another site but rather those who believe that the money needed to build a new plant would be better spent on more efficient light bulbs, refrigerators, electric motors and other consuming equipment.
The environmental impact of growth is small if natural gas is the fuel, but it is smaller yet if existing supplies of power are made to do more work at lower cost, efficiency advocates say.
The converters, led by CMS, argue that a converted Shoreham is the best option if a power plant is needed. (A Shoreham twin, the Zimmer reactor in Moscow, Ohio, is being converted to coal, and a 15-year-old reactor in Sacramento, Calif., may also be converted to natural gas. But in general, conversion is a strategy born of desperation.) At Midland, CMS's utility subsidiary, Consumers Power Company, had spent $4.1 billion to bring the twin-reactor project to a point that it said was 85 percent complete.
Facing stiff opposition from its customers and the Michigan Attorney General, and engineering problems, including the settling of parts of the plant into mud, Consumers Power stopped work in 1984. When CMS contributed the nonnuclear portion of Midland to the new venture, it valued those assets at $1.5 billion.
The conversion was opposed by many of those who fought the nuclear plant, and the power sales contract between the Midland Cogeneration Venture partners, which include CMS, and the CMS subsidiary, Consumers Power, has been the subject of extensive hearings before the Michigan regulatory authorities.
 
Abandonment Called Opportunity
But abandonment is an opportunity, Mr. McCormick said, adding that the Shoreham abandonment could transform the energy picture in the New York region in a positive way.
In electricity terms, Long Island is the end of the line, an extended finger at the end of the power grid that must fend for itself to a large extent because geography sets limits on imports.
But CMS would like to turn Long Island into the beginning of the line, an energy exporter generating enough electricity to provide steady power to Connecticut, New York City and New Jersey. Conceivably, the new transmission line being built under Long Island Sound to bring in power from the north might run in the other direction.
One essential reason for a gas-powered plant bigger than the reactor is technical. The part of Shoreham that turns steam into electricity is designed for nuclear steam, which is about 550 degrees.
 
Air Dumped at 1,000 Degrees
But when it comes to fossil fuels, the higher the temperature, the higher the efficiency, and natural gas is generally used to produce hot air at 2,000 degrees.
Plants that use that air to make electricity dump the air at 1,000 degrees, and that waste energy is still hot enough to make steam that the nuclear turbine can handle after it has had some modifications.
But it takes the waste heat of many gas burners to make enough steam to use the nuclear turbine. At Midland, a plant that was to be 800 megawatts will run, in its initial phase, at 1,200. Eventually, the complex, which includes a mothballed turbine from a second reactor, could be used to make 3,500 megawatts.
That amount of power is vast by any standard. The largest electric-generating complex in New York, in Scriba, where Nine Mile Point 1 and 2 and the James A. Fitzpatrick reactors are situated, comes to 2,500 megawatts. Shoreham was intended to be an 809-megawatt plant.
Even 809 megawatts is more power that Long Island is projected to need in the near future. The settlement under which Shoreham was shut envisioned three 300-megawatt plants going into service in 1997, 1999 and 2001.
 
Demand Rising Steadily
But in the Northeast as a whole, a strong economy and a long-term trend toward greater electrification of jobs previously done with fossil fuels are steadily raising demand.
New York State's position is relatively strong, but in the hottest and coldest days each year, the New England utilities have come uncomfortably close to their generating limits.
In hot weather, the group of utilities that serves the region from Newark to Washington, D.C. and west to the Allegheny Mountains has had to cut voltage repeatedly.
Pennsylvania added a large nuclear reactor, Limerick 2, earlier this year, and New England may add the Seabrook plant, but each of these represents only about one year's growth. Future growth is likely to be met by smaller gas-fired plants.
Does that make an expanded, gas-powered Shoreham a good deal for Long Island?
Mr. Kessel pondered that question as he gazed at a row of 12 rust-colored gas-turbine exhaust stacks at Midland, each towering 120 feet over the flat landscape.
''I'm trying to place it on Long Island,'' he told James A. Mooney, the CMS official in charge of engineering and construction. ''Does it have to have stacks?'' ''Well, you could paint them green,'' Mr. Mooney replied. The stacks also could be partly screened by the hilly terrain at Shoreham, said another CMS official who had scouted the Long Island site.
The Swiss-built gas turbines in use at Midland are 87 megawatts each. Probably at least four would be needed before it would be sensible to use the Shoreham turbine.
But if the waste heat were used in the turbine, about 43 percent of the energy in the gas would be turned to electricity, which is considered highly efficient. Most oil- and gas-fired plants achieve efficiencies of only about 34 percent.
A larger plant would have lower costs per kilowatt-hour produced, say its proponents, and, Mr. Kessel noted, would have a higher assessed valuation for tax purposes.
But he and other Power Authority officials expressed leeriness about large projects. He added, given the history of Shoreham, that for a conversion to work, ''This has to be seen as a good deal by Long Island.''

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)
HOLLYWOOD: A Novel of America in the 1930's, by Gore Vidal (Random House, $19.95.) The latest wonderfully literate installment in Mr. Vidal's docudramatic revision of American history and politics features a movie star with a mission: to persuade producers to make anti-German World War I movies.
ESCAPES, by Joy Williams. (Atlantic Monthly, $18.95.) A collection of quirky, ominous short stories in which "every person is on the brink of eternity every moment," and few fail to fall in.
IN THE FACE OF DEATH, by Peter Noll. (Viking, $19.95.) Death is an instructional tool in this provocative record of his own final months by Peter Noll, an earnest and dedicated Swiss law professor determined to revise our thinking about dying.
THE SPIRIT OF FOLK ART: The Girard Collection at the Museum of International Folk Art, by Henry Glassie. Color photographs by Michael Monteaux. (Abrams, $60.) With 154 splendid color pages, this rather ambitious illustrated essay celebrates a collection (located in Santa Fe, N.M.) that richly deserves it.
OUR NEW YORK, Text by Alfred Kazin, Photographs by David Finn (Harper & Row, $35.) A delightful collaboration on the New York landscape and its meaning by two wise old Brooklyn hands.
FORGED IN BATTLE: The Civil War Alliance of Black Soldiers and White Officers, by Joseph T. Glatthaar (The Free Press, $24.95.) An absorbing account, more social than military, of the revolution through which 180,000 blacks fought for the Union in the Civil War.
PICTURING WILL, by Ann Beattie. (Random House, $18.95.) Complex points of view unfold to yield the shock of enlightenment in Ms. Beattie's fourth novel, a lyrical, deeply affecting story about a little boy and the people who love him, or should.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 21, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 893 words

HEADLINE: So What if College Players Turn Pro?

BYLINE: By Donald Kennedy; Donald Kennedy is president of Stanford University.

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
Now that the January orgy of bowl and all-star games has almost faded from memory, we spectators can turn to other, more elevating activities, like today's Super Bowl. The players, meanwhile, some 2,000 of them representing more than 30 bowl-qualifying football powers, have returned to their campuses and resumed what the National Collegiate Athletic Association likes to describe as ''normal academic lives.''
What are these lives like? For a lucky few, they resemble the lives of their fellow students. But at a great many of the universities, life after the bowl game is very different. 
To begin with, the athlete is likely to feel, and to be, quite isolated. He will enjoy some protection from this feeling in his residential environment, which is likely to be an athletic domitory. But in the classroom, he will abruptly encounter people whose expectations about who he is and why he is there will set him dramatically apart from his fellow students.
His ''academic'' advisers, largely paid by the athletic department, will have arranged a course schedule that will keep him eligible by the N.C.A.A.'s soft standards, not a program that will move him toward the qualifications for a degree.
Indeed, for football players to earn degrees in many of the most athletically successful programs is appallingly rare. Graduation rates for football (and basketball) players are often less than half those for the student body as a whole. Thus, it is difficult to escape the conclusion that these athletes are performing a revenue-producing service without receiving anything lasting in return. The system, to be brief and blunt about it, reeks of exploitation.
The N.C.A.A., which is supposed to provide regulatory remedies for excesses of this kind, has proved ineffective, to put it kindly. But there is an organization that can help. It is -hold your breath - the National Football League.
The N.F.L. is in the business of presenting the best football to the public. In support of that mission, it wants and needs the best players. Some of the best players, however, play for college teams. Before now, the N.F.L. has maintained (mostly) a self-denying ordinance against hiring the occasional college underclassman who can play in that league. This agreement, however, is often honored in the breach: Exceptionally talented players are somehow made ''exceptions.'' Some have pointed out that the N.F.L. may find it economically advantageous to maintain an excellent ''farm system'' of college teams at no cost. These spoilsports charge that the league restrains the recruiting activities of its member teams. Such a practice would almost certainly be illegal; right-thinking persons would reject it immediately.
Now, there is fresh hope on this score. The N.F.L.'s new commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, has said the league will reconsider its self-imposed restraint against hiring underclassmen. I invite it to take this step.
Some will object that this would deny young people the opportunity to finish their degrees. But, in fact, very few of them will do anything of the sort. Instead, they will merely complete their eligibility, winding up their service to a lower paying master who will then pass them along to the N.F.L. - without a degree.
I urge the N.F.L. to go after underclass football players and sign them right up - if it can persuade them that their chances of economic success in the pros are better than their chances of genuine academic success.
What would be the harm? Doubtless, there would be a burst of negative publicity, but that should pass. Some will also argue that unhampered N.F.L. recruiting would discourage serious students from finishing degrees they actually have a chance of earning. But students who really expect to complete their degrees will likely defer signing so as to finish their studies; or they may complete their degrees while playing professionally.
About here someone will remember a Texas law that protects the young minds of undergraduates from seduction by those who want to pay them good money for what they do best. Some of us believe we detect a hint of self-service in the ''don't mess with Texas'' statute, and my legal colleagues here believe that a court test of the measure under the antitrust laws would prove interesting.
Who likes this proposal favoring freedom of access for the N.F.L., besides me? Well, I get a lot of quiet agreement from faculty members in institutions that view student-athletes as students first. My economist friends also like it, especially those to my right, because it presents such an attractive vision of the free market working just as it is supposed to: Those who would benefit more from football would go, those who would benefit more from college would stay.
Indeed, the change might even induce the strong football programs to insist on higher academic standards, thus offering athletically talented undergraduates a persuasive reason for deferring professional careers. The N.F.L. should like it, because what the N.F.L. wants is the best players; in contrast to the other institutional participants in this debate, it has never tried to kid anybody.
Who wouldn't like it? The N.C.A.A. and the institutions that are practicing athletic exploitation, poorly disguised as academic compassion. That by itself should tell you it's a pretty good idea.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 9, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1360 words

HEADLINE: FOCUS: Houston;
'Bottom-Fishing' Brings Up Bargains

BYLINE: By LETTICE STUART

 BODY:
OUT-OF-TOWN investors flocking to this city to scoop up real estate at rock-bottom prices have given rise to its newest sport - ''bottom fishing.''
Depressed property values in apartment complexes, office buildings, shopping centers, land and single-family homes, caused by the decline in the oil and gas industry in the early 80's, have attracted bottom fishers from Canada, Europe, Australia, Asia and both coasts of the United States.
Most properties are acquired from failed thrift institutions and are bought at 25 to 50 percent of replacement costs. If buildings are selling at prices well below construction costs, investors assume their value is bound to rise eventually.
''But the locals aren't buying because they are broke,'' said Dr. Barton Smith, chairman of the department of economics at the University of Houston, ''so out-of-towners are filling the void.'' 
Harvey Borsuk, a real estate investor from Stamford, Conn., was in the first wave of out-of-towners, arriving about six months before the city's economy hit bottom in February 1987. His first acquisition was a 232-unit apartment complex called Rush Creek Place in the northwest section of town.
He talked four top Merrill Lynch executives into joining him at a bargain 25 percent of replacement cost, with financing by a local savings and loan. The complex was 68 percent occupied at rents of 29 cents a square foot a month. Occupancy has increased to 92 percent and rents have been raised to 42 cents a square foot.
Mr. Borsuk and his investment partners have since bought more than 7,000 apartment units in 27 rental projects, some of which already have been resold. In all, he and his investors have spent $98 million, an average of $14,000 per unit, on Houston apartments. About 85 percent of the transactions have been all cash deals, with most of the rest financed by insurance companies.
His latest partners are foreign institutional investors such as the German group with whom he bought 1,964 apartment units in December for $32.5 million. He said those investors have put up an additional $42 million just to buy apartments in Houston.
But it is getting harder to find good deals, he said, with so much property in the hands of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which he said is ''extremely difficult to work with.'' The corporation is a new government agency set up to dispose of the billions of dollars of real estate held by insolvent thrifts.
Another investor, Maxwell B. Drever, based in San Francisco, has rented a helicopter to tour industrial sites from the air. Like Mr. Borsuk, he was looking for apartment complexes, but he believes industrial expansion is the best indicator of when to move into a market. New employees will be needed wherever industry is leasing new space, and every four new jobs means one apartment needed, Mr. Drever said. The formula, he said, works every time. Mr. Drever, president of Drever Partners, first began buying real estate in depressed areas 20 years ago in Seattle. He bought 16 apartment projects at fire-sale prices during a real estate recession there. Now the company owns apartments in Denver, Memphis, Tampa, Fla., Columbus, Ohio, and here.
Since entering this market in mid-1987, Mr. Drever has invested $125 million, buying 22 apartment projects with 5,100 units. All have been bought from failed thrifts at 30 to 70 percent of actual costs, or about $20 a square foot, he said. He says he concentrates on properties with high occupancy rates in locations where average family income exceeds $40,000. He then spends money on improvements and amenities and holds the properties for 5 to 10 years before reselling. Mr. Drever is backed primarily by institutional investors in New York, among them insurance companies and pension funds.
Then there is Dr. Andre Danesh of Boston, a chemistry professor turned real estate investor. He has no partners and, therefore, buys on a smaller scale. He was attracted to Houston in 1986, when he bought a small medical building from a private investor for $565,000. Eighteen months later, he bought Executive Plaza, twin 10-story office buildings fronting the southwest freeway, from Prudential Insurance Company for $12 million. He continues to spend several days a month here looking for other deals.
The list of buyers includes Peter Krulewitch of New York, who entered the Houston market in 1988 with a $3 million purchase of Westpark Mall and Plaza shopping center from Prudential Property Company. In January, Mr. Krulewitch and his Kingston Investor corporation bought a half block of vacant downtown property in Houston from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for $3.2 million - about a fourth of what it sold for a year ago, said Mr. Krulewitch.
British, Finnish, West German, Australian and Canadian investors have all joined the parade of buyers seeking opportunities in Houston. Since 1986, Daniele Silvestri, a Canadian, has bought 300 single-family homes, which he is holding for rental, dozens of single-family lots, five mid-rise condominium projects and nearly 1 million square feet of retail space in the Houston area.
Buckingham International PLC, a London company with hotels in Europe and in Orlando, Fla., bought the 320-room Grand Hotel in Houston in August and plans to acquire several more, said the company's chief executive officer, Nick Jivrav. The 14-story Grand Hotel was sold for $11 million by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and American General Insurance Company, which took over the property in a foreclosure sale the preceding year. Mr. Jivrav said the purchase price was 50 percent of replacement cost.
Since 1988, Andy Lai of Gulf South Investments, a Houston real estate company with an office in Taiwan, has sold several properties to Hong Kong buyers. A clothing manufacturer bought three small office buildings, a doctor's wife bought 12 single-family houses for rental and a 12-story office building downtown, and the owner of a Taiwan stock brokerage bought 30 single-family homes for rental.
Other Hong Kong clients have bought motels and hotels and some picked up totally vacant shopping centers for as little as $10 to $12 a square foot, he said.
''Real estate in Houston is a real bargain for these buyers because it's about one-tenth of the cost of real estate in Hong Kong,'' Mr. Lai said. He also noted that small investors had been encouraged by the recent arrival of big Japanese investors. In December, for example, Interfin Corporation of Houston sold an 85 percent interest in the Four Oaks Place office complex for $275 million to a partnership including Lehndorff USA Group of Companies and a Japanese group headed by Taikichiro Mori, a wealthy developer.
THE flurry of out-of-town investor activity is expected to slacken this year as the city's recovery strengthens. Foreclosures of commercial property in Harris County, where Houston is situated, dropped 42 percent during the first three-quarters of 1989 from the same period the year earlier, and further decreases are expected this year, according to Gary Cairns, vice president of REVAC, a real estate research concern. At the same time, office-building sales have increased 46 percent and more than a fourth of Houston's 400,000 apartments have been sold in the last two years, he said.
The indexes used to evaluate an area's growth - population, employment, retail sales, housing starts and office building, hotel and apartment occupancy rates - are all moving up, said Edward H. Cappel, first vice president of Coldwell Banker Commercial Services. As the economy recovers, real estate prices will continue to rise, weeding out the speculative investors, he said.
''Already we are seeing a different tier of buyers,'' he said. ''The first tier, the more speculative, risk-oriented buyers, have bought and now the more conservative, institutional buyers are coming into the market.'' As prices rise, the out-of-town bargain hunters will move elsewhere. ''Pretty soon, they will be saying, 'Why should I pay those prices in Houston when I can get a better deal in Phoenix?', '' said Dr. Smith, the University of Houston economist.

PUB-DATE: January 28, 1990

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 6, Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: Amtrak Plans Meeting On Troubled Rail Line

BYLINE: By JAMES RUTHERFORD

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
UNDER a Congressional order to break even or shut down its debt-plagued express line to Atlantic City, Amtrak officials want to bring New Jersey's casino executives to the bargaining table next month in hopes of finding a way to save the line.
Tim Gardner, Amtrak's vice president of marketing, said the federally subsidized passenger railroad would try to persuade the casino executives to budge from a standing refusal to provide the kinds of complimentary incentives they offer their bus customers. Amtrak says the incentives are needed to reverse eight months of chronically low ridership on the highly publicized run.
Talks are scheduled for Friday in Washington, the day after New Jersey's annual Chamber of Commerce junket of lawmakers and business people to the nation's capital. 
''We've invited them to meet here'' said Mr. Gardner, speaking from Amtrak's Washington headquarters. ''Several indicated they would come. It's not a make-or-break situation. But we'll be talking along a variety of lines.''
 
Harrah's Offers Incentives
A major issue, Mr. Gardner said, is the incentives for riders of the line, popularly known as the GamblersExpress. ''I'd certainly say it's key,'' he said. ''It's near the top of the list, definitely.''
So far, of the 11 casinos, only Harrah's Marina has a contract with Amtrak to provide riders with $10 in quarters and a $5 credit toward a return trip. That deal expires in March.
About 1,000 passengers a day are riding the Gamblers Express on six weekday round-trips and nine on weekends from Washington, New York City, New Haven and Philadelphia. When it began the run last May, Amtrak projected a need for 3,500 riders a day to meet costs anticipated at $28 million the first year. The line cost $100 million to build, $30 million of it from the Federal Government. Amtrak now says it stands to lose $14 million by the end of the first year.
Congress had given Amtrak a deadline for meeting 80 percent of its costs by May. With the unlikelihood of that happening, the deadline was extended another year. The same legislation set the break-even point for the end of the third year. If it is not met, the line must cease operations.
''It's a worst-case scenario, but it's not beyond the realm of possibility'' Mr. Gardner said. ''Some things have to break in our favor; and one thing is, we have to get casino participation.''
 
Buses Have Giveaways
Specifically, Amtrak wants the kind of money and meal giveaways that have been a staple of the casinos' efforts to lure the lucrative bus trade, the day-trippers who mostly live within driving distance of this seaside resort. But for economic reasons, the casinos, with the exception of Harrah's, have shied away.
''For the same reason, they cut back on the bus programs,'' said David Gardner, vice president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, which is an industry lobbying and promotional group. The Gardners are not related.
''They were found to be not as profitable as people thought in the past,'' he said. ''They're very expensive.''
To what extent Amtrak predicated the success of the line on those same giveaways is unclear, Tim Gardner said, ''but we judged that once in service, the incentives would come, that they would compete for the riders we were bringing.'' ''That didn't occur,'' he said. ''It was a serious miscalculation.'' Perhaps only one miscalculation of several on Amtrak's part, said Thomas Carver, president of the Casino Association. ''Whether Atlantic City even has the base traffic to support rail service in the first place is something that has to be seriously examined,'' he said. ''We told Amtrak well before this line ever started that in our estimation the service on the Philadelphia and New York lines would not be successful. Not when people can take a bus run by a private company that's going to pick them up at the corner of the local drugstore and get them onto the Garden State Parkway or the Atlantic City Expressway in the same amount of time it takes to get to the train station where they live, and for less money.''
 
'It Hasn't Worked'
Mr. Carver said he believed Amtrak would have benefited had the casinos been brought in at the line's inception to help map profitable routes and develop marketing strategies. They were not, he said. ''It was a lot of stubbornness, in our judgment, on their part,'' he said. ''They were going to do this and do it their way, and it hasn't worked.''
Evidence of the gambling industry's disenchantment came to light last November, when the Casino Association stopped running its own buses to the rail terminal near the foot of the expressway to shuttle riders to the gaming halls along the Boardwalk. ''It did not do well because nobody was coming in on the trains'' David Gardner said.
That is not likely to change anytime soon, Amtrak officials say, unless some kind of incentive program is forthcoming. ''We're convinced now that the lack of casino incentives has hurt the line very badly'' said Clifford Black, a spokesman for the railroad.
But officials on both sides now say they realize an even greater need to cooperate on marketing and promotion, particularly, and on better customer analyses. Acting as a mediator, Steven Richer, the president of the Atlantic City Convention and Visitors Bureau, was instrumental in setting up the February meeting.
''Everyone in the industry is anxious for Amtrak to be successful'' he said. ''We want to have an opportunity to discuss with them how it can be done. The meeting is nothing other than an attempt to look at the problems and challenges and make it work better.''
 
Extension of Line Planned
In the meantime, Amtrak is negotiating with outside agencies with a view to extending the line to Richmond and to Philadelphia International Airport. The airport extension with the possibility of tapping into nationwide air service farther West, had been suggested by the Casino Association from the beginning, Mr. Carver said.
''We want it to succeed,'' he said. ''It's a needed service. We'll sit down with them; I think we're obliged to sit down with them. But if they're looking to talk about this industry underwriting their costs, I'll tell you now, it's not going to happen.'' Which leaves Amtrak, Mr. Black said, with a ''selling job.'' ''Amtrak's pitch to the casinos is, we're bringing in, essentially, a clientele that's going to spend more time and more money in Atlantic City and we should be permitted to play on an even field with other modes of transportation,'' he said.
Tim Gardner added: ''It's a real uphill fight to compete when the incentives are offered to everyone else. It's a marketing area where people expect it. People back away when they're not getting a freebie they feel they're entitled to.''

HEADLINE: Budget Director is Praised As Smart and Faulted for It

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
When word spread recently that the Administration's budget would be presented this year in one large book instead of the usual collection of smaller volumes, the response around town, from Congress and the bureaucracy, from lobbyists and reporters, was the same: What is Darman up to now?
The suspicion that he has something up his sleeve, in this case probably unjustified, illustrates how Richard G. Darman, a pivotal figure in the Bush Administration and perhaps the most influential budget director ever, is regarded by many people he deals with as a man who approaches every task with a scheme, an angle.
Politicians and scholars disagree over whether that reputation, based on Mr. Darman's volatile personality as much as specific incidents, makes him less effective as one of the Administration's chief political negotiators and tacticians. But they agree that his personality often overshadows the fact that he is admired throughout Washington by his political enemies as well as his friends for his intelligence, his capacity for work, his analytical ability and his mastery of Government policy. 
 
Evidence of Foresight
Mr. Darman is also much more far-seeing than most people in politics and government. That is apparent from an introduction he wrote to the budget that will be submitted to Congress on Monday. The didactic tone may irk some lawmakers, but his warning that Congress must be prepared for enormous future expenses like medical care for an aging population reminds the lawmakers of future obligations they are inclined to neglect.
In the face of the political constraints imposed by President Bush's no-tax policy, Mr. Darman, in his first year as director of the Office of Management and Budget, dominated the policies of the Government's hundreds of departments and agencies to an ex- tent none of his predecessors did, took broad steps to weed out mismanagement throughout the Government and saw a budget enacted that fell within the broad range of President Bush's proposals.
He also assumed the role, normally outside the domain of the budget director, of political strategist and principal lobbyist for President Bush's domestic and economic policies.
 
Rift With Congress
But he failed to achieve a lasting solution to what many economists and politicians see as the nation's most serious problem, the Federal budget deficit. And he managed to damage the Bush Administration's relationship with Congress, especially with important Democratic senators, to such a degree that some lawmakers doubt it can be repaired.
''When I talk to him,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, ''I am reminded of the story about the two psychiatrists. One says, 'Good morning.' The other says, 'What did you mean by that?' ''
Mr. Darman declined to be interviewed on the record for this article, saying, ''I do not want to respond to those kinds of questions.'' He is irate at journalists and lawmakers who, he thinks, focus on his personality rather than the product of his work.
 
Resented for Being Smart
One of Mr. Darman's strongest supporters in Congress, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the top Republican on the Budget Committee, said he suspected the budget director was sometimes resented because he is so smart.
''There's a fine line,'' Mr. Domenici said, ''between having an angle, having a strategy, and being improperly devious. Some of those who think there's deviousness here don't like him because it's so hard to second-guess him, to outwit him, to outplan him, and maybe it's very hard for some to risk sitting down with him to negotiate.''
But Mr. Darman's critics maintain that the budget director has often broken his word, a cardinal sin among politicians. The critics include, in addition to Senator Bentsen, Senators George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader; Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Budget Committee, and Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
Their main complaint is that last April Mr. Darman negotiated a budget deal with Congress, a deal that everyone conceded was modest to buy time so that good will could be developed between President Bush and Congress and so that a comprehensive deficit-reduction package could be worked out late in the year. By all accounts, the initial deal did not include a reduction in the capital gains tax rate.
 
Push to Cut Capital Gains Tax
But after the House of Representatives surprisingly approved a capital gains measure, Mr. Darman pulled out all political stops, personally challenging Democratic senators' motives and intelligence, in an unsuccessful effort to move the tax cut through the Senate.
Mr. Darman said at meetings with reporters last fall that he had no choice but to pursue the capital gains issue once it was passed by the House.
Senator Sasser, for one, does not accept that explanation. ''I think his credibility has been diminished by his failure to deliver on a bipartisan agreement,'' he said.
Mr. Sasser continued: ''Congress gave the Administration a slip-by year, a free pass, to let the President get his feet on the ground. In exchange for that, it was strongly implied that we would get together later to make the tough decisions to put our fiscal house in order once and for all. As soon as the ceremonies were over, that evaporated in thin air, and then with the fierce fight over capital gains, a breech of the agreement, his credibility suffered another severe blow.''
Many top Republican senators, including Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, also criticized Mr. Darman for fighting the capital gains battle long after it was lost.
 
Praise at Highest Levels
Within the Bush Administration, Mr. Darman, who is 46 years old and has served in Government positions most of his adult life, is praised at the highest levels. He did not know the President well when he accepted the job as budget director, but White House officials say that he quickly won Mr. Bush's confidence and became, apart from John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, the President's main adviser on domestic and economic policy.
Over the years, Mr. Darman has had several important patrons in Government. In the Nixon Administration, for example, he worked for Attorney General Elliot O. Richardson. In the Reagan Administration, he was the deputy at the White House and the Treasury Department to James A. Baker 3d, who is now Mr. Bush's Secretary of State.
Mr. Darman's status in the Bush Administration has been enhanced by the warm relations he has developed with Mr. Sununu, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. Mr. Boskin speaks especially highly of Mr. Darman. ''He has an amazing ability,'' Mr. Boskin said, ''to deal simultaneously with a large number of very complicated issues and to do all of them well without letting any of them fall through the cracks.''
 
Object of Many Barbs
But elsewhere in the Government, one hears little but barbs about Mr. Darman. He has caused several Cabinet members embarrassment by forcing them into public retreats on controversial issues, as has happened in at least three cases.
Not surprisingly, officials in those departments speak disparagingly of Mr. Darman. So do most of the career budget analysts who work under Mr. Darman. They say he is contemptuous of them and their work and derides them in public.
Thomas E. Mann, director of government studies at the Brookings Institution, believes Mr. Darman's main problem is that he serves as a lightning rod for opponents of President Bush's policy of no new taxes. ''He does the President's work, and he does it well,'' Mr. Mann said. ''But people think someone as smart and knowledgeable as Darman ought to be able to turn the President around.''
But others attribute Mr. Darman's difficulty in getting along with some people to his unpredictably kaleidoscopic personality.
 
Witty, Loyal and Shrewd
He can be charming, as he was early last year when he approached Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and apologized to the powerful Illinois Democrat for the difficulties they had during the fight over tax legislation in 1985 and 1986, when Mr. Darman was President Reagan's deputy secretary of the Treasury. Mr. Rostenkowski agreed to bury the hatchet.
And loyal, as he has proved to the four Republican Presidents and six Cabinet secretaries he has served over the years.
And shrewd, as he was when he promoted Senator John Glenn's pet plan to make the Environmental Protection Agency a Cabinet department. Senator Glenn, an Ohio Democrat, is especially important to Mr. Darman because he is chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, which has jurisdiction over the Office of Management and Budget.
But he can also be insulting, as he has often been when staff members brought him work that did not meet his high standards.
And vindictive, as he was a few years ago after Larry Speakes, then the White House spokesman, described Mr. Darman as ''the ultimate second-guesser.'' As Mr. Speakes recounts the incident in his book, ''Speaking Out,'' he received this handwritten note from Mr. Darman: ''It has been my experience that the wheel turns 'round and 'round in this town. Please be assured that the next time I am in a position to influence the prospects of your success, failure or capacity to serve, I shall remember your thoughts.''
 
Blamed for Deeds of Others
And deceptive, as he appeared when he told Congress he had to postpone the submission of the budget this year from Jan. 22 to Jan. 29 because Congress had been tardy last year in approving and sending him necessary documents. The primary cause of the delay, White House officials said, was that Mr. Darman, for political reasons, wanted less time between the delivery of the budget and Mr. Bush's State of the Union address, scheduled for Wednesday.
No one interviewed in the Administration will criticize Mr. Darman for publication. One top official, explaining why he could not be quoted about Mr. Darman, referred a reporter to the passage in Mr. Speakes' book.
At times, Mr. Darman has been faulted for the decisions and actions of others. For example, last October, Treasury Secretary Brady announced that he was advancing the Treasury's regular borrowing schedule to raise money to pay Social Security benefits. The maneuver cost the Government about $20 million but undercut one of the Democrats' best arguments in the capital gains fight: that the President's intransigence would stop checks from going out. Senator Bentsen expressed outrage and blamed Mr. Darman for the tactic. But Mr. Brady and others said after the storm had passed that the decision had been Mr. Brady's alone.
''When a guy like Darman gets this reputation, God knows what he gets blamed for that someone else was responsible for,'' a veteran Senate staff assistant said.
 
Exercising Personal Control
Lawmakers like Senator Glenn who have dealt with Mr. Darman on matters that did not involve the budget deficit gave him high marks. Senator Glenn praised Mr. Darman for improving the management of the Government and said, ''He has never given me a fast shuffle.''
Mr. Darman has taken an extraordinary amount of personal control over the Administration's budget that will be released Monday. He has personally reviewed every page of the document the size of a big city's telephone book and has edited much of it himself, not just for substance but also for writing style. His unusual personal essay introducing and summarizing the budget and setting forth themes for the present and future is also a departure from past practice.
Presenting all the information in one book, several officials said, was done for convenience and structure. They insisted that nothing of consequence was left out and that Mr. Darman had no ulterior motive in changing the normal format.
How well Mr. Darman will be able to sell this budget to Congress is another matter.
''A lot of mistrust has built up that's going to hurt his effectiveness,'' said Stanley E. Collender, a Federal budget specialist here for Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm. ''That's a damning thing for a budget director who's got to make deals and keep them.''
