HEADLINE: Challenge for Panamanians: A Canal in Transition

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIRAFLORES LOCKS, Panama, Jan. 28

 BODY:
Most first-time visitors to this famous vantage point on the Panama Canal, eight miles from the Pacific, come away dazzled by the majesty of the 51.2-mile waterway and the near-miraculous ingenuity and sacrifice that went into its construction more than 75 years ago.
But Fernando Manfredo Jr., who escorted Vice President Dan Quayle on a brief tour of the canal today, wishes people would try to think of the place in more down-to-earth terms.
Mr. Manfredo, who took over Jan. 1 as the first Panamanian to administer the canal since it opened in 1914, often escorts well-known tourists around the vistors' center at the Miraflores Locks, and he says he has developed a routine.
''A lot of our guests come in thinking of the canal as some historic monument or curiosity, or as something that has to be protected,'' said Mr. Manfredo, who studied management at Harvard Business School. ''I try to get them to see that it's a commercial enterprise and that we depend on business from the outside.'' 
 
'Keep the Canal Efficient'
Now that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is out of the picture, Mr. Manfredo said, Panamanians must find ways ''to keep the canal efficient,'' so that by the time they take over from the Americans at the end of 1999, as specified under the 1979 canal treaties, the waterway will still be a major source of income and not merely Panama's answer to the Great Pyramids.
''Our users were very much concerned by the prospect that the canal was going to be in the hands of a dictator,'' said Mr. Manfredo, who is acting head of the Panama Canal Commission, the 10-year-old United States Government agency that is to operate the waterway until 1999. ''Now I think the Panamanian Government has to show that it can manage the canal efficiently.''
At the height of Panama's political and economic turmoil, many of the Canal Commission's 7,602 employees, more than 85 percent of them Panamanian, were harassed and threatened by the Noriega Government. Mr. Manfredo said that two days before the United States invasion, he learned that the general had been plotting ''my physical elimination.''
The canal employees also found themselves caught by United States economic sanctions. When the Reagan Administration suspended canal revenue payments to Panama in April 1988, General Noriega retaliated by virtually banning them from activities like traveling abroad, receiving packages in the mail and even registering cars.
 
Revenue Is Off
But through it all, ship traffic on the canal was hardly disrupted. In fact, canal economists say, none of the waterway's business problems in the last six years have had anything to do with General Noriega, who avoided any action that the Americans could interpret as a threat to the canal.
Since 1986, about 12,000 ships have used the waterway each year, although last year's toll revenue declined $10 million from 1988, to $329 million. Tolls are based on vessel size and cargo. Economists say the drop was caused by plummeting grain sales, a slump in imports of Japanese cars, and economic slowdowns in Japan and the United States.
The new civilian Government has immediate and long-term decisions to make about the waterway. For one thing, the Panamanians will have decide whether they want to try to operate the canal at a profit. Over the last decade, the Americans have run it as a break-even operation, as mandated by Congress; since 1979, it has taken in $4 billion and spent $4 billion.
In the short term, Mr. Manfredo and other canal officials say, Panama needs to demonstrate to shippers that it is committed to running the waterway in a businesslike fashion. The most obvious place to begin, they think, is to rehabilitate the canal's two ports, Balboa, on the Gulf of Panama, and Cristobal, on the Caribbean near Colon, the country's second largest city. The Government runs both ports.
Balboa, where ships enter from the Pacific Ocean, is mainly a refueling and servicing depot; Cristobal, on the Atlantic side, handles a huge volume of goods going through the Colon Free Zone, the world's largest duty-free port after Hong Kong.
Under General Noriega, Balboa, Cristobal and the country's nine other ports fell into the same spiral of graft and corruption as other Government agencies. Maintenance and security fell off, docks rotted, equipment rusted and pilferage spread. The decline accelerated under the effects of the American sanctions and sporadic disputes between the Government and dock workers' unions.
''Noriega appointed a lot of people who knew little or nothing about running the system, and now the ports are a total mess,'' said Richard A. Wainio, an American who is director of planning at the Canal Commission.
 
Ports Need Money
''If they're going to spend their limited funds wisely, they're going to have to concentrate on the ports,'' Mr. Wainio said. ''That would be a positive sign that Panama really means business.''
Mr. Manfredo said the Government of President Guillermo Endara had taken an important first step by naming Jerry Salazar, a highly experienced lawyer and engineer, as the new director of the National Port Authority.
General Noriega used to say he built his 15,000-member military in part to fulfill a treaty requirement that Panama prepare to defend the canal. Mr. Manfredo smiles at that explanation.
Only three threats face the canal in 1990, he says: landslides of the sort that forced it to close for nine months in 1914 (the only shutdown in its history until the 24-hour closure caused by the United States invasion on Dec. 20); the uncontrolled growth of aquatic weeds, which can foul propellers unless regularly cut back, and the remote possibility that the canal's 230 licensed ships' pilots could strike ''and close us down tomorrow.''
But Mr. Manfredo, who turns 63 years old on Monday, has one other worry: that the Endara Government may not appoint him as permanent canal administrator. At the moment, he is in an acting capacity, and there are at least two other contenders for the job.
Although Mr. Manfredo is the most experienced of the candidates, having served 10 years as deputy to the former American administrator, Dennis P. McAuliffe, his past political associations may prove a liability. He was a close adviser of General Noriega's predecessor, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, who came to power after a military coup in 1968. And he remains a member of the Democratic Revolutionary Party, which represented the military in elections as recently as last May.
Whatever happens, Mr. Manfredo expects it to be an improvement over the ordeal he says he underwent at the hands of General Noriega shortly before the invasion, when he defied the general and accepted President Bush's offer to extend his term as deputy administrator. By agreeing to stay on, Mr. Manfredo would have become acting administrator automatically, since by law the American administrator had to step down and be succeeded by a Panamanian no later than Jan. 1.
But Mr. Manfredo said the general wanted to nominate a political crony to the post, knowing the United States would never accept any candidate he put forward. General Noriega would then be able to tell the world that the Bush Administration had violated the canal treaties.
 
Harassment, Then Intimidation
Besides gaining a domestic political advantage, Mr. Manfredo said, ''Noriega wanted to put the Latin American countries in a very embarrassing position: they could either support the United States, or they could support him in his allegation that the treaties had been violated.''
Mr. Manfredo said his refusal to step down from his canal post infuriated the general, who quickly struck back.
''In the beginning, it was a campaign of pure harassment,'' Mr. Manfredo recalled. ''Then he escalated it to pure intimidation. I received threats that all my assets were going to be confiscated, and that I was going to be deprived of my citizenship and thrown in jail.''
But ''when they didn't see any reaction on my behalf,'' he said, ''a new campaign was begun on the national level to say that I was a traitor.''
On Dec. 18, Mr. Manfredo said, a friend in the military whispered to him that a new plan had been hatched. ''He told me that I was to be executed by a Panamanian patriot,'' Mr. Manfredo said. He responded by ''instructing my wife in how to transfer money from my bank account in case I was murdered.''
''Otherwise, I decided to continue my activities as usual,'' he went on. ''I didn't want to give these people the impression I was afraid.''
Two days later the invasion began, and Mr. Manfredo and his family were spirited away to an American base.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 691 words

HEADLINE: New Market Journal;
Nurturing New Seeds In a Garden Of Hopes

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW MARKET, Tenn., Jan. 24

 BODY:
''Public Auction Wipes Out Last of Highlander School'' read a 1962 newspaper headline, noting the apparent demise of the Highlander Folk School, one of the legendary incubators of the civil rights movement.
But when the school's founder, Myles Horton, died last week, some 58 years after the school's founding and 28 years after its apparent last gasp, he left behind an institution that is not only alive, but remains one of the most stubbornly tenacious instruments for social change in the nation.
''From its start, this has been one of the few places that takes seriously the notion that grass-roots people, dispossessed people, who do not have money or power or much formal education can solve their own problems,'' said Candie Carawan, who has spent most of the past 30 years working with the school, now the Highlander Research and Education Center.
Mr. Horton founded Highlander in 1932 in Monteagle, Tenn., in one of the nation's poorest regions, and it soon became one of the most important training grounds for union organizers in the South. 
In the 1950's, it shifted its focus to desegregation. It sponsored workshops, where people like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Rosa Parks and John Lewis argued late into the night about the direction of civil rights movement. It gave birth to Septima Clark's famous ''citizenship schools,'' where thousands of blacks learned to read and write so they could vote.
Highlander was considered subversive enough that Tennessee officials tried to shut it down. But when they succeeded in revoking the Monteagle school's charter in 1960, Mr. Horton relocated to Knoxville and then to the serene 110-acre site in northeastern Tennessee between the Cumberlands and the Smokies, where the school operates under its current status as the Highlander Research and Education Center.
Highlander's work did not end with civil rights. Much of its energy in recent years has been spent working with poor rural communities of Appalachia, fighting economic decay and environmental problems.
The center, which has a staff of 17 people and an annual budget of $800,000, has concentrated recently on environmental issues throughout the South. About 1,000 people attended workshops last year.
If the content differs widely, the format is much the same as it was in the civil rights era. Participants still come to a wood-frame hilltop meeting room bathed in light, where they sit in a circle in aged rocking chairs and share ideas. It still rings with the fading culture of the South, whether it be the dulcimer music of the Appalachian hills or the dances of the South Carolina Sea Islands.
Instead of outside experts, its participants are craggy-faced coal miners, mountain housewives turned environmental activists or rural blacks. The emphasis is still on what ordinary people can achieve, whether they be poor blacks seeking voting rights or poor whites fighting a toxic waste dump. ''The issues change, but the philosophy remains the same,'' said John Gaventa, a former Rhodes scholar and the center's director.
Still, what has changed is at least as significant. Mr. Gaventa says the challenges are as important now as in the civil rights era, but much of the work in small towns throughout the South like Minden, W. Va.,, Aliceville, Ala., or Lumberton, N.C., can seem invisible without the unifying focus of an overriding national movement.
Similarly, he said, Highlander now deals in a more complex environment where issues of pollution and economic displacement have to be viewed in an international context and communities are often torn by competing economic and environmental pressures.
''We're trying to find a way to save jobs and save the river, but no one wants to sit down and talk about it,'' said Stephen Hodges of Hartford, Tenn., who has worked with Highlander trying to solve pollution problems caused by the Champion International paper plant in Canton, N.C. ''What I like about Highlander is that they don't try to come in and take over.''
When Mr. Horton died Jan. 19, the center planted two dogwoods in his memory - a reminder that the seed he planted still grows.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Japanese Author Brushes Up His Image With Journey to U.S. Enemy's Lair

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
He wears $800 Saville Row suits and $80 Georgio Armani ties. He plays tennis, he sails, he paints, he writes best sellers. He has represented a Tokyo constituency in the Parliament for the past 22 years. But Shintaro Ishihara is an angry man caught in a name-calling game.
He has emerged in the American press with the label ''right-wing Japanese author.'' He responds with charges of racism.
He is angry at Americans for behaving ''more like mad dogs than watch dogs'' and for the racist feelings he believes they harbor against the Japanese. 
He is also angry at his own people, for bowing to American economic and trade demands and not using their technology for greater global leverage. And he is angry that a book in which these and other such incendiary thoughts are expressed, ''The Japan That Can Say No,'' which he wrote with Akio Morita, the chairman of the Sony Corporation, is being circulated here without authorization by - and payment to - the authors.
 
Embodiment of New Sour Mood
What makes this all significant is that Mr. Ishihara has become the embodiment of a new sour mood in Japanese-American relations. Indeed, alert to the threat vacuum left by the Soviet thaw, culture critics were warning that Americans might turn on Japan even before Mr. Ishihara's views became known here. The reaction has been fanned by an English translation of his book, paid for by the Pentagon and entered into the Congressional Record in November at the request of Representative Sander M. Levin, a Michigan Democrat.
And so, this month Mr. Ishihara spent three days in Washington seeking to brush up his image.
Critic though he is of the American way, he took to it naturally, figuring out the public relations value of being seen meeting on Capitol Hill with his enemies in the United States' protectionism caucus. The third-ranking candidate for prime minister in 1989, accused of spurring Japanese jingoism, sat down with, among others, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader who was charged by his rivals for the 1988 Democratic Presidential nomination of running on an economic nationalist plank.
To set up things for him in Washington, Mr. Ishihara used the Washington office of a St. Louis-based public relations firm, Fleishman Hillard, Inc. Its Tokyo affiliate, the Tokyu Agency Inc., is managed by one of Mr. Ishihara's oldest friends, Matahiko Imaoka, a fellow yachtsman.
 
'Beyond the Pale'
But not even this influential firm could open all the doors. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Finance Committee's Subcommittee on International Trade, turned down an offered appointment. Through an aide, Mr. Baucus said that although he has traditionally maintained an open-door policy United States-bashing at Mr. Ishihara's volume level ''is a little beyond the pale.''
Some samples of Mr. Ishihara's writing:
''The only reason'' Americans could use the atomic bomb against Japan in World War II, Mr. Ishihara said, was ''their racial attitude toward Japan,'' adding that American racism is ''based on the cultural belief that the modern era is the creation of the white race, including Americans.''
The United States had better straighten out economically, he wrote, or it might suffer the consequences. ''If, for example, Japan sold chips to the Soviet Union and stopped selling them to the U.S., this would upset the entire military balance.''
Mr. Ishihara told the Americans who would see him in the private meetings that because of ''mistranslations'' and ''deletions'' the unauthorized version of his book distorted his ideas. His objective in writing the book was really to make the Japanese-American partnership ''tighter and more productive,'' he said.
''I think that at long last Japan has become a major league ball player after being in the minor league for so long,'' Mr. Isihara told Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the senior Republican on the Agriculture Committee and former chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, a Lugar aide said. ''Japan and the U.S. should be a battery,'' Mr. Ishihara added.
''We talked about misconceptions on both sides,'' said Representative Levin, who had lunch with him in the Power Court Restaurant of the Phoenix Park Hotel on Capitol Hill. ''I think it was useful that he was here.''
It was ''a good honest discussion,'' said aides to Mr. Gephardt, who declined to go into the substance of the meeting in the majority leader's Capitol Hill office.
 
Barbs, in Nautical Terms
And then there was the session in Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher's high-ceilinged office looking out over the Mall and the Washington Monument. The Secretary reminded Mr. Ishihara that under a little-known section of trade law known as Section 232 at the Commerce Department, relating to the reliability of suppliers to the United States Government, Japan could suffer considerable economic damage if it sold semiconductors to the Soviet Union.
Mr. Ishihara blanched, a Commerce Department aide said, and then said that for his part he was upset by polls in the United States showing that Japan is perceived a greater threat to American future well-being than the Soviet Union. Such conclusions are ''frivolous'' and ''dangerous,'' Mr. Ishihara said.
The two men discovered their mutual love of the sea. Mr. Mosbacher, a world-class yachtsman, used nautical images to zing his guest over the FSX, the fighter aircraft that the two countries agreed to build together after a prolonged and bitter dispute. Japan ''wanted to get the whole boat and give nothing back for jib and tiller technology from America,'' the Secretary said.
Mr. Mosbacher said he hoped to be able to write a sequel to the Ishihara book, called, ''The Japan That Can Say Yes And Mean It.''
All in all, most of the Americans who saw the Japanese politician here said they found him not nearly as frightening as his advance billing suggested. ''There's a discrepancy between what he reportedly says and what he actually says,'' noted an aide to Senator Lugar who sat in on the meeting with Mr. Ishihara.
 
Personal Protectionism Issue
They also said that, invariably, Mr. Ishihara raised a personal protectionism issue, appealing for the kind of help his critics say he would deny Americans in Japan. Since he has gained no royalties from circulation of the unauthorized book, Mr. Ishihara said, he is really one of the latest victims of intellectual property piracy. And he would like the Japanese Government, a frequent target of Washington's unfair trade complaints, to file formal charges of copyright infringement against the United States.
''I have brought up this issue with the Japanese Writers Association as well as the Japanese Pen Club,'' he said in an interview. ''Some say that in America my book is a 'non-best seller.' If so, I have incurred a lot of economic damage. Who is going to compensate me for that damage?''
Mr. Levin said he acted without compunction in entering the work in the Congressional Record, from which thousands of photocopies have apparently been made. ''It seemed to me we should be able to read what we were talking about,'' he said. ''I feel when it comes to allies that we ought to be able to say to each other what we are saying to ourselves.''
The Defense Department's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, the Government's coordinator of efforts to enhance national competitiveness in semiconductors, high-definition television and computing, ordered the translation.
It was, said Pete Williams, the Penatgon spokeman, a routine operation. Agency ''managers needing access to foreign language literature not available on a timely basis from other sources, can obtain access,'' he said. ''The material is available only for official'' use, he said, adding that such translation, for internal Defense Department purposes, is ''not a violation of any copyright restriction.''
 
New, American Version
Hence another lesson for Mr. Ishihara. The American bureaucracy may not be as formidable as Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, but it is beating him with its rulebook all the same.
As for the prospects for an authorized publication, they are blocked by Mr. Morita, the co-author, whose company gets one-third of its global revenues from the American market. Mr. Morita maintains that he was ''not fully aware'' of Mr. Ishihara's sentiments about America and Japan and now ''regrets'' being involved, said Stephen M. Burke, Sony Corporation of America's director of public affairs.
''The book, as it stands, is confusing and inflammatory,'' Mr. Burke said, while noting that as for any customer backlash, ''I don't think anyone has sent back their product.''
Mr. Ishihara is now hoping to get an official American version into print here minus Mr. Morita's contribution. That, of course, would not be the same book that has sold more than half a million copies in Japan; the book is actually a series of individual speeches made in Japan by the two men over a period of months and then packaged by an enterprising Japanese publisher.
In effect, the American version would be expurgated for Americans. Or, as Mr. Ishihara put it, ''Because there are parts that need elaboration, parts that could be easily misunderstood, we want to elaborate on the general theme and add some background information.''
Presumably the elaborating will start in March, after Japan's elections in February, when Mr. Ishihara is planning another trip to the United States. One of his tentatively scheduled events is a visit to a town meeting in Michigan, at the suggestion of Representative Levin, whose constitutents have been hard hit by Japanese auto sales. Mr. Levin has been asked to reciprocate in Tokyo.
But the hands across the sea mood went only so far. Mr. Ishihara stuck to his guns on the issue that has probably caused the greatest resentment here: American racism.
In his book Mr. Ishihara wrote that the ''roots of the U.S.-Japan friction lie in the soil of racial prejudice.''
In an interview, he expanded on these thoughts, noting that ''there are different emotions and sentiments at work'' in the relationship with the United States, ''but at the bottom of this psychological and emotional sentiment there is a certain sense of superiority toward the Japanese.''
Asked whether he thought his book would help him some day to become Japan's prime minister, which he acknowledged was his ambition, he said he thought that it might actually work negatively.
''Many Japanese are still saying, 'Better hush and not say these things,' '' he said.

HEADLINE: Boston Banks Agree to Fight Racial Disparity in Mortgages

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Faced with a new study showing a wide racial disparity in mortgage lending, a group of Boston banks has agreed to take part in a $430 million program to narrow the gap.
Last August the Federal Reserve Bank here reported that whites were twice as likely as blacks to receive mortgages, even when conditions like income and market value were taken into account. The new study, commissioned by the city, found an even wider disparity.
The $430 million program was announced on the national holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. It came as the city was focusing on race relations in the wake of the Charles Stuart case, in which a white man's claim that he and his wife were abducted, robbed and shot by a black man was eventually declared false. 
The program evolved through months of negotiations among bank representatives, city officials and blacks. Some have hailed the agreement as the most comprehensive of its kind. Others are more cautious, saying it is the first step on a long road.
 
'It's a Start'
''I don't know how many people it's going to reach, but it's more than we had before,'' said Diana Strother, a co-chairwoman of the Homebuyers Union, a community group that took part in negotiations with the city and the banks. ''It's a start, and it gives people a ray of light to look forward to.''
The move comes at a time when the state's economy is faltering and most banks are reeling from one of their worst years in recent memory. Bad real-estate loans, many in condominiums here and in other states, are being blamed for heavy losses. This week, the Bank of New England announced a $1.05 billion loss for the year, and it may be sold or turned over to Federal regulators.
Critics say the banks could have avoided heavy losses by investing in the neighborhoods they ignored, rather than in speculative ventures in Florida and elsewhere.
''What we're saying is that if people had stayed close to home and invested in the community, we'd have a stronger economy and stronger banks,'' said Stephen Coyle, director of the Boston Redevelopment Authority, which commissioned the city's study on lending bias.
Mr. Coyle and other critics say the problem was fostered by ignorance about black neighborhoods that led to institutional discrimination against them. Properties in these neighborhoods were often appraised as risky ventures for the banks when it came to lending money. But some experts say that because of the high demand for urban housing, supported by state and Federal housing programs, such a home can easily be rented if the mortgage holder defaults and the bank has to take over the property.
 
Lower Interest Rates
A major sticking point in the negotiations with the banks was whether to provide mortgages at below-market rates. Banks do not like such mortgages, not only because they bring in lower interest but also because they tie up money that could be lent at market rates.
City officials won a small concession there. The package includes $60 million for low-rate mortgages, usually a percentage point below market levels, for people buying their first homes. Half the money will be designated for Boston.
The package also includes $100 million for mortgages at market rates but with flexible terms, like reduced down payments; $50 million in Federal tax credits for investing in low-income housing, and $5 million from the banks in equity capital for minority-owned businesses. The banks have also agreed to finance $100 million in new low-cost housing, mostly in Boston. Potential risk will be shared by all the banks involved.
The banks view parts of the new program as risky and a sacrifice, especially since it comes at a time of heavy losses for many of them.
''Our timing would have been better if we'd done this five years ago,'' said Grady B. Hedgespeth, director of governmental and community affairs for the Bank of Boston, which recorded a $70 million profit last year, down from $322 million in 1988. The bank lost $244 million last year from bad real estate loans, according to its year-end earnings report.
To bankers who object to issuing below-market mortgages, some experts reply that developers trying to sell condominiums in the present market glut are offering similar discounts. Those condominiums ''just happen to be in these non-minority areas,'' said Ronald A. Homer, president and chief executive officer of the Boston Bank of Commerce, which has invested substantially in minority neighborhoods and posted a 10 percent rise in profits last year.
He added that the bank attracted many potential homeowners by offering flexible terms, like allowing people to spend a higher proportion of their incomes on mortgage payments and to put as little as 10 percent down.
The city's study found that from 1981 to 1987, mortgages were issued to white applicants nearly three times as often as to black applicants who met the same criteria in categories like income, credit history and liabilities. And the gap widened, to 3.4 to 1, when federally backed mortgage loans, for which the banks take little risk, were eliminated.
The Federal Reserve study, covering 1982 to 1987, found an imbalance of about 2 to 1 in favor of whites.
Ms. Strother, of the Homebuyers Union, said, ''A lot of the people I know who have homes went to mortgage companies because they didn't qualify at the banks.'' Those companies charge considerably higher interest than banks do.
The city's study also pointed out imbalances in the numbers of bank branches and automated teller machines in white and black neighborhoods. The neighborhoods of Mattapan and Roxbury, which are predominantly black, have at least 16.6 percent of the city's population but only 4 percent of the bank branches and teller machines.
 
Enforcement of Laws
Part of the problem, many officials said, is the Federal and state governments do not adequately enforce laws requiring banks to serve all neighborhoods of the areas in which they are chartered.
In the absence of a state agency to enforce the law, the city plans to issue periodic ''report cards,'' rating individual bank performance in community reinvestment, Mr. Coyle said. The city also plans to deposit its money only in banks that reinvest in the community.
''It's not the greatest leverage in the world, but it is leverage,'' Mr. Coyle said. ''Our concern is to educate the entire community on this issue.''

HEADLINE: Don't Cut Israel and Others to Aid East Europe

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I disagree with my colleague and leader Senator Bob Dole on cutting foreign aid allocations to help emerging democracies in Eastern Europe and elsewhere (Op-Ed, Jan. 16). The idea that aid to these nations requires penalizing our friends and allies is neither logical, correct nor necessary.
The foreign aid accounts of the United States Government, while they receive much attention, are embarrassingly small. From statements on the floor of the Senate and news releases sent back home, one would conclude that if this item in the Federal budget alone could be contained, the deficit would soon be in hand. 
The foreign aid budget constitutes slightly more than 1 percent of Federal spending. Not many years ago, it was more than 2 percent, so those who argue for less have already been successful.
Each of the aid recipients Senator Dole mentions - Egypt, Israel, Pakistan, the Philippines and Turkey -has seen its aid decrease in real terms in recent years.
If the United States picks this moment to reduce its aid to the Middle East, this reduction in our commitment would undermine the likelihood of progress on peace. In the shadowy currents of Middle East politics, a partial withdrawal of the United States commitment would be seen as a victory for those most intransigent - a signal to increase the pressure so that the United States would further erode its support to our friends and allies. Moreover, the threats of terrorism, chemical warfare and ballistic missiles hang over Israel, Egypt and other friendly nations in the Middle East, giving them additional substantive reasons for looking to us for aid.
If Senator Dole is looking for funds to aid the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, he need not go so far afield. While technically not part of the foreign aid account in the Federal budget, the bulk of our spending overseas - perhaps as much as 90 percent - is found in the military budget. Most of that is spent in Europe to protect North Atlantic Treaty Organization and American interests against the military forces of the very countries that are now democratizing and, presumably, pose less of a threat.
Furthermore, we are protecting developed West European economies far stronger and more able to afford such expenditures than the foreign aid recipients Senator Dole seeks to penalize. These European nations spend barely 3 percent of their gross national product on defense, while we spend twice that. Why should they spend more when a generous and rich uncle is willing to pick up the tab? The main source of economic aid to Eastern Europe should come from its neighbors to the west.
The second large area of our defense expenditures overseas is in the Far East. Including naval expenditures in the region, our costs there surely are five or six times greater than the entire aid package under attack by Senator Dole. Yet the Japanese spend barely 1 percent of gross national product on defense. We provide huge subsidies to our principal trade competitors - Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Europe - by underwriting their defense.
If our defense expenditures were largely taken over by our allies, our deficit would be wiped out and interest rates lowered, more funds would be available for research and development, and we could better compete and rebuild our infrastructure.
I don't suggest we abandon our allies. But surely the enormous funds spent in Europe and the Far East protecting the wealthiest countries in the world could far more easily and more appropriately be diverted in small part to assist democracies in those very same regions.
It would be a most destabilizing mistake to divert money and moral support from developing democracies like Pakistan, the Philippines and Turkey or from the caldron of the Middle East.
 
RUDY BOSCHWITZ
U.S. Senator from Minnesota
 Washington, Jan. 18, 1990

LENGTH: 1643 words

HEADLINE: Affordable Housing Issue Ruffles Idyllic Westchester

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: NORTH SALEM, N.Y., Jan. 26

 BODY:
In a court battle over the future of Peach Lake, two suburban imperatives are colliding in this remote corner of Westchester County: the need for affordable housing and the yearning for open spaces.
A developer who wants to build nearly 200 condominiums on the lakefront says North Salem stole the value of his land when it adopted new zoning rules that barred multifamily housing. Moreover, he says, the town turned a deaf ear to the region's housing crisis.
In its defense, North Salem, with 4,800 residents among wooded hills and horse farms, says its zoning plan is one of the most environmentally sound in the county. Town officials say it is not ''exclusionary'' zoning. 
 
Broad Ruling Sought
The trial, which began this week in State Supreme Court in White Plains, is being watched closely by builders and local officials far from Peach Lake. For the developer's lawyer, Stuart R. Shamberg, is pressing for a court mandate that would require all municipalities in New York to amend their zoning ordinances to encourage affordable housing.
He would like to win a version of New Jersey's Mount Laurel rulings, which held that all communities have a constitutional obligation to provide a fair share of a region's low- and moderate-income housing and allowed developers to build more units than local zoning permitted in return for selling some at low prices.
Westchester County planning officials and housing advocates here say Mr. Shamberg's case may just be solid enough and the time right for New York to adopt such a mandate. ''There's no doubt that this case has the potential to be significant,'' said Larry C. Salley, deputy commissioner of planning in the county's Division of Housing and Community Development. ''It goes beyond one town's action to the broader issue of how that action fits in with the overall regional housing picture. Here in Westchester, it's pretty bleak.''
 
Builder Seeking Millions
The 34-year-old developer, Lawrence M. Clifford, president of the Continental Building Company of White Plains, is suing the Town of North Salem and seven former Planning Board members for millions of dollars each. The town's rezoning in 1987 drastically reduced his land value and future profits, he said. Where before he could build 184 condominiums on his 63 acres on Peach Lake, now he can build only 18 single-family houses.
The case has evoked sharply different reactions from planning experts and proponents of affordable housing, many of whom share the same goals.
''Given its location, overall character and lack of infrastructure, North Salem is probably the least appropriate place to focus new development,'' said John A. Humbach, an associate dean of the Pace University Law School whose academic speciality is land-use regulation. ''It would be a shame if 25 or 50 years from now people had to drive up to Columbia County to find a farm.''
But Joseph Dzaluk, the executive director of the Westchester Housing Forum, a private, nonprofit organization that promotes affordable housing for the working middle class, said, ''What North Salem did is an outrage, and it's what precipitates lawsuits.'' But Is It Affordable? Mr. Shamberg is not new to pivotal cases. A partner in the Mount Kisco law firm of Shamberg, Marwell, Cherneff & Hocherman, he challenged New Castle in 1977 on behalf of a builder who wanted to put up condominiums, resulting in a landmark decision known as the Berenson Doctrine.
It held that a municipality had to consider the region's needs and therefore could not exclude multifamily housing. The decision had the effect of a mandate in the county and established a precedent in the state, county planning officials say.
At the time the assumption was that multifamily housing meant affordable housing. But much of the multifamily housing built in the last 10 years turned out to be luxury town houses. Now Mr. Shamberg is hoping that on an appeal to the state's highest court, a ruling might guarantee housing in every community that is not only multifamily, but also affordable.
''The wider issue is what is a muncipality's moral and social responsiblity when it is in the middle of a region that has a severe housing crisis,'' Mr. Shamberg said.
 
Profit Motive Suspected
To many in North Salem, where gentle hills still frame lakes and farms, his position is suspiciously high and mighty. They suspect that the primary motive in the suit is improving profits, and their cynicism is fueled by the vocal - and monetary - support that Mr. Clifford has received from the building industry.
''The builders would love to have Mount Laurel in New York because it would be great for business,'' said Karen Iacovelli, editor of The Rural Press, a quarterly periodical, and a former member of the North Salem Planning Board who was not named in the suit.
''The hypocrisy is that in the last 10 years, it's the builders themselves who reaped the greatest benefit from large-lot zoning,'' she said. ''But all of a sudden the bottom fell out of the housing market, and the builders have no place to go, so you keep hearing this phrase affordable housing.''
Indeed Mr. Clifford's condominiums, as originally planned, would not have been affordable at all, with an average two-bedroom town house selling in the mid- to upper-$200,000 range. Now, though, because of the mushy housing market, the builder said he would consider garden apartments priced on the average below $200,000 - still ''unaffordable'' according to strict housing guidelines.
But Mr. Clifford has pledged that if he is allowed to build 184 units of the less-expensive garden apartments and that if the court issues a Mount Laurel type of ruling, he will also construct affordable housing. In the past, North Salem officials have said affordable units should sell for approximately $85,000.
 
Land Planning Faulted
Mr. Shamberg and his supporters say North Salem has a history of arrogance in land planning.
In 1981 a state judge ordered the town to redraw its zoning map to allow multifamily housing after another developer sued. The town complied, delineating six areas for about 350 town houses and condominiums scattered across 22 square miles.
But several years later, when the town decided to redo its entire ordinance to stave off the development consuming its neighbor, Somers - where International Business Machines and Pepsico were building office complexes - it abolished five of the six multifamily zones, including Mr. Clifford's. The town also added one, bringing the total to two multifamily zones.
The Westchester County Planning Department praised the new ordinance as an environmental model that protected slopes, vistas and wetlands, while accounting for a sparse network of narrow roads, a lack of sewers and a reliance on well water. But the department ultimately objected to the zoning changes on the ground that they hampered the town's ability to contribute housing to the county.
 
Housing Quota Unmet
In 1980 the County Planning Department, citing a shortage of all forms of housing that threatened to undermine its economy, asked each municipality to project the number of new units it could produce over 10 years. North Salem estimated its contribution at 393 units, but as of 1988, only 160 units had been completed.
''They had not met their target, and here they were taking steps that would further reduce the number of multifamily units in the town,'' said the County Planning Commissioner, Peter Q. Eschweiller.
Countering those criticisms, town officials stress that the town's ordinance, in addition to encouraging accessory apartments, rewards builders for setting aside some homes with affordable prices by permitting them extra units, or greater density, along the lines of what Mr. Shamberg is seeking.
For example, a development now under construction in one of the town's two multifamily zones would ordinarily hold 71 units. But with the affordable-housing bonus, the builder is putting up 14 additional units, about half of which will priced according to a formula.
''Our ordinance is probably the most progressive in Westchester, because it allows the density bonus,'' said Peter C. Bliss, chairman of the Zoning Board and a past Planning Board member who is one of the seven being sued.
However, county officials said North Salem's spacious zoning, consisting mostly of two- and four-acre lots, rendered its density bonus worthless.
 
Lake Pollution Cited
Another major concern in North Salem is the health of Peach Lake. Measuring two miles across and straddling the border of Putnam and Westchester Counties, the lake is ringed by two country clubs and a golf course, as well as several hundred summer bungalows, converted long ago to year-round homes. Failing septic tanks have dirtied the waters, town officials say, and more development could make matters worse.
Mr. Clifford, who bought his land on the lake's south end in the late 1960's, agrees. ''There's no question that Peach Lake is in trouble,'' the developer said.
But he has a solution: given the chance to build 184 units, he could afford to install a tertiary sewage treatment plant at the condominium complex. ''We would allow some homes around the lake to tie into our plant,'' he said. ''It would save Peach Lake.''
Not so, say the lakeside residents, the strongest opponents to the development. ''The lake is so polluted now,'' said Alexander Zack, who lives in a two-bedroom cottage. ''It's not the views or the extra traffic we mind. We just don't want any more sludge in that beautiful lake.''
The crucial test in the upcoming trial, according to land-use experts, will be the developer's ability to prove that he had a ''vested interest'' in the property, even though North Salem had not issued any approvals for his site plan at the time the zoning was changed.

HEADLINE: Budget Chief Defends Plans For Spending on the Military

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
On the eve of the submission of President Bush's new budget, his budget director, Richard G. Darman, today defended the size of the military budget, the proposed cut in the capital gains tax and the Administration's opposition to a reduction in the Social Security tax.
Mr. Darman also repeated the charge he made in his introduction to the new budget that Congress had not been serious about reducing the budget deficit.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California and chairman of the House Budget Committee, took issue with the contention that Congress had been irresponsible, but he said that this year the lawmakers would have to confront the necessity for new taxes to lower the deficit.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who has proposed a sharp cut in Social Security taxes, criticized Mr. Darman for being unwilling to act sooner to stop using those taxes to pay for the Government's operating expenses. 
 
Rise in 'Star Wars' Spending
Interviewed on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' Mr. Darman maintained that continued international threats warranted increased spending for the ''Star Wars'' missile defense system and new weapons like the Stealth bomber.
Regardless of the improved relations with the Soviet Union, he said, ''There are third parties now, non-superpowers, who have ballistic missile capability.'' That, he said, made continued work on the Star Wars system imperative.
Officials say the Administration will propose spending $4.8 billion on the missile defense system in the fiscal year 1991, which begins Oct. 1. That would be about $1 billion more than in 1990 but about $1 billion less than had been previously planned.
The Administration will propose spending $292.1 billion on Pentagon programs in the next fiscal year, about $5 billion more than this year but about $6 billion less than what would be needed to keep pace with inflation. Congress is expected to try to cut the military budget further.
 
Debate on Taxes
Mr. Darman argued that a reduction in the capital gains tax would lead to economic growth, benefiting the entire economy, while a cut in Social Security taxes, as Senator Moynihan has proposed, would inhibit ''investment in all these worthy purposes, social insurance and housing and education and so on.''
A reduction in the Social Security tax, without an increase in other taxes, would increase the Federal budget deficit. That would force the Government to borrow more money and thus reduce the amount that could be invested.
In recent years, an increasing surplus from Social Security revenue has been used to pay the day-to-day cost of Government instead of being invested in a way that would guarantee pension benefits for today's workers when they retire. The Administration plans to reduce the reliance on those taxes beginning in 1993 and to stop using them for operating expenses entirely by 1996.
Senator Moynihan, in a statement, said those plans reminded him of the the line from ''Through the Looking Glass'': ''The rule is, jam tomorrow and jam yesterday - but never jam today.''
''It is well known that the Federal budget is always in balance three years from now,'' the New York Democrat said. ''Never, however, now.''
 
Criticism of Congress
Mr. Darman was equally critical of Congress. Referring to Congress, he wrote in the introduction to the President's proposed budget, ''At some point, there is an obligation to be serious.''
The preachy tone irritated some Democrats, but Mr. Darman continued the criticism on television today.
He said of Congress: ''There's an awful lot of hypocrisy. There's an awful lot of posturing.''
Representative Panetta, reached by telephone at his home in California, said Mr. Darman's statements could be taken either of two ways - as the remarks of ''a frustrated budget director who can't get his own Administration to focus on these issues'' or as ''a cynical way'' to curry favor ''with the economists at the same time you present a political budget to the economists.''
Mr. Bush will deliver his State of the Union Message on Wednesday night, two days after submitting his proposed budget to Congress.

HEADLINE: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: HARNESS RACING;
At 21, He's Off And Winning

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
NOT every 21-year-old college student can say he owns a string of harness horses. But then, not every college student has a mother who operates a chain of Chinese restaurants.
Gilbert Chang's mother does, though, and enough of the profits from Misa Chang's share of 13 Empire Szechuan restaurants in New York City have filtered down to give her son the wherewithal to indulge his whims. 
And as Chang, a junior at New York University, is the first to acknowledge, his No. 1 whim is harness racing. ''I've been going to the track since I was 8 years old,'' he said in an interview.
His first love was actually thoroughbreds, but since most of them usually race during school hours, Chang switched to standardbreds, who usually compete at night.
He bought his first horse last February and has spent some $700,000 putting together a nine-horse stable known as the Chang Dynasty.
The key event in his transition from fan to owner took place when Chang was introduced to Steve Manzi, a trainer who was between assignments. Manzi, who grew up in the harness world, was looking for a compatible owner. Chang was looking for an experienced trainer who didn't mind working for a novice.
The two have since then forged the perfect working relationship: Manzi makes all the decisions. Chang signs all the checks.
The money includes $50 a day per horse for Manzi, who keeps what's left over after buying feed, straw and the like, enough to keep the trainer from returning to his previous job.
''When I met him, he was digging ditches,'' Chang said.
The Chang Dynasty had a fairly good year in 1989, taking 23 firsts, 19 seconds and 17 thirds in 109 starts and grossing just over $300,000 in purses.
By September, Chang said, he was up about $120,000 for the year. Then he was hit by a devastating blow: the Meadowlands' annual thoroughbred season, when harness purses stop without a corresponding hiatus in expenses. After four months, Chang's profits were down to the $20,000 level.
That's not much of a return on his investment, but Chang, an economics major who plans a business career, sees racing as a hobby, not a business. As long as his earnings cover his expenses, he said, he's satisfied.
As for his business future, Chang said his mother was leaning toward hotels, and where his bankroll leans, he bends.
One can envision what such a future might consist of: a chain of Chang Dynasty resort hotels each overlooking an expanse of tennis courts, a golf course or two - and a harness track.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Struggle With Conscience In an Almost Forgotten War

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON

 BODY:
In one of the early episodes of the television series M*A*S*H, Col. Henry Blake, the Army surgeon played by McLean Stevenson, bitterly observes that there are two rules of war. The first is that people die. The second is that there is nothing that doctors, chaplains or field officers can do about Rule No. 1. Rod Serling's teleplay ''The Strike,'' which is being given its first stage production by the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company at the South Street Theater, examines the agony of conscience of one Army major who must make a battlefield decision that could end in the death of a score of men he himself has sent out on a reconnaissance patrol.
''The Strike,'' which was originally presented as a ''Studio One'' television production in 1954, represents something of a departure for the worthy Vietnam Veterans company. First, it is a play about the Korean War, a conflict that has almost been forgotten in the decades of our national turmoil over Vietnam. Furthermore, it focuses on the soul-searching of an officer, Major Gaylord, as he wrestles with a life-and-death decision. In all the plays, novels or movies about Vietnam there has been little outpouring of sympathy for anyone in uniform above the rank of corporal. 
Thomas Bird, the founder of the Vietnam Veterans company and the director of this production, opens the short, stark evening with a brisk staged reading of passages from ''The Korean War: An Oral History - Pusan to Chosin'' by Donald Knox. It is an imaginative and effective device that provides a quick survey course on the Korean War and cleverly sets the scene for Serling's play.
A group of American G.I.'s recount in rapid, staccato bursts of speech the events of the last six months of 1950 as personal reminiscences - being shipped from the fleshpots of occupied Japan to wartime Korea, the retreat to Pusan, the landing at Inchon, the early successes against the North Koreans, only to be met at the Yalu River by the Chinese Army poised for an invasion of its own. There are references to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's promises that American soldiers would be home by Thanksgiving (a pledge quickly revised to being home for Christmas), and to Bob Hope performing for the troops in Pyongyang.
This gripping tale ends abruptly in a barrage of incoming artillery fire that, once the smoke clears, turns into a snowbound command post for a decimated American battalion. The Americans are in a ''fluid situation,'' which, as Major Gaylord explains, ''is what you call it when you're losing and don't want to admit it.''
Despite some familiar dramatic military terrain - a lost patrol, broken communications, wounded needing evacuation - ''The Strike'' is a well-crafted play that creates a taut dramatic situation with an economy of action, principally through characterization. That the tension in Serling's play is only partly realized in the Vietnam Veterans production is due mostly to a rather tentative, low-key performance by Tucker Smallwood in the pivotal role of Major Gaylord that only occasionally penetrates much below the surface. ''I wish someone with a star on his shoulder would tell me what's right and wrong,'' the Major says, but there is little sense that the decision presents much of an agonizing quandary. Mr. Smallwood is better in passages recalling his own days before command. The actor delivers a moving account of being ordered to shoot a soldier who refused to give a password only to learn the soldier sacrificed himself for his platoon.
Anthony Chisholm is especially good as Chaplain Walker, whose job of listening to battlefield confessions is like ''eavesdropping on death.'' Ray Robertson is credible as Captain Chick. Matt Tomasino as Lieutenant Peters and Jim Tracy as Captain Franks generate a sense of urgency about the lost patrol that occasionally flags elsewhere onstage. And Brian Markinson delivers a small gem of a performance as Richard Golden, a wounded soldier who can only say his name, address and hometown over and over and over as a plea for help.
George A. Allison's set is simple yet evocative, complete with a 48-star flag, an old hand generator and field phone, some empty ammo crates -all World War II surplus, which is what the G.I.'s in Korea had to fight with.
 
Oh! That War!
 
THE STRIKE, by Rod Serling; directed by Thomas Bird; set design, George A. Allison; costume design, Jim Buff; lighting design, Terry Wuthrich; sound design, Scott Sanders; production stage manager, Jerry Bihm. Presented by Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Company, Mr. Bird, artistic director. At the South Street Theater, 424 West 42d Street.

LENGTH: 1815 words

HEADLINE: Savings Unit Seeks 2d Chance

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
The Imperial Corporation of America, one of California's largest savings and loans companies, made a series of spectacular mistakes in the last few years, including betting heavily on speculative high-yield ''junk bonds,'' buying a portfolio of consumer loans that went sour and financing the importer of the ill-fated Yugo automobile.
But now, Imperial wants another chance. Lacking a permanent chief executive, its capital exhausted and its depositors nervous, the company is still trying to convince Federal regulators that it can recover and eventually meet the Government's tough new standards for the financial health of savings and loan associations.
''If I were the regulator, I would say that if the people at this institution have a good chance of working the problem out, let's let them have a fair chance to prove they can do it,'' said Lyman C. Hamilton Jr., who took over in January as interim chief executive of Imperial, the San Diego-based parent of Imperial Savings, which has 80 branches throughout California.
 
Route to Salvation
Like many other savings and loans, Imperial was devastated by its forays into investments far afield from mortgage-lending and deposit-taking. Now it has decided that its salvation lies in becoming a traditional savings institution, one that lives off the spread between what it pays for deposits and what it takes in as interest on loans. 
That survival plan, submitted to the Government to specify how the institution intends to reach the new standards, calls for cutting the institution's assets in half and generating earnings over the next several years from its remaining portfolio of home loans and mortgage securities. It is typical of the approaches being taken by the hundreds of other struggling institutions that are trying to stave off Government seizure.
But Imperial's plan also illustrates the immense, often insurmountable difficulties that face those savings and loan companies now trying to pull themselves out of the deep financial holes they dug through various combinations of mismanagement, fraud and bad economic luck.
And the optimistic business assumptions that buttress Imperial's plan suggest why the Government is unlikely to be very sympathetic as it resolves the fate of institutions scrambling to survive under the stricter new regulations, which force owners to put up more of their own money as a buffer against losses.
 
'Harder-Nosed Regulation'
''You have to be very skeptical of plans to earn your way out of a hole,'' said Bert Ely, an industry consultant in Alexandria, Va. ''Usually, what you find when you look closely at these plans is that a lot of things have to break just right. Now that we're in a new era of harder-nosed regulation, we are kidding ourselves less about how best to deal with these problems.''
Imperial is far from alone. There are almost 900 savings and loan institutions that do not meet the savings and loan bailout bill's new capital regulations. Like Imperial, they have been required to submit plans to the Government.
Many can bring themselves into compliance relatively easily in the next few years by shrinking in size and selling assets to raise money. But for Imperial and others, the task is much harder, if it is possible at all. Ultimately the Government expects to seize at least 200 marginally solvent or newly insolvent institutions, perhaps adding to the projected $160 billion cost of dealing with the savings and loan crisis.
In Imperial's case, the regulators have already suggested they are skeptical of a recovery. In early January, just one day after Imperial submitted its recapitalization plan to the primary Federal regulator, the Office of Thrift Supervision, the agency directed Imperial to not make any more loans or engage in any investment activities.
 
Possibly a Death Sentence
It was one of the harshest actions short of seizure taken by the agency since it began reviewing the undercapitalized institutions in the latter part of 1989, and many analysts perceived it to be a death sentence. By Imperial's own account, the regulatory action shattered the confidence of depositors, who quickly withdrew $100 million.
But Mr. Hamilton, the 63-year-old former chief executive of the ITT Corporation, contended in an interview that the company could be returned to health if the regulators give it a chance.
Mr. Hamilton has been a member of Imperial's board for seven years, and is heading the company until a permanent successor is found for Kenneth J. Thygerson, who resigned as chief executive under pressure last summer. Mr. Hamilton replaced Allan R. Tessler, another board member who was chief executive for seven months after Mr. Thygerson left.
''I met with the regulators and I tried to convey to them that our plan is real, it is implementable and that we are implementing it every day,'' Mr. Hamilton said.
 
Big Buyer of Junk Bonds
The roots of Imperial's troubles are in a decision by Mr. Thygerson several years ago to seek profits in businesses far from the usual activities of savings and loans. Under him, Imperial became one of the largest buyers of junk bonds in the industry.
The institution also sought to expand its loan portfolio rapidly and inexpensively by acquiring automobile-loan packages from a large Chevrolet dealership in Los Angeles. It sought out speculative financing opportunities, like making loans to Global Motors Inc., which imported the low-priced Yugo automobile from Yugoslavia.
All those moves proved to be disastrous. Global Motors did not sell many Yugos, and sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection not long after borrowing heavily from Imperial, which was forced to set aside $15.7 million for losses on the loans in 1988. The Chevrolet dealership also entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy under a cloud of fraud investigations, and many of its loans that Imperial had bought quickly went into default. Imperial has suffered losses of at least $38 million on the portfolio. $33 Million Loss Provision The junk-bond investments fared no better. The company was forced to take a $33 million loss provision last year on $40 million of the bonds issued by Integrated Resources Inc., the financially ailing investment concern. Then, under the provisions of the savings-and-loan bailout bill signed by President Bush in August, Imperial, like all other savings institutions with junk bonds, had to start carrying the bonds on its books at the lower of market value or face value.
Because the bond market has fallen sharply in recent months, Imperial has had to reduce the bonds' value by $200 million, to $830 million, wiping out what capital it had left after the loan losses.
Imperial is expected to post a large loss for the fourth quarter and for the year.
Mr. Hamilton acknowledges that the institution made big mistakes, particularly in failing to spot the poor credit quality of the automobile loans it bought. But he said that the remaining core of the institution is profitable and can be brought up to the new capital standards by the final deadline of 1994 if its asset size, loan portfolio and expenses are carefully handled.
Mr. Hamilton said Imperial planned to shrink to about $5.9 billion in assets in five years from its current level of about $10 billion. The institution has already shrunk from $12.3 billion in the middle of last year, and plans to decline in size to $8.2 billion by the end of this year by selling loans and other assets.
 
Less Money Would Be Needed
By reducing its size, the institution will need to raise less money to comply with Federal regulations, because capital requirements are measured as a ratio of asset size.
Mr. Hamilton said Imperial can generate and retain earnings of $300 million over five years, enough to raise its most basic level of capital to about 5 percent of its asset size, or well above the 3 percent required by the new regulations.
Most of the money would come from keeping the earnings it expects to make on its home-loan portfolio. But about $75 million of the after-tax profits would come from a series of real estate projects that the company is completing and plans to sell in the next few years. And the company will have to go to Wall Street to raise $75 million in several years to meet a secondary test of capital strength.
Mr. Hamilton said Imperial would help its cause by slashing operating expenses as it shrinks. Expenses this year are budgeted at $154 million, down from $200 million last year. And he said the company planned to make sure it was fully covered for any further losses from its loan portfolio, by adding to its reserves in its financial results for the last three months of 1989.
 
'Still a Good Earning Engine'
''We're going to look like the most traditional of traditional thrifts,'' Mr. Hamilton said. ''This is still a good earning engine.''
But the plan includes several assumptions that regulators are certain to question. For example, Imperial assumes that junk-bond prices will not decline further, something that many analysts doubt will happen if the economy sinks into a recession.
It also assumes that the company can sell huge quantities of other assets without suffering substantial losses, a task that would be especially tricky if interest rates go higher, making the institution's mortgage-backed securities and other rate-sensitive holdings less valuable.
Analysts also wonder whether the company can count on hefty profits from its real estate developments in California at a time when home prices have begun to soften and some experts think the market could fall sharply.
Moreover, the company will have to survive for some time without a chief executive who has experience in the savings and loan business. Mr. Hamilton, who admits that he is just starting to learn all the details of Imperial's situation, acknowledged that it is impossible to hire a permanent replacement while the threat of seizure hangs over the institution.
 
Hard Case to Make
In the meantime, regulators are being asked to entrust the direction of the company to members of a board that approved the failed strategies.
''It's a very hard case for Imperial to make,'' said Mr. Ely, the industry consultant.
But perhaps the biggest obstacle facing Imperial's plea for a second chance is the political pressure on regulators to act swiftly and decisively to deal with troubled institutions before their problems get worse and the costs of the cleanup increase.
With regulators still smarting from criticism that they allowed institutions like the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association to remain in business for too long, even Mr. Hamilton knows there is little incentive for Federal officials to take a chance on Imperial and institutions like it.
''There's no upside for anybody who makes the tough decision to give us a chance,'' Mr. Hamilton said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Slow Pace For Reform In East Bloc

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The rush toward political reform has swept through the nations of Eastern Europe with startling speed. But their attempt to move from the central planning of Communism toward free markets promises to be a much slower, more difficult and socially divisive transition.
Opening political life in Eastern Europe to several parties and to stronger parliaments is one thing. Allowing prices to surge, workers to be laid off and other consequences of a market economy is a far more touchy matter, Eastern European government officials and economists acknowledge.
Even here in Poland, Eastern Europe's leader in the move to market economics, there is a recognition that the policy changes may already be running ahead of public attitudes and that a state-controlled system in place for four decades will not be quickly dismantled. 
''Poland has almost entered capitalism, but mentally we are still in socialism,'' said Andrzej Wroblewski, editor of Gazeta Bankowa, Poland's leading economic newspaper. ''People still believe that there should always be someone to protect them, that there should be a cushion between them and hard ground.''
 
Consensus Is Emerging
Despite the obstacles and prospect of public resistance, a striking measure of consensus is emerging among officials and economists in Eastern Europe about the strategies necessary to move these societies from their current economic stagnation to a more prosperous future.
More than two dozen East European officials and economists interviewed were virtually in agreement on which basic steps were needed. All Eastern European nations should follow the steps being taken by Poland, they said, though perhaps at a different order and pace. The measures include abolishing most price controls, slashing subsidies to consumers and industry, giving enterprises autonomy, ending monopolies, permitting layoffs, accepting bankruptcies and moving toward a convertible currency.
''There is a basic minimum package of steps that must be taken,'' said Vladimir Dlouhy, an economist who was named Deputy Prime Minister in Czechoslovakia.
The aim of these reforms would be to scrap the ossified system of central planning that provided little incentive for initiative. A market-oriented system would in theory reward - and encourage - initiative and hard work.
For all the talk of free markets and capitalism, the vision of a better future in several Eastern European nations often appears to bear more resemblance to Swedish-style social democracy, with its generous welfare benefits, than to the more free-market brand of capitalism practiced in the United States.
''If you want to have a Scandinavian-type economy, first you need an economy in good working order to be able to underwrite all those social programs,'' said Aleksander Paszynski, Poland's Minister of Construction and Housing.
 
Years to Complete
There is also general agreement that transforming a centrally planned economy into a market-oriented one will be a bumpy and often painful process. It could take years, even decades, to complete.
The structural obstacles to reform could scarcely be overstated. Perhaps most daunting is the sheer weight of state control in the Eastern European economies and the impossibility of tilting the balance quickly toward private enterprise. In East Germany, for instance, less than 4 percent of the work force is employed in the private sector and less than 1 percent of industry is privately owned. Throughout Eastern Europe, the state typically owns more than 95 percent of industry.
Eastern European officials emphasized that the speed and specifics of each nation's reform must be tailored to domestic needs. Differences in the standard of living, inflation rate, debt burden and political climate will mean differences in the economic strategies each nation adopts.
East Germany, with its low inflation and relative prosperity compared with other Eastern European nations, can make its transition slowly and look to West Germany for special guidance and assistance. In Poland, by contrast, Government officials concluded that a painful crash program was needed to tackle its 500 percent inflation rate and revive its prostrate economy.
''I don't believe that any country can copy another country's process, because they start from different initial conditions,'' said Janos Kornai, a leading Hungarian economist who teaches at Harvard University. ''At the same time, these countries have much in common and can learn from each other's experience.''
 
Differences on Goals
The nations of Eastern Europe also take a different approach about what their ultimate destination should be. Poland seems to be moving most forcefully toward capitalism, while Czechoslovakia seems intent on maintaining generous social protection and Government involvement in industry.
While Eastern European nations must take these market-oriented steps themselves, officials from those nations agree that they need Western investment and technology. Encouraging foreign joint ventures is viewed as essential.
''We need foreign investment like we need oxygen,'' said Mr. Paszynski, the Polish construction minister.
Government officials and economists interviewed said the basic steps needed to build a market economy include:
* Lifting price controls. Price controls should be removed on tradeable goods like bread, gasoline and steel. This will help create an accurate pricing system, which is essential to discerning which enterprises are profitable and which are not and will help industry discover what consumers want. Allowing companies to charge what they want will also give them incentives to expand.
''For an enterprise to produce effectively, it must be free to make decisions on prices,'' said Heinrich Machowski, an economist with the Institute for Economic Research in Berlin. ''In order to be able to measure your costs properly, you have to have market prices.''
* Slashing subsidies. Large subsidies to consumers are seen as distortions in the pricing system, while subsidies to industry keep inefficient industries in business. Subsidies can also be a huge drain on public coffers, so much so that subsidies accounted for more than 30 percent of Poland's budget last year.
* Giving enterprises autonomy. Economists say managers must be given operating independence as well as orders or incentives to make a profit. This will force them to become more efficient, which will benefit the whole economy.
''It's not important who is the owner,'' said Paul Zieber, who has founded one of the first economic consulting firms in East Germany.''The presidents of many American companies are not owners. What's important is to structure things so that managers work like owners.''
* Ending monopolies. Many Eastern European officials had an unhappy surprise when they began to end central planning and gave enterprises independence, only to see these companies raise prices substantially. There was little to prevent them from price-gouging; in many industries there was just one company.
Eastern European officials are talking about breaking up steel-making or slaughterhouse monopolies, and eliminating the red tape that makes it hard for new companies to enter an industry.
* Creating a convertible currency. Restoring faith in a country's currency increases incentives to work and reduces inflationary expectations. Without a convertible currency, foreign trade is more difficult and often is tied to cumbersome barter and bilateral agreements.
* Allowing enterprises to lay off workers. In many Communist countries, layoffs were all but forbidden, which allowed many companies to become bloated. Economists say it is important to permit layoffs to help companies reduce costs and increase efficiency.
* Permitting bankruptcies. Since bankruptcies were more or less taboo in Eastern Europe, many managers and workers felt little incentive to be efficient because they knew their enterprises would never be allowed to fail.
* Creating a sound banking system. Eastern European banks have long done little more than funnel subsidies to inefficient enterprises. Government officials say a solid banking system is needed as a disciplining force that steers investment to efficient companies and promising start-ups.
There are many lesser reforms that are deemed desirable. For example, many economists say Eastern Europe's accounting system must be changed to enable enterprises to have a true measure of their profitability, costs and efficiency. Stock markets can be created to help raise capital for privatized companies.
