HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Exporters Shrug At Dollar's Drop

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE dollar just might be on the verge of a big drop in value. It is already off 15 percent against the West German mark since mid-September, and Japan is taking steps to strengthen the yen and weaken the dollar. That should be wonderful news for the nation's exporters, the main beneficiaries of a cheaper dollar, but surprisingly, many greet the prospect with a shrug.
Both the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers reflect this lack of enthusiasm. They are deeply engaged in lobbying hard for a number of causes dear to the hearts of thousands of members, but getting the dollar down in value isn't one of them. ''How do you weigh in on this when there isn't a hue and cry?'' asks William T. Archey, a Chamber vice president. 
Talking to executives reveals the reasons for the lack of enthusiasm. Most do believe that a cheaper dollar - say one worth 120 yen and 1.60 marks instead of 144 yen and 1.69 marks - would help to increase sales abroad. Don V. Fites, who was recently promoted to chairman and chief executive of Caterpillar Inc., even bangs his fist on the table, demanding a cheaper dollar. But others focus on different issues.
Some executives believe that the key to successful exporting is a product's quality and its uniqueness. The Industrial Brush Company of Pomona, Calif., for example, has developed a brush made of abrasive nylon that removes impurities from computer circuit boards. No foreign company makes anything quite like this brush - yet - and it is a big seller in Asia, says John Cottam, Industrial's president. About $1 million of the company's $11 million in annual sales come from exports.
''People are willing to pay a premium for these brushes so we were able to offset the rise in the value of the dollar last year,'' Mr. Cottam said. He acknowledges that if the dollar falls in value by, say, 15 percent, then brush exports would probably go up $100,000. After such a drop, a brush that costs $1 (144 yen) to make in Pomona would still cost $1 to make there, but the yen equivalent of that dollar would decline to 122. A lower manufacturing cost, in yen, will allow Mr. Cottam to sell the brush in Japan for fewer yen, without sacrificing profit.
But if a lower price might increase sales by $100,000, the assignment of more sales representatives abroad would jump sales by a much greater amount, in Mr. Cottam's view. ''It is hard to sort out which is more important, a good sales network or a weak dollar,'' he said.
Some companies do not get excited about the dollar's fluctuating value because they are largely immune to it. The Boeing Company is in this category, and its overseas sales of commercial airliners alone account for $1 billion of the nation's $31 billion in monthly exports. Boeing bills foreign customers in dollars, not their currencies. And all Boeing's costs are in dollars, even payment for the many parts purchased abroad. Boeing forces a German supplier, for instance, to absorb the exchange loss, when a falling American currency makes each dollar collected from Boeing worth perhaps 1.60 marks instead of 1.69.
Then there are companies that avoid the issue by putting factories abroad to supply foreign markets, thus shifting most costs out of dollars. And others who might favor a cheaper dollar for exports, worry about the negative side: a weak dollar encourages foreign competitors to put factories in the United States. When the dollar declines, the same yen or mark buys more dollars to invest.
Against this ambivalence, Mr. Fites sounds particularly annoyed. Caterpillar bulldozers and earthmovers made in Peoria, Ill., compete head to head against essentially similar Kamatsu or Hitachi equipment made in Japan. These huge machines list for $500,000 a shot, and everyone is cutting prices to win sales around the world.
Caterpillar's discounts, however, have cut into the corporation's profits, Mr. Fites said. The Japanese, on the other hand, have been saved from this anguish because of the dollar's appreciation since 1988. It has gone from 120 yen to 144 yen, which means the Japanese could cut their prices in dollars by 20 percent and still collect the same number of yen. ''If the yen-dollar relationship stays where it is, wait and see what happens to our trade deficit in six months,'' Mr. Fites said. ''It will go back up again.''
He is probably overstating the case. Even without rising exports, a weak American economy could reduce the demand for imports, and as imports declined, so would the trade deficit. But Mr. Fites's point is essentially correct. Commerce Department data show clearly that exports begin to rise two years after the dollar begins to lose value. And this response is usually produced only if the decline is 15 percent or more, said Howard Murad, who is in charge of collecting trade data at the Commerce Department.
Product quality, salesmanship and other factors play important roles in exporting, of course. But in Mr. Murad's view - one shared by a number of economists - a significant decline in the dollar, achieved over a period of months, also gets results.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Caterpillar to Promote President to Chairman

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the largest maker of earth-moving machinery, has named Donald V. Fites as its chairman and chief executive, effective July 1. It also reorganized the executive suite, eliminating the posts of president and executive vice president, in a move to push decision-making further down the ranks.
Mr. Fites, 56 years old, has been Caterpillar's president since June. He will succeed George A. Schaefer, 62, who is retiring after leading the company since 1985. 
Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., also named James W. Wogsland, 58, executive vice president, to the new post of vice chairman.
Caterpillar took some strong blows in the last decade as its competition in the heavy-equipment industry intensified with the entry of large Japanese and other foreign players while demand for the equipment fell.
Earlier this month, Caterpillar reported net income for last year of $497 million, or $4.90 a share, down from $616 million, or $6.07 a share, in 1988. Sales last year rose to $10.88 billion from $10.26 billion in 1988. A November report on Caterpillar by Standard & Poor's predicted that both sales and earnings would be lower this year.
The company said its management reorganization was intended to move accountability and decision-making downward. The new setup will include 18 vice presidents, 14 of whom will head profit centers.
''Profit centers will be expected to do exactly what the name says -produce a profit - and they'll have the authority to make it happen,'' Mr. Schaefer said in a statement.
As part of the reorganization, the three current executive vice presidents - Glen A. Barton, Gerald S. Flaherty and Pierre C. Guerindon -will become group presidents and the executive office will be reduced to five officers from six.
''Currently, we're organized mostly on a functional basis,'' Mr. Fites said in the statement. ''The new organization is a profit-driven product/geographic matrix. We believe the title 'group president' will help underline the basic autonomy of profit centers.''
Mr. Fites joined Caterpillar in 1956 after graduation from Valparaiso University with a civil engineering degree. He received a master's degree in management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and is a former Sloan Fellow. He has worked for Caterpillar in South Africa, Switzerland, West Germany, Japan and Brazil.
In 1981 he was named a vice president with responsibility for economics, pricing and scheduling, product control and product source planning. He became an executive vice president in 1983.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yields Expected to Climb Further

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Many credit market analysts say the gloom in the bond markets, prompted by an unexpectedly large increase in long-term interest rates, is not likely to evaporate quickly. As a result, yields could rise further, they said.
The prospect for a further rise was heightened late last week, when the yield on the 8 1/8 percent Treasury bonds of 2019 broke through the high end of an 8 1/2 percent-to-7 7/8 percent trading range it had occupied for seven months. Hammered all last week, by late on Friday the bellwether issue was quoted at a price to yield 8.51 percent. 
''With yields outside the familiar trading range, establishing a new level for the the 30-year bond may prove to be difficult,'' said Susan M. Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''With a major jolt of new supply looming, the bond could break away to 8.75 percent before a new ceiling is established.''
 
'Shell Shocked'
Paul L. Kasriel, a vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company, said: ''Everyone is basically shell shocked. The dealer community is not going to fight this. I intend to wait and let somebody else be the first guy who buys the long bond. And I think a lot of other people feel that way.''
The sight of the coming flood of new issues has hung like a cloud over the market since early January. But it will be another week before the market participants will be forced to cope with the fresh supply.
The magnitude of the task will be clearer on Wednesday, when the Treasury is expected to announce the size of the quarterly refunding auctions to be held the week of Feb. 5.
Most analysts say they expect that the Treasury will sell a total of $30 billion in 3-year and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.
Anxiety about the refunding auctions continues to center on the Japanese, and whether their appetite for the issues will be as strong as in the past. At times, Japanese investors bought as much as 40 percent of a new bond offering.
Doubts about the Japanese have been heightened as yields on fixed-income securities in West Germany and Japan have risen to levels that make them increasingly competitive with those in the United States.
 
Japan Rates Eased
Japanese interest rates eased somewhat last week, and further declines before the refunding could halt the price slide in Treasury issues, some of the analysts said.
Still, Mr. Kasriel suggested, a diminished Japanese presence at Treasury auctions could become a fact of life in the 1990's, even if interest rates in the United States are more attractive than those in Japan or elsewhere.
''The Japanese trade surplus is getting smaller, which means the rate of growth in funds to invest abroad is shrinking,'' he said. ''In addition, they have discovered alternative investments in this country. They are diversifying within the United States as well as globally.''
Worries about the refunding, as well as a sharp, weather-induced upward blip in inflation for the present, appear to have obliterated evidence that the economy is soft, and that it is likely to remain that way for some time.
Anthony J. Vignola, managing director in fixed-income research at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said that in some respects the current environment was the opposite of what happened in the summer and fall of 1988.
''Back then, bond yields fell on the perception of a slowing in the economy,'' he said.
''It took until the end of November to show that growth was not below trend. Now, the economy is weaker than it appears, and bond yields are rising,'' Mr. Vignola said. ''Sometime in mid-February or early March, I would expect the inflation numbers to start trending lower, and for the market to start reverting to an environment of continued slowing.''
 
Outlook on Growth
Moreover, the recent rise in rates is likely to further blunt growth in the second quarter.
''Whatever your forecast for second-quarter growth was, it has to be lower now because of the run-up in rates,'' said Donald J. Fine, the chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
But for the time being, the market is likely to remain extremely nervous.
An example of how edgy participants in the markets have become was provided on Friday, when Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it had downgraded certain securities of RJR Nabisco Inc.
The Moody's downgrade, to B-3, from B-2, covered about $7 billion in senior convertible debentures and payment-in-kind securities. The agency cited uncertain prospects for the domestic tobacco industry in downgrading the securities.
At the same time, however, the Standard & Poor's Corporation reaffirmed its ratings on the company, and suggested that slightly stronger cash flow than anticipated could lead to a ratings upgrade in the future.
The traders chose to focus on the Moody's report, and bids on RJR issues tumbled, some by as much as 10 points.
The price move amazed many participants in the market for high-yield ''junk bonds.''
''I have a hard time believing that a bond could be down 10 points on a ratings downtick,'' said Mark Vaselkiv, a vice president at the T. Rowe Price High Yield Fund. ''It just shows how nervous this market is.''
Robert Long, the director of high-yield research at the First Boston Corporation, said that ''cash flow is better than expected, and all of the company's asset sales have been accomplished at close to projected levels.
''Next month, RJR will pay down $5.5 billion worth of debt with proceeds from those sales,'' he said. ''The bottom line is that it is a very strong credit in the market.''
 
Doubts Linger on Pricing
Still, the development casts doubt on when a $1.25 billion offering of senior RJR notes will be priced.
The issue, which Standard & Poor's has rated BB, had been expected to be offered to investors in February. But now, it may have to be delayed, the market participants said. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the lead manager for the underwriting, would not comment on its plans.
''Before this happened, I would have said that the RJR deal would have been a pretty do-able issue,'' said Frank V. Colombo, the director of high-yield research at Dillon, Read & Company.
''There is still an appetite out there for RJR, and these securities will be senior to all of the rest of the company's paper. But due to this shock, it draws into question how well the deal will go.''
Almost certainly, Mr. Colombo and others said, the market will demand a much higher coupon on the new securities than it would have before the Moody's downgrade and the subsequent steep slide in RJR prices.
Before Friday, price talk on the 10-year securities had placed a coupon on the notes of 11 3/8 percent.
''At the right price, I would load up my truck with that bond,'' Mr. Vaselkiv of T. Rowe Price said. ''But 11 3/8 percent just won't fly now.''

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1170 words

HEADLINE: The 1991 Budget: Reaction;
Democrats Shun Budget Theories Bush Embraces

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Democrats greeted President Bush's $1.23 trillion budget today with strong skepticism about its central thesis that growth in the nation's economy will eliminate the budget deficit without the need for new taxes.
Democrats also clashed with Mr. Bush over his emphasis on cutting social programs. Some lawmakers said the Bush budget for the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, did not make the sweeping reductions in military spending they believe are warranted by the declining Soviet military threat.
Congressional Democrats ignored the criticism of their previous fiscal management in an introductory essay by Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget. Still, they sought to fling Mr. Darman's impassioned prose and far-reaching analysis of budget problems back at him by saying his introduction made promises on which the actual budget did not deliver. 
''It's like the doctor who tells his patient that he's suffering from terminal cancer and tells him, 'Take two aspirin and call me in the morning,' '' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who serves as chairman of the House Budget Committee.
Democratic leaders in Congress and some private budget analysts also criticized the guiding principle in Mr. Bush's budget: that the nation can overcome the budget deficit through economic growth and cuts in social programs without making tough decisions to impose deep cuts in military spending, raise taxes or reduce retirement benefits.
Mr. Bush's budget offered no sweeping new social agenda. Instead, Mr. Bush relied heavily on tinkering with Ronald Reagan's legacy. Mr. Bush offered modest adjustments to a broad range of social programs to reduce spending. He also proposed new or increased fees and improvements in the collection of the income tax as the principal methods of cutting the budget deficit.
 
'Charmin' Darman'
Mr. Darman, who has been trying to mend his relations with Congress after the acrimonious debates last year over the Bush Administration's failed effort to cut the capital gains tax, shrugged off his problems with sardonic humor.
''I'm going to try to be 'charmin' Darman' again and this year go for holding on to that approach for more than six months,'' he said at a news conference shortly after the budget was released. ''I don't know if that will be sufficient, but it seems to be a precondition.''
As for chastising Congress in the introduction to the budget request, Mr. Darman said he did not think it ''should be viewed as in any way confrontational or contentious, compared with the normal standard I have set.''
 
Set of Stage Directions
As required by law, Mr. Bush's budget offers a way to reduce the Federal deficit by $36.5 billion, to $63.1 billion. But like all Presidential budgets, this one is primarily a political document that serves as a set of stage directions for the debate in Congress, rather than a final judgment on how every Government dollar will be spent.
Reflecting that dynamic, some Congressional Democrats had qualified praise for the intellectual force of Mr. Darman's essay, while disagreeing with many of its points. ''I admire his way of putting things,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who is on the House Budget Committee.
Sarcastically referring to Mr. Darman's essay as ''interesting and informative,'' the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, said: ''It was the ultimate example of the old saying, 'Do as I say, not as I do.' I know of no person more responsible for budget practices spanning the past decade in two Administrations than Mr. Darman.'' Mr. Darman was deputy chief of staff and later Deputy Secretary of the Treasury under Mr. Reagan.
 
Cut in Military Spending
In his request for the 1991 fiscal year, Mr. Bush offered the first proposal by the White House for a reduction in Pentagon spending, after accounting for inflation, since the military buildup began in 1981 under President Reagan.
But he balanced that with cuts in social programs, including a $5.4 billion reduction in Medicare benefits and a 25 percent cut in money to help low-income families pay their energy bills.
And Congressional Democrats said the 2 percent cut in military spending after inflation, which would produce Pentagon spending of $292.1 billion in 1991, was not nearly enough. Many pointed out that the actual amount of money Mr. Bush wants to spend on the Pentagon would increase by about $5.4 billion over the current year.
Their reaction reflected a growing desire to use the relaxation of East-West tensions to cut military money and create a ''peace dividend'' that could be used to avoid big cuts in social programs.
Mr. Bush's military budget, said Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, ''is a Rip Van Winkle budget that has not yet awakened to the changes in the world or the major challenges at home.''
 
Criticism of Domestic Cuts
As expected, much Congressional fire was directed at Mr. Bush's proposed cuts in domestic programs and his heavy reliance on economic forecasts, which many Democrats and private economists described as overly optimistic.
Mr. Bush's budget included detailed economic forecasts through 1995, a significant departure from past practice. But they were presented with a take-it-or-leave-it defiance; the Administration declared that its forecasts, and the health of the economy, were predicated on Mr. Bush's budget being approved intact.
''I don't think any President expects his budget to be adopted as a whole,'' Mr. Mitchell said. He and others noted that some reductions Mr. Bush proposed had repeatedly been rejected by Congress. These included the Medicare cut, about half of which would be reductions in subsidies to hospitals and for doctors' education, and elimination of cost-of-living pay increases for Federal employees.
Mr. Bush is likely to have an easier time this year in passing a proposed reduction in the tax on profits from investments, or capital gains, which died in Congress last year. But it was clear today that Democrats were ready to take political advantage from the debate over the proposed cut, as well as Mr. Bush's opposition to a reduction in Social Security taxes proposed by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.
Mr. Bush proposed instead that the $65 billion Social Security trust fund surplus, which the Moynihan plan would eliminate, be used to help reduce the national deficit starting in 1993.
''At a time when President Bush wants to cut the capital gains tax for the wealthy and maintain punishingly high Social Security taxes on everyone else, I question whether his priorities are right for the times,'' said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
There was also some criticism of the budget from Republicans. Representative Bill Green, Republican of Manhattan, said the budget proposal is ''gentler than were Reagan's, but not as kind as Congress will want.''

HEADLINE: The 1991 Budget: Armed Forces;
CHENEY WOULD CUT DIVISIONS IN ARMY BUT MAINTAIN B-2

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney outlined his long-term plans for reshaping the military today, proposing the elimination of five of the Army's 28 active-duty and reserve divisions and making new investments in costly long-range nuclear programs through the mid-1990's.
As a first step, Mr. Cheney said the Pentagon would cut two of the Army's 18 active divisions in the 1991 fiscal year while holding the Navy roughly constant and continuing spending on the B-2 bomber.
The Secretary said major long-term changes in the military would depend on completion of agreements with the Soviet Union to cut conventional forces in Europe and to make deep reductions in long-range nuclear forces.
 
Pentagon News Conference
Mr. Cheney discussed his vision of the military at a Pentagon news conference at which the Defense Department proposed a military programs bill of $295 billion for the fiscal year 1991, a 2.6 percent decline in the department's purchasing power taking inflation into account. 
While information about the Pentagon's budget for the fiscal year 1991 has seeped out over the past few weeks and Pentagon officials have described a number of potential approaches to cutting spending through the mid-1990's, Mr. Cheney had not previously talked in detail about how he would reshape the military in light of a diminishing Soviet threat and changes in Eastern Europe.
He made clear today that he has approved plans to trim projected increases in Pentagon spending by as much as $167 billion from 1990 through 1994, a cut that would be somewhat smaller than the cuts identified last November by the armed services. Mr. Cheney asked the services then to draw up plans for cutting projected spending by $180 billion from 1992 to 1994.
 
A Political Strategy
Mr. Cheney's plans and other budget-cutting steps outlined by the Pentagon in recent weeks constitute both a program to reshape the military and a political strategy for dealing with Congress, which is eager to impose its own visions and spending plans. The Defense Secretary, in effect, has given Congress a detailed plan and challenged it to accept his approach or come up with its own formula for making the hard decisions about how to trim the military budget.
Liberal Democrats in Congress complained that Mr. Cheney had failed to cancel some expensive weapons programs and that the reductions proposed in the Pentagon budget cuts did not go far enough.
The military budget is ''very disappointing,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California.
But Republicans like Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking minority member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, cautioned against making sweeping changes in American military planning during a period of tumultuous political change in Europe.
 
Army Gets Biggest Cuts
In discussing his plans for reshaping the military, Mr. Cheney said he had resisted some possible cuts over the next year, including retiring some aircraft carriers. But he did not exclude that possibility in the future. He imposed the biggest budget cuts on the Army, whose mission of defending Western Europe has been brought into question by political changes in Eastern Europe and the withdrawal of some Soviet forces there.
Under Mr. Cheney's plan, the number of Army and Air Force personnel would be reduced in 1991 to its lowest level in 40 years, a cut that includes the elimination of two active Army divisions, the Second Armored Division at Fort Hood, Tex., and the Ninth Infantry Division at Fort Lewis, Wash.
Mr. Cheney said three additional divisions, one active and two reserve, would be eliminated in the future if the Soviet conventional threat continues to recede. The Pentagon projects reducing active Army strength in five years by 135,000 soldiers, about 18 percent from its current strength of 764,000.
Other reductions that Mr. Cheney said could be made pending completion of arms control efforts includes cutting Air Force tactical fighter wings from 36 to 31, reconsidering plans to build Trident submarines and other ships, and further cuts in the National Guard and the Reserves.
Mr. Cheney also made public a list of 35 domestic and 13 overseas bases that the Defense Department is considering closing, a move that is expected to touch off a political uproar on Capitol Hill.
Mr. Cheney's stress on preserving a long-range nuclear program is also likely to be the focus of debate in Congress. Many lawmakers have challenged the Pentagon's plan to build Stealth bombers, which cost more than $500 million each, and to increase money for the ''Star Wars'' missile defense system by $900 million when Moscow and Washington are moving to conclude a treaty cutting long-range arms.
At the news conference, the Secretary said the threat posed by Soviet nuclear forces had not diminished substantially. Referring to Moscow's long-range nuclear forces, he said, ''What we don't see is any reduction with respect to their strategic capability.''
While the Pentagon's purchasing power has declined steadily since 1985, Mr. Cheney said the 1991 military budget was the first time in recent years the Pentagon has proposed a cut in spending after allowing for inflation.
The Pentagon's long-term spending plan would leave the military with 22 percent less purchasing power in 1995 than it had in 1985, the height of the Reagan Administration's military buildup. Under the plan, military spending would represent 4 percent of the nation's gross national product in 1995.
The Pentagon budget for the fiscal year 1991 would cut 38,000 people from the armed services. The reduction would leave the military with 2,038,800 personnel, a force roughly equal to the size of the military in 1980. The Army and the Air Force would bear the brunt of the cuts; by the end of 1991, those two services would be at their lowest active force levels since 1950.
Under the 1991 budget, the Navy would eliminate two of its four battleships, including the Iowa, which lost 47 sailors last April when a gun turret exploded in a naval exercise. But the total number of ships would remain roughly constant at 546.
The Marine Corps, which emerged relatively unscathed, would begin planning to deactivate 14 artillery batteries. The Air Force would deactivate 14 of its 157 conventionally armed B-52 bombers and end production of its F-15E fighter plane.

HEADLINE: Soyapango Journal;
Why the Sand Diggers Don't Protest Anymore

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOYAPANGO, El Salvador, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Under the fiery sun on the bed of Las Canas River, sweat flows more freely than water. Here sand, not coffee, is king.
A roaring current carving a chasm through ash-skirted volcanos in the rainy season, Las Canas River is little more than a steamy trickle of diluted sewage from October to May.
That is a small blessing for legions of Salvadorans who earn their living excavating the riverbed's sand, which is used to make cement. It is backbreaking work. The heat and water-logged loads turn 35-year-olds into stooped, sun-wizened workers. 
But two years ago, an entrepreneur, Jose Rene Mendoza, undertook an ambitious plan to make himself the master of the Canas riverbed. His effort to corner the sand supply touched off a cycle of protest and violence involving three killings that offers a glimpse of the social and political melange behind the civil war.
 
A Matter of Survival
In most countries, the dispute would have been a civil case over property rights, the killings a common crime. But in this overpopulated country, survival often depends on land, and the line between civil and political crimes often blurs.
If the killings demonstrate the country's class divisions, the failure to prosecute the killers demonstrates why many Salvadorans believe that it is useless to try to change this stratified society through nonviolent efforts. As much as anything else, it is that feeling of futility that sustains the leftist rebels and drives the decade-old conflict.
That is an important lesson for United States policy makers, who are considering whether to renew aid to this country. Congress's attention has focused on high-profile human rights cases like the killing of six Jesuit priests in November. But it is the experiences of common Salvadorans, like the sand diggers, that will determine the success of American-financed effort to end the war by opening this rigid, class-conscious society.
Many of the sand diggers, who live in slums along the river's shores, are victims of the civil war, driven off their tiny plots around the country by the fighting. They are among the poorest of the poor. Few receive any of the $1.5 million a day in United States aid that sustains this all but bankrupt country. $6 on a Good Day The strong boast they can load four trucks in 10 hours, earning $6 on a good day, the same wage they received a decade ago, but their wives and children, who usually work alongside them, rarely complete more than two. After a decade of inflation, in which prices have quintupled, that is barely enough to survive.
''Every day it gets harder to get by,'' said 35-year-old Maria Candelaria, who has dug sand here for eight years.
Before the sand-digging season began two years ago, Mr. Mendoza expropriated a large part of the riverbed where she and about 350 others had worked. He put up barbed-wire fences and brought in armed guards and bulldozers. But the sand diggers said the land was public domain and began organizing with the help of a union, a member of a leftist labor coalition linked with the guerrillas.
A short time later, three soldiers came to the mud-walled home of 25-year-old Jose Arnoldo Cerritos. They bound his wrists. While one soldier stayed at the small house to guard his 19-year-old wife, two soldiers took him and her 56-year-old uncle, Vicente Cerritos Torres, human rights monitors say.
That same night, April 14, 1988, Arturo Navarro Garcia and his helper, Manuel de Jesus Lopez Ramos, were intercepted by two armed men in uniform as they returned from working on the river bottom, the rights monitors say. The soldiers made them lie face down on the ground and, after asking for Mr. Navarro by name, took him away.
 
Bodies Are Found
The bodies of the three men, who had attended meetings to organize a sand diggers' local, were found two days later in a ravine. All three had been shot in the head.
In his weekly homily, Gregorio Rosa Chavez, the Auxiliary Archbishop of nearby San Salvador, denounced the killings and blamed the air force. Residents who witnessed the three men's abduction say that an air force patrol had been in the area hours before the killings.
A court case was started. But two years later it has been forgotten as attention has passed to more recent human rights abuses. A spokesman for Tutela Legal, the Roman Catholic Church's legal affairs office, dismissed the likelihood of further progress in the case.
''We found the bodies,'' the spokesman said. The response illustrated how it is often impossible here to do more than identify the bodies of victims of rights abuses.
The rain-fed torrents long ago ripped out Mr. Mendoza's barbed-wire fence. But the sand diggers remain scared. They make sure to stay clear of the river bottom claimed by Mr. Mendoza.
Competition to dig and sell the sand is fiercer than ever. In the last two years, the number of sand diggers has climbed from 800 to 1,000, the workers estimated. But although double-digit inflation keeps eroding their earnings, they no longer even consider forming a union.
''It was a whim,'' one worker said. ''We need to organize, but look what happened last time.''

HEADLINE: Officials Chided in Virginia On Labor Day Racial Strife

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., Jan. 29

 BODY:
A special commission studying the racially tinged violence that shook this resort over the Labor Day holiday sharply faulted city officials today, asserting that they had failed to plan properly for the weekend and had failed to communicate adequately with blacks.
''There was an absence of leadership; there were failures of communication,'' the 17-member biracial commission said in a report submitted this afternoon to the City Council.
The commission stated unequivocally that ''no amount of rationalization'' could excuse the rioting and looting that occurred here for two nights in a final summer fling by thousands of black students from college fraternities and sororities all over the East Coast.
The commission also criticized leaders of black organizations, local as well as those representing student groups from elsewhere, for failing to stay in communication with city officials. 
 
'Unfortunate Combination'
But the ''magnitude of the 1989 problems,'' the commission said in its report, resulted not so much from ''the unlawful actions of a small percentage of the crowd'' as from ''an unfortunate combination of a lack of leadership, inadequate planning, poor preparation, failure of communication'' on the part of city officials.
The commission recommended that city officials begin planning immediately for next Labor Day, saying it was all but inevitable that ''black students will return to the city in large numbers.''
For next Labor Day, the commission suggested, the city should begin by analyzing race relations in this predominantly white resort and should consider establishing a permanent panel to monitor black-white tensions.
The commission also suggested that for future Labor Day weekends the city bring in promoters to stage events rather than leave visitors to find entertainment for themselves.
 
Message to the Police
Further, the commission said the predominantly white police force should be briefed on the concerns and sensitivities of young blacks. It said that more black officers should be visible on the streets for Labor Day weekends.
If city officials do not develop better plans and communication avenues for the 1990 Labor Day weekend, the commissioned warned, Virginia Beach could suffer further damage to its economy, already struggling from beach-front decay before the 1989 disturbances.
Further, the commission said, ''A repeat of Labor Day 1989 would, without doubt, strike a major blow to race relations in the city, the region and the Commonwealth.''
In the two days of beach-front rioting last Labor Day, at least 50 people were injured, hundreds were arrested and about 125 stores were looted.
The local police called in several hundred state troopers and several hundred National Guardsmen to restore order.
 
Reaction Is Positive
The commission was established by the City Council early last fall and was made up of educators, businessmen, civil rights leaders and other community figures, black and white.
The commission took statements and testimony from 74 people and reviewed scores of news articles and dozens of television tapes, some filmed by the police at the height of the looting.
Initial reaction to the report by top city officials, businessmen and black leaders was mostly positive.
Mayor Meyera Oberndorf, perhaps the prime target for the report's criticism, said she would study the report and its recommendations thoroughly.
''It is clear that everyone has the opportunity now to learn from the past and to move forward positively for the future,'' she said. ''The important thing is to learn how to accommodate and have a positive Labor Day 1990.''
Ms. Oberndorf asked the City Council members to study the report at once and to put into effect by the end of next week the recommendations they accept. ''I'm going to push you,'' she said.
 
'A Sense of Relief'
E. George Minns, the president of the Virginia Beach Chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called the commission's report ''balanced'' and a ''solid contribution'' toward race relations, which were badly strained by the Labor Day events after being fairly good for the better part of a decade.
''There is a sense of relief and a lessening of tension,'' Mr. Minns said. ''The report brings forth some light of hope. The differences about it are minimal, and I think that's the conclusion of about 90 percent of the black leadership around here. The report looks at both sides, and all sides ought to stop pointing fingers now, take it like a man, so to speak, and move on toward implementation.''
A leading local businessman, Linwood O. Branch, president of the Virginia Beach Hotel and Motel Associations, praised the report, saying the commission ''did a really good job.''
The report said some tapes indicated that some of the looting was done by young people who were more likely high school students than any of the college students who had come to Virginia Beach to celebrate. The annual gathering first drew fraternities and sororities about 10 years ago and since has become known as ''Greekfest.''
The commission also said it had found some evidence of excessive police force. As for the rioters and looters, the commission report stated, ''No amount of rationalization can excuse the behavior of those individuals who destroyed, looted and generally violated the bounds of decency that circumscribe the actions of all who live in a civilized society.''

HEADLINE: Site Picked for Space Museum Annex

BYLINE: By BARBARA GAMAREKIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The Smithsonian Institution announced today that it had selected Dulles International Airport in northern Virginia for a proposed expansion of the National Air and Space Museum that would have room to display a space shuttle, a supersonic Concorde and other historic aircraft.
The planned $300 million complex, a series of vast hangars and other display areas expected to cover 27 acres at the southeast corner of the airport, would also provide much more research and storage space for the museum, which receives more visitors than any other in the nation.
Nearly 10 million people each year visit the 13-year-old museum on the Mall here. 
Congress must approve the Dulles site and provide money for the project before construction can begin, but Smithsonian officials said the first phase could be completed in five years. The expansion is expected to be completed by 2010, at which time the number of visitors to the annex could well reach six million, the officials said.
The Smithsonian's Board of Regents selected the Dulles location over the Baltimore-Washington International Airport in Maryland after a four-month site evaluation and heavy lobbying on the part of Maryland and Virginia legislators and the two state governments.
 
Factors in Selection
A principal reason Dulles was selected, the board said, was its more direct connection in people's minds with the city of Washington and, the board felt, it was important to maintain that attachment. Another reason was greater flexibility of planning afforded by the Dulles tract.
The annex is expected to prove an economic boon to the surrounding area. The airport is 26 miles, or about a 45-minute drive, from the center of Washington.
Visitors to the main museum on the Mall see only about 75 pieces of the 350 aircraft in the museum's collection, which traces the age of flight from its infancy to the moon landing and beyond.
New hangars at Dulles would display German, Japanese and American fighter planes from World War II; the space shuttle Enterprise; the restored B-29 Enola Gay, which dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima; a supersonic Concorde and other aircraft and spacecraft too large for display in the museum in Washington.
Plans also include a hangar where visitors would be able to observe restoration work in progress, said Martin Harwit, director of the National Air and Space Museum.
''We have for many years now wanted to get the go-ahead for constructing such a facility,'' Mr. Harwit said. ''Increasingly we have only been able to show airplanes from the early part of the century rather than the latter part of the century; they are too large to be brought down to the center of Washington.''
 
Authorization Is Required
Today's announcement on the new complex, which will be built with Federal and private money, is but a ''first step,'' said Robert McC. Adams, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Mr. Adams pointed out that no authorization legislation was yet in place. At its May 7 meeting the board is expected to review draft legislation to establish the extension.
''We will work with Congress on authorizing legislation over the coming months,'' Mr. Adams said, ''and I should emphasize that today's declaration of preference does not mean Congress will support that preference. Congress may have a will of its own on this matter.''
The Smithsonian is a national institution, federally and privately supported, that includes arts, science and history museums, and research centers. Fourteen museums, including the Air and Space Museum, come under the institution's umbrella.

HEADLINE: Founded by Idealists, Group Thrives on Need

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
In the 70's, they were a phenomenon in philanthropy: rich young people with avowedly leftist politics using their inheritances to promote ''change, not charity.''
Around the country, they organized community groups opposing the Vietnam War, picketed nuclear plants and demonstrated for desegregated housing. On the local level, they gave money for battered women and abused children, the homeless and disabled, homosexuals, lesbians, minority members and a range of neighborhood groups that could not attract help from conventional donors.
Today, they have grown into a network called the Funding Exchange covering 25 states; last year they gave away $5.5 million, typically in small grants of about $1,500. The sums are tiny when compared with the Ford Foundation's $218 million in annual donations, but important because they often provide seed money for an emerging community group. 
''We find and help these newcomers because we are closer to the ground,'' said June Makela, executive director of the network since its beginning in 1979. And to keep the decisions close to the ground, all Funding Exchange members have governing boards with community representatives determining how money should be spent.
 
Landscape of Philanthropy
In a buoyant reunion, the original organizers of the Funding Exchange, now in their 30's and 40's, joined hundreds of their supporters in Manhattan recently for the 10th anniversary of the network, which now links 15 statewide or regional members like Vanguard and Liberty Hill in San Francisco and Los Angeles and Crossroads and North Star in Chicago and New York.
''We've grown up; we're part of the landscape of American philanthropy,'' said George Pillsbury, an heir to the family baking fortune, who gave away most of a $400,000 inheritance and helped found the Haymarket People's Fund in Boston. ''We're now seen as members of the club.''
The political activism of the network members has not changed, although the causes have. Network members oppose United States involvement in Central America and dealings with South African businesses. They organize demonstrations by rent-strikers, support farmers' boycotts and rally against growth in military spending.
''North Star gives to the smartest, angriest and most community-active groups in New York,'' the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, said of that 12-year-old philanthropy.
Over the years, network members have often been out in front in supporting new issues.
 
Help for Battered Women
Vanguard financed one of the first shelters for battered women in 1976, years before larger foundations or government agencies began supporting projects against domestic violence. When other foundations begged off, Vanguard was among the first to finance a brochure on safe sex. The brochure, ''Can We Talk?,'' has been translated into 40 languages.
But increasingly the network is adopting techniques of mainstream philanthropy. Instead of depending on a fragile year-to-year financing base, the Funding Exchange has begun a fund-raising campaign to establish a $15 million endowment. And members are scouting college campuses to attract a new generation of wealthy donors.
''The endowment represents a giant step,'' Ms. Makela said. ''It says we intend to stay around for decades to come. Skeptics predicted these rich young kids would soon get tired and outgrow radical politics. Instead, our donor base has grown to 4,000 contributors, and they are no longer just young people with inheritances, but wage earners.''
The network's organizers came to terms with their generation's role in philanthropy in different ways.
A few of the network's organizers grew up in families with a tradition of giving to liberal causes. Anne H. Hess, for one, quotes the teachings of her grandmother Edith Stern, a daughter of Julius Rosenwald, the philanthropist, who amassed a fortune in the 1890's from Sears, Roebuck & Company.
 
'Responsibility of Wealth'
Ms. Hess, who, along with Mr. Pillsbury, is directing the endowment campaign, said: ''My grandmother always said one responsibility of wealth is giving it away responsibly. This was a lesson she learned from her father.''
''I came of age when young people in their 20's with a social conscience felt foundations were not meeting our political agenda, or promoting human rights for women, for prisoners, farm workers or Native Americans,'' Ms. Hess said.
Some young donors said inheriting money evoked feelings of guilt, embarrassment, fear of envy, or doubts about self-worth. Many of these concerns, they found, are explored sympathetically in a manual called ''Robin Hood Was Right,'' which network members published in 1977.
John Lapham said that when he came into his inheritance from a family business, he felt confused and isolated. ''It was taboo to talk of money to my family and friends,'' he said. ''I read the Robin Hood book, and I went to a Haymarket meeting and I found a place where I could give my money and it felt right for me.''
Charles Collins, a great-grandson of Oscar Mayer, founder of the meat-packing company, learned at 16 that he would come into an inheritance. ''I dreaded the whole idea,'' Mr. Collins said. ''My father told me I need never work, but he hoped I would.''
A steady supporter of the Haymarket Fund, Mr. Collins gave away virtually all his $300,000 four years ago, mainly to Haymarket. He supports himself with a modest salary from the Institute for Community Economics, a 12-year-old nonprofit organization that runs the country's largest loan fund for low-income housing.
''My biggest worry was the bad effect this might have on my family relations,'' Mr. Collins said, ''and I simmered inside. But I was able to talk it through during long walks with my father.''
At the Funding Exchange's celebration, with his father looking on proudly, Mr. Collins was given the group's first Robin Hood award.
''Whenever I begin to sound self-righteous, my partner, Rebecca Morrison, has a way of pulling me up short,'' he said. ''She reminds me all I did was the moral equivalent of finding a wallet on the street and returning it to its owner.''

HEADLINE: The 1991 Budget: Tax Breaks;
Bush Offers Savings Plan and Asks for Smaller Cut in Gains Tax

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
President Bush proposed a revised plan today for cutting capital gains taxes and offered tax breaks for a new type of savings account.
He said the measures, which are the centerpieces of his revenue proposals, would encourage people to save and would promote business investment and economic growth.
The proposals are part of a package of more than two dozen tax changes outlined in the President's budget for the fiscal year 1991, including new or increased fees and taxes on a variety of activities, from boating and air travel to securities transactions.
The capital gains cut proposal, identified in the President's budget only as a measure to ''enhance long-term investment,'' is less generous than the one Mr. Bush advanced unsuccessfully last year. 
 
A Money-Maker in '91
The rate reductions, which would vary according to a taxpayer's income bracket, would be phased in over three years and would be smaller for assets held only one or two years. Under current law, capital gains are taxed at the same rate as ordinary income; last year, the President proposed cutting the rate to 15 percent.
The Administration estimates that cutting the capital gains tax would raise $4.9 billion in new revenue for 1991 as people cash in their holdings to take advantage of the lower rate. This would be the largest item in the revenue package. The second largest, at $2.5 billion, would be achieved through unspecified ''management reforms'' at the Internal Revenue Service.
Other tax changes, like the savings account proposal and an expansion of existing tax credits to help parents pay for child-care expenses, would cost the Treasury money. But taken together, the Administration said, the major proposals in the package would raise at least $13.9 billion in new revenue for the next fiscal year, and the new or increased fees would bring in $2 billion more.
Congressional Democrats were skeptical of these revenue calculations, saying some of the projected gains were temporary or based on accounting gimmickry. For example, the growth in capital gains revenue would be a short-term phenomenon, they said; in the long term, reducing rates would cost the Treasury billions and enlarge the Federal deficit. They were particularly doubtful that management changes at the I.R.S. could raise $2.5 billion.
Mr. Bush's modified version of the capital gains rate reduction addresses some of the issues raised by the Democratic leadership in Congress last year, but it is still likely to be the major battleground in this year's tax policy fight.
Capital gains, the profits on sales of real estate, stocks, bonds, timber and the like, are taxed at the same rate as ordinary income. For those in the 28 percent bracket, Mr. Bush's proposal would reduce the rate to 19.6 percent for assets held at least three years. The rate for assets held two to three years would be 22.4 percent, and the rate for assets held at least one year but less than two would be 25.2 percent.
Investments in artwork, antiques or precious metals would not qualify for the reduced rates.
The budget proposals include a number of new fees and levies that affect businesses, including a ''transaction tax'' of 11 cents on all commodity trades. Another proposal would limit the deductions permitted to banks or other lenders for loans to employee stock opportunity programs, or ESOP's.
Mr. Bush's proposal to increase domestic saving, which his budget says ''is of major importance for promoting higher rates of growth and an improved standard of living,'' builds on ideas advanced by Democrats as well as Republicans last year. It would create a new type of savings account on which interest would not be taxed, and it would change rules on existing Individual Retirement Accounts to permit penalty-free withdrawals for people buying their first home.
The new savings accounts would be limited to people with income below $60,000 a year and couples with joint incomes below $120,000 a year. Up to $2,500 a year could be contributed to these special accounts, and interest earned on it would be tax-free as long as the money remained in the account. After seven years, the money could be withdrawn tax-free.
 
Incentives to Keep Saving
To encourage people to hold the accounts for that period, money withdrawn in the first three years would be subject to a 10 percent excise tax on the investment income. Withdrawals made between three and seven years would be taxed like ordinary income.
The Administration estimated that the plan would cost $200 million in 1991, rising to $1 billion in 1993.
A separate proposal by the President that would permit first-time home buyers to withdraw their money from Individual Retirement Accounts without tax penalties is a more limited version of savings incentive plans that lawmakers in both parties suggested last year. Under current law, deductions for contributions to retirement accounts are limited to a relatively small number of lower-income taxpayers, and there are no exceptions for withdrawing the money.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, proposed last year that people with higher incomes be eligible for some tax break on retirement accounts and that penalty-free withdrawals also be permitted for home buying and educational expenses.

HEADLINE: The 1991 Budget: Forecasts;
The Rosy Path to Cutting the Deficit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
To meet the budget deficit level required by law, the Bush Administration used favorable assumptions about economic growth, proposed many of the same spending cuts Congress has rejected time and again and suggested several accounting tricks.
Thus, despite the exhortation of Richard G. Darman, the budget director, that ''there is an obligation to be serious,'' the Administration's proposals do not provide a sure-fire way of cutting the deficit.
The projection that the economy will grow by 2.6 percent in this calendar year is not implausable, but it is at the optimistic end of the range of forecasts by private economists.
The Congressional Budget Office predicts that growth this year will be only 1.8 percent, in line with the consensus of private economists. If that is the case, the deficit in the next fiscal year would be $100 billion, not the $63 billion foreseen by the Administration, Congressional economists said. 
 
The Record of Forecasting
Over the years, the executive branch's record of forecasting has been about as good as Congress's. A favorable forecast last summer for the calendar year 1989 proved much closer to the mark on unemployment, interest rates and growth than the more pessimistic forecasts of most economists. But the discrepancy shows how much the Administration's deficit estimate depends on continued prosperity.
The Administration calculates that if all Government programs were continued with an added allotment to account for inflation, the deficit in the 1991 fiscal year would be $100.5 billion. This is called the current services budget, or baseline.
The budget submitted today lays out $36.5 billion in spending cuts and revenue increases to bring the projected deficit below the $64 billion mandatory target set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
Some of those proposed cuts, like a slowdown in the increase of military spending and legislated reductions in Medicare fees to doctors and hospitals, would, if enacted, provide real budget saving.
But other proposals, like ending operating grants for urban mass transit systems and disallowing cost-of-living pension increases to retired Federal employees, have been rejected year after year by Congress and stand almost no chance of being approved.
 
Stumbling Blocks to a Goal
If the economy does not perform as well as the Administration expects and if Congress continues to refuse to accept cuts in popular domestic programs, the deficit target will be missed. No compromise is in sight. The outlook is for another difficult year of negotiations.
In addition, billions of dollars would be raised, according to budget estimates, through accounting gimmicks or steps like generating a quick surge of revenue by cutting the capital gains tax. These may be painless, but they are of questionable long-term benefit to deficit reduction.
After a decade of Presidential requests for large increases in the military budget, Mr. Bush asked Congress to approve less for the Pentagon than what would be needed to keep pace with inflation.
Democratic lawmakers are sure to try to cut the military budget further to allow more money for domestic spending. But they concede that this will be difficult this year when the President is already offering a relatively low level of military spending.
 
The Medicare Payment Plan
The other proposal that promises a large saving over many years is a limit on Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals. Two powerful lobbies - doctors, who would see their fees cut, and the elderly, who fear doctors would stop treating Medicare patients if their fees were lowered - will vigorously oppose this measure, and its enactment is thus problematical.
Most other spending reductions come from a familiar list proposed many times by the Reagan Administration. In addition to cuts in mass transit grants and Federal pensions, the list includes an end to subsidies for Amtrak, a reduction in payments to poor families for home heating and weatherization, the abolition of the Economic Development Administration, a cut in school assistance to communities with military bases or other Federal installations and the end of grants to public libraries.
 
The Power of Constituencies
In private, many lawmakers concede that some proposals are worthwhile. But most have powerful constituencies - developers, teachers' unions and big-city mayors, for instance - and Congress is reluctant to touch these programs.
The largest single revenue increase proposed by the Administration would come from its measure to lower the capital gains tax. The budget estimates that the tax cut would raise nearly $5 billion in the first year.
Economists do not generally dispute that figure, agreeing that investors would pay more taxes right off the bat as they sold investments to take advantage of the lower rates. But while the Administration maintains that revenue would be increased indefinitely, Congressional tax experts have calculated that the long-term loss of money to the Treasury would be substantial.
 
Darman Concedes a Gimmick
The rest of the nearly $14 billion in higher revenue would come from fees for using Government services or from accounting tricks.
Like some of the proposed spending cuts, many of these fees have been repeatedly turned down by Congress. Having rejected many times the idea of charging boaters a fee for using waterways patrolled by the Coast Guard, Congress is hardly likely to go along with it this year.
At his news conference today, Mr. Darman conceded one gimmick to raise money. The budget proposes that large employers be required to submit daily to the Government the taxes they withhold from workers' paychecks.
If that sounds familiar, it is because Congress passed such a law last year to cover this fiscal year, 1990. But, to leave themselves room to find last-minute revenue in this year's negotiations, they allowed employers to take more time to forward the money. The Administration would simply leave the one-day requirement in place.
 
The Tricks May Be Inevitable
Other revenue increases seem less solid. The budget envisions raising $3 billion through management improvements at the Internal Revenue Service. About $500 million of this would come from hiring new tax agents.
The rest would come, said Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, by having agents concentrate on tax cases likely to produce the biggest settlements for the Government.
In addition, the Administration decided late last year to speed up Medicare reimbursements to doctors and hospitals for one year. As a result $1.5 billion was shifted from the fiscal year 1991 to the fiscal year 1990.
Given the constraints of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings legislation, the favorable economic forecasts, the unrealistic spending cuts and the accounting tricks may be inevitable.
The law, said Joseph White, a budget specialist at the Brookings Institution, ''sets a total no one can possibly hit with serious policy proposals.''

HEADLINE: The 1991 Budget;
A Guide to Budget Trouble Spots

 BODY:

ITEM: MILITARY
BUSH: Bush's budget would increase military spending by less than the rate of inflation, but spending would still increase.
DEMOCRATS: Democrats in Congress will want to cut Pentagon spending beyond what Bush has proposed and are more eager to eliminate expensive weapons systems. 
 
ITEM: DEFICIT
BUSH: The budget reduces the projected deficit to under $64 billion, by continuing to use the surplus in the Social Security trust fund to mask a larger operating deficit. It assumes, the economy can grow out of the budget deficit, avoiding tax increases or severe spending cuts.
DEMOCRATS: The Democrats question whether economic conditions will allow the Government to grow its way out of the deficit and believe that some of the spending cuts Bush has proposed are unrealistic.
 
ITEM: TAXES
BUSH: Bush proposes no general tax increase and is seeking to lower the taxes on capital gains.
DEMOCRATS: Most Democrats say that cutting the capital gains tax alone favors the rich, and some are considering reducing the Social Security tax.
 
ITEM: DOMESTIC
BUSH: Bush would expand Federal child care assistance through tax credits, and would add money to fight drugs, improve education and plant trees, while cutting money for Medicare, Amtrak and mass transit.
DEMOCRATS: Democrats would give grants to states and communities for child care, would provide more money for the fight against drugs, education and the environment and resist other proposed cuts.
 
ITEM: FOREIGN AID
BUSH: Bush-would increase foreign aid, and wants more flexibility to distribute foreign aid payments. He has not formally endorsed a plan to take money from Israel and Egypt and give it to Eastern Europe.
DEMOCRATS: Democrats and Republicans will zealously guard Congress's practice of saying specifically where the money should go, and want to give more new money to East Europe than Bush would.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1321 words

HEADLINE: The 1991 Budget: Proposals;
How Bush's Plan Would Affect Domestic Efforts

 BODY:
Here are President Bush's budget proposals for major domestic programs for the 1991 fiscal year:
 
Drugs and Crime
The President's spending proposal would increase the Justice Department's budget by 19 percent from last year to nearly $9 billion, excluding funds set aside for a multiyear Federal prison construction program. The most significant increases, earmarked for anti-drug activities, were announced last week as part of President Bush's new plan to combat drug trafficking.
Some agencies in the Justice Department would suffer reductions. The Federal Bureau of Investigation, for instance, would receive a slight spending increase, but would lose nearly 400 positions. The decrease would probably result in a reduction in the number of agents assigned to areas like organized crime and white-collar crime. 
 
Education
The Administration proposed $41 billion for education, training, and employment programs and ancillary social services, $400 million more than would be spent under current law and $3 billion more than is expected to be spent in the current fiscal year.
The budget proposed an $880 million increase to $10 billion in spending for elementary and secondary school education for the disadvantaged.
The budget would also increase by $500 million the funds for Head Start, a program intended to prepare young children to succeed in school, for a total of $1.9 billion. The proposal would also increase by $1.2 billion, to a total of $19.7 billion, discretionary funds for education.
The budget also proposed $239 million for adult literacy programs, a 25 percent increase over the current budget.
 
Environment
Continuing to reverse the pattern of budgets under President Reagan, Mr. Bush is proposing substantial new spending on environmental programs. Among the significant additions are $269 million for a program to provide money for acquiring parkland and for a major reforestation effort across the country. Mr. Bush is also calling for increased spending to protectwetlands, a hefty increase for research into global climate change and using nearly $780 million to clean up nuclear contamination and other pollution at Federal installations.
The Environmental Protection Agency's total proposed budget would rise by a modest $48 million dollars to $5.6 billion. But its important operating budget, with which it administers the anti-pollution laws, would rise by 12 percent to $2.17 billion.
 
Health
The Administration proposed reducing Medicare premiums by $60 a year for beneficiaries who join a Health Maintenance Organization. To further encourage membership in such programs, the Administration is developing a new program, ''Medicare Plus,'' that would combine membership in a Preferred Provider Organization with Medigap, the Medicare supplemental insurance.
The proposal would also offer the states incentives to enroll people in such programs. An H.M.O. is a highly structured organization of doctors and others that offers a full range of medical services. A P.P.O. is a less structured group of doctors who have agreed to take lower fees than they would otherwise charge in exchange for a higher volume of patients.
The Administration also proposed reducing the projected growth of Medicare by $5.6 billion, and obtaining $1.9 billion more in revenues. But Medicare expenditures are still expected to increase by $10 billion, to $116 billion.
The budget would also provide a $109 million increase in AIDS research, prevention and other activities, for a total of $1.7 billion. Total spending on AIDS would be $3.1 billion.
 
Labor
For the Labor Department, the President proposes a small increase in spending, from $24.9 billion in the 1990 fiscal year to $26.3 billion. Most of the budget, $19.4 billion, represents benefits the Government pays to unemployed workers. If the unemployment rate is higher than the 5.3 percent the Government predicts for the year - a rate that some economists say is optimistic - that spending would rise.
Still, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole obtained room for spending increases in areas that she has put high among her priorities, including an increase of $261 million, to $5.3 billion for employment and training, she told reporters today. She would reduce spending for special summer training programs, from $715 million to $220 million, but she would raise spending from $44 million in the 1990 fiscal year to $1.4 billion for longer-term programs, especially one designed to ease young people's transition from school to work.
The Occupational Safety and Health Administration would get 34 more inspectors, bringing to more than 200 the number that she has addeed since taking office.
 
Science and Space
A major theme of the proposed budget is investment in the future, and the Bush Administration, seeing the space program as a big part of that, wants to increase the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's budget to $15.2 billion. That would be a 24 percent rise from the previous year, which would be the largest percentage increase for any major agency.
The additional $2.9 billion includes a 36 percent increase for the space station, alloting $2.6 billion for the manned space platform, which is to be launched in 1995, so that construction could begin on those parts requiring long lead times. The space agency also asked for $237 million to start an orbiting Earth Observing System, a program that would use a series of satellites and a computer network to measure and monitor environmental changes.
 
Transportation
The Transportation Department requested $26.9 billion, a figure that is 4.2 percent below this year's spending level. Big increases for the Federal Aviation Administration and the Coast Guard were offset by proposals to eliminate Federal subsidies for the Amtrak rail system and to cut operating subsidies for mass transport systems in large cities. In past years Congress has refused to make similar cuts in both programs.
The department proposed to cover 77 percent of its budget through user fees, and proposed two increases in the user fees that help pay for aviation programs. The existing 8 percent tax on airline tickets would be raised to 10 percent, and local airports would be granted authority to impose their own taxes on passengers and could spend that money on airport improvements.
 
Agriculture
President Bush also proposed increasing spending at the Department of Agriculture by $500 million in the 1991 fiscal year to $48.7 billion. The Administration proposed changes in Federal law that would reduce spending for crop subsidy programs by $1.5 billion to $10.24 billion. The Administration has called for cuts in a broad array of programs administered by the Department of Agriculture including programs for feeding children which now cost $127 million, meat and poultry inspection costing $52 million, loans for farmers which would cost $848 million, and housing for rural families, costing $420 million.
Several programs were identified by the Administration for modest increases. The Presidents asked Congress for $38 million for basic farm research. Several lawmakers criticized the small increase at a time when consumers are calling for more field studies on cultivation practices that produce food with fewer chemicals.
 
Energy
The Administration has asked for $1 billion more for the Department of Energy, for a total of $17.5 billion. Much of the extra money would go into improvements to make the network of deteriorating nuclear weapons laboratories and factories safer and to clean up decades of environmental contamination. Overall, the Administration has asked Congress to approve $3.3 billion to address environmental issues, making the Energy Department one of the Government largest managers of environmental programs. In comparison the budget for the Environmental Protection Agency is $5.8 billion.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 31, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a summary article yesterday about President Bush's budget proposals for domestic programs misstated the proposed budget for the Environmental Protection Agency. It is $5.8 billion.

HEADLINE: The Moment, Missed;
Mr. Bush on Defense: Too Much, Too Late

 BODY:
The foundations of Communist power are crumbling. The threat of Soviet attack is radically diminished. Yet President Bush, in his new budget, would continue to arm for nuclear war. His unwillingness to declare a ''peace dividend'' creates a monumental missed opportunity. 
Mr. Bush's one-page budget message makes no mention of any savings on defense spending. Worse, Budget Director Richard Darman derides the whole notion as a ''wonderland'' fantasy. With that attitude, the opportunity for America to assert its concern for neglected needs at home and abroad will just have to wait.
No one expects a quick big dividend. Strategic arms and conventional force reductions are still in negotiation with Moscow; they will take years to carry out. In time, the savings could amount to $50 billion a year. But planning for peace takes time, too. After four decades of cold war it is time to test new ideas - to help country after country as they emerge from the Communist chrysalis; and to relieve desperate domestic problems too long ignored.
For now, President Bush seeks to cut military spending - in real terms, discounted for inflation -by 2.6 percent next year, and 2 percent annually thereafter. Symbolically, that's a reversal of the upward path he projected just a year ago, and a dramatic departure from President Reagan's escalation. As a practical matter, however, this only acquiesces in what Congress has been doing to the defense budget for five years. Since the peak of the Reagan buildup in 1985, defense spending in constant dollars has shrunk by 16 percent.
The Administration argues against shrinking faster now, on grounds that conditions in the Communist world remain uncertain. It advances only cautious cutbacks, in order to be flexible in the unlikely event that the cold war resumes. Indeed, the cuts proposed are uncertain too, like base closings that protective Congressmen are bound to resist.
Mr. Bush puts his emphasis not on money for peace but on more weapons - five more Stealth bombers, a new Trident submarine and continued deployment of a global Navy.
As an example of far-fetched rationalization, consider his request for the ''Star Wars'' nuclear defense system. Continued research is in order, but Mr. Bush goes further. He seeks $1 billion more than the $3.8 billion Congress voted last year. Why? Ignoring the erosion of the Soviet menace that originally justified this system, the Administration argues now that America needs this protection against smaller countries with nuclear weapons.
No budget is a Bible. In proposing to cut defense only 2 percent, Mr. Bush knows perfectly well that Congress will cut more. In his failure to acknowledge deeper cuts at the outset, he invites a year's battle with Congress over where to chop. The year might be spent more profitably debating where to plant new seed.

HEADLINE: The Moment Missed;
His 'Integrity Fund': Arbitrary, Unfair

 BODY:
The Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund: what a noble-sounding proposal President Bush offers in his new budget. But it's deceptive nobility, that masks two devastating facts:
* The proposal would do nothing to save Social Security.
* It would amass huge budget surpluses at the expense of valuable Federal programs and with the help of a payroll tax that hits low-paid workers hardest. 
The Administration deserves acclaim for its willingness to take the deficit seriously. This plan, however, swings astonishingly far in the opposite direction. It sets an unwise goal, and would reach it in unjust ways.
The new Bush proposal is plainly meant to parry the recent thrust from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and others who want to end the use of Social Security payroll taxes to pay the Government's bills. But like the Senator, Mr. Bush has disguised the cost of his proposal.
The President contends that his Integrity Fund will protect future retirees and taxpayers. But that's impossible. The goods that retirees will buy with their Social Security checks come from the economy's current taxpaying producers. Future taxpayers cannot be spared the burden. So Mr. Bush's idea has little to do with saving Social Security. But it has a lot to do with controlling the Federal deficit.
At the moment, increases in the Social Security payroll tax help offset deficit spending. Under the Bush plan this money would, in effect, be excluded from the calculation of the deficit under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law. How would the Government then cover the resulting deficit? It would have to pass big expenditure cuts or tax increases.
At first glance, that might seem attractive. It would end the practice of paying ordinary bills with money that was supposed to pay the retirement benefits of future retirees. And it would lower the deficit, releasing the nation's savings for private investment. Economists plead for that type of fiscal discipline.
But there are two glaring faults. The goal is excessive; the method of finance is unfair.
The goal is excessive because the nation does not need the Government to run hundred-billion-dollar surpluses. Given the arbitrary way the Federal deficit is defined, there's no special significance in the number zero. There is plenty of reason to reduce the deficit but no compelling reason to balance the budget, let alone run huge surpluses.
Yes, the nation's savings rate is too low. Yes, lowering the deficit would improve matters. But flipping from huge deficits to huge surpluses would be unfair and unjustified.
Why unfair? Because Mr. Bush refuses to raise income taxes, leaving only one way to reduce spending enough to create huge surpluses: harsh cuts in valuable Federal programs. What's left to cut? Food stamps? Head Start? The weakness of the Integrity Fund idea becomes obvious as soon as the costs are confronted.
The Integrity Fund, in other words, is a means to control the budget, not to protect Social Security. As soon as Congress recognizes that, it might choose a wholly different form of control. Instead of cutting deeply into programs, it could raise income taxes, or gasoline taxes. Some such combination would be much fairer to poorer people than payroll tax hikes.
There is little integrity in disguising a draconian policy.
