HEADLINE: Dinkins Makes Choices For 3 More High Posts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Carol O'Cleireacain, chief economist of the largest municipal workers union in New York City, to be the city's finance commissioner, and Catherine M. Abate, head of the State Crime Victims Board, as probation commissioner.
Mr. Dinkins also appointed Victor M. Quintana, who was a special assistant in the Manhattan Borough President's office under Mr. Dinkins, to head a newly created office of constituent affairs, overseeing the Mayor's relations with black, Hispanic and Asian-American New Yorkers and with veterans, lesbians and gay men.
At the same time, city officials said Mr. Dinkins was negotiating with Milton Mollen, presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, to become the city's criminal justice coordinator. One official said the Mayor went to the judge's chambers yesterday to discuss the job. More Weight for Job? The post of the coordinator, who oversees dealings among the police, district attorneys and the courts, has the rank and pay of a commissioner but has not been a strong position in recent years, though it once had the rank of deputy mayor. Some members of the Mayor's staff and transition team have urged that the job be given greater weight in organizing crime-fighting policy in the face of rising violence and overcrowded courts and jails. 
Justice Mollen, who is 70 years old, is one of the most powerful judges in the state. He is reported to want the status of deputy mayor as a condition of taking the job. The judge did not return a telephone call to his office seeking comment. First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel refused to comment.
Ms. O'Cleireacain (pronounced oh-CLARE-uh-kun) has been the chief economist of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees since 1976. She was a fiscal adviser to Mr. Dinkins in his mayoral campaign last year.
The finance commissioner is responsible for collecting taxes and helping form the city's tax policy and also sits on the boards that oversee pension funds for city workers. Asked whether as a longtime union advocate she would have trouble being part of management, both Ms. O'Cleireacain and Mr. Dinkins said no. ''I consider myself a professional,'' she said.
Ms. O'Cleireacain, 43, with bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Michigan and a doctorate from the London School of Economics, took pains to say that she considered the finance commissioner's main role to be raising money, not spending it.
She is to take office Feb. 20 and be paid $110,000 a year.
Ms. Abate (pronounced uh-BAH-tay), who is 42, formerly served as executive deputy commissioner of the State Division of Human Rights and as a training director and trial lawyer for the Legal Aid Society. She is Vassar College graduate with a law degree from Boston University. She is to take office in March at a salary of $103,000.
 
'The Bottom Line'
She replaces Kevin T. Smyley, who has been mentioned as a candidate for several city jobs. In a telephone interview, he said his plans were still uncertain. ''The bottom line is I want to serve in whatever capacity that I can be of use to the Mayor and the city,'' he said.
Mr. Quintana, 41, has worked as an organizer for community-based housing and tenant groups, and managed the Borough President's field office in upper Manhattan. A graduate of Lehman College, he is to take office Feb. 5 at a salary of $70,000 a year.
In his new job, which consolidates parts of several functions that were performed by different people in the Koch administration, he will report to Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, the Mayor's chief political aide.

Abate, the new probation commissioner, as they were introduced at City Hall.; Mayor David N. Dinkins named his former special assistant, Victor M. Quintana, to the new office of constituent affairs. (NYT/Ed Quinn)

LENGTH: 1244 words

HEADLINE: From Minnow to Sturgeon, North American Fish Are in Peril

 BODY:
ONE in three species or subspecies of native freshwater fish in North America is or may be threatened by the degradation of lakes, rivers and streams, scientists say.
Fish in waterways all over the continent are being affected by urban, agricultural and industrial development, pollution and the introduction of competitive or predatory fish, the researchers say.
And though governmental efforts like the Endangered Species Act have been successful in individual cases, they have been unable to solve the overall problem.
There are about 1,000 species and subspecies of freshwater fish in the United States, Canada and Mexico. In a new report, the American Fisheries Society says 364 of them fit one of three categories: endangered, which means facing extinction in all or a significant portion of their ranges; threatened, meaning likely to become endangered in the near future; and of ''special concern,'' meaning that relatively minor disturbances to the environment could place them in danger. 
That is 113 more species and subspecies than were on the society's first list, compiled in 1979. It does not include the 40 species thought to have become extinct in this century.
 
From Minnows to Sturgeon
On the new list, published in the November-December issue of the journal Fisheries, are many types of fish throughout the continent, including all 50 states. They range from large to tiny, from obscure to well-known; the list includes species of minnows and killifish, the paddlefish, the Colorado squawfish and two-thirds of all species of North American sturgeon.
Many kinds of game fish are also endangered or threatened, including sunfish, perch, catfish and 34 kinds of trout, but the report said that only 3 percent of all species on the list are threatened by recreational or commercial fishing.
''The situation is more alarming than we expected,'' said Dr. Jack E. Williams, director of the society's endangered species committee. ''There has been a continuing downturn in the status of freshwater fish in North America. What is more alarming is that our report finds very few cases of success.''
Since the Endangered Species Act was adopted in 1973, only four species of fish have recovered enough to be moved from the endangered to the threatened category. None has been removed from the list. In the same period, six species have become extinct and scores more have become endangered or threatened.
Scientists and environmentalists predict that burgeoning human population and development will push many more species to the brink of extinction or over it. ''The rate of extinction will increase,'' said Dr. Williams, who is also fisheries director of the Bureau of Land Management. ''If we cannot reverse this trend, we will see large-scale species losses and large-scale system failures.''
Dr. Peter B. Moyle, a fishery biologist at the University of California at Davis, said the list might be too conservative. ''We have lost a number of species,'' he said, ''but we are in danger of rapidly losing many more not on the list.''
And Maitland Sharp, executive director of the Isaak Walton League, a conservation group, said the study showed that the Endangered Species Act was ''not doing an adequate job protecting these threatened and endangered species.'' He added that Congress and the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service might need to reassess the law.
 
The Death of Habitats
While there is seldom a single factor responsible for a species' decline or extinction, experts agreed that the most pervasive threat is destruction of delicate fish habitats. That destruction assumes many forms: the diversion of water for drinking and irrigation; industrial and agricultural development; sewage and chemical pollution, and the introduction of non-native species.
A new and serious threat is the proliferation of acid rain. Some lakes and streams in the Northeast and Canada have become so acidic that fish can no longer live in them. In 100,000 lakes in Ontario and Quebec, wild stocks of the endangered aurora trout have been eradicated; half the range of the endangered Acadian whitefish of Nova Scotia has been destroyed.
''Across southern Canada there has been a tremendous alteration of fishery habitats,'' said Charles Dauphine, coordinator of endangered species for the Canadian Wildlife Service in Ottawa. ''We are quite alarmed by the scale of the threat.''
But scientists agree that the hardest hit regions are in the arid parts of the Southwestern United States and northern Mexico. The fisheries society says 62 percent of the imperiled species are in five American states - California, Nevada, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas - or in the Mexican states of Sonora, Chihuahua and Coahuila.
''Every fish in the Southwest is endangered whether or not it is on the list because of the continued population growth in the region,'' said Phil Pister, a biologist for the California Department of Fish and Game who is secretary of the Desert Fishes Council. ''The situation is going to get nothing but worse.''
The Colorado River once flowed 1,450 miles, from the Rocky Mountains to the Gulf of Mexico. Now not even a trickle often remains at the river's mouth, the water having been captured by large dams and diverted for thirsty crops and human populations.
 
In Special Danger: Mexican Fish
As a result, many fish species have disappeared from the Colorado and its tributaries. And many that survived the loss of habitat have been eliminated by the introduction of non-native fish like the largemouth bass, which prey on native species or compete with them for dwindling food supplies. Compounding the crisis, many species in the arid Southwest live in single small streams or springs, fragile aquatic ecosystems that are easily disrupted.
Of the 113 species added to the American Fisheries Society's list since 1979, 56 are native to Mexico. The society says that many were added because improved techniques have identified more imperiled species, but that many others were included because growing population and pollution have devastated habitats.
''Most of our fish in Mexico are in some sort of danger,'' said Dr. Salvador Contreras-Balderas, a co-author of the report who is a professor at the Autonomous University of Nuevo Leon in Monterrey, Mexico.
''Strong regulations are now beginning to be enforced, but the situation will not get better,'' he said. He cited a lack of experts, ''a lack of economic resources, a lack of ecological conscience.''
In the Yucatan, for example, many people dump trash and sewage into crevices and caverns, unwittingly destroying the fragile subterranean habitat of the dama blanca ciega, a tiny blind species that faces almost certain extinction.
In the United States, scientists say, 30 Federal agencies and a plethora of state bodies have addressed the problem species by species instead of dealing with entire communities of fish and freshwater ecosystems. And many experts agree that efforts to halt the decline of freshwater species will meet resistance from political and economic interests.
But Bob Herbst, executive director of Trout Unlimited, a sport fishing association, said something must be done to halt the decline of even small, obscure and seemingly unimportant species. ''Fish are barometers for the future of humans, like the canary in a coal mine,'' he said. ''Whether a fish species lives indicates the quality of the environment for man.''

HEADLINE: Business Programs Reaching Big Time

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON

 BODY:
THIS is a tale of two computer programs that grew up. One started life as shareware, which is try-before-you-buy software; the other was always a commercial product, but a home-grown and home-distributed one. Now both are offered through more traditional sales channels. 
The first program is SolveIt! The Financial Calculator. It carries out 29 financial routines, like telling you how much time and interest will be saved if you speed up the payments on a loan, how much you made on a series of stock trades, and how much you are indeed worth.
These operations all have technical names in the financial world, of course: for the examples just given, accelerated payments, gross profit margin of a series, and net worth statement. Other routines include future value of a series of deposits, straight-line depreciation and economic ordering quantity.
Each routine presents you with a series of questions, and you do little more than fill in the blanks. For the affordable-house-price routine, the program asks the buyer's annual income, cash available, interest rate and terms in years, estimates of tax, insurance and maintenance costs and percentage of income to be devoted to payments. Then, in a flash, the screen shows how expensive a house you can afford, the amount to be financed and what percentage of the house price the available cash represents.
SolveIt! works on an I.B.M.-compatible computer with 384 kilobytes of free memory and two floppy disk drives. A hard drive is desirable, though, and the more memory the better. With sufficient memory, the program can be loaded as a T.S.R. (Terminate and Stay Resident) utility, so it can be called up while you're in the middle of doing something else. The version I tried is designated 3.1b. It is $49.95, plus $2.95 shipping and handling, from Pine Grove Software, 67-38 108th Street, Suite D-1, Forest Hills, N.Y. 11375; telephone (800) 242-9192. New York residents should add $4.12 sales tax. Version 4.0, with improvements, is coming in a few months, with a free upgrade for owners of version 3.1.
The other program was called Tony Stewart's Home Office when it was discussed here in late 1988. It has been licensed to Spinnaker Software and considerably enhanced and speeded up, and it is now One-Person Office, part of that company's handsome Better Working series.
One-Person Office is designed for anyone who has separate clients and projects, with expenses to be tracked, invoices to be mailed, contacts to be organized and reports to be printed. It will even remind you whom to call.
The expense section, for example, has 62 categories: travel, entertainment, repairs and the like. You can use the existing categories, edit them or add your own. You can print out all expenses, or just those for particular jobs or categories or dates.
Like the other programs in the Better Working family, One-Person Office is exceptionally easy to like. Menus and one-letter commands run the various modules and submodules, and if you press the F1 key, help appears on the screen. The program requires a computer running DOS 2.1 or later, 430 kilobytes of available memory and a hard disk with at least 900 kilobytes of space free. It can also be used on a system with two floppy disk drives. Spinnaker Software is at 1 Kendall Square, Cambridge, Mass. 02139; telephone (617) 494-1200. The retail price is $69.95.

HEADLINE: Argentina's Unlikely Disciplinarian

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
While all eyes are focused on economic and political events in Eastern Europe, dramatic changes are also convulsing Argentina. The fate of President Carlos Saul Menem's bold play to build overnight a modern free-market economy hangs in the balance - and perhaps with it, the fate of Argentina's seven-year-old experiment in democracy.
After months of political honeymoon, during which Mr. Menem outlined his plans for revivifying the economy and monthly inflation returned to single digits, prices again started to rise and the fragile social contract among labor, business and government again began to unravel.
The President responded by declaring war on financial speculation. And in the view of many analysts, the gambit has worked: his Jan. 3 freeze on bank savings deflated pressures for higher prices and bound the fortunes of Argentina's skittish middle class to the success of the economic reform program. 
 
An Attempt to Buy Time
But Mario del Carril, a former Argentine diplomat who is now at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington, argues that the move does not solve the underlying problem. It only ''buys time'' - time for Mr. Menem to prove that he can break the power of entrenched interests. Those interests have presided over the long decline of an economy that at the turn of the century had a per capita income equal to the United States'.
The purchase, moreover, may prove politically expensive. As Eduardo Amadeo, head of the Provincial Bank of Buenos Aires, points out, ''President Menem has made powerful new enemies,'' just when he can least afford to.
''Any sign of irresolve,'' said a well-informed official at an international lending agency, ''is likely to tip the economy into hyperinflation.''
When Mr. Menem ran for president last spring, he offered no hint that he was prepared to play economic disciplinarian to a nation that has never been able to live within its means. As the flamboyant governor of La Rioja, Argentina's poorest province, he had invented thousands of jobs for supporters and even printed his own money when the provincial treasury ran out. And as heir to the Peronist coalition, he was politically indebted to militant trade unions and inefficient industries accustomed to passing high labor costs on to consumers.
But once in office, President Menem responded to the inflationary crisis with a program calculated to evoke the enthusiasm of the coolest-eyed free-market technocrat. He appointed as economy minister a conservative executive from Argentina's largest multinational corporation. He demanded wage restraint. He endorsed initiatives to sell off bloated, unprofitable Government enterprises, to slash ''development'' subsidies to politically connected businesses, to broaden the tax base and to encourage efficient foreign producers to compete in Argentina's industrial markets.
Inflation fell from almost 200 percent in July to just 6 percent in October on the strength of wage-price guidelines that Mr. Menem bullied business and labor into accepting. That, in turn, narrowed the Government budget deficit, which had ballooned in previous months as expenses raced ahead of tax collections.
The list of import items protected from foreign competition was cut to just 100, from 800. Ambitious plans were drafted to sell off railroads, television networks, the telephone monopoly, the national oil company and the national airline. Public utilities' prices were raised to reduce losses and public-enterprise subsidies were scheduled for elimination by 1991.
A bill extending the national sales tax to most products was submitted to Congress. The International Monetary Fund, which had turned its back on President Menem's predecessor, Raul Alfonsin, agreed to provide a $1.4 billion line of credit to stabilize the exchange rate.
 
'Economy on a Knife Edge'
But as Eduardo Amadeo points out, ''the inflationary memory of Argentines kept the economy on a knife edge.'' Those looking for glints of the blade began to spot them.
William Cline, an economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, believes the Menem administration first stumbled in October, when it failed to oppose a 70 percent wage increase over six months, negotiated by big labor and big business. The perception of weakness was compounded by delays in designing a credible means for collecting the new sales tax.
The public's fear of getting stuck with depreciated currency proved self-fulfilling, as anxious Argentines rushed to exchange Argentine australs for dollars. Inflation, a mere 7 percent in November, exploded to 40 percent in December when the Government was forced to devalue the austral to conserve its rapidly depleting stash of foreign exchange. And the Dec. 15 replacement of the conservative Economy Minister, Nestor Rapanelli, with Antonio Erman Gonzalez, a political crony of Mr. Menem, was widely seen as a sign that the President was retreating to the Peronist bunkers.
But the Menem administration again confounded the pundits. Mr. Erman Gonzalez reaffirmed the commitment to free markets by allowing the austral to float freely and removing vestiges of price controls.
 
A Radical Dollar Plan
Mr. Menem's advisers briefly considered a plan to ''dollarize'' the economy, a tactic that would have eliminated the Government's discretion to print money by making the United States dollar the legal currency of Argentina. Roughly four trillion australs were in circulation, while foreign currency in the Treasury totaled only $1 billion. Thus, speculators reasoned, the Government would buy back the australs at a rate of 4,000 to the dollar.
Anticipating the announcement, Argentines rushed to trade australs for dollars and drove the exchange rate, which had been about 1,000 australs to the dollar before Christmas, to 3,800 by New Year's weekend. Merchants jacked up prices accordingly.
Once again it was the Government's turn to surprise. Mr. Menem's breathtakingly radical response, reportedly devised by Foreign Minister Domingo Cavallo, a Harvard-trained economist, was to disable the engine of currency speculation.
Argentines, rich and not so rich, had grown accustomed to keeping most of their australs in interest-bearing seven-day savings certificates at banks. The banks, in turn, had lent the money to the Treasury to finance the national debt.
 
Converted Savings to Bonds
On Jan. 3, the Menem administration short-circuited the arrangement, converting all but a million australs of each depositor's savings into 10-year Government bonds with interest and principal guaranteed in dollars. The bonds can be used at face value to pay taxes. Yet because of widespread skepticism about the Government's ability to honor the dollar guarantee, they trade at less than half the face value on the free market. The conversion thus amounted to confiscation of financial assets worth close to $2 billion.
The immediate effect of the conversion was to reduce spending power. ''Money in people's pockets,'' Mr. Amadeo estimated, ''is just 30 percent of what it was before.'' That eliminates the pressure on prices -indeed, supermarket tabs fell by half or more in the week after the announcement. And it makes it almost impossible for Argentines to shift assets into other currencies. Perhaps most important, the freeze accomplished its goals without exacting sacrifice from those in greatest need. ''Poor laborers,'' Mr. del Carril noted, ''cannot afford bank C.D.'s.''
Less noticed, but of great significance, the freeze relieved the Government of a chronic burden on the budget, Mr. Cline said. While the internal national debt is relatively small, the Government had often paid as much as 200 percent a month in interest -far more than the inflation rate.
Now most of the money supply is locked in long-term bonds indexed to dollars, with interest payable at the international lending rate of about 8 percent a year. ''If they can institute the promised tax reform,'' said Mr. Cline, of the Institute for International Economics, ''the budget will not be far from balanced.''
But Mr. Menem and his advisers are hardly home free. It is one thing to stop an economy from veering out of control. It is quite another to coax shellshocked enterprises to return to the routines of buying and selling, of making contracts to deliver supplies at prices set months in advance. And the freeze has compounded the continuing uncertainties of operating in an economy that has been on the edge of hyperinflation for years.
No one really knows, for example, whether the economy can adjust smoothly to greatly diminished financial liquidity. Businesses must be able to borrow at less than extortionate rates to operate normally; consumers need cash in their pockets to make routine purchases. A reduction in money supply of comparable magnitude plunged the American economy into the Great Depression.
Argentines today are far more practiced at adapting to financial shocks than Americans were in the 1930's. Businesses and individuals do hold tens of billions in American dollars, which can legally be used as a substitute for scarce australs. Still, Argentines are unlikely to part easily with the one stable financial asset in their unstable world.
Once burned, Argentines will not voluntarily lend the Government more australs. ''The internal debt market is dead,'' says Martin Redrado, vice president of the International Merchant Bank in New York.
 
New Money or Borrowed Money
That limits the Government's options for covering future deficits to printing money or borrowing from abroad. The printing press option is really no option at all, since it would probably set off financial panic.
Reportedly, Mr. Menem's economists have already sounded out the Bush Administration for a loan. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are more plausible candidates to act as lenders of last resort, if only because they do not wish to be the messengers of doom for another democratically elected Argentine Government. But they will have to be convinced that Mr. Menem can quickly balance the budget.
That leaves President Menem with the task of putting Argentines on a crash fiscal diet, while simultaneously moving forward with the reforms needed to make private enterprise competitive. Nothing in Argentina's history suggests that the nation is up to the challenge.
But as one Argentine businessman points out, nothing in the country's history would have indicated Mr. Menem's transformation from Peronist good old boy to resourceful economic pragmatist.
The best analogy, this businessman suggests, is President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. Both are skillful politicians, unencumbered by ideology, who are willing to make unorthodox alliances. Each faces daunting economic problems armed one great weapon: the widespread sense that failure would be a disaster for almost everyone.

HEADLINE: Overseas Tool Sales Are Pushed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Troubled by the slump in the auto industry and competition from the Japanese, makers of machine tools have been looking to new businesses and markets overseas, particularly in Western and Eastern Europe.
Analysts and executives say it is too early to tell how successful the manufacturers have been, and some of them say the efforts will never be able to offset the downturn in automotive orders. But there have been notable accomplishments, they say.
Litton Industries' machinery unit, for example, has been winning contracts with manufacturers in Europe and has a nearly $200 million backlog for machine tools used in making engines, transmissions and brake systems for Ford Motor in Britain. Cincinnati Milacron Inc. has been seeking business from the aerospace industry. And Giddings & Lewis Inc. has become more aggressive in its sales efforts overseas, looking to drum up business in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. 
 
Growth Abroad Is Stronger
''Demand for machine tools is growing at a quicker pace in Western Europe, Japan and in newly developed economies than in the United States,'' said John F. Townsend, vice president of planning and business development for Giddings & Lewis. ''And we hope to take advantage of that.''
The Association for Manufacturing Technology reported yesterday that new orders for machine tool products dropped 22 percent last year, to $2.81 billion. And several analysts estimate that new orders will fall another 14 percent, to about $2.4 billion, this year. That would be down significantly from the peak of $3.6 billion in 1988, but much better than the levels in 1986 and 1987, when orders sagged to around $2.1 billion.
Power-driven machine tools cut or shape metal parts used in a wide array of products, from appliances and vehicles to aircraft and construction materials. The strength in machine-tool orders generally reflects strength in industrial production.
 
A Large Backlog
The immediate impact of smaller orders from the automobile industry is negligible because machine-tool makers are still working at close to capacity to fill a fattened backlog. Indeed, shipments of machine tools were up 33 percent last year, an indication that production has been humming. Order backlogs at the end of the year totaled $1.8 billion, That figure is up sharply from the $1.2 billion at the beginning of 1988.
Auto makers, which have historically accounted for about a third of the nation's machine-tool orders, have responded to slumping sales by slowing production and deferring some capital spending.
As a result, makers of machine tools are now looking more to other industries, particularly aerospace, as well as abroad, particularly to Western Europe, where demand for machinery has been stronger recently.
For example, Giddings & Lewis, a producer of high-precision machine tools based in Fond du Lac, Wis., sold more than $1.5 million worth of boring mills and drill point grinders to the Soviet Union last year. ''Things are opening up in Eastern Europe and we hope to take advantage of that,'' said John F. Townsend, vice president of the company's planning and business development.
He said Giddings & Lewis's overseas sales climbed 15 percent last year. ''We feel we've had a breakthrough,'' he said.
 
Aerospace Business Climbs
Cincinnati Milacron, the nation's third-largest machine tool maker, has been looking to the aerospace industry to offset automotive orders, which typically account for 20 percent of its business.
''Our aerospace orders are up to 30 percent of our business from 20 percent last year,'' said Daniel J. Meyer, the president. ''We can see a continuing good demand for machine tools in the aerospace sector, in both the commercial and defense side.''
But many analysts are cautious. ''Exports are still only a small part of the market, maybe about 5 percent,'' said Walter F. Carter, vice president of DRI/McGraw Hill. ''So the export efforts will help, but only partially.''
 
Japanese Moving In
Another problem facing American tool makers is the increased number of Japanese machine-tool companies with operations in this country. Figures from the Japan Economic Institute indicate that the number has grown to 36, from 17 before 1987. The Association for Manufacturing Technology said it had no figures on the market penetration of Japanese tool makers in the United States. But analysts say the impact has been noticeable.
''The Japanese machine tool companies are making headway here,'' said James J. Paper, an analyst at Kirkpatrick, Pettis, Smith, Polian of Omaha. ''They are here to serve the Japanese auto companies that have operations in the United States and there is a great deal of loyalty on the part of Japanese auto companies toward Japanese machine tool companies.''
Mr. Meyer and other American machine tool executives hope that big backlogs will keep them busy and that many of the stalled spending programs in the auto industry will be started again within months. They also hope that new Government emissions standards will be detailed by this summer, prompting auto manufacturers to begin ordering tools to make new engines.
 
Concern About Japan
''We expect the current market conditions to have very little impact on our business,'' said James A. Egbert, president of the Cross Company, a unit of the Cross & Trecker Corporation, in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.
Mr. Egbert said his company expects the downturn to be short, adding that he is optimistic about the prospects for the long term. Still, he said, he is concerned about the American auto makers' loss of market share to Japanese producers.
Some analysts consider attitudes like Mr. Egbert's overly optimistic. ''I know that the general expectation is that the automotive industry will probably resume new orders by the second half of the year,'' said Mr. Carter of DRI/McGraw Hill. ''But automobile companies change their plans very abruptly.''
Mr. Carter suggested that machine tool companies would be better off ''improving quality and marketing heavily elsewhere and in other industries.''
But moves into other industries are easier said than done, particularly for companies without a substantial foothold in those industries. ''You're not going to be a reliable supplier to the aerospace industry unless you are a regular supplier to the aerospace industry,'' said E. Kidder Meade, vice president for Litton Industrial Automation.
Indeed, machine tool makers, whose memories of the depressed conditions in the early 1980's are still vivid, say the best insurance against a downturn in the industry is to keep their operations as lean as possible. Despite Cross & Trecker's optimism, the company's chief executive, Norman J. Ryker, plans to lower costs by 5 percent this year.
''These cycles are intrinsic in the nature of the business we're in,'' Mr. Meade said. ''If you're going to survive in this business, you can do a lot of things. But you basically have to have flexibility in your production. You have to control costs and operate as lean an operation as possible.''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Corporate Pullback That's Rattling Stocks

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Corporate America, one of the biggest buyers of shares during the boom years of the 1980's on Wall Street, is apparently pulling back, contributing to the stock market's recent weakness.
American companies spent hundreds of billions of dollars in recent years buying other corporations and buying their own stock. But now, with the pace of corporate takeovers slowing and company profits declining, there are increasing signs that corporations will no longer purchase shares with abandon.
This apparent retreat has worried Wall Street and has played a big role in the recent stock market fall. With the Dow Jones industrial average off 5.85 points yesterday, to 2,553.38, it is now down 9 percent from the peak of 2,810.15 it reached on Jan. 2. 
''The support that corporations provided in the past is no longer there,'' said Carmine Grigoli, chief portfolio strategist for First Boston.
 
Concern Is Understandable
The concern on Wall Street is understandable. Last year, for example, American corporations were the main force behind the 27 percent rise in share prices, purchasing over $100 billion worth of shares more than they sold, Goldman, Sachs estimates. By contrast, American financial institutions and individual investors sold more shares than they bought.
Rising interest rates around the world, brought on by inflation fears in West Germany and Japan, have also been an important cause of the market's weakness. Those rates stabilized in recent days, helping to stem the decline on Wall Street at least temporarily.
Other forces cited by analysts as contributing to the slippage include concerns about higher oil prices and falling corporate profits as the economy slows.
 
Buyers Must Be Willing
But in the end, share prices rise when buyers are willing to buy, and decline when they are not. And the prospect of corporations pulling back as a major buying force could well hurt prices considerably.
Yet it could also help to slow, or perhaps reverse, the trend toward an ever-growing level of debt for American companies, because much of the corporate share-buying was financed with borrowed money. A lightened debt burden would give American companies a more sturdy financial foundation, making them better able to compete with foreign companies and more likely to survive a recession.
For generations, it was taken for granted that corporations would normally be sellers of stock, as they issued shares to finance expansion and to pay for takeovers. But as debt-financed takeovers became much more common during the 1980's, many companies began to buy their own shares as an act of defense, hoping that by keeping share prices relatively high they would discourage raiders.
In 1988, according to Federal Reserve figures, all corporations bought $118 billion more in stock than they issued. For the first nine months of last year, the annual rate was about $129 billion. But Mr. Grigoli said he believed that slowed in the final quarter, for which Government figures are not yet available. The pace of announced mergers, he estimated, was down 35 percent in the October-December period from the pace early in the year.
In 1990, Mr. Grigoli forecasts, American corporations will be net buyers of only about $50 billion worth of shares, less than half last year's level.
With the ''junk bond'' market all but closed to new issuers, many companies have less to fear from raiders, so they need not be eager to buy their own shares to increase their stock price. ''There will be less pressure on corporate managers to maximize shareholder value,'' said Leon G. Cooperman, chief executive of the asset management division at Goldman, Sachs.
In addition, corporate profits have been declining since early last year, according to Commerce Department figures, reducing the available cash companies have on hand for buying their shares or for other purposes.
It is not easy to trace corporate buybacks of shares. Some companies do not announce purchases, except after long delays, and some announce plans for purchases but do not follow through. But in January, Laszlo Birinyi, head of a market analysis firm that bears his name, said, ''There have been very few announcements.''
The trend toward corporate repurchases of shares began in the 1970's, when pioneers like Teledyne Inc. made major buybacks despite criticism that such purchases left the companies financially weaker and amounted to an admission by a management that it had no better investment available to it.
But by the mid-1980's, those repurchases were much more fashionable. The culmination may have come last fall, when the International Business Machines Corporation announced two repurchase plans, totaling $5 billion, and the General Electric Company said it would buy back $10 billion worth of shares over five years.
Some analysts say companies will keep buying shares even if the volume is reduced. ''There are still strategic takeovers,'' noted John D. Connolly, chairman of the investment policy committee at Dean Witter Reynolds, pointing to the pending attempt by Georgia-Pacific to acquire Great Northern Nekoosa. He added that ''the market for new issues of corporate equity securities is not the best'' and concluded, ''We will see less supply of stock.'' Mr. Connolly said the recent retreat of stock prices has been overdone and created a buying opportunity.
But there are signs that corporate America, which is more heavily indebted now than after any other economic expansion, may be forced to return to issuing shares even if the market is not receptive. Companies like Shearson Lehman Hutton and First Interstate Banks are now trying to sell stock because they need the extra capital.
Over all, according to calculations by Merrill Lynch, interest payments ate up 25.2 percent of corporate cash flow in the third quarter of last year, a record level. Until last year, the record was 22.7 percent, set in the third quarter of 1974, when cash flow had been severely reduced by a recession. Just how high the figure would go in a new recession is not clear, but the fact that corporate balance sheets are so laden with debt is likely to restrain stock buybacks.
No one knows the extent to which recent share repurchases have been motivated by fear of raiders, as opposed to a genuine management belief that the shares were a good investment. But it is clear that many raiders who could have obtained financing to go after a company six months ago could not raise the cash to do so now. That motivation is clearly reduced.
In the long run, there is no need for companies to buy shares to have a bull market. Both individuals and institutional investors now have a smaller proportion of their assets in stocks than they did two decades ago. If they decide to return to those levels, that could more than offset the reduction of demand from corporations to buy stocks. But such a change is not likely to happen quickly.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Cutting the Cost Of Medicaid Drugs

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
THE pharmaceutical industry is fighting growing pressure to reduce the prices of prescription drugs used by low-income Americans in the financially pressed Federal-state Medicaid programs. Medicaid officials said spending on prescription drugs rose last year by 12 percent, to $3.87 billion, from $3.45 billion in 1988.
Medicaid officials in 37 states are discussing or preparing measures that would try to force the companies to negotiate on prices for patent-protected drugs, a recent survey by the Senate Aging Committee found. In most cases, the manufacturers have successfully resisted, even persuading legislatures in a number of states to outlaw efforts by Medicare officials to gain negotiating leverage by approving some drugs and rejecting others. 
Some states have tried to establish lists of Medicaid-approved drugs known as formularies, like the lists used by most university teaching hospitals and many health maintenance organizations. Committees of doctors and pharmacists would decide which drugs produce similar effects in most patients. The drugs would then be put out for bid, and only the least expensive in each therapeutic group would be approved.
In Kansas, for example, Medicaid pays for only one brand of a potassium supplement, rejecting a dozen other products commonly prescribed for heart patients taking diuretics. Medicaid officials said that after requesting bids from manufacturers, the program chose K-Norm, made by the Fisons Corporation. The program pays about $7 per hundred, compared with at least $10 before.
The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group, is strongly opposed. The industry says individual reactions to drugs vary, so all medications should remain available to everyone. Bruce J. Brennan, the association's general counsel and senior vice president, argued that even the most expensive drugs save money in the end by reducing spending for doctors and hospitals. Restricting the choice of drugs, he said, would mean ''second-class medicine for Medicaid patients.''
The drug companies have won legislative battles in recent years blocking restrictions in Utah, South Carolina and Louisiana. Two Louisiana State University economists, William J. Moore and Robert J. Newman, said a survey of 47 states showed that Medicare spending was up to 15 percent higher in states that had restrictive formularies.
But RaeDell Ashley, a Medicaid program director in Utah, said spending on prescription drugs in her state ''escalated right off the charts'' when Utah eliminated its restricted list in 1985. She said Medicaid spending on drugs soared from $6 million in 1984 to $15 million last year. There was ''no change in hospital and physician costs'' that could be attributed to the change in drug policy, she said.
The pharmaceutical industry is backing bills to ban Medicaid drug restrictions in Tennessee, Kansas, Missouri and Colorado.
Last week, the struggle shifted to Congress. Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who heads the Aging Committee, said drugs that cost less are often as effective as costlier products.
''While new drug prices are pegged an average of 49 percent above the price of drugs they replace,'' he said, ''the Food and Drug Administration finds that 60 to 80 percent of them offer little or no therapeutic advantage.'' In a reply to the committee, the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association said there was no agreement among doctors and pharmacists about the interchangeability of some drugs. ''Leading physicians and pharmacists reject this notion because of individual differences among patients,'' the association said.
Senator Pryor said he would introduce a bill to establish a Federal drug ''formulary'' to be used by state buying groups in negotiating drug prices with manufacturers. To placate doctors who oppose restrictions that could keep them from picking a drug that a particular patient might need, Senator Pryor's bill would permit them to prescribe drugs not listed in the formulary. Doctors would do so by writing ''medically necessary'' on prescriptions.
Dr. Ray W. Gifford, a member of the American Medical Association board of trustees, said he would not object if the procedure for exceptions was simple and did not ''make the physician jump through hoops.'' The Cleveland Clinic, where he is a specialist in hypertension, has a formulary, he said, but ''it doesn't restrict us very much.''
The Pryor proposal revives a plan for a Federal drug formulary that was part of the ill-fated law that would have added payments for drugs to the Medicare program for the elderly and disabled and expanded coverage for catastrophic illnesses. The law was repealed last year when many elderly Americans objected to being taxed to pay for it.
Some members of Congress complained then that they had been misled by estimates understating the costs of adding a drug benefit to Medicare. By calling attention to drug prices, which have been outrunning overall inflation for a number of years, the Medicare battle may have improved the prospects for restricting drugs in Medicaid.

HEADLINE: Income Up For Month And Year

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The personal income of Americans grew at a modest annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in December and spending grew at twice that rate, the Commerce Department said today.
For the year, personal incomes rose by 9 percent after a 7.6 percent increase in 1988. It was the largest annual increase since 1984, when incomes went up by 9.5 percent. 
The December increase in income was the smallest since a two-tenths of 1 percent rate rise in August. Economists said today's report was encouraging amid widespread concern about a slowing economy.
 
October-November Gains
Personal income rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent each in October and November.
''I don't think we're going to see consumers folding up, and that's going to keep us out of recession,'' said Marin Mauro, a senior economist with Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
Personal savings declined in December, to 5.6 percent of disposable income, from 6.2 percent in November.
The low rate of savings has been a longstanding worry for economists, because it forces the Federal Government to look abroad for money to cover the Federal deficit.
Spending by consumers accounts for about two-thirds of total economic output. In December, the rate of increase rose to 1 percent, from three-tenths of 1 percent in each of the two previous months. It was the fastest monthly rate of increase since August.
 
Harsh Winter Weather
Mr. Mauro said extreme winter weather in December played a role by raising fuel purchases and prices. Spending for home heating, including for fuel oil, electricity and natural gas, jumped by $15 billion, after a $3 billion increase in November.
But spending on durable goods, items expected to last three years or more, also rose in December, after falling in November, a sign of economic strength.
Incentives offered by automobile companies late last year helped revive sales modestly, Mr. Mauro said. Durables purchases increased in December by $6.7 billion, after falling by $2.8 billion in November.
On Friday, the Commerce Department said the nation's gross national product, or total output of goods and services, expanded only at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the final three months of last year, partly because of weaker consumer spending in the quarter.
The Bush Administration is forecasting continued moderate economic growth. Most private forecasters expect the United States to avoid recession but anticipate a weak first half of this year.
Personal incomes last month were helped by a return to work following settlement of strikes at the Boeing Company, the Seattle-based aircraft maker, and in the telephone industry, the department said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Light Trading After Drop in Stock Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against major foreign currencies in light trading yesterday in reaction to a drop in stock prices.
Gold prices also slipped. At the Commodity Exchange in New York, an ounce of gold fell $1, to $419.10. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $418.20 an ounce, down $1.80 from Friday. 
Dealers said the dollar began trading higher in New York after it lost strength overnight on overseas markets, where the West German mark rose against the dollar in reaction to an announcement of earlier elections in East Germany and an easing of tension in Soviet Azerbaijan.
But then stock prices fell on Wall Street, sending the dollar lower.
Recent economic reports that indicate the American economy is sluggish also worked against the dollar, said Robert Hatcher, a dealer with Barclays Bank P.L.C.
''I think it is resurrecting the fear within the dealer community of possible easing down the road,'' he said, referring to the possibility of the Federal Reserve's acting on interest rates. Lower interest rates would make the dollar less attractive to overseas investors.
The Government reported yesterday that consumer spending in 1989 posted its largest increase in three years and personal incomes rose 9 percent last year, but the reports had little effect on the dollar, traders said.
Charles A. Spence, a vice president at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles, said currency dealers were awaiting the release tomorrow of the Commerce Department's leading indicators for December, which should give further evidence on the direction of the economy.
''They're looking for slightly positive numbers,'' he said.
Earlier, dealers overseas said a few large orders had an exaggerated impact on the dollar because volume was thin with Hong Kong and Singapore closed for the Lunar New Year holiday.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.75 yen, to 143.22 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 143.15 yen. In New York, the dollar closed lower still, at 142.98 yen, but up from Friday's close of 142.80 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.6775, from $1.6571 late Friday. In New York, it strengthened further to $1.6810, up from $1.6635 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday rates, included: 1.6770 West German marks, down from 1.6865; 1.4815 Swiss francs, down from 1.4900; 5.6950 French francs, down from 5.7290; 1,248.00 Italian lire, down from 1,254.50, and 1.1871 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1966.
Gold dipped in London to $418.50 an ounce, from $418.75 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold finished at $418.50, unchanged from late Friday.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Management School Shifts With Times

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
FEW graduate schools of business can keep current with world economic and political trends just by analyzing their student rosters, but the Management Education Institute Inc. in Cambridge, Mass., can do just that. The reason: more than 95 percent of its students come from abroad to study for a master of science degree in management, which is earned over 11 months.
Dr. Kenneth L. Hoadley, the dean of M.E.I., which celebrated its 25th anniversary several months ago, commented last week, ''Originally, most students were civil servants from West Africa, financed by their home government or by agencies like the World Bank, United Nations and Usaid,'' the United States Agency for International Development.
With more limited funds available to African governments, the number of Africans attending has dropped to 6 percent of the class of 1990, from 57 percent of the class of 1980. Today, Asians and Latin Americans dominate, with 45 percent from Asia, mostly Japanese, compared with 13 percent a decade ago, and 32 percent from Latin America, compared with 4 percent 10 years ago. 
The change reflects many students coming from regions where private business is growing rapidly. Nowadays, private employers pay tuition for 36 percent of the students, compared with 15 percent a decade ago, while 47 percent of the students pay their own way, compared with only 19 percent in 1980, an indication that some own or want to own businesses.
''Even though we continue to enroll a similar number of Usaid-sponsored participants as we did a decade ago, they are more likely to work in the private sector than in government service,'' Liz A. Reisberg, a school spokeswoman, explained.
About 13 percent of the current class of 53 students are women, compared with 8 percent of the 1980 class of 47 students. The roster also reflects a political change: In the 1970's, the Iranian Government sent students, including women. Now, no Iranian students study at the school.
The curriculum has changed to meet the new needs of students. Electives like agribusiness and public administration that had been popular now find less favor than courses with titles like management technology, managing for quality, and starting and managing a small business.
Besides mirroring economic and political changes, M.E.I. has another unusual claim to fame: It is the only American graduate school of business operated by a private company, the worldwide management consulting firm of Arthur D. Little. Like most leading educational centers in Massachusetts, it is accredited by the New England Association of Schools and Colleges. The faculty includes professors from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Tufts and Northeastern Universities and Babson College, as well as experts from Little, assuring a combination of the academic and the pragmatic.
Students, 31 years old on average, must have undergraduate degrees. They take core courses typical of an master in business administration program, like accounting, financial management and economics, and then choose from electives. Students also take field trips that require written analyses. This year, outings will focus on two industries, agribusiness and tourism. As an example, students on the agribusiness tour will visit a supermarket, a food processor, a large commercial farm, a seed research organization and the Chicago Board of Trade for an overview of the food industry.
Tuition is $17,250, plus $1,000 for books, materials and field trips, plus whatever it costs for rent and food. But a typical two-year graduate business school program probably would cost twice as much. In all, the school has 1,200 alumni worldwide. Another 1,200 have taken its executive education programs.
Dr. Hoadley, 43 years old and dean for almost four years, graduated from Colby College, in Waterville, Me. He spent his junior year in Mexico. After Colby came three years in the Peace Corps in Latin America, working in an agrarian program. ''While in Colombia, I realized management was the missing factor in my education,'' he said.
That led him back to New England, where he obtained an M.B.A. degree and a doctorate from the Harvard Business School. Before the dean's job, he served as an associate dean and administrator at a business school in Costa Rica. He and his wife, who is Nicaraguan, speak Spanish at home to make sure their children stay bilingual. And bilingualism is a must for M.E.I. students, since teaching is in English. The students come from 25 countries.

HEADLINE: RECESSION CHANCES HAVE DIMINISHED, GREENSPAN INSISTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, told Congress today that the chance of an imminent recession has diminished markedly since spring and that the nation's current slow growth is likely to prove only a ''temporary hesitation.''
Mr. Greenspan's remarks appeared to dampen hopes that the Federal Reserve would soon move to cut interest rates further.
The Federal Reserve chairman made his comments to the Joint Economic Committee of Congress in the first of several appearances in the next few weeks on Capitol Hill to discuss the economic outlook and the central bank's monetary strategy.
 
Consistent With Earlier Views
His remarks were consistent with the reported views earlier this month of two fellow Federal Reserve governors, who suggested that with inflation running at about 4.5 percent, the economy was not weak enough to warrant fresh infusions of credit to head off a possible recession. Additional credit could ease interest rates but would risk making inflation worse. The Fed has taken several steps since last spring to lower interest rates in an effort to support the economy. 
Surprisingly for a Fed chairman, Mr. Greenspan attached specific figures to the prospects for additional gains by an economy that has now entered its eighth year of uninterrupted expansion. Federal Reserve chiefs, including Mr. Greenspan, tend to speak in Delphic generalities because of the way markets hang on each utterance, and they like to keep their options open.
 
Wouldn't 'Bet the Ranch'
He said today that by one gauge the chances of recession in the next six months are about 20 percent, down from 30 percent last spring, and that by another gauge the chances have fallen to about 10 percent.
Both of these probabilities, Mr. Greenspan observed, ''are much smaller than those occurring at the beginning of each of the four recessions'' of the last 20 years, the last of which was in 1981 and 1982.
''I wouldn't want to bet the ranch on such statistical measures,'' Mr. Greenspan added in a statement prepared for the committee. ''But such imbalances and dislocations as we see in the economy today probably do not suggest anything more than a temporary hesitation in the continuing expansion.''
When asked directly why interest rates remain relatively high, Mr. Greenspan said this was mainly because long-term inflation expectations remain high. This, he said, affects rates whether or not they are adjusted for inflation.
On Friday, the Commerce Department reported that the gross national product grew by a meager five-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989, the weakest performance since a 1.8 percent decline in output three and a half years ago. This was a sluggish rate even allowing for the strike at the Boeing Company and exceptionally harsh December weather.
Mr. Greenspan said the Federal Reserve's estimate of a 20 percent possibility of a recession was derived from the Commerce Department's index of leading indicators, a monthly tabulation of 11 economic and financial variables. Federal Reserve statisticians compared recent movements with the patterns just before and during recessions and then expressed their findings in terms of probability.
The leading index, which declined three-tenths of 1 percent in October, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in November. It is expected to show a modest rise when the December reading is published on Wednesday.
The Fed's second reading - which showed a 10 percent chance of recession - is based on a predictive index developed recently by the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private group that has become a quasi-official arbiter of recessions. That index relies less on manufacturing performance than does the Commerce Department index and does not include stock prices, another factor in the leading indicators.
 
Softness in Durable Goods
Over all, Mr. Greenspan said, much of the recent softness in the economy is concentrated in durable goods, or items that last more than three years. That category indicated that weakness in motor vehicles had been spreading to metals, textiles, machine tools and related supplier industries. In addition, he said, various capital goods and consumer hard goods, as well as construction, had softened of late.
But durable goods should rebound after a pause, he said, and softness in housing prices ''is unlikely to prove highly contagious.''
Mr. Greenspan said that demand for durable goods is still growing in some sectors, especially civilian aircraft, and that there had been no speculative building up of inventories or cyclical upswings in either inflation or inflation psychology. Foreign demand for American goods, moreover, ''remains sizable,'' he said, and the economy continues to generate healthy numbers of new jobs.
In the credit markets, prices of Treasury bonds fell and interest rates rose as news reports of the Fed chairman's testimony flashed across trading screens, although bond prices finished the day higher because of other factors.
The timing of Mr. Greenspan's comments was considered noteworthy because the Fed's main policymaking body, the Federal Open Market Committee, is to meet next Tuesday and Wednesday to set monetary strategy for the year. The results of these deliberations, which involve the six sitting Fed governors - the seventh nomination is pending - and 12 presidents of regional Fed banks, are scheduled to be first disclosed before a House subcommittee on Feb. 20.
Since there is always at least some division among the participants, who meet eight times a year, Mr. Greenspan's comments may have reflected, at least in part, a desire to stake out his position before the important meeting. The February and July meetings each year lead to formal reports to Congress on the economic outlook and the Fed's strategic plan.
While Fed chairmen nearly always dominate internal policy discussions, the anti-inflation emphasis implied in Mr. Greenspan's comments found strong support from W. Lee Hoskins, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and one of the committee's 12 voting members. Mr. Hoskins, who contends that the Fed's goal should be to reach zero inflation, said in a speech today in Columbus, Ohio, that ''threats of recession should not interfere with the long-run goal of price stability because price stability actually reduces the risk of recession and is a pro-growth policy.''
In response to questions from the panel, Mr. Greenspan minimized recent apparent differences with the Bush Administration over interest rates. He said the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, used ''looser'' language than he would have liked in appealing for lower rates, but the Fed chairman said he saw nothing inappropriate in the sentiment and did not believe that the Administration was ''bashing us.''
Earlier this month, when the latest statistics on consumer prices were released, Mr. Fitzwater said inflation was ''under control,'' suggesting that this meant the Federal Reserve could afford to ease monetary policy further to prevent the economy from slipping into a recession. The next day, in an address to the nation's homebuilders, President Bush hailed the broad decline in home mortgage rates in the 1980's and suggested that rates should be lowered further.
The statements by both Mr. Fitzwater and the President, however, were considered mild compared with the sharp attacks on the Fed by officials in previous administrations when the economy was flagging in an election year.
 
Defends Bush Budget Plan
Mr. Greenspan gave these responses to other questions from committee members:
* He defended the Bush budget plan, which he said would produce a deficit ''not all that far'' from Gramm-Rudman targets if spending cuts are achieved.
* He said that no ''grand compromise'' of tax increases and spending cuts was needed because the financial markets would respond favorably to spending cuts alone.
* He implied that two fellow governors, the vice chairman, Manuel H. Johnson, and Wayne D. Angell, may have ''crossed a very fine line'' in discussing monetary strategy with journalists. At the same time, however, he credited financial journalists with a ''dramatically'' improved ability to interpret subtle Fed statements.
In a report in The Wall Street Journal on Jan. 18, the two Fed governors indicated in interviews that they would probably not favor easing credit for now because various economic indicators were looking better than last year.

HEADLINE: But Is the Child Learning? Schools Trying New Tests

BYLINE: By EDWARD B. FISKE

 BODY:
John Mangini, a biology teacher at Kennedy High School in Waterbury, Conn., recently gave his students some live brine shrimp instead of a test. Or, rather, the shrimp were the test.
The students were told to determine the best saltwater solution for keeping the shrimp alive to mail them to a cousin with an aquarium in another state. ''They had to design their own experiment, figure out the salinity and test their hypothesis,'' said Mr. Mangini.
In that small way, he joined a growing effort in American education to find better ways to test students and evaluate the performance of teachers and schools. 
 
Book Knowledge and Reality
New approaches include hands-on science tests - like Mr. Mangini's - aimed at determining whether students can apply book knowledge to concrete situations, and the grading of portfolios of student work in writing, math and other subjects, to show academic growth over a period of time.
Such methods may not always be startlingly new in themselves, but their widening use in determining grades reflects a sense that the multiple-choice and other standardized tests now used to evaluate students are overly simplistic and distort education.
Critics say teachers, under pressure to make their students do well on standardized tests, waste valuable time teaching test-taking skills, or topics specific to a particular test.
''We need assessment devices that measure what we think is most important for students to learn,'' said Eva Baker, director of the Center for Research on Evaluation, Standards and Student Testing at the University of California at Los Angeles.
 
A Multimillion-Dollar Task
For all their faults, multiple-choice tests are efficient and economical, and finding alternatives is likely to be complex and expensive.
''You're talking about changing fundamental educational techniques and values,'' said Grant Wiggins, a consultant who has worked with school districts on new ways to test. ''And if the decision is made to build a national testing program, you're talking about tens of millions of dollars.''
Instead of tests on writing at the end of a semester, some English teachers in California now require portfolios of students' writing, including successive drafts of the same work. Schools in Connecticut and Vermont are experimenting with portfolios in math and science.
The goal is to measure what students can do over a period of time, not what they know on the day of a particular test.
''We are at a major turning point in how we think about educational assessment,'' said Richard P. Mills, Vermont's Commissioner of Education.
Since the early 20th century, the first pillar of accountability has been a tightly controlled bureaucracy. State education departments pick textbooks, design curriculums and certify teachers. The assumption is that such steps will produce good education. Educators who follow prescribed procedures rarely face discipline. ''No teacher ever lost her job just because students were not learning,'' said Mr. Mills.
 
Reaction Against Traditions
An important measure of how students fare is standardized tests of two basic skills, reading and mathematics. Since newspapers routinely publish school-by-school results, these tests are important in shaping public attitudes toward public schools.
Largely because of business and political leaders' doubts about the quality of American schools, the last few years have produced a reaction against the traditional ways of fixing responsibility. ''If you blame the system, then no particular person or group is accountable,'' said Mr. Wiggins.
Standardized multiple-choice tests have drawn increasing fire as too simplistic, measuring the ability to recognize knowledge rather than the ability to think and solve problems, an important skill in today's jobs.
''It's testing for the TV generation - superficial and passive,'' said Linda Darling-Hammond, a professor at Teacher's College of Columbia University. ''We don't ask if students can synthesize information, solve problems or think independently. We measure what they can recognize.''
 
The 'Holistic' Approach
Meanwhile, like big corporations, many school systems have been decentralizing management and giving teachers a larger role in deciding things like curriculum design. As a result, teachers are trying out new learning theories. In English, for instance, they now emphasize a ''holistic'' approach: students are judged on how effectively they handle longer passages of literature and writing and editing numerous drafts of essays.
 
The Trend Toward Portfolios
Perhaps the most promising new procedure for making such judgments is the use of collections of student work, the portfolios, which are already common in art and other fields in which teaching leads to a demonstrable product.
California is experimenting with writing portfolios in 12 districts. In one, Winfield Cooper, an English teacher at Torrey Pines High School in La Jolla, Calif., makes her students develop portfolios that include writing in the style of James Joyce or Mark Twain as well as writing a piece of original fiction. The students must then write an introduction to the portfolio that tells what they have learned about themselves as writers. ''We were amazed at what we saw,'' said Ms. Cooper. ''These weren't just the honor students.''
In Connecticut, a new high school mathematics and science assessment, to take effect the 1991-92 school year, measures performance on series of tasks that may take students as long as a semester.
 
Studying Projectile Motion
In New York, students in Sidney Fiarman's math-science class at the Central Park Secondary School in East Harlem have been studying the motion of projectiles. Each student was told to select some sort of moving object, learn the rules for calculating its motion and then demonstrate what he or she had found to the class.
Kelly Ross, a 10th grader, chose a basketball free throw. She put the math on the blackboard and then took her peers to the gymnasium for a demonstration. Once she has taken a pencil-and-paper test to show that she can apply what she learned to other situations and once she has defended her work before faculty members, she will receive a grade.
Miss Ross, who is 16 years old, said she sometimes felt self-conscious in front of her classmates but added, ''It's nice to have the chance to figure things out for yourselves and not have to run to an adult every time you don't know something.''
 
On Grading of Portfolios
The new approaches pose numerous problems, many of them technical. A major attraction of standardized test questions is the single right answer that a machine can translate into a score. But how do you grade portfolios?
Proponents say setting up a scoring system for such work - a scale of one to six, for example - is no more complicated than judgments made in athletic competitions like diving. ''Just because something is subjective doesn't mean that it can't be quantified,'' said Marc Tucker, president of the National Center for Education and the Economy.
Major designers of tests have developed ways of of training various evaluators to arrive at judgments on the quality of writing samples on examinations like the Scholastic Aptitude Test.
Evaluating portfolios and samples of writing is also far more time-consuming and costly than running score-sheets through a computer. Proponents say that when an entire school system is being judged, the costs can be kept down by testing a scientific sample of students rather than each student. ''You're evaluating an educational system, not individual students,'' said Lauren Resnick, a professor of education at the University of Pittsburgh.
 
Between Instruction and Testing
The current movement is seeking tests whose exercises more closely resemble the learning objectives. Critics of the current system say, for instance, that teachers frequently ''teach to the test'' in ways that undermine overall learning - for instance, by drilling their students on multiple-choice tests about writing rather than giving them practice in real writing.
To avoid such situations, California has added open-ended questions -questions difficult to answer by guessing - in the 12th grade math test. The idea is to make teaching to the test a virtue by changing the nature of the test.
 
Stressing 'Important Things'
Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, says a new accountability system must hinge on ''measuring important things.''
''There are no standardized tests in writing, so you don't have these annual things each year which say our district is above average in writing,'' he said. ''The same is true of science.''
Another issue is whether the United States should develop a national system of testing with some of the new techniques. For more than two decades the federally supported National Assessment of Educational Progress has been sampling the reading, math and other skills of schoolchildren. Congress recently authorized increasing the number of samples, for the first state-by-state comparisons of student achievement. The program will also begin collecting new kinds of information, including writing portfolios.
This month the President's Education Policy Advisory Committee recommended to President Bush that the national assessment program be expanded to permit the testing of every 9-, 13- and 17-year-old.
The National Governors' Association is working with the White House to draft such goals. ''If you're going to have a performance-oriented assessment system, you'd better have a serious discussion of what it is that you want students to be able to perform,'' said Mr. Tucker. ''And if you're going to have serious goals, you'd better have serious tests.''
