HEADLINE: U.S. and Laos Are Getting Friendlier

BYLINE: By HENRY KAMM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENTIANE, Laos

 BODY:
The Communist leaders of Laos want better relations with the United States and American economic aid, and the United States appears ready to respond.
In separate interviews, Prime Minister Kaysone Phomvihan, who is also the Communist Party leader, and Acting President Phoumi Vongvichit both asserted that Laos wanted to turn the page on the past, in which the Laotian Communists warred against the American-supported royal Government and the United States heavily bombed this country and organized and sustained a clandestine Laotian army.
Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan, in his first interview with an American journalist in the 15 years that he has ruled Laos, said, ''Lately relations between the two countries have made some progress, after some delay.''
The Laotian leader referred to a little-publicized American project agreed to last Sept. 30. It was the first United States development aid to Vietnam, Laos or Cambodia since the Communist victories in those countries in 1975. 
 
Anti-Drug Accord
The agreement was signed in this most reclusive of Indochina's capitals and not announced in Washington. It was followed in January with another first, the signing of an agreement for American-Laotian cooperation in fighting the narcotics trade.
The mountainous regions of Laos are prime opium-growing areas, and some is refined into heroin in illicit Laotian laboratories.
The $8.7 million development project signed last year was linked to the accord on anti-drug cooperation, since its goal is to persuade nomadic mountain tribespeople in two remote northeastern districts to substitute other cash crops for opium, their traditional money-earner.
The districts are part of Houaphan Province, where, during the Vietnam War, Laotian Communist leaders like Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan and Mr. Phoumi Vongvichit lived in caves to escape years of heavy American bombing. So intense was the air war that peasants stayed in their caves by daylight and tilled their fields only at night. Sam Neua, the provincial capital, was the headquarters of what Communists called the ''liberated zone.''
The project, which is scheduled to take six years to complete, provides for the building of roads and irrigation dams, establishing communications links and extending agricultural, public-health and educational services.
A Western ambassador said the development program had been submitted earlier to the European Community and Australia, but they declined to undertake it, saying major gains in the anti-narcotics effort would be too difficult to achieve.
The diplomat added that the United States probably held a similar view, but had agreed to provide the aid for the political reason of moving toward a resumption of normal relations with Laos; such a step could presage normalized relations with Vietnam.
 
Ties Maintained
The United States has never interrupted diplomatic relations with Laos, as it has with Vietnam and Cambodia. It maintains an embassy, run by a charge d'affaires. The small staff rattles about in large buildings where American officials, in addition to normal diplomatic activities, once oversaw a major war effort and took part in most of the activities of the Laotian Government.
Acknowledging the development project, Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan, speaking in French, said, ''I think two districts is not enough, compared with the number of bombs America poured on our country.''
The subsequent Laotian-American agreement was signed on Jan. 9 in a friendly, low-key ceremony at the Foreign Ministry. It was toasted with champagne by the charge d'affaires, Charles B. Salmon Jr., and Deputy Foreign Minister Souban Sritthirath.
Mr. Salmon called the signing an ''auspicious event'' and said it was ''reflective of the improving relationship.'' Mr. Souban Sritthirath, raising his glass in response, said he hoped the ''memorandum of understanding'' would ''contribute to understanding and normalization in the relations of our two countries.''
 
House Delegation Visits
The agreement commits Laos to a ''maximum effort'' to eliminate the cultivation of opium and its trafficking. The United States has agreed to help in development efforts to provide high landers with ''viable economies'' based on crops other than opium. Laos promised to cooperate with the United States in curbing drug trafficking and ''make officials and facilities available'' to that end.
The accord followed President Bush's ''decertification'' of Laos last March for what Washington called Vientiane's failure to cooperate in narcotics suppression. Alluding to this, Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan said, ''There are things that do not exist, but we are blamed.'' Laotian and American officials said they hoped that the agreement would remove the block on cooperation.
A House delegation led by Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan and chairman of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control, spent a day here recently and, surprisingly, was received by Nouhak Phoumsavanh, president of the National Assembly and held to be the most anti-Western of the Laotian leaders. The Americans were the first to meet with Mr. Nouhak Phoumsavanh, who was reported to have received them in a friendly and relaxed atmosphere.
Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan said Mr. Nouhak Phoumsavanh assured his visitors that Laos would proceed with severity against narcotics offenses.
 
Coopoeration on M.I.A.'s
American officials also expressed satisfaction with Laotian cooperation in the search for the remains of American servicemen missing in action, believed to have been killed when their planes were shot down over Laos. A 17-member American military search mission spent several days in southern Laos in January and recovered remains from two crash sites.
Mr. Kaysone Phomvihan and Mr. Phoumi Vongvichit linked this cooperation directly with demands for American economic aid. ''We gave you all that you needed,'' the Acting President said he had told American diplomats. ''But you have given us nothing directly.''
Both leaders acknowledged that the United States, through international organizations, had contributed rice during periods of drought. ''We want direct aid from you to us,'' said the 80-year-old Mr. Phoumi Vongvichit, who for several years has served as President in place of Prince Souphanouvong, who has apparently retired.

GRAPHIC: photo: A recent agreement to combat the drug trade and an aid package signed last fall are indications of American willingness to improve ties with Laos. The leaders of Laos say they want a new chapter in relations with the United States, which backed the royal Government before the Communist victory of 1975. (NYT/Henry Kamm)

HEADLINE: Mitterrand Is Said to Agree to Free Hunger Striker

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Jan. 30

 BODY:
President Francois Mitterrand has promised to release a convicted pro-Iranian terrorist in exchange for his agreement to end a four-month hunger strike, published reports said today.
The French weekly satirical newspaper, Le Canard Enchaine, said the 36-year-old terrorist, Anis Naccache, who had lost nearly 80 pounds, agreed over the weekend to stop his hunger strike after weeks of secret negotiations.
He had been sentenced to life in prison in connection with an attempt to kill a former Iranian Prime Minister, Shahpur Bakhtiar. 
One of Mr. Naccache's lawyers, Jacques Verges, has indicated that the terrorist received a direct request from Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, to end his strike, leaving the strong impression that the Iranian leader was part of a deal.
Spokesmen at Elysee Palace, the Prime Minister's office and the French Foreign Ministry all refused to comment on the report in the French newspaper and another, in a Kuwait daily.
President Mitterrand said on Jan. 5 that Mr. Naccache could not obtain his liberty by going on a hunger strike, but added that ''he can always hope to be liberated when the time comes.''
The release of Mr. Naccache has repeatedly been demanded by Iran, which has officially stated that it was part of complicated agreements that led to the release of all French hostages held in Beirut in 1988.
Several Iranian leaders, including President Hashemi Rafsanjani and the Foreign Minister, have said they expected France to live up to the accord, which included a pledge by Iran to refrain from sponsoring any acts of terror against France and a French commitment to normalize ties and resume economic and industrial cooperation.
The accord has been largely upheld, except for the continued detention of Mr. Naccache, who went on a hunger strike Sept. 8, saying he would stop only when France lived up to its agreement to release him.
 
U.S. Hostages in Lebanon
A report in the Kuwaiti daily Al Qabas today said ''extremely secret high level'' talks have recently been held between senior Iranian and American officials in Paris, Geneva and an unidentified West German city about the fate of the American hostages in Lebanon and about normalizing ties between Iran and the United States.
Al Qabas went on to say that the administration of President Rafsanjani was persuaded that the hostages have outlived their usefulness and is ready to release them.
But a few days ago, a senior Iranian official said that Iran was putting the issue of improved ties with the United States at the end of its list of priorities, concentrating instead on better ties with Western Europe.
In 1988, Jacques Chirac, who was then Prime Minister, pledged that France would do what it could to bring about the release of other nationals after it negotiated the release of its own hostages.
A number of pro-Iranian terrorists are held in France as prisoners. A group of 10 led by Fouad Ali Saleh, a Tunisian accused of terrorist acts, went on trial Monday in Paris.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes Economic Sanctions Against China

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The Senate unanimously approved legislation today that included a series of economic sanctions against China.
But the Senate action leaves President Bush wide discretion to waive the sanctions if he considers it in the national interest to do so.
The sanctions, prompted by China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last June, were approved five days after President Bush won a political victory when the Senate sustained his veto of a bill protecting Chinese students from deportation.
The sanctions approved today were part of a $9.7 billion measure authorizing State Department activities for fiscal years 1990 and 1991. The bill now goes to the President, who is expected to sign it into law. 
The legislation, which was approved 98 to 0, urges the Export-Import Bank to continue to postpone financing for United States exports to China and suspends financial support from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation and the Trade and Development Program.
 
A Halt to Licenses
The legislation also halts the issuance of licenses for the export of military items and, if the repression in China deepens, calls for a review of China's most-favored-nation trade status and bilateral trade agreements related to satellite technology and nuclear energy.
But the measure gives Mr. Bush the power to end any of the sanctions if he decides that doing so serves the national interest of the United States or if he judges that significant change has taken place in China.
The bill includes $3.3 billion this year and $3.7 billion next year for the State Department, most of it for basic expenses like employees' paychecks and the expenses connected with American embassies and consulates. The bill also includes about $2 billion for the United States Information Agency and $600 million for the Board for International Broadcasting, which runs Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty.
Last Thursday Mr. Bush in effect won the right to pursue his own China policy when the Senate, by 62 votes to 37, sustained his veto of the bill on deporting Chinese students. The bill was passed by wide bipartisan majorities in November as a response to the crackdown in Tiananmen Square in June. Mr. Bush said that he had ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to adopt measures that would protect all Chinese who wanted to stay in the United States. The day before the Senate vote, the House had voted to override by 390 votes to 25.
 
The End of an Impasse
The vote today ends a two-month impasse between the Administration and Congress over authorizing funds for the State Department, the United States Information Agency and other related agencies.
Congress approved a State Department bill in November authorizing spending for the State Department, the Voice of America and other agencies. But President Bush vetoed the measure because it contained a provision stemming from the Iran-contra affair that would have made it a crime for American officials to solicit money from foreign nations or from individuals to promote military, intelligence or foreign policy activity barred by law. Mr. Bush said the provision would have infringed on his constitutional powers to conduct foreign policy.
The provision had been introduced by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.
After the veto, the House dropped the provision from the bill and approved the measure. The Senate failed to vote on it before the recess.
Before the vote today, a group of liberal Democratic senators proposed a package of aid to Eastern European nations worth $511 million. The proposal, sponsored by Senators Clairborne Pell of Rhode Island, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Paul Simon of Illinois and Joseph Biden of Delaware, is an increase of more than $200 million over the Eastern Europe aid package that the Bush Administration requested in its fiscal 1991 budget.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 BUDGET: CONFLICT;
Move to Stop Base Closings Begins Battle Over Spending

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
In the first direct challenge to President Bush's budget, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee filed legislation today that would derail the Pentagon's proposal to consider closing dozens of military bases.
The measure, filed by Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, struck at the heart of Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's plans to change the American military. Those plans are emerging as one of the most contentious issues in Mr. Bush's proposed budget for the 1991 fiscal year.
Apparently hoping to keep base closings from producing the kind of political brawl over other issues that threw the military budget debate into disarray in the House last year, Mr. Aspin proposed creating a bipartisan commission to choose bases for closing. Otherwise, he said, the list could be used as a ''political gun'' to control votes on other legislation. 
Representative Patricia Schroeder, the Colorado Democrat who heads the Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Installations, accused Mr. Cheney of producing ''an unbalanced, partisan hit list.'' Mrs. Schroeder produced figures showing that 19 of the 21 bases under consideration for closing are in Congressional districts with a Democratic representative, as are 99 percent of the civilian jobs that would be cut if the proposed actions are carried out.
 
Political Considerations Denied
The Pentagon denied Mrs. Schroeder's charge. ''The list you've got are recommendations by the services for bases that they would close in light of decisions to reduce the overall size of the force,'' said Bob Hall, a Pentagon spokesman. ''It was not made with political considerations in mind.''
The lines of conflict also came into sharp focus today over other parts of Mr. Bush's requests, especially proposals to limit increases in Medicare, Federal pensions and other Federal benefits that are particularly volatile in an election year.
At a hearing of the House Budget Committee, the panel's chairman, Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, focused on one major objection to the budget request, the economic forecasts on which it was based. He sharply rebuked the President for not making what he called ''a serious effort at deficit reduction.''
''If the President is not serious about deficit reduction, why should Congress be serious?'' Mr. Panetta asked Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, who testified at the hearing.
 
'Of Course I'm Serious'
''It's almost regretable that I should even have to say this, but of course the President's serious,'' Mr. Darman told Mr. Panetta. ''Of course I'm serious.''
Represented by Mr. Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the Administration fought back, defending the budget as an attempt to promote savings, continue economic growth and make needed changes in programs like Medicare and Social Security without jeopardizing benefits.
Mr. Darman also defended the economic forecasts used to write the budget, which projects steady economic growth and constantly declining inflation over the next five years. Congress disputes those figures, and its own forecasters are more pessimistic.
Testifying today before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said he believes that the current economic slowdown is temporary and that the risk of recession is less than it was last spring. But when asked about the economic forecast used for the budget, Mr. Greenspan said it was based on the assumption that the President's budget would be approved intact, a prospect that lawmakers from both parties dismiss.
 
Setting Up the Battle Lines
Much of what went on today in press briefings and Congressional hearings was maneuvering to define the lines for the battle that eventually will be fought out in the House and Senate.
Many Democratic legislators focused their attack today on the $295.1 billion Pentagon budget that that Mr. Bush is seeking for 1991. That is a decrease of 2.6 percent from the current fiscal year, after accounting for inflation, but in simple terms is an increase of about $3.8 billion. When nuclear weapons research and production in the Department of Energy and military related activities in other agencies are included, the budget request for the military goes up to $306.9 billion.
On Monday, Mr. Cheney sent Congress a list of bases and other military installations in the United States and abroad that are being considered for closing, along with others that are being considered for reductions.
 
'The Process Stinks'
Mr. Aspin said the ''substance'' of what Mr. Cheney is trying to do was right. ''But the process stinks,'' he said.
He also said the Pentagon's base closings list also had a political dimension. ''The list can be changed,'' he said. ''Bases can be deleted or perhaps added. That creates hostages for the Administration. Vote against a veto override, your base is safe. Vote to override, your base is threatened. Simple as that.''
Mr. Aspin said he was introducing legislation to create a bipartisan commission to select bases for closing, like the one that offered 86 closings and reductions approved by Congress last year. Congress then had a choice of rejecting or approving the entire list, which gave members political cover for cuts ordered in their districts.
At a news conference on Monday, Mr. Cheney said the chairman of that base closing commission had told him ''he'd never serve again in that kind of a capacity.''
''He also said the commission decided to recommend against another commission,'' Mr. Cheney said.
In addition to the conflict over the military budget, the Administration and Congress clashed today over Mr. Bush's proposals to reduce the increase in Medicare payments by $5.5 billion in 1991, to extend the Social Security tax to local and state employees and to eliminate cost-of-living increases in Federal retirement benefits.
''You don't know what a tough choice is,'' Representative Marty Russo, Democrat of Illinois, told Mr. Darman. ''Do you think $5.5 billion cutting out of Medicare is a tough choice for you? It's easy for you. You've been doing it for all these years. Your party's been doing it.''
Mr. Darman said the reduction in the Medicare increase was part of an effort to bring down the costs of Medicare and not to reduce services.
When Mr. Panetta, Mr. Russo and others said they did not think the proposals would survive, Mr. Darman replied, ''We don't expect to get every last dime, especially in the sensitive and controversial areas. But by the same token, we can't have these health costs continue to go up at much higher rates than the general inflation rate.''

HEADLINE: THE 1991 BUDGET: EUROPE;
Momentum Grows for Military Spending Cuts in West Europe

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
The upheavals in the Communist countries in Eastern Europe and the Bush Administration's talk of closing bases and withdrawing troops from Greece, Britain, Italy, West Germany and Turkey have stepped up the political momentum toward greater military spending cuts in Western Europe.
Some governments - notably in Britain and France - are hoping to keep these feelings under control, and British officials have reacted in a studiously relaxed way to American budget proposals that military operations here be consolidated by ending operations at three British bases. But other officials at NATO headquarters in Brussels said they saw a danger that the alliance could begin to unravel if reductions are not carefully managed.
Some Eastern European politicians, like Czechoslovakia's Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, have said that changes in NATO could be only logical, since the Warsaw Pact is already in a more advanced state of collapse, and that both alliances should gradually be superseded by a wider framework. 
In both East and West, there is agreement that some of this could be provided by the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a gathering of 35 nations that took place in Helsinki in 1975 and will convene again later this year, possibly in Vienna.
 
Rate of Change Questioned
But all over Western Europe, politicians and commentators are beginning to say that NATO's way of responding to the bewildering speed of change in the East - with the conventional arms talks that have been under way in Vienna since last year - may not produce results fast enough. Richard N. Perle, regarded by most left-of-center Western Europeans through most of the 1980's as a sinister influence on the American Government, is now cited approvingly as saying the Soviet Union is no longer capable of mounting a sudden conventional attack on the West.
And all over the political spectrum, political pressure is mounting on Western European Governments to draw the consequences by cutting military spending. Here, even The Daily Telegraph, a conservative newspaper, said today that changes had to come. ''It is not credible for Britain, alone among the senior NATO partners, to sing a wholly different song,'' Max Hastings, its editor, wrote.
West Germany is at the heart of the debate, as it was bound to be once the rationale for the separate existence of an East German nation began collapsing with the Berlin wall last autumn. West Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, stressing his country's continuing commitment to NATO in an interview with the mass-circulation Bild am Sonntag, seemed to warn that the commitment would end, or have to change, if East and West Germany became one.
 
A Commitment to NATO
''Anybody who wants to extend NATO's borders to the Oder and Neisse,'' he said, referring to the East German frontier with Poland, ''shuts the door on a united Germany.'' For West Germany, he said, ''Our commitment to remain in NATO, on the other hand, is undisputed.'' One NATO diplomat in Brussels said the statement was carefully worded but still ambiguous.
President Bush suggested a joint ceiling of 275,000 Soviet and American troops in Europe at the NATO summit in Brussels last May. But already some Western European officials are saying that this proposal, which was seen as a daring initiative then, is not enough now. One NATO expert said that the United States was already under pressure within the alliance to reduce the negotiated troop-strength ceilings to 200,000 to 250,000.
''It's going to be a question of what the right political timing is,'' one official said. ''Right now, the people in Washington feel, is not the time to change that.''
 
Major American Bases
The major American installations are the cruise missile bases at Comiso in Italy and Greenham Common in England. United States operations at Zweibrucken Air Base in West Germany, a center for tactical and photo-reconnaissance activities, are also ending.
Tanker refuelling operations at Fairford Air Base in Britain will be moved elsewhere, as will a smaller installation at Wethersfield.
An Air Force transport unit at Hellenikon Air Base near Athens will be transferred, and a small naval communications station at Nea Makri in Greece will be closed, as will two installations in Turkey: an air base at Erhac and a nuclear munitions storage site at Eskisehir.
While the negotiations in Vienna now concern only American and Soviet forces in Western Europe, NATO countries are already beginning to speculate about when and how much their own forces can be reduced in the next stage of negotiations, whose existence is now taken for granted even though the alliance hasn't formally agreed that they should take place. The prospect has already set off reverberations in France, which as the British weekly The Economist points out in its current issue, would be ''in the hot seat'' if a reunited Germany banned foreign troops from its territory.
 
Cuts for Dutch and Belgians
''The maintenance of West European forces on the territory of the Federal Republic is an expression of particular solidarity that will not be affected by the negotiations,'' the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said in Vienna last week, but to many it seemed like wishful thinking.
The Belgian Defense Minister, Guy Coeme, suggested in interviews with Brussels newspapers last week that Belgium was thinking about the eventual withdrawal of 25,000 troops stationed in West Germany. His Dutch counterpart, Relus Ter Beek, said that over the next two years, 750 of the 5,000 troops the Netherlands keeps in Germany would be brought home.
British military officials were also reported last weekend to be considering the possibility of cuts in the $32 billion military budget, and of reductions in the 67,000-strong British Army of the Rhine in West Germany, though they denied an account in The Sunday Times of London that suggested these were more than contingency plans.
''Our view is that there is no scope for defense cuts,'' an official in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office said. ''We aim at keeping our forces in Germany as far into the future as we can see, and any restructuring would not save us much money at all.''
West Germany, whose 494,000-strong armed forces are the core of NATO military strategy, has already canceled plans to extend the 18-month hitch that draftees serve, and announced plans to restructure its forces by the end of the decade, possibly reducing them to below 400,000.

HEADLINE: THE 1991 BUDGET: SOCIAL SECURITY;
Of Budgets And Truth

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Shaken by the political appeal of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan to cut the Social Security tax, the Bush Administration has put a new gloss on an old proposal. In the budget submitted to Congress on Monday, the Administration called for creation of a new ''Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund.''
As the budget describes it, the purpose of the fund would be threefold: to create a surplus of revenue late in this decade that could be used to begin retiring the Government's debt; to prevent an increase in Social Security benefits or a reduction in the Social Security tax, and to force spending cuts in other Government programs after 1992.
This is in large part public relations maneuvering. The Government cannot begin to pay off the Federal debt - the total amount owed to those who hold Treasury bonds and other Government securities, now amounting to about $3 trillion - until the overall annual budget, including the Social Security system, is in surplus; that is, until the annual deficit is eliminated. Even by the Administration's calculations, which critics say are unrealistic, that will not occur until 1996. 
The plan allows the Administration to make the popular political argument that it is protecting Social Security entitlements for today's baby boomers when they retire in the next century.
 
Need to Meet Obligations
That, too, is somewhat misleading. The Government will have to tax or borrow enough in the 21st century to meet the retirement obligations, regardless of what is done now.
Because Social Security taxes rose in the last decade and income taxes were cut, an increasing share of Government revenue comes from Social Security taxes.
In the current fiscal year, $62 billion more will be paid in Social Security taxes than will be paid out in benefits, with the surpluses rising year by year.
At the same time, according to the President's budget, the deficit in the rest of the Government will be $183 billion in this fiscal year. Even if the optimistic economic forecasts of the Administration are accepted and all President Bush's budget-cutting proposals are adopted, this deficit in the part of the budget outside Social Security will continue until 1996.
The Administration and Senator Moynihan, Democrat of New York, agree that the Social Security surplus is being used to mask the size of the deficit in the Government's operating expenses, which range from paper clips to aircraft carriers. They also agree that this is bad policy and that the money should be used for investments to guarantee pensions for baby boomers when they retire.
But they attack the problem from different directions.
 
Raising Other Taxes
Mr. Moynihan would like to raise other taxes to meet day-to-day expenses, so Social Security money could be used to insure future retirement benefits. Since Mr. Bush refuses to do that, the Senator argues, the tax should be reduced, by more than $60 billion over two years, so that Social Security taxes and benefits would be in balance. That would require higher taxes later on when baby boomers retire.
The Bush Administration would continue to use Social Security taxes to pay operating expenses for the next two years. At that point, the Administration figures, the overall budget, including Social Security, will be in balance, and the Government can be weaned from reliance on Social Security taxes.
This is where the Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund fund would come in. In the fiscal year 1993, $14.1 billion, or 15 percent of the Social Security surplus, would be paid into the fund. In 1994, $53.6 billion, or 50 percent of the surplus, would be put in the fund. In 1995, the figure would be $101.8 billion, or 85 percent, and in 1996 all the surplus would go into the fund.
The Administration describes the money in the fund as being used for debt retirement. But that would not be the case until 1996. Before that, it would simply mean that the Government would have to borrow less money, and the debt would grow less rapidly.
What it would mean, however, is that, assuming taxes do not rise, other Federal expenses would have to be cut by the amount placed in the fund.
Most economists agree that good reason exists to build up a Social Security surplus and to invest the money.
The notion that workers' payroll taxes are placed in a trust fund to pay for their own retirement is a fiction. No matter how the budget is sliced, this is one Government. Social Security is a pay-as-you-go system. Each generation pays taxes to finance the retirement of their parents' generation.
When more money is received in Social Security taxes than is needed for benefits, as is now the case, the surplus is used to buy Treasury bonds.
If there were no deficit in the everyday operating budget, all the surplus could be used to buy Treasury securities held by private lenders. Those lenders' money could then be invested in plants, equipment and other productive enterprises, stimulating growth in the entire economy.
That was the theory behind the payroll tax rises that began in 1983. If more money is invested in private ventures and the economy grows accordingly, it will be easier for the children of the baby-boom generation to pay for their parents' retirement benefits.
Mr. Moynihan would have no difficulty with the Administration's plan if it began today to segregate all the Social Security money and found money elsewhere, in taxes or reduced spending, to pay the rest of the Government's expenses. What he objects to is the continued payment for operating expenses of money from a tax that mostly affects the poor and middle class.
As of Jan. 1, workers and their employers each pay 7.65 percent on payday, 6.2 percent for retirement under Social Security and 1.45 percent for Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and disabled. The tax is paid on the first $51,300 of wages.
The Social Security tax has risen steeply in recent years. At the beginning of the last decade, it was 6.13 percent on the first $29,700 of wages.
At the same time, income tax rates have been lowered. The top rate for individuals is now 28 percent or 33 percent, down from 70 percent at the beginning of the 1980's. The corporate income tax has also been sharply cut.
As a result, the share of Federal revenues coming from Social Security taxes rose by 23 percent in the 1980's. The share covered by individual income taxes fell 6 percent, and that of corporate taxes by 23 percent.
Unlike income taxes, which rise as a proportion of income as taxpayers' income increases, Social Security taxes are not only cut off at $51,300 but are paid at the same rate by all workers. Moreover, they apply only to wages and not to interest, dividends, capital gains and other forms of income enjoyed largely by the well-to-do.
What that means is that a husband and wife earning $35,000 each pay more in Social Security tax than a single person who earns $350,000. #2 Sides of Picture Mr. Moynihan believes it is unfair for such a tax to be used for ordinary expenditures. On the other hand, he tends to overlook that Social Security benefits are skewed in favor of the less well-off.
According to the Social Security Administration, someone who retired in 1989 after paying the maximum Social Security tax for an entire working life would be receiving $10,837 this year in benefits. If this retiree's average salary had been, say $50,000, the benefit would be only 22 percent of what the worker usually earned.
On the other hand, a retiree whose average salary was $19,334 would be receiving 42 percent of his average salary, or $8,053, in payments this year. Someone whose average wages were only $8,700 would get $5,036 in benefits, or 58 percent.
In addition, nonworking spouses are entitled to a benefit even if they paid nothing into the system. And the poorest workers get some of their tax payments back each year in the form of an earned income tax credit.

HEADLINE: One Yugoslavia or Six?

 BODY:
Yugoslavia has come to the brink of radical change later than its Eastern European neighbors. Now it faces fundamental questions, like the future of Communist rule and its survival as a single country. Yet unity is not automatically the top priority. Yugoslavia's most compelling need now is for effective reforms to halt its slide toward ethnic conflict and economic ruin. Washington still has an interest in trying to preserve Yugoslav unity, but not at any cost. 
Yugoslavia is a 20th-century invention. Right after World War I, the prewar states of Serbia and Montenegro merged with defeated Austria-Hungary's Slavic provinces of Croatia, Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina. That union satisfied aspirations that had helped trigger the war.
But it also created new nationality problems, jumbling together Roman Catholics, Orthodox Christians and Muslims with conflicting allegiances and mutual suspicions. Non-Serbians feared domination by Serbia, by far the largest component of the new country. And Serbians feared that other groups would gang up against them, an anxiety reinforced by anti-Serbian atrocities in World War II.
In 1945 Yugoslavia was reorganized into the present federation of six republics under the Communist leadership of Marshal Tito. When he split with Stalin in 1948, he gave the West an interest in defending Yugoslav unity and independence.
That independence has partly insulated Yugoslavia from the upheavals in Eastern Europe. Communist authority did not rest on Soviet legions. But Yugoslavia had home-grown problems. Its economy has bogged down in corruption and hyperinflation. The sense of nationhood imposed by Tito weakened after his death, in 1980.
Tito's model consciously discriminated against Serbia. With his demise, Serbian nationalism caught fire. Its demagogic torchbearer is Slobodan Milosevic, president of the Serbian Republic. His program is Serbian dominance, Communist supremacy and economic centralism.
Non-Serbian Communists, led by Slovenes and Croats, now demand pluralism and market reforms. They hint that they might quit the federation if Serbia blocks nationwide reform. Since Serbia seemed to do just that during last week's Communist Party conference, Yugoslavia's dissolution seems possible.
But there may be a less drastic alternative. Prime Minister Ante Marcovic is a popular, effective reformer. His strategy is for the federal Government to work around the Communists if they will not embrace reform. But perhaps national disintegration has already gone too far.
A year ago, a breakup of Yugoslavia would have left the surviving pieces dangerously vulnerable to Warsaw Pact pressure. That's no longer so. Dissolving the federation might be less explosive than fierce ethnic friction or continued economic paralysis. The basic choices are for Yugoslavs to make. America's preferences should be reform, stability and unity, in that order.

HEADLINE: A Chance to Expand Democracy

 BODY:
Why don't Americans vote? While other parts of the world edge closer to democracy, America's democracy is shrinking. Reflecting a steady decline in participation, barely half the voting-age population took part in the 1988 Presidential election - the worst turnout in 64 years. The uninspiring campaign surely didn't help. But the problem starts with simple arithmetic. Only 61 percent of all eligible voters are registered. 
Landmark legislation now before the House would transform the system for registering voters - a crazy-quilt of 50 state laws whose net effect is to discourage voters. Despite last-minute objections from the Administration and the House minority leader, Robert Michel, the measure deserves swift approval.
Sponsored by Representative Al Swift, Democrat of Washington, and Representative William Thomas, Republican of California, the measure would supplant present state-by-state barriers to registration with common-sense standards for Federal elections. The most important is a ''motor-voter'' provision. It would require states to register eligible citizens automatically whenever they apply for a driver's license or license renewal.
That would be a giant boost for enrollment; nearly 87 percent of voting-age Americans drive. The impact on voter turnout is hard to predict. But since roughly 8 registered voters in 10 go to the polls, it is likely to be significant.
States would also be required to allow registration by mail instead of asking citizens to show up at municipal offices, a practice still required by an astonishing 27 states. Another provision would make registration forms available at public agencies like welfare and unemployment offices. The bill would also end the destructive practice of purging voters from the rolls simply for not voting, and would build in new safeguards against fraud.
Chances for House approval looked bright until some Republicans complained the bill would impose undue burdens on state election boards and encourage phony votes. But over all, the bill represents a sensible compromise between Democrats, who traditionally support easy registration, and Republicans, who worry more about fraud.
Congress cannot motivate citizens to vote but it can remove needless restrictions on voter registration. House approval of the ''motor-voter'' bill would inspire the Senate to follow suit, set a high standard for bipartisanship and, not least, expand democracy.

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Once Again Now

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
This week we had the budget. The budget is a big story in Washington, which is probably why we have it. To understand the budget, remember: The budget is not a budget. The budget is a story.
Naturally the news industry loves it. It sets up so many stories to get the news industry over the dull patches in the coming year. Examples:
''President Accuses Congress of Busting Budget.'' 
''Congress Accuses President of Budget Fakery.''
''G.O.P. Blames Dems for Budget Overruns.''
''Dems Charge G.O.P. With Etcetera . . .''
New Presidents innocent about Washington ways always ask: ''Why are we wasting time and energy on this budget rot? Let's forget it and do something useful.''
These Presidents are soon visited by delegations from the news industry explaining the facts of the Presidency. Fact One: Presidents who cut off the industry's budget story get 90,000 reporters looking for dirty pool in all 45,000 agencies for which every President is responsible.
Wouldn't the President rather waste energy on budget rot than read a daily rat-tat-tat of news stories about the Director of Superfluous Excess ignoring reports of a growing excess gap? And don't forget the Department of Bureaucratic Presentability: always plenty of scandal to be mined there, Mr. President, what with dozens of assistant secretaries appearing on television looking unpresentably barbered and tailored.
You get the idea. So do Presidents. They play along, and we get the annual budget story. Here are a few of the better story elements: 1. Silly revenue estimate: Revenue is the money the Government takes in. Budget writers have to guess how much the coming year's take will be. To get the story rolling, they guess absurdly high.
This leads the press to some of its favorite stories: (1) Democrats accuse President of cooking up ridiculously optimistic revenue estimates; (2) G.O.P. accuses Democrats of abusing beloved President; (3) etcetera ad infinitum, or at least ad January 1991 when it will start all over again.
It also sets up a yearlong series of infinitely tedious stories about revenue estimates being readjusted, and paves the way for the inevitable year-end disclosure that the January guess was miles off base.
In between, economics reporters and columnists grind out the same old material about factors - how these bozos love factors - that account for the slippage. (All Washington loves slippage, especially the Pentagon.) 2. Gramm-Rudman: Gramm and Rudman are two guys who had one of the dumber ideas of the era; to wit, that you could stop Congress from spending the country bankrupt if you just passed a law putting a limit on how much it could spend.
Naturally, Congress passed this law, since it offered a cheap and easy chance to come out against profligacy. Naturally, the President signed it. Naturally, President and Congress immediately invented ways to get around it, so as not to impede the headlong race toward ever higher debt.
For the press, the beauty part of Gramm-Rudman is the resulting gusher of technical stories about domestic programs that have to be cut to stay within Gramm-Rudman limits, of political stories about the President slashing domestic programs for the downtrodden middle class, and thousands of political stories about conservatives and liberals squabbling about who is an evil big spender and who is a revolting softie on Pentagon waste. 3. Off-budget items: ''Off-budget'' is Washington code talk and means, ''This baby is going to cost us the whole farm, but let's pretend it doesn't count.'' It is the President's and Congress's favorite way to avoid the Gramm-Rudman problem.
For instance, the staggering cost of the savings-and-loan bailout is kept ''off-budget'' by common agreement simply not to count it. This makes farce of stories about Gramm-Rudman and the size of budget deficit, which may be why the press doesn't pay it much heed. Why let awkward facts wipe out a good old story the public has come to know and love? 4. ''Read my lips'': Many tired but beloved stories flow from the President's promise not to raise taxes, which would be necessary if anybody were serious about conquering the infamous mountain of debt and dealing honestly with the bashable Japanese.
The most interesting potential story this year: how finaglers in White House and Congress will manage to continue avoiding an income-tax boost by using the constantly rising soak-the-downtrodden Social Security tax to pay the daily bills.

HEADLINE: For Colombians in Queens, Time of Pain and Questions

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
In the boxcar restaurants and boisterous salsa-pumped bars of Queens, where the talk is all too often of bad things that happen to Colombians, conversations of the last few days have been more painful than usual, and sometimes more bitter.
First came news of the crash of Avianca Airlines Flight 52 and the loss of neighbors from Jackson Heights, Corona, and other parts of Queens where Colombian immigrants have established themselves in large and close-knit numbers.
 
Many Questions, Few Answers
Then came questions: How, so near to two airports, could the plane have run out of fuel? Why had airport controllers not given it permission to land in time? And why, after decades of violence and intermittent natural disasters, did another tragedy have to befall Colombians?
''It makes you feel like crying even if you had nothing to do with it,'' said Deifan Rodriguez, a tiny soft-spoken woman of 40, as she swabbed the floor of a tiny Jackson Heights grocery store. 
By their last rough estimates, the Colombian Consul General and community leaders count anywhere from 450,000 to 800,000 Colombian natives and their children living legally and illegally in the New York metropolitan area.
About 270,000 Colombians have immigrated legally since the 1950's, the Immigration and Naturalization Service says.
 
To Many, Flight Symbolized Success
Yet to listen in the convenience stores, nightclubs and churches of several Queens neighborhoods, it would seem that nearly everyone lost a relative, a friend, or a friend of a friend.
As the country's only nonstop to New York, the Avianca flight was especially familiar to Colombian New Yorkers. To many of the more recent immigrants, the plane trip home had been a prized symbol of economic success in the United States.
''Yesterday I almost couldn't work,'' Walter Segura, a 44-year-old taxi driver who often met the flight said late Saturday night at the counter of a bustling diner.
''It's almost like it happened to the rest of us,'' said Mr. Segura, a stout man in a blue jean jacket. ''I have suffered a lot - my mother died, and others - and in a country that has suffered from drugs and guerrilla war and everything, it makes you sensitive to things like this.''
 
A Familiar Pulling Together
Indeed, many in the Colombian community said the tragedy had pulled them together in a fashion that has grown sadly familiar.
In just the last five years, they recall the 1985 volcanic eruption that buried more than 20,000 in the mountain town of Armero - just weeks after leftist guerrillas killed 85 people, 11 of them Supreme Court justices, in an attack on the Palace of Justice in Bogota.
Since then the tidings have been of guerrilla attacks, economic troubles and, increasingly, killings and terrorism by the hugely powerful cocaine cartels of Medellin and Cali. In September it was the drug barons' murder of a popular Presidential candidate; a spate of Government ''war'' on the traffickers followed. Last month, traffickers from Medellin were blamed for the bombing of an Avianca flight from Bogota to Cali.
''With everything that has happened to the Colombians, then the plane, and then on the plane there was a guy with drugs!'' lamented Gilberto Garrido, proprietor of a Jackson Heights restaurant called La Pequena Colombia, or Little Colombia.
 
Accusations of Discrimination
Mr. Garrido, part of a ready chorus of Colombian-American voices, bemoaned what he described as widespread discrimination against Colombians here because of their homeland's status as the world's foremost producer of cocaine.
Not far away, at the Restaurante Mondongo, named for its tripe soup, a debate among the cook, a truck driver and two other men came to the dead-serious conclusion that drug-related discrimination had not only kept Avianca Flight 52 from a safe landing, but had delayed the delivery of victims' bodies from the coroner.
''I'm somebody who works 18 hours a day,'' offered Javier Trujillo, the restaurant's owner. ''What fault do I have that one guy in 150 on some plane was carrying some cocaine?''
Drug control agents in Queens also describe a picture at least more complicated than popular mythology would suggest.
Police officials say that while Colombians undoubtedly head major distribution operations and cocaine sales are prevalent in some areas where many Colombians live, the police arrest few street-level drug sellers who identify themselves as Colombians. Of some 300 people arrested on drug arrests in the last month in Jackson Heights and Elmhurst, 21 were Colombians, said Capt. Edward Lyons, commanding officer of the Queens Tactical Narcotics Task Force.
Far less noted than the drug connections of their homeland, community leaders say, is the vibrancy of the Colombian communities spread out from Queens across New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Since Colombian immigration began to boom in the 1960's, high numbers of graduate students, professionals and skilled workers have stamped the commmunity as particularly middle class. Hard work, a traditional emphasis on education, and some of the street savvy of Colombian myth have colored in the profile.
Still, the capital of Colombia in New York remains a precarious outpost, mostly liberated from the old denizens of Queens but hardly secure from the influences of other immigrants.
The epicenter of the Colombian New York community is not called Little Bogota, perhaps, because the calenos from Cali, the paisas from Medellin and the costenos from coastal cities like Barranquilla and Cartagena would not have it.
There are separate associations of Colombian professionals, doctors, dentists, artists and salesmen.
''Our community has grown so much that it has become hard to hold together,'' said Dr. Guillermo Davila, a dentist who is head of Queens's Colombian Civic Center. Of the outpouring of sentiment at the plane crash, he added: ''Things like this, although you would like them not to happen, bring us together. My phone is always ringing with people saying, 'Whose fault was it? What happened? We have to do something!' ''

HEADLINE: Connecticut Alarmed as an Old and Trusted Bank Falters

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Financial troubles at one of Connecticut's oldest and largest banks, Connecticut Bank and Trust, have brought home to people across the state the harsh reality of New England's economic downturn.
After months of industry rumors and troubling reports, the bank's Boston-based parent, the Bank of New England Corporation, announced this month that it had lost $1.2 billion in 1989 on bad real-estate loans. It would have to sell billions of dollars in assets to stay afloat.
The news was little short of a bombshell. After 176 years as a linchpin of the state's economy, Connecticut Bank and Trust -and its 160 branches, all marked by the understated blue CBT logo - suddenly seemed less secure. 
CBT began losing deposits. In the most public withdrawals, municipal finance officials from West Hartford to Norwalk withdrew millions in public funds. Some officials began questioning the state's system to protect public funds, should the bank fail. State banking officials issued a statement of confidence and urged people not to overreact.
''It's painful,'' said Antoinette J. Anderson, the director of finance in Windsor, which removed CBT from its list of banks eligible to compete for the $10 million to $20 million in tax revenues and capital funds that the town offers out for deposit. ''But when you have this much public awareness of problems, the public perception is that funds could be in danger.''
 
Assessing the Problem
What has also colored the reactions is the often intensely held view here that Connecticut is and should be insulated from the corrupting taint of its larger neighbors. In such a light, the plight of CBT, which completed its merger with the Bank of New England only five years ago, has almost taken on the tones of a morality play, a warning against the danger of out-of-state liaisons.
''We had a perfectly fine bank here,'' said Lewis Mandell, a professor of finance at the University of Connecticut and a former Federal bank regulator. ''The feeling is that it was the merger with the Massachusetts-based banks - the expansion - that caused the problem.''
The native feeling that CBT - and by reflection, Connecticut - may not be as bad off as the Bank of New England's numbers indicate is bolstered by economists and analysts who track the banking industry. They said that while banks across New England have suffered from defaulted loans in an overbuilt real-estate market, the hardest hit areas have so far been concentrated in Massachussetts and farther north, where CBT's corporate siblings do their business, rather than in Connecticut, where CBT is the company's only franchise.
''There's no question that the Connecticut economy has slowed significantly, but at this juncture the perception is that the problems are not as deep,'' said Don J. Kauth, an analyst who follows the banking industry at the First Albany Corporation, a stock brokerage concern.
 
Liabilities for Bad Loans
What remains unknown until Federal auditors finish their work on the parent company's books over the next few weeks is whether and how much CBT may share liabilities for bad loans made outside the state and the extent to which losses in deposits from Connecticut towns or other clients may be aggravating the wounds.
Marcia Ryan, a spokeswoman for the Bank of New England, said the idea that geography would make a difference in how the drama plays out was simply false. She declined to provide any total of lost deposits.
''The issue is not Connecticut vs. Massachusetts; it's real-estate lending across New England,'' she said.
What is also uncertain is how much of CBT may be left when the Bank of New England completes its assets sale.
On Monday, for instance, the parent bank, which has said it must raise $6 billion in cash to stem the losses, sold its entire consumer credit-card business - with nearly half of it in Connecticut - to Citicorp for $828 million.
For some municipal officials who have tax money to invest and legal liabilities of their own to watch out for, those uncertainties have overwhelmed any loyalty they may feel to the bank as a longtime local presence.
 
Investments Cut Back
''We're not going to make speculative investments,'' said Andrew F. Urban, the director of financial services and treasurer for the town of West Hartford, which gradually cut back its investments with CBT until last weekend, when a decision was made not to renew any of the $25 million to $50 million in funds that had been occasionally on deposit with the bank.
''When we started to hear about large loan write-offs, we just started to take a more prudent position,'' he said.
One concern cited by Mr. Urban and other town officials is how great a net the state would provide municipalities if the bank did collapse. Current laws, for example, require every bank in the state to set aside 3 percent of the value of the money held for state and local governments in a ''collateral pool.'' If any bank folded, the pool would be used to reimburse government agencies for the value of their deposits.
The problem, the municipal investors said, is that while the pool may be adequate for a small bank, it would not likely be large enough for CBT, which is the second largest commercial bank in the state by assets, according to the State Banking Department. The pool is currently put at about $52 million.
 
Guarantee on Deposits
CBT had $10.3 billion in assets and $7.5 billion in total deposits as of last June 30, state figures showed. The Connecticut National Bank, the state's largest commercial bank, had $12.1 billion in assets and $7.2 billion in deposits. All bank deposits in Connecticut, whether from municipal investors or private individuals, are guaranteed up to $100,000 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
''This is something very new for us,'' said Jack E. Miller, finance director in Norwalk and head of the state chapter of the Government Finance Officers Association. He said Norwalk removed CBT from its bid list on $10 million to $20 million in funds two weeks ago.
''I suspect that most of us have had long relationships with CBT, very positive relationships,'' Mr. Miller said. ''It's been very unsettling.''

HEADLINE: New York Assembly Chiefs Offer $62 Million Hospital Rescue Plan

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Signaling that the rescue of the state's troubled hospitals will be a legislative priority, the Democratic leadership of the State Assembly today proposed spending $62 million to ease the crisis caused by crowding in emergency rooms, drug abuse, AIDS and increased labor costs.
The money would be pumped into the state's complex Medicaid reimbursement formula, which also controls private insurance reimbursement rates. Because of the impact on private insurance payments, and because state Medicaid contributions must be matched by an equal amount from local governments and by twice as much from the Federal Government, the new state money would leverage a total of $540 million for hospitals, the Democrats said.
Spokesmen for the state's 262 acute-care hospitals reacted jubilantly to the proposal, which was announced by Mel Miller, the Assembly Speaker, and Richard N. Gottfried, the chairman of the Assembly Health Committee. The hospital leaders encouraged the Senate and the Cuomo administration to back the Assembly initiative, but those two corners of the legislative triangle have been more reluctant to support major infusions of money for hospitals. 
 
Budget Hurdle to Cross
With the state's three-year hospital reimbursement formula due to expire on Dec. 31, the Legislature must deal with the issue this year, but any major spending proposal must overcome pressures created by the state's tight budget. Mr. Miller did not specify what changes he would make in the Governor's proposed budget.
The state's two largest hospital organizations, the Hospital Association of New York State and the Greater New York Hospital Association, have lobbied for changing the base year in the state's reimbursement formula from 1981 to a more recent year.
The base year is the year used by the Department of Health as the starting point for determining hospital costs, with yearly increases for inflation.
The two big hospital organizations argue that new developments affecting the hospital industry, like the cost of treating AIDS patients and the dire shortage of nurses, led to projected losses by New York hospitals of more than $1 billion in 1989.
Mr. Miller said today that changing the base year would reward hospitals that had done little to control costs. He said he preferred to direct money to needy hospitals by tinkering with the existing formula.
His proposal would distribute $50 million to all hospitals, based on the number of beds in each. The rest of the money would be targeted for hospitals with skyrocketing labor costs, a growing volume of AIDS-related and drug-related admissions, increased use of emergency rooms and growing costs for the disposal of medical waste.
Mr. Miller's plan also would gradually increase the cap on Medicaid reimbursements for outpatient visits to $75 from $60 by 1992.
 
Community Clinics Supported
Mr. Miller applauded the goals of Dr. David Axelrod, the State Health Commissioner, in seeking to move the delivery of primary health care away from hospitals and into community clinics. But he said the state had been slow to accomplish those goals.
''Until it's a reality, you have to reimburse hospitals adequately, because right now they are the provider of health care,'' Mr. Miller said. ''We can't wait for the millennium.''
Peter Slocum, a spokesman for Dr. Axelrod, said the administration had little philosophical difference with Mr. Miller's proposal. He said the Governor expected to disclose his hospital reimbursement proposal soon.
Although the hospital associations prefer a change in the base year, they seemed happy with what Mr. Miller proposed to hand them. ''I'm just beside myself,'' said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. ''This is probably the best shot in the arm the hospitals have had in three years.''
On another health-related issue today, Dr. Axelrod said he did not expect the Cuomo administration to submit legislation this year for a system of no-fault medical malpractice insurance.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
The assignment for Henry Harms's ninth graders at the Great Hollow Intermediate School in Smithtown, L.I., was to create a model Hovercraft that would travel at least eight feet, suspended in air, over a row of magnets.
Jessica DeHart decided to propel her vehicle, made of Styrofoam with magnets affixed to the bottom, by soaking a Popsicle stick in hot water, bending it into a propeller and winding it up with a rubber band. ''I thought this would make for a smooth ride,'' she explained.
Eugene Jang used a slingshot device because, he reasoned, it would be ''faster than a propeller.'' Ed Enterlin tried using a small motor, found that it was too heavy and opted for a house fan that blew air into a sail fabricated from a garbage bag. 
''There was no single best solution,'' Mr. Harms said. ''The designs depended on what the students wanted their vehicles to be able to do.''
Mr. Harms teaches technology education - an updated version of industrial arts, or shop. Instead of taking home yet another generation of handmade bookcases and pencil holders, destined perhaps to remain unused, many of today's students are cloning plants, sending messages with lasers and using pint-sized wind tunnels to figure out why the rear windows of station wagons are usually dirty.
The transformation of industrial arts into technology education reflects the broader shift from an industrial to an information-driven economy, but it is more than a curricular facelift. Implicit in the teaching of technology are ideas that could serve as models for other academic subjects: the possibility of multiple solutions, the value of group learning and the notion that students can be inspired to learn just about anything if they see that it will help them solve an interesting problem.
The case for teaching about technology is strong. Fabricated objects play an increasingly important role not only in the lives of individuals, but also in political and social decisions. The chemical leak at Bhopal and the nuclear accident at Chernobyl are evidence that disasters formerly attributed mainly to ''acts of God'' are now increasingly manmade.
''Technology is the new basic,'' said Robert Fixler, director of the Bureau of Technology Education for New York City public schools.
Approximately 40 states require teaching about technology. One of the most aggressive has been New York, which in 1984 started requiring local school districts to give junior high school students a year of technology education and to offer pre-engineering courses as electives in senior high schools.
Teaching about technology poses a challenge to schools because it does not fit into the traditional academic categories.
For example, science - the search for the rules that govern the natural world - has absolute standards. Students' answers are usually either right or wrong. By contrast, technology - the study of how people reshape nature - forces students and teachers alike to deal in the gray area of value judgments, tradeoffs and multiple solutions.
At Canarsie High School in Brooklyn, Myron B. Rock, who supervises engineering courses, drives home these points by asking five-member teams of students to design a portable shelter that would keep five survivors of a plane crash alive for three days.
To carry out the assignment, students must delve into thermodynamics and the properties of various types of insulation and then brainstorm such decisions as whether the survivors are better served by thicker insulation or more living space. ''We decided that we could make it big enough to stand and still have thick enough insulation,'' said Brian Cobham, a senior.
Most school assignments have students working on their own and competing against other individuals for grades, but the study of technology is biased toward groups. ''It's most like the real world, where you work and solve problems collectively,'' said Kenneth M. Ford, a teacher at Sauquoit Valley Central High School near Utica, N.Y. He divides students into teams to design, test and evaluate an electric-eye mechanism that will sort clear and colored marbles.
Technology education even turns traditional ''hands on'' education on its head. Science laboratories, for example, are usually intended to show the application of information learned in class. In technology classes students start with a problem and then gather the information they need to solve it.
Implicit in this approach is a new role for the teacher as the manager of a learning process, not the source of answers. ''With good technological exercises, the teacher does not know all the good answers in advance,'' Mr. Harms said.
In his 1963 book ''The Two Cultures,'' the English scientist and writer C. P. Snow spoke of the gap between the worlds of literature and science. Perhaps in technology education - an arena where factual knowledge and value judgments must be dealt with simultaneously - educators have at last found a way to bridge this gap.

HEADLINE: FOOD NOTES

BYLINE: By Florence Fabricant

 BODY:

Tomato Juice, Anyone?
''Orange juice is going to get expensive,'' said Dan Shafer, director of communications for Coca-Cola Foods, which makes Minute Maid Orange Juice products. The freeze in Florida at the end of December reduced the crop by 30 percent, driving prices up. In some Manhattan supermarkets the price for half-gallons of not-from-concentrate orange juice is $3.59 and expected to rise further.
While the freeze caused a shortage of juice made in the United States, producers usually make up for shortfalls by buying concentrate from Brazil. But Brazilian producers have taken advantage of the situation and increased their wholesale prices, from $1.37 a pound before the freeze to $1.92 a pound last week. 
Dr. Bob Behr, economic research director for the Florida Department of Citrus, said the full impact of the price increases will probably not be felt until late February. Prices had been reduced in October, making the increases appear that much more dramatic, he noted.
''Retail prices are due to go up around 20 percent,'' he said, ''but on the basis of yearly averages, we expect that orange juice will cost about 8.5 percent more this year than last year.''
Prices for grapefruit juice will also increase, but not as sharply, he said.
 
Abundance From Chile
Now for some good news. Thanks to a very large harvest in Chile, fruits like peaches, nectarines, plums, apricots and cherries are more abundant and better quality, with more juice and flavor, than ever before.
''It's like summertime here with all the fruit,'' said Joe Doria, an owner of Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street) in Manhattan. And prices, often $1.29 to $1.99 a pound in supermarkets, are also down.
Fruit labeled ''tree-ripened'' is likely to cost around $1 a pound more but will be sweeter. Some markets have excellent fruit that is fully matured, at $4 to $5 a pound.
But there is also some more bad news. The Florida freeze affected some vegetable crops, reducing supplies, driving prices up and diminishing quality. Eggplants, tomatoes, zucchini, green peppers, cucumbers, green beans and arugula are very high at the moment. Corn on the cob is 75 cents to 85 cents an ear.
''The effect on tomatoes was horrendous,'' said Rob Bildner, owner of RLB Food Distributors in West Caldwell, N.J. ''The wholesale price has more than tripled. Comparatively speaking, it makes the Israeli tomatoes a better buy, since they are now only a few cents more a pound than Florida tomatoes and far better quality.''
The next harvest, and lower prices, will not appear in the markets for another four to eight weeks, he said.
 
Italian to Go
Restaurants are opening retail food stores right and left. The latest to sell prepared food is Barocco in TriBeCa.
The Barocco Alimentari, 297 Church Street (at Walker Street), has a limited but varied menu of well-seasoned Italian dishes. Among them are a salad of fennel and Parmesan cheese ($6 a pound), tomatoes and mozzarella with basil ($6.50 a pound), artichokes vinaigrette ($2.75 each), roast pork ($10 a pound), lentils with sausage ($6.50 a pound), meat lasagna ($10 for a portion serving two) and large half-moon spinach ravioli stuffed with ricotta and Swiss chard ($10 a pound).
Stupendous hearth-baked breads are $3.50 each, a splendid cream-filled berry tart on a cookie crust is $3 a portion, and a refreshing but anatomical-sounding mixture of navel and blood orange segments is $6 a pound. The shop is open Monday to Friday, 9 A.M. to 7 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. Telephone 212-431-1456.
The shop recently opened by the restaurant Arcadia, called Out of Arcadia, has already closed in the Citicorp Center. The owner, Anne Rosenzweig, said the closing was only until she can find larger quarters.
Another restaurant, Chez Louis, is hoping to open Chez Louis to Go next to the restaurant on Second Avenue and 54th Street.
 
German Delicacies
Whether the crumbling of the Berlin Wall and other sections of the Iron Curtain will inspire a renaissance of German and East European cooking in this country remains to be seen. But a group of young American chefs in Washington, the World Capital Chefs Society, has decided to be on the cutting edge. Led by Clive DuVal of Tila's in Chevy Chase, Md., and Kep Sweeney of 21 Federal, the group is holding a German buffet dinner on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Adirondacks in Union Station in Washington.
On the menu are fresh eel soup, pork roulade on red cabbage, braised rabbit, sauerkraut with pork knuckles, potato pancakes, pea puree, plum strudel and chocolate torte. The event will benefit Exodus, an organization that works with homeless children. Tickets are $50 each; call 301-652-8452.
 
A Video for Home Wine Makers
A NEW video, ''Making Fine Fruit Wine at Home,'' with James Barry, who owns Dover Winery in Dover Plains, N.Y., offers step-by-step instructions for turning berries, peaches, apples and even bananas into wine.
Mr. Barry demonstrates how to press the fruit, use a hydrometer and a fermentation lock, test for acidity, rack the wine and bottle and cork it. He supplies a list of ingredients and the sources for them and for the equipment.
The 45-minute video is $37.45, including U.P.S. shipping, from Videocraft Classics, 1790 Broadway, Suite 701, New York, N.Y. 10019; 212-246-9849.

The Economy
Alan Greenspan told Congress that the chance of a recession had diminished markedly since spring. His comments appeared to dampen hopes that the Federal Reserve would move soon to cut interest rates further. [Page A1.] 
A man who claims to have invented the intermittent windshield wiper won a patent-infringement case against Ford. [D1.]
The Government unsealed an indictment against a fugitive financier and offered a $200,000 reward for his capture. [D1.]
Car and truck production in the U.S. and Canada will climb during the rest of the first quarter if Big Three auto makers adhere to production schedules. [D5.]
 
 
 
Companies
Peter A. Cohen resigned as chairman and chief executive of Shearson Lehman Hutton in a move that reflects the continuing turmoil on Wall Street. [A1.]
American Brands said five inside directors had resigned in order to make its board structure similar to that of other large corporations, where the outside directors are a majority. [D1.]

Connecticut Bank and Trust has financial problems. It is one of the state's oldest and largest banks. [B1.]

Moving aggressively after a recent court decision, Genetics Institute fired another volley in its battle with Amgen. [D5.]

Markets
Prices of Treasury securities closed higher after a volatile session. Bonds were bolstered by a report on CNN that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would step down as chairman of the Communist Party. [D1.] Yields remained mostly flat on C.D.'s and money market accounts. [D17.]
Pessimism about stocks involved in deals depressed prices, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.14 points, to 2,543.24. [D8.]
The dollar jumped against major currencies after the report that Soviet President Gorbachev would resign as Communist Party chairman. [D18.] Sugar futures prices fell sharply. [D18.]
 
International

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Up After Hectic Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A rumor from Moscow overtook news reports from Washington in the credit markets yesterday and prices of Treasury securities closed higher after a volatile session.
The rumor - a report on Cable News Network that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would step down as chairman of the Communist Party as early as next week - helped to reverse a sharp early slide in prices that followed testimony before Congress by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. In the foreign exchange markets, the dollar also jumped against major currencies after the report. [Page D18.] The suggestion that the Soviet President might give up his party post was interpreted as a sign that reforms and democratization in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe might be jeopardized. That encouraged some market participants to buy dollars or United States bonds. 
''Political events in Eastern Europe and Russia have been an important reason for the market's six-week decline,'' said Nancy J. Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data, a Boston-based concern that provides research for institutional clients. ''It makes sense that a pullback from glasnost would boost U.S. bond and currency prices.''
 
Sharp Gains for Nabisco
The high-yield ''junk bond'' market was also volatile, and prices of RJR Nabisco bonds posted sharp gains after plummeting for two sessions.
In his remarks before the Joint Economic Committee, Mr. Greenspan called the economy's sluggish performance in the fourth quarter a ''temporary hesitation in the continuing economic expansion.'' He added that the current 4.5 percent inflation rate was too high.
Mr. Greenspan's comments underscored a point that has become increasingly obvious in recent weeks, economists and other people who watch the Federal Reserve said.
''Our interpretation of his comments is that the Fed will wait to see further evidence of economic contraction before easing monetary policy further,'' said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes fell as news reports of Mr. Greenspan's testimony flashed across trading screens. By early afternoon, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 had fallen about a half-point, to yield 8.61 percent, its highest level since June.
One government bond trader who asked not to be named said: ''For better or worse, the rumor smoked out a lot of people who were betting the market would go lower.''
But by late in the day, after the Gorbachev rumor had spread, the 8 1/8 percent bonds were offered at a price of 95 1/2, up 7/8 of a point from their lows of the day, to yield 8.54 percent.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 95 30/32 in late trading, up 1/4 point, to yield 8.49 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 23/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.28 percent.
 
Easing in Bill Rates
Treasury bill rates eased slightly. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.74 percent, down a basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by a like amount, to a late offered rate of 7.70 percent. And one-year bill rates dipped by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.51 percent.
A major source of nervousness in the bond market lately - concern about absorbing huge quantities of new Treasury notes and bonds - will be pushed out in the open this afternoon, when the Treasury announces the size of its quarterly refunding auctions.
Worries that buyers, especially from Japan, will be scarce have been a big reason behind the recent increase in interest rates. But some analysts say that yields are now at levels where investor interest at the auctions could be strong.
''Long-term interest rates are as high now as they were in June, when the Fed began to ease monetary policy,'' said David Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. ''If the Japanese are smart they will be here, given the retreat in prices we have seen.''
 
High-Yield Bonds Recover
Prices of high-yield junk bonds, which for the last two days had been in full retreat, recovered smartly yesterday.
The biggest gains were recorded by RJR Nabisco bonds, which were battered on Friday and again Monday. Among RJR issues, the 13.71 percent payment-in-kind debentures due in 2009 rose by nearly 5 points, to 70.
''A lot of people came in here looking to buy bonds because they thought the selloff was overdone,'' said Peter Karches, head of high-yield trading and sales at Morgan Stanley & Company.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the ARCO Chemical Company offered $225 million of 30-year debentures through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 9.80 percent debentures, which mature Feb. 1, 2020, were priced at $99.355 to yield 9.867 percent, 1.24 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/8 percent Treasury bonds of 2019 at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Traders in the secondary market for corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, market participants said that prices of most actively traded issues eased by about 1/8 of a point.
