HEADLINE: Savings Fugitive Indicted; U.S. Offers $200,000 Reward

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Prosecutors call it the latest chapter in the Maryland savings and loan scandal, which shook financial markets in the summer of 1985, gave the country vivid pictures of depositors lined up in front of savings associations and became a grim harbinger of the nationwide scandal to come.
It involves a fugitive financier and former owner of one of the largest of the Maryland institutions, a reward of $200,000 for his capture, wiretaps, the interception of a $500,000 wire transfer to an accomplice and the collapse of one of the country's largest real estate partnership networks.
The United States Attorney in Baltimore today announced the indictment of the fugitive, Tom J. Billman, and two other business associates, who controlled the Community Savings and Loan Association of Bethesda, Md., and the $1.2 billion Equity Programs Investment Corporation. Both collapsed in the summer of 1985, creating losses estimated to total more than $400 million. 
Mr. Billman and the others are accused of looting Community Savings of $28 million and salting those funds away in Swiss bank accounts.
In December 1988, Mr. Billman fled the country, the Government says. It calls him a fugitive from justice. The Justice Department said it would offer a reward of $200,000 to anyone who supplies information leading to his arrest.
''This is being done now in the hope that some banker or professional that might have recently worked with Billman or knows where he is might come forward,'' said Breckinridge L. Wilcox, the United States Attorney in Baltimore.
Mr. Wilcox conceded that the Government was not sure of Mr. Billman's whereabouts. ''But we know he is somewhere in Europe and keeping a very low profile,'' he said.
The indictment of Mr. Billman is the fourth brought by either state or Federal officials against operators and owners of now defunct or acquired Maryland savings and loan associations, Mr. Wilcox and other Government officials said.
Like their counterparts in Texas, Oklahoma and Colorado, the Maryland collapses were the product of lax regulation, poorly trained examiners, high-risk investments, mismanagement and outright fraud. The result was an alarming cost to investors and taxpayers.
While the total cost of the Maryland crisis - $370 million - is small compared with the $159 billion price tag of the national crisis, it nonetheless has been painful for many.
Lloyd W. Jones, director of the Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund, said that only in November had all insured depositors at Maryland savings associations finally been paid off. And he added that the fate of $30 million in uninsured deposits has not yet been decided.
''But with Billman, I think you have the last of the real big money people,'' Mr. Jones said.
 
Real Estate Collapse
The collapse of Community Savings and Equity Programs reached far beyond Maryland. In the early 1980's, Mr. Billman took what was once a sound financial idea and built it into a house of cards that collapsed when the Texas economy plunged.
Equity Programs' basic business was to form limited partnerships by raising funds from investors like doctors, lawyers and dentists and buying single-family homes, particularly a developer's model homes.
''It was basically a sound idea,'' Mr. Wilcox said, noting that the partnerships would rent the model homes back to the builder and then sell them, at a considerable profit, when the builder had finished the development. ''But it was predicated on the hope that housing prices would continue to rise,'' Mr. Wilcox added.
When the oil economy collapsed, so did the viability of the partnerships, and to meet mortgage payments Mr. Billman used his Community Savings, which he bought in 1982, and began advancing large unsecured loans to the 357 partnerships.
 
'Could Not Rent Them'
''Many of the houses were just vacant; they could not rent them out and they were vandalized,'' Mr. Wilcox said.
Beginning in 1984, the indictment says, Mr. Billman entered into a conspiracy with Clayton C. McCuiston, president of Community Savings and 20 percent owner of Equity Programs, and Barbara A. McKinney, legal counsel to Community Savings, ''to divert over $106 million'' to cover financing needs at Equity Programs and for their own use.
In all, the indictment charges that Mr. Billman paid himself almost $28 million.
When regulators shut Community Savings they estimated that the losses would total more than $100 million. But losses went far beyond the savings and loan. When Equity Programs defaulted on its $1.2 billion in mortgages, losses reverberated into the banking industry, the savings and loan industry and the mortgage insurance industry. Some put the final price at almost $400 million.
 
A Sealed Indictment
After a three-year investigation, a grand jury in Maryland indicted Mr. Billman and his two former associates in December but agreed to seal the indictment to give the Government time to find and extradite him.
Because the hunt was unsuccessful, the Government decided to unseal the indictment and offer the reward, Mr. Billman said.
Mr. Wilcox said that Mr. Billman was still active ''in several business deals,'' and that investigators had uncovered through the use of a wiretap a plan by Mr. Billman to wire $500,000 from a European bank to an account that Ms. McKinney had in a Detroit bank.
''We have reason to believe he is living on more than $20 million of Community's depositors' money,'' Mr. Wilcox said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Does Japan Play Fair?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE Japanese do not mean to offend, say the new breed of Japan-watchers, whose revisionist views on international trade and finance have become fashionable from Capitol Hill to the Commerce Department. But the Japanese hardly understand what is meant by free markets and are not about to be converted by the Heritage Foundation. Rather than rage across the cultural abyss, the revisionists say, it would be in everyone's interest for America to insist on a fair share of the international market and let the Japanese figure out the least unpleasant way to accommodate the demands.
The revisionists have a point, says Yoshi Tsurumi, a professor of international business at Baruch College in New York. But in the latest issue of World Policy Journal, Mr. Tsurumi argues that the point is out of date. Long a nation of self-sacrificing workaholics, ''Japan is rapidly becoming a consumer-oriented democracy on the U.S. model,'' he says. 
Revisionists believe that Japan is run by ''Japan Inc.,'' a partnership of giant export-minded enterprises and Government bureaucrats that defends producers against the interests of consumers and guarantees that foreigners will never get an even break.
From this perspective, it makes little sense to fight to lower the formal barriers that block imports at the dock. Japan's bureaucratic-industrial complex will always manage to undermine the spirit of open commerce. The only international agreements likely to make a difference are the ones that manage trade, assuring American semiconductor manufacturers a given percentage of the Japanese market, or limiting exports of Japanese cars to so many million a year. But as Mr. Tsurumi points out, facts have an irritating way of contradicting the most elegant theories. Since 1985 Japan's immovable trade surplus has moved from 4.2 to 3.2 percent of gross national product. West Germany's surplus, by contrast, rose to 6.6 percent from 4.5 percent in the same four years.
Even more striking is the change in composition of Japanese imports. Manufactured goods amounted to just 22 percent of Japan's total import bill in 1980. Nine years later, the figure had risen to 61 percent - a higher percentage than, for example, Italy, which has a weaker technological base and is far closer to self-sufficiency in food and energy.
Much of the growth of imports, Mr. Tsurumi concedes, has come from Japanese companies, which moved offshore in the 1980's to cut costs. But that is hardly a reason to criticize. Japanese manufacturers are helping to develop low-wage, capital-poor economies in southern Asia the way American multinationals helped to industrialize South Korea and Taiwan and Brazil in the 1970's. Today, American-based companies generate a quarter of America's imports. In any case, Mr. Tsurumi notes, foreign companies have hardly been excluded from Japan's import boom. Dozens of foreign companies, from Schick to Texas Instruments to American Family Insurance, have gained large, profitable niches in the Japanese market.
And contrary to conventional wisdom, foreigners who cannot lick the Japanese at the marketing game are welcome to join them. Merck took over two Japanese pharmaceutical houses in 1985; Federal Express bought two local express-mail businesses in 1988. The only formidable barriers to foreign ownership of Japanese companies are the absurdly high price-earnings multiples at which they trade.
Why is Japan Inc., the mighty union of Mitsui, Mitsubishi and friends, allowing all this to happen? In part because the alliance between Japanese corporations and the Japanese Government has never been as seamless as Americans believed. In part because Japanese multinationals have grown so rich in cash that control of bank credit no longer assures Government bureaucrats the last word on corporate strategies. But mainly, Mr. Tsurumi suggests, because the alliance is under great pressure from Japanese consumers, who no longer believe it is necessary to live in rabbit hutches to sustain the strength of the nation.
Until the last few years, a combination of electoral gerrymandering and the best elected officials that corporate money could buy effectively denied Japan's urban majority a strong say in the Government. But bribery scandals have put the ruling Liberal Democratic Party coalition on the defensive. And the increasing frustrations of urban life have galvanized Japan's long-suffering ''salaryman'' to action.
That does not mean the Japanese will soon stop worrying about productivity and join the no-money-down generation. But it does suggest that Japan is almost ready to play by the rules of open competition. Are we?

HEADLINE: Panel to Study Move by Campeau

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30

 BODY:
Representative Jack Brooks said today that the House Judiciary Committee, which he heads, would review the bankruptcy of the American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation and examine the need for legislation to restrict corporate takeovers.
The Texas Democrat's remarks, at the end of the first of several hearings into Campeau by his Economic and Commercial Law Subcommittee, suggest that Congress may look for new ways to stem the growth of takeovers and leveraged buyouts. Previous efforts to do so were unsuccessful.
''It is time for Congress to seriously assess whether legislation is needed in a number of areas just in the leveraging of corporate America,'' Mr. Brooks said.
He said he could foresee possible changes in bankruptcy, securities and tax laws designed to inhibit such buyouts, takeovers financed with borrowed money and a practice that became widespread in the financial boom of the late 1980's. In today's weaker economy, companies like Campeau are being crippled by interest payments on debt.
At the hearing, state officials, union leaders and economists discussed the $7.5 billion bankruptcy declared earlier this month by Campeau's Allied Stores Corporation and Federated Department Stores Inc. units.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Flat

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions remained mostly flat in the week ended yesterday compared with the week earlier.
Analysts said the interest-rate picture remains clouded, with few banks seeing the current high interest rates available in foreign countries as a long-term distraction to the general downward movement of yields in the United States.
According to 100 Highest Yields, a newsletter covering interest rates published in West Palm Beach, Fla., the same forces currently pushing up mortgage rates affect certificate rates as well. 
It cited the fear of inflation, which has exerted upward pressure on interest rates recently, and the absence of Japanese investors, who are the primary buyers of United States Treasury securities, as among the factors holding up interest rates.
 
Influence of Treasury Auction
At the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction on Monday, interest rates on three- and six-month bills were up. The auction results are considered an influence over what many banks pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit.
The average rate for a three-month bill at the auction increased by 11 basis points, to 7.77 percent, its highest level since the auction of Dec. 26. For a six-month bill, the rate increased by 15 basis points, to 7.73 percent, the highest since the Oct. 2 auction. A basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point.
A weekly survey of New York area banks showed that average yields on certificates of deposit offered at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed compared with the week before.
Average yields on money market accounts at commercial banks fell 4 basis points, to 6.49 percent, with yields on three-month certificates falling a basis point, to 7.82 percent. The average yields on six-month certificates were up 4 basis points, to 7.85 percent, the survey showed.
 
Rates at Savings Units
Meanwhile, at savings institutions, money market accounts and three-month certificates were unchanged, at 6.60 percent and 8.06 percent, respectively. The yield on a six-month certificate was down a basis point from a week earlier, to 8.08 percent.
Among 20 large banks surveyed nationwide, average yields on deposits were also mixed, with money market accounts off by 2 basis points, to 6.32 percent, and six-month certificates of deposit up 3 basis points, to 7.80 percent, from a week earlier.
Average yields on deposits at large credit unions nationwide were also mixed, with money market yields down a basis point, to 6.70 percent, and yields on one-year certificates of deposit down by a basis point, to 8.09 percent. Six-month certificate yields at credit unions were unchanged, at 8.04 percent, while two-and-a-half-year certificate yields were up 2 basis points, to 8.20 percent, and five-year certificate yields were up a basis point, to 8.22 percent.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
An Addition To Newark's Downtown

BYLINE: By Shawn G. Kennedy

 BODY:
DOWNTOWN Newark has a striking addition to its evolving skyline, the $74 million Newark Legal Center. The structure, which was completed last month and got its first tenant this month, was built to house law firms and keep them in the city.
The success of the project is regarded by Newark officials as a sign of the slow but sure gains being made as this much-troubled city struggles to recover from the economic decline that began in the 1960's.
The project's developers, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Newark Economic Development Corporation, have accomplished a feat that few builders of any offices in the metropolitan area can now claim: their building opened with nearly all its 360,000 square feet of office space spoken for. Of the building's 18 office floors, 14 have been sold as condominium units or leased to tenants, and agreements are waiting to be signed for two more floors. Deals are close to completion for another two floors. 
''That top law firms chose to stay here says a lot,'' said Alma J. Smith, project development officer with the Newark Economic Development Corporation, ''The center has spread the word that Newark is alive and well.''
The occupants in the building, which stands on the Passaic River waterfront at the intersection of Raymond Boulevard and McCarter Highway, are some of the city's largest law firms. Among them are Crummy, Del Deo, Dolan, Griffinger & Vecchione, which bought 90,000 square feet of space; Sills Cummis Zuckerman Radin Tischman Epstein & Gross, which has leased 80,000 square feet, and Podvey, Sachs, Meanor & Catenacci, which bought a 30,000-square-foot condominium unit and moved in this month.
David Sheehan, managing partner of Crummy, Del Deo, said, ''Newark is still the commercial and legal center of the state.''
The idea for the development of a building devoted to the legal profession came from economic development officials in Newark. They felt that retaining law firms - traditionally among the city's largest category of office tenants - was essential for the continued revitalization of Newark's downtown.
That goal turned into a concrete plan as the result of a 1983 agreement between Governors Mario M. Cuomo and Thomas H. Kean that called for the Port Authority to build such a project in Newark in return for the approval of a fare increase on the PATH commuter system.
The final plan called for the Port Authority to build and operate the office structure and for the Newark development commission to be responsible for putting up a 674-space underground parking garage as well as a pedestrian bridge linking the building to Pennsylvania Station and the Gateway Center hotel and office complex across the street.
Designed by the Grad Partnership of Newark, the building has a dark- blue mirrored glass tower that rises from a three-story rose-colored granite base.
The new building's lobby includes 17,000 square feet of retail space, of which 9,000 feet has been leased, including 4,000 for the National Community Bank. The Port Authority is also negotiating with a tenant to take 4,000 square feet designed for a restaurant.
The legal center is linked by fiber-optic cable to Teleport, the Port Authority's satellite communications center on Staten Island. A key to the successful marketing campaign for the building was the Port Authority's decision to give occupants the option of renting or buying space.
''All along, the plan was for the legal center to be a condominium,'' said Roger Muessig, the Port Authority's manager of sales for world trade and economic development. ''But we also decided to leave open the option of offering leases in case market conditions changed.''
Another component of the project was Port Authority financing for the condominiums, which allows buyers to pay for their space through 25-year installment sales contracts with the agency.
Mr. Muessig said prices in the new building average about $205 a square foot and include up to $14.95 a square foot for interior office contruction. Rents average about $25 a square foot.
The success of the legal center is not the only sign of confidence in the future of downtown Newark.
The Linpro Company, a national real estate development and investment concern based in Berwyn, Pa., will build a second office tower next to the legal center. The foundation for the 600,000 square-foot, 22-story building, to be known as Two Riverfront Plaza, was built as part of the parking garage. Construction is scheduled to begin as soon as tenants are found.
Across McCarter Highway from the Legal Center, foundation work has started for a Bellemead Development Corporation development project that will include a 200,000-square-foot building for Seton Hall Law School and 400,000 square feet of speculative office space.

HEADLINE: Hal Draper, 75, Socialist Writer Who Recounted Berkeley Protest

BYLINE: By PETER FLINT

 BODY:
Hal Draper, a scholar and writer on Marxism and socialism for 50 years, died of pneumonia Friday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 75 years old.
Mr. Draper, a Trotskyite who later termed himself an independent socialist, wrote full time after serving as a librarian and bibliographer for the University of California at Berkeley from 1960 to 1970. His works were credited with inspiring the nonviolent free speech movement there by Mario Savio and other leaders of the 1964-65 protests, which began a period of campus activism throughout the country. 
Mr. Draper, a veteran of student insurrection in the 1930's, recounted the later protests in ''Berkeley: The New Student Revolt'' (1965). A. H. Raskin of The New York Times called the author ''a master polemicist'' who lamented a disposition of many protest leaders to ''disaffiliate from society, rather than transform it.''
His four-volume ''Karl Marx's Theory of Revolution'' (1975-85), was hailed in The New York Review of Books by Robert L. Heilbroner, professor of economics at the New School, as an ''extraordinarily stimulating work written in a fresh, open style which comes as a welcome relief after the turgidities of so much Marxist writing.''
 
Other Political Books
Other works by Mr. Draper were ''Introduction to Independent Socialism'' (1963 and 1970), ''The Dirt on California: Agribusiness and the University'' (with his wife Anne, 1968) and ''The Dictatorship of the Proletariat from Marx to Lenin'' (1987).
Besides editing and contributing to other political books, Mr. Draper earned favorable reviews for his translation, ''The Complete Poems of Heinrich Heine: A Modern English Version'' (1982). He also explored science fiction comically in ''Ms Fnd in a Lbry: Or, the Day Civilization Collapsed'' (1982).
Mr. Draper was a Brooklynite and a graduate of Boys High School who earned a bachelor's degree at Brooklyn College in 1934 and a master's degree at Berkeley in 1960. He taught in New York City high schools and was a shipyard worker in World War II.
Mr. Draper was a national organizer and antiwar activist for the Young People's Socialist League in the 1930's and a founder and director of the Center for Socialist History in Berkeley in the 1980's.
His wife, the former Anne Kracik, died in 1973. Surviving are a sister, Dorothy Rabkin, of Palm Beach, Fla., and two brothers, Theodore Draper, of Princeton, N.J., and Robert Draper, of Great Neck, L.I.
